He answered me: “How do you begin the prayer”? I then recited: "Praise be to Allah, Lord of the worlds", until the end of this sura". He tells me: “She is precisely this surah, because it includes the seven verses that are repeated and also the great Koran that I have been granted". 
(188) 41 - Jaber Ibn Abdallah said: "He who makes a raka't without having recited the mother of the Quran, his prayer is not valid unless he has prayed behind the imam”? (These are dawn, sunset and evening prayers). Chapter IX Of the recitation behind the imam when it comes to prayers that are not recited aloud 
(189) 42 - Abu Huraira reported that he heard the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) say: “He who prays without reciting the mother of the Koran, her prayer is missed and is no longer complete”. The reporter said to Abu Houraira: “Sometimes I pray behind the imam”? Abu Houraira pinched my arm and replied: “O Persian! Recite it for yourself, because I heard the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) say: “Allah the Blessed and the Most High said: "I have divided the prayer, between My servant and Me, into two parts: One half belongs to me, and another is the his" The Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Be upon him the grace and peace of Allah) added: “So recite! The worshiper recites: “Praise be to Allah, Lord of the Worlds”. Allah the Blessed and the Most High says (meaning): "My worshiper has praised Me”. The worshiper recites: "The Merciful, the Most Merciful", Allah says (meaning) "My worshiper has exalted Me". The worshiper recites: "The King of the Day of Judgement". Allah says: "My worshiper has glorified Me". The worshiper continues: "It is You whom we adore, it is You whom we implore for help». Allah says (meaning) "This verse is between Me and My worshipper, and I will grant My worshiper what he asks". The worshiper recites: “Lead us in the straight path, the path of those you have fulfilled benefits; not the way of those who incur Your wrath nor that of the lost”. Allah says: "This belongs to My worshiper and I will grant him what he asks of Me". 
(190) 43 - Hicham Ibn Ourwa reported from his father that he "recited while praying behind the imam, when the latter should not recite aloud". 
(191) 44 - The same previous hadith, narrated by Al-Kassem Ibn Muhammad. 
(192) 45 - The same previous hadith, narrated by Jaber Ibn Mut'em. Malek said, "That's the best I've heard about it." Chapter X The fact of no longer reciting what the imam recites aloud 
(193) 46 - Nafe' reported that when Abdallah Ibn Omar was asked about of the recitation, while praying behind the imam, he replied: "when one to pray to you behind the imam the recitation of the imam is enough for him, but if he prays alone, he must recite». He also said that Abdallah Ibn Omar did not recite behind the imam. Malek said, “What we follow in Medina is that man should recite during a prayer, where the imam does not recite aloud, and leaves the recitation in the other prayers”. 
(194) 47 - Abu Huraira reported: “The Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Be upon him the grace and peace of Allah) finishing a prayer where he recited aloud, he asked the faithful: "Has any of you recited the Koran with me”? A man replied, "Yes, I, O Messenger of Allah". He said to her: "I said to myself: why don't they let me recite the Koran”? Since then, men have stopped reciting at the same time with the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Be upon him the grace and peace of Allah) and that when he recited aloud, after this remark he made to them". Chapter XI Saying "Amin" behind the imam 
(195) 48 - Abu Hurairah reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him be Allah's grace and peace) said: "when the imam says “Amin”, say Amin because whoever makes his “Amin” correspond to that what the angels say, his previous faults will be forgiven him”. Ibn Chehab said: "The Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him be Allah's grace and peace) said 'Amin'". 
(196) 49 - Abu Huraira reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Be upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said: “when the imam recites "Not, (the path) of those who incur Your wrath nor that of the misguided", say: "Amin", because whoever says it at the same time as the angels, his sins will be blotted out to him”. 
(197) 50 - Abu Huraira reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Be upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said: "when one of you says "Amen," and the angels in heaven also say "Amen", at the same time, the faults of this man will be erased from him". 
(198) 51 - Abu Huraira reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Be upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said: “when the imam says: "Allah listens to those who praise Him", say: "Great Allah, our Lord, to You the praise”. He whose saying this corresponds to that of the angels, his faults will be erased from him”. Chapter XII How should one sit during prayer. 
(199) 52 - Ali Ibn Abdel-Rahman Al Mou'awi reported: "Abdallah Ibn Omar saw me distract with pebbles while I was praying. My prayer finished, he forbids me to do such a thing and says to me: "do, what the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah). I him I asked: “What was the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (upon him the grace and peace of Allah) doing”? He answered: “When he sat down, during the prayer, he put his right hand on his right thigh joining all his fingers except the index finger, which he kept straight, and his left hand on his left thigh. This is what was doing the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah). 
(200) 53 - Abdullah Ibn Dinar reported: "A man made the prayer with Abdallah Ibn Omar, after the fourth raka't, he sat down, leaning on his feet folded. When the prayer was over, Abdallah Ibn Omar reproached the man for having so acted. The man objected and said: “but, you did the same”? He replied: "I did it because my feet hurt". 
(201) 54 - Al Moughira Ibn Hakim reported that he saw Abdallah Ibn Umar sitting on the front of his feet after the second and fourth raka't. When he finished the prayer, he made a remark to him concerning his posture of sitting”. Abdullah replied: “I know very well that this is not traditional, but I did this because my feet hurt". 
(202) 55 - Abdullah Ibn Abdallah Ibn Omar, reported that he saw Abdallah Ibn Omar squatting, when he sat in prayer. He continued: "as I imitated him when I was very young, he forbade me to do so, saying: "The good tradition of prayer is to lift up your right foot and bend the left”. I answered him: “but you, you do that”? He replied, "It's because my feet can't support me". (203) 56-Yahia Ibn Sa'id reported that Al-Kassem Ibn Muhammad showed the devotees the way to sit to show the unity of Allah: he raised his foot right, bent the left, sat on his left hip, and did not sit on his (left) foot. Then he said: "Abdallah Ibn Omar my watch this by saying that he saw his father do the same". Chapter XIII Of the testimony of the unity of Allah during prayer. (204) 57- Abdel Rahman Ibn Abd Al-Qari reported that he heard Omar Ibn Al-Khattab, being in the pulpit, teaching people about doing unity testimony of Allah. He said to them, "Say, 'Greetings to Allah, good works to Allah, good words and prayers to Allah. Peace be upon you oh Prophet (salallahou alayhi wa salam) as well as the Mercy of Allah and his blessings. Peace be on us and on the holy servants of Allah. I testify that he there is no god but Allah, and I testify that Muhammad is his servant and his envoy. At-tahiyatu lillah, az-zakiyatu lillah, at-tayibatu wa's-salawatu lillah. As-salamu alayka ayyuha'nnabiyyu wa rahmatu'llahi wa barakatuhu. As-salamu alayna wa ala ibadi'llahi s-salihin. Ash-hadu an la ilaha illa 'llah wa ash-hadu anna Muhammadan abduhu wa rasuluh." 
(205) 58 - Nafe' a reported that Abdallah Ibn Umar testified the unity of Allah and said: “In the name of Allah, greetings to Allah, prayers to Allah, good works to Allah. Peace be upon the Prophet (salallahou alayhi wa salam) as well as Allah's mercy and blessings. Peace be on us and on the holy servants of Allah. I testify that he there is no god but Allah and I testify that Muhammad is the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam)". "Bismillah, at-tahiyatu lillah, as-salawatu lillah, az-zakiyatu lillah. As-salamu ala'n-nabiyyi wa rahmatullahi wa barakatuhu. As-salamu alayna wa ala ibadi'llahi's-salihin. Shahidtu an la ilaha illallah. Shahidtu anna Muhammadu'r-rasulu'llah." He said that after the first two raka'ts and invoked Allah after his testimony, what he wanted. And if he sat down towards the end of his prayer (after the fourth raka't), he repeated the same formula of his testimony, but he did it before calling on Allah, and asked what he wanted. Once the testimony is over, and wishing to make the final salutation, he said: "As-salamu ala'n-nabiyyi wa rahmatu'llahi wa barakatuhu. As-salamu alayna wa ala ibadi'llahi'ssalihin." “Peace be on the Prophet as well as Allah's mercy and blessings. Peace be upon us and upon the holy servants of Allah. Peace be upon you," turning his face to right and answering the imam. And if someone saluted him on his left, he answered the salutation”. 
(206) 59 - Abdel Rahman Ibn Al-Kassem reported from his father that Aisha, the wife of the Prophet (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him be Allah's grace and peace) said, testifying to the unity of Allah: "As-salamu ala'n-nabiyyi wa rahmatu'llahi wa barakatuhu. As-salamu alayna wa ala ibadi'llahi'ssalihin." "Greetings, good works, prayers and good words belong to Allah. I testifies that there is no other god but Allah, the Unique, he has no partner, and that Muhammad is his servant and his envoy. That the Peace be upon you, O Prophet, and the Mercy of Allah and his blessings. Peace be upon us, and upon the saints servants of Allah. Peace be with you". 
(207) 60 - Al Kassem Ibn Muhammad reported that Aisha, the wife of the Prophet (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said, testifying to the Unity of Allah: "Greetings, good works, prayers and good words belong to Allah. I testify that there is no god but Allah, the Unique, he has no partner. And I tell you that Muhammad is the servant of Allah and his messenger. Peace be upon you oh Prophet (salallahou alayhi wa salam) as well as the Mercy of Allah and his blessings. Peace be upon us and upon the holy servants of Allah. Peace be with you". 
(208) 61 - Malek asked to Ibn Chehab and Nafe', the slave of Ibn Umar about a man who prayed together with the imam, and that the latter preceded him by one raka't, should he testify with him, the Unity of Allah after the second and the fourth raka't, knowing that he only made raka'ts odd”?. They answered him: "that he bear witness with the imam”. Malek said: "That's what we do in Medina." Chapter XIV From the fact that a man raises his head before the imam. 
(209) 62 - Abu Houraira said: “Whoever raises his head and lowers it before the imam does so, his forelock will be in the hand of a demon". About a man who raises the head after bowing or prostration before imam to do so, Malek said: “it is our tradition that this man must return to its bowing or prostration posture without wait for the imam, because by doing this, he will have committed a fault, because the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (On him the grace and peace of Allah) said: "The imam was only instituted to be followed, so don't argue about it". Abu Houraira added: "Whoever raises his head and lowers it before the imam do, this one has the cheek in the hand of the demon". Chapter XV What should a man do who recklessly salutes after the second raka't. 
(210) 63 - Abu Huraira reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Be upon him the grace and peace of Allah) had finished his prayer after having made two rakats. Zouliadaine said to him: “Has the prayer been abbreviated, O Messenger of Allah or did you forget to complete it? The Envoy of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) addressing the faithful, these affirmed to him the words of Zouliadaine”. He got up, did the two raka'ts omitted, and made the final salutation. Then he pronounced the takbier, prostrated himself for an equal duration even a little more long, raised his head, uttered the takbir a second time, prostrated himself for the same or a little longer, then he lifted his head. 
(211) 64 - Abu Sufian Ibn Abi Ahmad's slave reported that he heard Abu Hurairah say that the Messenger of Allah (sallallahu alayhi wa salam)r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) praying the asr, made the final salutation after the second raka't". Zouliadaine stood up and said, "O Messenger of Allah has the prayer been abbreviated, or have you forgotten"? The Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) replied: "of all this, there is none is nothing”. Zouliadaine replied: "but if, O Messenger of Allah, was". The Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam)r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) came then meet the faithful and asked them: “Is it true what is what Zouliaidaine said”? They answered him: "Yes". The Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) then completed, what he missed the prayer, then made two prostrations after the salutation final, while seated. 
(212) 65 - Abu Bakr Ibn Suleiman Ibn Abi Hathema reported: “I was told that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) made two raka'ts during one of the two prayers of the day, that of midday, or that of the asr, and he gave the final salutation. Zou-Achamalaine said to him: "the has prayer been shortened, O Messenger of Allah or have you forgotten? The Envoy of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Be upon him the grace and peace of Allah) answered him: "Prayer has no not been abridged, and I do not I forgot nothing”. Zou-Achamailaine replied: “There have been some, O Messenger of Allah". The Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Be upon him the grace and peace of Allah) looking at the people, said to them: “Is it true what Zouliadaine said”?. They answered him: “Yes”. The Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah), then completed his prayer and gave the final salutation. 
(213) 66 - Malek reported, according to Ibn Chehab, Sa'id Ibn Al-Mous-saiab, and Abu Salama Ibn Abdel-Rahman a similar hadith”. Malek said: "all distraction causing incompleteness of prayer, prostration is to be done before the final salutation. Any distraction causing surplus in prayer, prostration is the same to be done, but after the final salutation. Chapter XVI On the doubt of the incompleteness of prayer and how to complete it 
(214) 67 - Ata Ibn Yassar reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Be upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said: "when one of you, doubt in his prayer, of the number of raka'ts already made, are they to three or four, let him do a fourth raka't and then do two prostrations while seated, before the final salutation. Yes this raka't was the fifth, these two prostrations would make the raka'ts to an even number. And if this raka't was the fourth, these two prostrations would be a humiliation of the demon”. 
(215) 68 - Abdallah Ibn Omar said: "When one of you doubts the number of raka'ts he has made, let him try to remember the exact number and pray what is lacking, then make two prostrations of distraction, while seated”. 
(216) 69 - Ata Ibn Yassar reported: "I asked Abdallah Ibn Amr Al'-As, and Ka'b Al-Ahbar, about the man who doubts the number of raka'ts he has already made, is it three or at four? Each of them answered me: "Let him make a raka't, then prostrate himself twice, all while sitting." 
(217) 70 - Malek a reported from Nafe' that by asking Abdallah Ibn Omar about oblivion during the prayer, he replied: "that one of you is looking for what he omitted, then complete it". Chapter XVII Of the one who rises from the second rakat or at the end of the prayer. 
(218) 71 - Abdallah Ibn Bouhaina reported: “The Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) made a prayer to us and got up of the second raka't without sitting down, and the people did the same. The completed prayer, we expected his final greeting, but he made the takbir, then two prostrations. being seated, before the final salutation, then he saluted”. 
(219) 72 - Abdallah Ibn Bouhaina reported: “The Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) Upon him the grace and peace of Allah prayed to us from noon when he got up after the second raka't without sitting down. About the man, who after doing four raka'ts, stand up, recite, bow and raising his head from the recline, remembers he did the four raka'ts, Malek said, "let him come back and sit down without prostrating himself, even if he has made only one prostration, he will not have to make the other. When he finishes his prayer, let him make two prostrations, seated, after the final salutation”. Chapter XVIII Of what causes distraction while praying. 
(220) 73 - Aisha, the wife of the Prophet (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Be upon him the grace and peace of Allah) reported: “Abou Jahm Ibn Houzaifa had presented to the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) a "Khamissa" (kind of garment) that contains designs; he prayed while carrying it; completing his prayer, he said, "give this Khamissa back to Abu Jahm, for looking at his drawings while praying, I was almost disturbed». 
(221) 74 - Hisham Ibn Ourwa reported from his father that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) carried a Khamissa which contained drawings, then he gave it to Abou Jahm, and took in exchange an “Anbijania” (Garment of coarse fabric, not containing of drawings). Abu Jahm asked, “Why are you doing this, O Messenger of Allah”? He replied, "I was passing time, looking at his drawings, praying". 
(222) 75 - Abdullah Ibn Abi Bakr reported: "praying in his garden, Abu Talha Al-Ansari watched a small woodpigeon fly past him, looking of an exit. As it pleased Abou Talha, he followed him with his gaze a lapse of time, then, noticing that he was in prayer, he happens not to remember many of the raka'ts he has done. He says to himself, "my possessions have caused me some trouble". He comes to find the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Be upon him and the peace of Allah) and told him what had happened to him saying at the end: "I make this garden an alms for the sake of Allah, you can dispose of it”. 
(223) 76 - Abdullah Ibn Abi Bakr reported: “In the season of fruit ripening, an Ansar man was praying in his garden at Al- Whew, a certain valley of Medina, looking at its palm trees surrounded by dates and easy to pick, and he marveled. Wanting to continue prayer, he no longer remembered the number of raka'ts already made, and said: "my possessions have caused me trouble". He came to find Osman Ibn Affan, while he was caliph and told him what he had in saying: "I offer this garden as alms, dispose of it in the way of good". Osman sold this garden for fifty thousand (dinars). Later, this garden was called: "the good of fifty". MOUATTAA Book 4 First chapter About distraction in prayer. 
(224) 1 - Abu Houraira a reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said: "when one of you get up to pray, satan came to trouble his mind to the point to forget the number of raka'ts he has made. When this happens to him, let him make two prostrations, while remaining seated”. 
(225) 2 - We reported to Malek that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said: "It sometimes happens to me (in praying) to forget, or (Allah) makes me forget to the point of becoming indecisive". 
(226) 3 - A man says to Al-Kassem Ibn Muhammad: "I happen to beg to forget the number of raka'ts I made in point of forgetting to remember it”. Al-Kassem replied: "Continue your prayer, for it only ceases to trouble your mind at the end of the prayer you will ask yourself: "did I make a complete prayer"? MOUTTAA Book 5 the Jumaa day (Friday) First chapter Lotion on Friday. 
(227) 1 - Abu Houraira a reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said: "Whoever makes a lotion on the day of Friday, as it is practiced following an impurity ritual, then goes (to the mosque) first thing in the morning, is comparable to a man who gives alms to a camel, one who returns at the second hour, is comparable to one who gives alms of a cow, the one who surrenders at the third hour, is comparable to who gives alms from a horned ram, who goes to the fourth hour, is like one who gives alms to a hen, finally the one who goes to the fifth hour, is comparable to the one who donates an egg. When the imam enters the mosque, the angels will be present in order to listen to the mention of Allah”. 
(228) 2 - Sa'id Ibn Abi Sa'id Al-Maqbouri reported that Abou Houraira said: "Friday's lotion is an obligation for each puberty, as it is following an impurity ritual". 
(229) 3 - Salem Ibn Abdallah a reported that one of the companions of the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) entered the mosque, a Friday, when Omar Ibn Al-Kattab was making his sermon. Omar him said, "Why are you coming so late"? The man replied, "O Prince of believers! Hearing the first call to prayer, I left the market and I did nothing but ablution"? Omar exclaimed: "You have satisfied with ablutions again? Did you not know that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) ordered us to make the lotion”?. 
(230) 4 - Abu Sa'id Al Khudri reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said: "The lotion of the Friday is obligatory for every puberty”. 
(231) 5 - Ibn Omar has reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said: "when one of you goes to Friday prayers, let him make a lotion". Malek said: “The one which, on Friday, makes a good morning lotion, this lotion is not enough for him because he must redo it before going to the mosque, because the messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) according to the hadith narrated by Ibn Omar, said: "When one of you goes to Friday prayers, let him make a lotion”. Malek also said: “Whoever on Friday make a lotion sooner or later, intending to make it, just for today's prayer, and stop being impure, he will only have to redo his ablutions because his lotion is enough for him” Chapter II From listening the imam preaching on Friday. 
(232) 6 - Abu Houraira a reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said: "when you tell your companion, "shut up" when the imam gives the Friday sermon, you will have said futile things”. 
(233) 7 - Tah'iaba Ibn Abi Malek Al-Kourazi a reported: "In the time of Omar Ibn Al-Khattab, people used to Friday prayer, so that when Omar arrived and sat on the pulpit and that the muezzins had called for prayer, we entertained. Once the first call is over, Omar stood up to preach, as for us, we kept silence to listen without uttering a word. Ibn Chehab said: "The arrival of the Imam in the mosque puts an end to all prayer, and its sermon interrupts all conversation". 
(234) 8 - Malek Ibn Abi Amer reported: “When Osman was preaching Friday, he was saying, and it was one thing that he rarely said: "When on Friday, the imam does his preach, listen and keep silence, because whoever keeps the silence without listening, will have a reward as much as that of the one who keep silent and listen. When you get up to pray, equalize your ranks and stand next to each other, because equalizing ranks is part of a prayer made to perfection. On the other hand, Osman did not do takbir before people responsible for him come and tell him that the ranks have been well equalized, and then he pronounced the takbir”. 
(235) 9 - Nafe'a reported that Abdallah Ibn Omar, at the sight of two men conversing, while the imam was giving his sermon, he threw stones at them in order to make them to hush up". 
(236) 10 - It was reported to Malek, that a man sneezed on a Friday, while the imam was giving his sermon. Another who was next to him said: "May Allah make you Mercy". Asking the opinion of Sa'id Ibn Al-Mussaiab on this subject, he forbids him to do it again, telling him: "don't do it again". 
(237) 11 - Malek, asked Ibn Chehab about the conversation on Friday when the imam descends from his pulpit and before pronouncing the takbir, he replied, "There is nothing wrong with that". Chapter III Of the one, who on Friday, manages to make a single raka't in common 
(238) 12 - Malek reported that Ibn Chehab said: "Whoever, on Friday, manages to do common, a single raka't, that he completes his prayer with a second". Ibn Chehab added: “such is the tradition”. Malek said: "It's good, what I have found versed men, follow to Medina, because the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him be Allah's Grace and Peace) said: "Whoever achieves to pray a raka't in common, it is as if he did all the prayer in common". Malek was asked about the man, who on the day Friday, meets a crowd of people, and manages to bow without be able to bow down until the imam rises or completes the pray? He replied, "Yes, after its inclination, it manages to prostrate when the faithful rise (from their prostration), that he prostrates himself, and if he cannot do so only when the imam finishes his prayer, it is my preference that this man prays of four raka'ts (Note that the Friday prayer is made up of two raka'ts). Chapter IV From the one who, on Friday, suffers a nosebleed. 
(239) 13 - Malek said: “The one, who, on Friday, suffers a nose bleed, while the imam is preaching, and leaves the mosque and does not comes back only after the imam has finished the prayer, will have to pray four raka'ts" About him who, on Friday, does a raka't with the imam and suffers a nosebleed which forces him to leave the prayer, if he returns after the imam has finished the two raka'ts, he can complete his prayer with a second raka'ts if he held no conversation. Malek said: “Whoever, on the day of Friday, suffers a nose bleed or some other reason that requires him to leave the prayer, he is not required to ask permission to the imam”. Chapter V About the Efforts Lavished on Friday 
(240) 14 - Malek asked Ibn Chehab about the interpretation of this verse: “O you believers! When you are called to the Friday prayer, hasten to the invocation of Allah” (Koran LXII, 9). He him replied: "Umar Ibn Al-Khattab used to recite this verse in the following way: "When you are called to the Friday prayer, go to the invocation of Allah". Malek said: “These efforts mentioned in the Book of Allah, are the works and acts. Allah the Blessed and the Most High said: “As soon as he turns his back on you, he strives to corrupt what is on earth”. (Qur'an II, 205). "But the one who comes to you full of zeal" (Koran LXXX, 8). “And he turned hurriedly back" (Koran LXXIX, 22). "But your efforts are divergent” (Koran XCII, 4). Malek continued: “These various efforts that Allah mentioned in his book, do not mean walking or walking. trouble that one takes, but it is a question of (good) works and deeds". Chapter VI Of the imam, who being in trip stops in a village on Friday. 
(241) 15 - Malek said, "When a imam stops, while traveling on Friday, in a village, makes the sermon and the prayer, the inhabitants of this village and others will have performed all the rites of Friday with him”. Malek has said: "When the imam who travels, stops on Friday in a village where the member of the inhabitants and those who come is lower to the normal number, the rites of prayer are not considered accomplished, and in this case, these must make the midday prayer like in other days. Malek also said: “Assistance at the Friday office is not compulsory for a traveler”. Chapter VII About the hour of fulfillment on Friday. 
(242) 16 - Abu Hurairah reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) by mentioning the day of Friday, said: “there is a period of time (lit: an hour) when everything Muslim worshiper meets him, being in the state of prayer, and ask something from Allah, but it is not granted”. Then he did waved his hand to show his short duration. 
(243) 17 - Abu Huraira reported the story following: "I went to Mount (the ulema said that it is Mount where Allah had spoken to Moses) and I met ka'b Al-Ahbar. I sat with him, told me about the Torah, and I told him about the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam)r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah). Among other things I told him, I tell him: “the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said: "The best day when rises the sun, is the day of Friday, because in that day Adam was created, came down from Paradise, Allah returned to him there, and on the day when he died. The supreme hour will rise only on this day, and every beast will listen in this day from the moment it is morning until the day when the sun rises in fear of this Hour, except for the geniuses and human beings. On this day there is an hour when everything Muslim does not meet her while praying and ask Allah for something without until it is granted”. Ka'b asked me: “It happens in a day of the year". I replied, “No. rather, every Friday”. Ka'b reads then the Torah and said, "The Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) spoke the truth”. Abu Houraira continued his story: "Returning of the mount, I met Basra Ibn Abi Basra Al-Ghifari who asked me "where do you come from"? I replied: "of the mount". He replied, "If I had you met there before leaving it, I would not have gone out. I heard the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) say: "One does not strap the mounts only to get to these three mosques: The Sacred Mosque, my mosque (in Medina) and the mosque of “Ylia” or the Sacred House”. The reporter doubted. Abu Huraira added: “then I met Abdallah Ibn Sallam. and I told him of my talk with Ka'b Al-Ahbar about the day of Friday saying to him: "Ka'b guess the time granted will take place only one day of the year". Abdallah Ibn Salam replied, "Ka'b lied." I tell him: "but Ka'b read the Torah (for confirm his words) then he says: "in every Friday". Abdullah then said: "Ka'b has spoken the truth", then he resumed: "I know this time". I asked him: "inform me about him and don't show yourself miser". Abdullah Ibn Salam replied: “it is located at the end of the day of Friday”. I then exclaimed: “How will it be situated at the end of Friday while the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said: "every Muslim worshiper meet her praying knowing that this hour is no longer the time for prayer”? Abdullah replied: “The Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) did he not say: "the one who found among people awaiting prayer, he is considered to be in prayer until he accomplish it”. Abu Houraira added: “I answered him: “certainly, it is so”. Chapter VIII Of appearance, of passing before a man who prays, and how to receive the imam on Friday. 
(244) 18 - It was reported to Yahia Ibn Sa'id that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said: "why does one of you procures two garments, which he wears on Friday, apart from his two work clothes”. 
(245) 19 - Malek reported from Nafe that Abdallah Ibn Omar did not attend Friday prayers until after having applied ointment, only after having perfumed himself, unless he is in a state of ihram. 
(246) 20 - Abou Houraira said: "He better for one of you to pray on stones hot volcanic rocks, rather than, while sitting, he rises to pass people on Friday, when the imam goes up to the pulpit to make his sermon". Malek said: "It is a tradition with us in Medina that the imam stands in front of people when he wants to preach on Friday when men face the qibla or to other sides”. Chapter IX Of recitation during Friday prayer, wrapping himself in his garments, and of him who neglects this prayer without valid excuse. 
(247) 21 - Al-Dahhaq Ibn Qais asked to An-Nu'man Ibn Bachir: "What suras, recited the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) on Friday after that of "Juma""Friday"?. He replied: “He was reciting surah “Al Ghashiyah (Koran, LXXXVIII). 
(248) 22 - Malek (doubting that this hadith is according to the Prophet (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) or not) has reported that Safwan Ibn Sulaim said: “He who, without valid excuse, neglect prayer of Friday, three consecutive times, Allah seals on his heart. 
(249) 23 - Ja'far Bem Muhammad reported from his father that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him grace and peace of Allah) gave two sermons on Friday and sat between them". MOUATTAA Book 6 The supererogatory prayers of Ramadan First chapter Encouragement to pray (supererogatory) prayers in the month of Ramadan. 
(250) 1 Aisha the wife of the Prophet (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) reported: "One night, the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) made a certain prayer in the mosque, the men also made it. The following night, the men became numerous, then the third night then the fourth, and their number increases, but the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Be upon him the grace and peace of Allah ) did not pray. the next morning, he said to them: "I saw, what you did, what prevented me from coming to see you, it was the fear that this prayer would become an obligation". It happened in Ramadan. 
(251) 2 - Abu Hurairah reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) wished to spend the nights of Ramadan by praying, without imposing such prayers on Muslims. He said to them, “He who spends the nights of Ramadan with faith and conviction of the reward, his previous faults will be erased from him”. Ibn Chehab added "The Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the mercy and peace of Allah) died, men did not stop following this tradition even at the time when Abu Bakr was caliph and at the beginning of the caliphate of Omar Ibn Al-Khattab". Chapter II Prayers (supererogatory) in the month of Ramadan. 
(252) 3 - Abdel Rahman Ibn Abdel-Kari reported: “While going with Omar Ibn Al-Khattab to the mosque in the month of Ramadan, we found that people were scattered praying in such a way that one man was praying alone, others were praying behind an imam. Umar then said, “By Allah! It will be ideal, if I ask the men to put themselves behind a single reciter». He asked them to pray, behind Ubai Ibn Ka'b”. The rapporteur continues: "Another night, I also went with Omar, to the mosque, and we found the men praying behind a reciter. Omar, then exclaimed: “What a superb innovation this is. That prayer you say before you go to bed is better than the one you say when you get up at night”. He meant: “at the end of the night, because the Muslims said this prayer at the beginning of the night. 
(253) 4 - As-Saib Ibn Yazid reported: “Omar Ibn Al-Khattab ordered Ubai Ibn Ka'b and Tamim Ad-Dari to preside over a prayer of eleven raka'ts, made in common. He said, "And the Imam (the reciter) recited hundreds of verses, so that, wanting to stand, we leaned on sticks (the prayer was lying down). And we left only with the clarity of the dawn”. 
(254) 5 - Malek reported that Yazid Ibn Rouman has says: "In the time of Omar Ibn Al-Khattab, men made a supererogatory prayer of twenty-three raka'ts in the month of Ramadan". 
(255) 6 - Malek reported from Daoud Ibn Al-Houssain that he heard Al-A'raj say, "What I saw men doing, in the month of Ramadan, was to curse the impious." Then he added: “the reciter (the one who presided over the prayer) recited the surah "The Cow" in eight raka'ts, but if he recited it in twelve raka'ts, men would realize that he had caused them less pain". 
(256) 7 - Abdallah Ibn Abu Bakr reported that he heard his father say: "when we finished the prayer in the month of Ramadan, we hurried the servants in the preparation of the meal before we were surprised by the dawn". (256 - Bis): Ourwa reported that Zakwan posthumously freed from Aisha, the wife of the Prophet (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah)) prayed with Aicha during the nights of the month of Ramadan. MOUATTAA Book 7 Night Prayer First chapter Night prayer. 
(257) 1 - Aicha, the wife of the Prophet (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said: “Anyone who has accustomed to making a night prayer, and where sleep prevails (without making the prayer), Allah will grant him the reward of his prayer, and his sleep will be reckoned to him as alms". 
(258) 2 - Aicha, the wife of the Prophet (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) reported: “I slept before the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Be upon him the grace and peace of Allah) and my feet were in the direction of his qibla. When he prostrated, he pinched them for me to remove them, and when he stood up I stretched them out”. She added, "and at that time the houses were not lamp-lit." 
(259) 3 - Aisha, the wife of the Prophet (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) reported: "When one of you falls asleep, while doing his night prayer, that he goes to sleep until he is no longer sleepy, for if he is dozing, it may be that, instead of asking Allah to forgive him his sins, he may curse himself”. 
(260) 4 - Ismail Ibn Abi Hakim was told that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) was told (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) about a woman who spent the night praying. He asked, "Who is this woman"? He was answered: "It's Al-Hawla Bint Touwait who never sleeps at night." How displeased the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) so that one could notice the discomfort on his face, he said: "Allah, the Blessed and the Most High not get tired of (rewarding for your pious works) until you get tired of doing them. Do these works as long as you are capable”. 
(261) 5 - Aslam reported that Omar Ibn Al-Khattab was praying at night, which Allah willed. Towards the end of the night, he woke up his family saying to them: “prayer! the prayer", then he recited: "Command the prayer to your family and persevere yourself in prayer. We do not claim any good from you; it is we who give you what you need. The happy ending will be for those who fear Allah”. (Koran XX, 132). 
(262) 6 - Malek was informed that Sa'îd Ibn Al Moussaiab said: "It is disgusting to go to bed before the prayer of the evening and to hold a conversation once it is done". 
(263) 7 - It was reported to Malek that Abdallah Ibn Omar, said: "the night prayer, is done by two repeated raka'ts, and we make the final greeting after each two raka'ts". Malek said, "That is what we follow in Medina." Chapter II From the odd raka't made by the Prophet (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) at the end of his prayer 
(264) 8 - Aisha, the wife of the Prophet (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him be Allah's grace and peace) prayed the nightly prayer of eleven raka'ts, the last of which was odd. Once the prayer was over, he lay down on his right side”. 
(265) 9 - Abu Salama Ibn Abdel-Rahman Ibn Awf, asked Aicha, the wife of the Prophet (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) how was the night prayer of the Messenger of Allah ( sallallaahu alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) during the month of Ramadan”? She replied: "In the month of Ramadan, and in other months, the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) did not make more than eleven raka'ts. It began with four, and don't ask me about their duration or their perfection, then four other following ones which were also durable and perfect, and finally, it was three raka'ts”. I said to him: “O Messenger of Allah! do you sleep before doing an odd raka't'? He replied, “O Aicha! My eyes close, as for my heart it does not sleep”. 
(266) 10 - Aisha, the mother of the believers reported: "The Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) was praying a night prayer of thirteen raka'ts, then hearing the call to the dawn prayer, he prayed two light raka'ts”. 
(267) 11 - Abdallah Ibn Abbas reported that he spent a night with his aunt Maimouna, the wife of the Prophet (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah). He said, "I lay down in the middle of the cushion (it is the mattress) while the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him be Allah's Grace and Peace) and his wife stretched lengthwise. The Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) fell asleep until midnight; a little before or a little after midnight, he woke up, sat down, rubbing his face in order to wake up well; he recited the last ten verses of the sura "The Family of Imran", then he got up to use the water contained in a hung waterskin and to do his ablutions perfectly, then he prayed. Ibn Abbas added: "I arose to do similarly, then I stood next to the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) who put his right hand on my head, took my right ear and rubbed it. He made a prayer of two raka'ts, then two more, then two more, then two more, then two more, then two more, then an odd raka't. After that, he lay down until the muezzin came to find him, he got up to make two light raka'ts, then he went to the mosque to make the dawn prayer”. 
(268) 12 - Abdallah Ibn Qais Ibn Makhrama, reported that Zaid Ibn Khaled Al-Jouhani told him: “I said: “this night, I intend to observe the night prayer of the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah). I stretched out on the threshold of his door - or of his tent -, I saw him get up at night to do two raka'ts so long, then two others shorter, then two more shorter than the previous ones, then two others shorter than the latter, then two others shorter, then two others less short, finally, he made an odd raka't, his prayer was formed in all of thirteen raka'ts. Chapter III About to make an odd raka't. 
(269) 13 - Abdallah Ibn Omar reported that a man asked for the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him be Allah's Grace and Peace) regarding the night prayer; he answered him: "it is done by two repeated raka'ts if one of you is afraid of being surprised by the moment of the dawn prayer, that he makes a raka't which will make his prayer odd" . 
(270) 14 - Ibn Muhairiz reported that a A man from Bani Kinana called Al-Moukhadji had heard a man in Syria called Abou Mouhammad say: “odd raka't is obligatory”. Al-Mukhadji added: “I was going to find Oubada Ibn As-Samett as he was heading towards the mosque, blocking his way and making him from the words of Abu Muhammad. Oubada answered me: “Abou Muhammad lied, because I heard the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him be Allah's Grace and Peace) say: "Five prayers have been prescribed by Allah, to Him the power and glory, to His worshipers, he who observes them without missing anything through negligence, will have concluded a pact with Allah which will make him enter Paradise. Whoever neglects them, will not enjoy this pact and Allah will punish him if He wills, or will, if He wills, enter Paradise”. 
(271) 15 - Sa'id Ibn Yassar a reported: “I was with Abdallah Ibn Omar, marching towards Mecca. As I feared to be surprised by the dawn prayer, I got down (from my mount) and I made an odd raka't, then I joined him. He asked me: "where were you"? I answered him: “as I feared to be surprised by the prayer of the dawn, I descended and made an odd raka't”. Abdallah replied: "Did you not have in the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah), an example”? “Certainly yes, I say”. He continued: “The Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him be Allah's Grace and Peace) would (sometimes) do the odd raka't while riding his camel. 
(272) 16 - Sa'id Ibn Al-Musaiab a reported: “when Abu Bakr Al-Siddiq wanted to lie down, he made an odd raka't; and Omar Ibn Al-Khat-tab did it towards the end of the night”. Sa'id Ibn Al-Mussaiab added: "As for me, wanting to go to bed, I was doing an odd raka't". 
(273) 17 - A man asked to Abdallah Ibn Omar about the odd raka't; is it compulsory”? He replied, "The Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the Grace and Peace of Allah) made her and the Muslims". As the man insisted on the question, Abdallah gave him the same answer”. 
(274) 18 - Aisha, the wife of the Prophet (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said: "He who fears not to no longer get up at night to pray, until morning, that he makes a odd raka't before bedtime. As for the one who will be assured of waking up at night, that he does this odd raka't only at the end of the night". 
(275) 19 - Nafé reported: "being with Abdallah Ibn Omar, in Mecca, when the sky was cloudy, Abdallah, fearing to be surprised by the dawn-prayer, then made an odd raka't. But as soon as the sky cleared, and as he expected to wake up at night, he made another to make his prayer even. Then he made a prayer of two repetitive raka'ts, and fearing again to be surprised by the dawn prayer, he made an odd raka't. 
(276) 20 - Nafé reported that Abdallah Ibn Omar made the final salutation between the two raka'ts he performed and the odd raka't, and sometimes engaged in other matters, (in order to separate them)”. 
(277) 21 - Ibn Chehab a reported that Sa'd Ibn Abi Waqas performed the odd raka't after performing the evening prayer". Malek said, "What we practice in Medina is to pray a nightly prayer of at least three raka'ts." 
(278) 22 - Abdallah Ibn Dinar reported that Abdallah Ibn Omar used to say: “the sunset prayer (which is formed of three raka'ts) makes the daytime prayers odd”. Malek said, “Whoever makes the odd raka't and then falls asleep at the beginning of the night, to get up at night and pray, let him make a repetitive two-raka't prayer. That's the best I've heard about it." Chapter IV Of the odd raka't after dawn. 
(279) 23 - Sa'id Ibn Joubair reported that Abdallah Ibn Abbas slept and then woke up, saying to his servant, “Go and see what the men have done (while he was blind). The servant went and then came back saying to him: “the people have just finished the dawn prayer”. Abdallah Ibn Abbas, then got up, made an odd raka't then the dawn prayer. 
(280) 24 - It was reported to Malek that Abdallah Ibn Abbas, Oubada Ibn Al-Samett, Al-Kassem Ibn Mouhammad and Abdallah Ibn Rabiaa, made the odd raka't after the appearance of the dawn”. 
(281) 25 - Ourwa reported that Abdallah Ibn Mass'oud said, "It will not cause me any discomfort to hear the second dawn prayer call, while I am at the odd raka't." 
(282) 26 - Yahia Ibn Sa'id reported that Oubada Ibn Al-Samett presided over the prayer for the people. Going one day to the mosque to pray the dawn prayer, the muezzin the first call of this prayer. Oubada asked him to interrupt this call, so that he could do the odd raka't, then he presided over the dawn prayer. 
(283) 27 - Abdel Rahman Ibn Al-Kassem reported that he heard Abdûllah Ibn Abi Rabiaa say: "it sometimes happens to me to make the odd raka't while hearing the second call to prayer or even after the appearance of the dawn (there is a doubt of the protractor Abdel-Rahman). 
(284) 28 - Abdel-Rahman Ibn Al-Kassem reported that he heard his father Al-Kassem Ibn Mouhammad say: “I happen to do the odd raka't after dawn”. Makek said, "He who lies down, without making the raka't odd, must do it again after the dawn prayer. It is not befitting anyone to do this on purpose or else to perform the odd raka't after the dawn prayer”. Chapter V Of the two supererogatory raka'ts before the dawn prayer. 
(285) 29 - Hafsa, the wife of the Prophet (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah), "after the muezzin made the first call to the dawn prayer, he made two light raka'ts, before the second call". 286) 30 - Aisha, the wife of the Prophet (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) made two light raka'ts before the dawn prayer, so short, to the point that I said to myself, “did he recite the mother of the Book or not” 
(287) 31 - Abu Salama Ibn Abdel Rahman reported: "Having heard the second call to prayer, the men got up to make (two light raka'ts) before that of the dawn. Upon arriving, the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said to them: "two prayers at once" two prayers at once"? These are the two supererogatory raka'ts before the canonical dawn prayer”. 
(288) 32 - It was reported to Malek that Abdallah Ibn Omar, having missed the two raka'ts before the dawn prayer, he did them after sunrise. 
(289) 33 - Al-Kassem Ibn Muhammad did like Abdallah Ibn Omar. (see previous Hadith). MOUATTAA Book 8 Common prayer. First chapter. The merit of common prayer and its advantage over that which is made by a single individual. 
(290) 1 - Abdallah Ibn Omar reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him be the grace and peace of Allah) said: "the prayer in common surpasses by twenty-seven degrees that which is made by a single individual. 
(291) 2 • Abu Hurairah reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him be Allah's grace and peace) said: "Common prayer is twenty-five times more valuable than that of one of you if he does it alone". 
(292) 3 - Abu Hurairah reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him be the grace and peace of Allah) said: "by him who has my soul in his hand! I was thinking of ordering wood to be brought to me, making the call to prayer and appointing someone to preside over it, then to go to people's homes to burn them in their homes. By him who has my soul in his hand! if one of these people knew how to find a fat bone or good sheep's trotters, he would not have failed to take part in the evening prayer”. 
(293) 4 - Zaid Ibn Thabet said: "the the best prayers are those you make at home, apart from the prescribed prayers”. Chapter II Dawn and evening prayers. 
(294) 5 - Sa'id Ibn Al Moussaiab reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said: "what distinguishes us from hypocrites, it is the fulfillment of the two dawn and evening prayers in common, because they are incapable of doing them (to benefit from their merit and their reward) or so to speak. 
(295) 6 Abu Hurairah reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him be Allah's grace and peace) said: "Walking on a road, a man found a thorny tree branch, he pushed it aside. Allah was grateful to him, and forgave him his sins" Then he said: "The martyrs are five in number according to the causes of their death: by the plague, by the colic, by the drowning, by the landslide , or to be a martyr (in a fight) in the way of Allah. He added, "If people knew the merit one gets from making the call to prayer and to be in the front row, and they couldn't find any other way but toss, they would have tossed. And if they knew reward received, to come so early to the prayer, they would have run, if they knew the reward which there is in the prayers of the dawn and the evening, they would have gone while crawling on all fours”. 
(296) 7 - Abu Bakr Ibn Sulaiman Ibn Abi Hathama reported that Omar Ibn Al Khattab did not find Sulaiman Ibn Abi Hathama (in the mosque) at the dawn prayer. Then Omar surrendered to the market knowing that the residence of Soulaiman was on the way between the market and the mosque of the Prophet (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (On him the grace and the peace of Allah). Passing through "Al-Chifa", he found Soulaiman's mother and said to her: "I did not see Soulaiman, at the dawn prayer"? She answered him: "As he spent the night praying, he fell asleep". Omar replied, "To do the dawn prayer in common is better for me than to spend a whole night in prayer." 
(297) 8 - Abdel-Rahman Ibn Abi Amra Al-Ansari has reported: “Osman Ibn Affan went to the mosque to pray in the evening together. As the men were few, he lay down at the back of the mosque waiting for the men to be more numerous. Ibn Abi Amra coming to keep him company, asked him: “who are you”? He answered her. Osman replied: “What do you know of the Koran”?. He informed her. Osman says at the end: “He who prays in common, it is as if he has spent half a night praying. Whoever prays the dawn prayer in common, it is as if he has spent a whole night praying”. Chapter III From redoing the prayer with the imam. 
(298) 9 - Mihjan reported: “Sitting with the Apostle of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) in an assembly, the first call to prayer was made. The Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) got up and made the prayer then returned while Mihjan had not left his place, not taking go to prayer. He asked her, “What prevented you from praying with men? aren't you a Muslim”? Mihjan replied, “Certainly, yes! Sent from Allah but I had already prayed with my family. The Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) replied: "When you find yourself with men, pray with them, even if you have already made the prayer". 
(299) 10 - Nafé reported that a man asked Abdallah Ibn Omar: “I pray at home, then I catch the prayer with the imam, should I still pray with him? Abdallah answered: “Certainly yes” The man replied: “Which of his two prayers will be accepted”? Ibn Umar said to him, “Is it up to you? All this will be up to Allah who will accept what he wills”. 
(300) 11 - Yahia Ibn Sa'id reported that a man asked Sa'id Ibn Al-Mussaiab: "I prayed at home, then on going to the mosque, I found the imam who is praying, should I pray with him”? Sa'id answered him: “Certainly, Yes”. The man resumed: “Which of his two prayers will be reckoned to me”? Sa'id replied: "It will be up to Allah". 
(301) 12 - Afif Al-Sahmi reported that a man from Bani Assad asked Abou Ayoub Al-Ansari: "I pray at home, then I come to the mosque, and I find the imam who pray, should I pray with him”? Abu Ayoub replied: “Certainly, yes” because whoever does this, will have the merit of the prayer in common, or according to a variant, an equivalent to the reward of the prayer in common”. 
(302) 13 - Nafé reported that Abdallah Ibn Omar used to say, "Whoever has prayed the sunset prayer or the dawn prayer, then he goes to the mosque to pray one of them, he will not be required to pray them again." Malek said, "I don't mind that a man also prays with the imam, even if he has already done the same prayer at home, except, the sunset prayer, which if he does it again, it will make even all the prayers performed for the day. Chapter IV Common prayer 
(303) 14 - Abu Hurairah narrated that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him be Allah's grace and peace) said: "If one of you presides over prayer, may he lighten it, for among men there is the weak, the sick, the old. But when he prays alone, let him lengthen the prayer as much as he wants”. 
(304) 15 - Nafé reported: “I stood behind Abdallah Ibn Omar, to make one of the common prayers, as there was no one else but me, he held out his hand behind him, to pull me, then he placed me next to him". 
(305) 16 - Yahia reported that a man was presiding over the prayer with the people at Al-Aqiq. Omar Ibn Abdel Aziz banned it”. In commenting, the hadith Previously, Malek said, "he banned it because we didn't know his father." Chapter V From the Imam's prayer made seated. 
(306) 17 - Anas Ibn Malek reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) fell from his horse, and his side right was scratched. He said one of his prayers, seated, and we said it like him. When the prayer is over, he tells us: “The imam was instituted only to be followed in prayer; if he does it standing up, do it same; when he bows, bow, and when he raises his head, raise yours. When he says: “Allah listens to those who praise him”, say: “Our Lord, Yours is the praise”. If he prays while seated, do the same”. 
(307) 18 - Aisha, the wife of the Prophet (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said: "being sick, the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) made the prayer sitting and the men made her stand; he motioned for them to sit down. When the prayer was over, he said to them: “The imam was only instituted to be followed. When he bows, bow, when he raises his head, raise yours, and if he sits it down, sit it down." 
(308) 19 - Urwa reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah), during his illness, returned (to the mosque) and found Abu Bakr standing presiding over the prayer with the men. The seer, Abu Bakr, wanted to back down, the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) beckoned him to keep his place; and he sat next to Abu Bakr, who followed the prayer of the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the mercy and peace of Allah) and the men followed Abu Bakr". Chapter VI The valuation of the prayer made standing compared to that which is made seated. 
(309) 20 - Abdallah Ibn Amr Ibn Al'-As reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said: "the prayer of one of you seated, is worth (as a reward) half of that made standing”. 
(310) 21 • Abdallah Ibn Amr Ibn Al-As reported: “Arrived at Medina, an epidemic made us feverish. The Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) went (to the mosque) and found that the men made a supererogatory prayer while seated. He their says: "the prayer made by a seated man is worth (in reward) half that made standing". Chapter VII The supererogatory prayer made seated. 
(311) 22 - Hafsa, the wife of the Prophet (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said: “I have never seen the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) making a prayer supererogatory seated only a year before his death. He said his supererogatory prayers while seated and recited the surah while chanting so that it appeared longer than it actually was. 
(312) 23 - Aisha, the wife of the Prophet (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) reported that she never saw the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) do the night prayer sitting only when he has become old. He recited seated, and when he wanted to get up to bow, he remained standing long enough to recite thirty or forty verses, then he bowed. 
(313) 24 - Aisha, the wife of the Prophet (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) was praying and reciting seated. When he had some recitation left, about thirty or forty verses, he got up (to continue) his standing recitation, then he bowed and then he prostrated himself. He was doing the same during the second raka't. 
(314) 25 - It was reported to Malek, that Urwa Ibn Al-Zoubair and Sa'id Ibn Moussaiab, were doing their supererogatory prayers seated and sealed off with their clothes. Chapter VIII Intermediate prayer. 
(315) 26 - Abu Younos, the freedman of Aicha, the mother of believers reported, “Aisha instructed me to transcribe a copy of Quran for her, and she said to me, “when you come to this verse: “Be diligent in prayers and praying median. Stand upright to pray to Allah with piety,” (Koran II, 238), let me know”. Arrived at this verse, I warned her, and she dictated to me: “write: “be assiduous in the middle prayer, the prayer of the asr, and stand up, with piety to pray to Allah”. Aisha added: “I heard it from the mouth of the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Be upon him the mercy and peace of Allah). 
(316) 27 - Amr Ibn Rafé reported: "by transcribing a copy of the Koran for Hafsa, the mother of believers, she said to me: “when you get to this verse: “Be diligent in prayers and to the middle prayer. Stand up to pray to Allah, with piety,” Let me know". Arrived at this verse, and warning him, she dictated to me: "Be diligent in the prayers and the middle prayer, and the prayer of the asr, and stand, to pray to Allah with piety". 
(317) 28 - Ibn Yarbou'Al-Makhzouni reported that he heard Zaid Ibn Thabet say: "the middle prayer is that of the noon". 
(318) 29 - It was reported to Malek that Ali Ibn Abi Taleb and AbduUah Ibn Abbas said: "the intermediate prayer is that of dawn". Malek said: "and the words of Ali and Ibn Abbas were, on this subject, the best I have heard”. Chapter IX Permission to pray while wearing only one garment. 
(319) 30 - Omar Bin Abi Salama reported that he saw the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) praying, wearing only one garment by wrapping oneself in it, at Oum Salama. He put his extremities on his shoulders. 
(320) 31 - Abu Huraira reported that a man asked for the Messenger of Allah (sallallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Be upon him the grace and peace of Allah) about praying while wearing one garment, he replied: “Does each of you have two garments”?. 
(321) 32 - Sa'id Ibn Al Moussaiab reported that a man asked Abu Huraira: "Can a man pray while wearing only one garment"? He replied, "Yes." They say to Abou Houraira: “do you do it too”? He replied, “Certainly, yes, I pray in wearing only one garment, although my other garments are hung on the hook". 
(322) 33 - It was reported to Malek that Jaber Ibn Abdallah prayed wearing only one garment”. 
(323) 34 - Rabi'a Ibn Abi Abdel Rahman reported that Muhammad Ibn Amr Ibn Hazm, prayed while wearing a single tunic". 
(324) 35 - Jaber Ibn Abdallah reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him be Allah's grace and peace) said: "He who does not find two garments for praying, which he wears only one while wrapping himself in them. If this garment is short, put it around his waist like an izar”. Malek said: "He is preferred to me, than the man who wear only one tunic to pray, put on his shoulders another garment or another turban”. Chapter X Authorization to the woman who prays to wear a shirt and a veil. 
(325) 36 - Yahia Ibn Malek reported that Aisha, the wife of the Prophet (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) was praying while wearing a shirt and a veil. 
(326) 37 - Muhammad Ibn Zaid Ibn Quonfoz reported that his mother asked Umm Salamah the wife of the Prophet (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) "What should a woman put on to pray"? She answered him: “she must put on the veil, wear the long dress which hides the posterior parts of her feet”. 
(327) 38 - Busr Ibn Sa'id reported that Oubaidallah Ibn Al-Aswad Al Khawlani, who was under the guardianship of Maimouna the wife of the Prophet (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said, that she was praying while wearing a long dress and a veil without putting on an izar”. 
(328) 39 - Hisham Ibn Ourwa reported that a woman asked her father: “Izar causes me pain, can I pray while wearing a shirt and a veil? He replied: "Yes, if that shirt is long enough to hide (the backs of the feet)." MOUATTAA Book 9 First chapter The meeting of two prayers in town and on the road. 
(329) 1 - Abu Hurairah reported that "the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) had gathered, in his expedition in Tabouk, the two prayers, that of noon and that of the asr”. 
(330) 2 - Mu'az Ibn Jabal reported, that the year of Tabouk, during this expedition, with the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah), and the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) united the two prayers that noon and asr, then that of sunset, and that of evening. Continuing, Mu'az said: "The Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the mercy and peace of Allah) delayed, one day, the prayer went out (from his apartment) and said the two midday and asr prayers, both together, then he went home. Again he went out, to pray, bringing together the two sunset and evening prayers, and said, finally to his devotees: "If it pleases Allah, you are going to be, tomorrow, at the source of Tabouk; however, you will only arrive once the sun is very high in the sky. The one who will get there that he does not touch the water of the spring there, before I have arrived there”. And Mu'az continuing his story said: "We got there, but two men had preceded us there and the water source still shone with a few drops of water. The Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) asked them: “Have you touched its water”? The two men replied: "Yes". The Messenger of Allah (Be upon him be grace and peace of Allah) rebuked them with whatever Allah willed, rebukes. The faithful, for their part, began to draw water little by little, so that when they had had enough, the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) washed his face and hands, then returning this small quantity of water to the source, which flowed freely. The men drank and gave drink to their mounts. The Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said to me: “O Mu'az! If a long life will be granted to you, you will see this place returned to gardens like paradises”. 
(331) 3 - Abdallah Ibn Umar reported: "When the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) wanted to hasten his march, he combined the two sunset and evening prayers”. 
(332) 4 - Abdallah Ibn Abbas reported that he made with the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) the two prayers of noon and the asr, reunited, then those of sunset and Isha (evening) also reunited, without them being on a trip, and without there being any danger”. Malek said, "I think it was done in rainy weather." 
(333) 5 - Nafé reported: “the emirs had to bring together, in a rainy weather, the two prayers of sunset and evening, and Abdallah Ibn Omar had made them with them”. 
(334) 6 - Ibn Chehab reported that by asking Salem Ibn Abdallah: “Can we unite, the two prayers of the noon and the asr, when we are on a journey”?, he answered: “Yes, there is no harm in that; didn't you see the men doing that in Arafa”? 
(335) 7 - It was reported to Malek, that Ali Ibn Hussain said: "When the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) had to travel a day (in his expeditions), he united the two prayers of noon and asr. And, if he wanted to continue his march, still during the night, he combined those of sunset and evening. Chapter II The abbreviated prayer while traveling. 
(336) 8 - Ibn Chehab reported that a man of the family of Khaled Ibn Assid asked Abdallah Ibn Omar: “O Abu Abdel-Rahman! We find, well mentioned in the Koran, the prayer in case of danger, and that of town; but we don't find that that of the trip is there”? Ibn Umar replied, “O son of my brother! Allah to him the power and the glory sent us Muhammad r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) when we knew nothing (of our religion). We only did what we saw him do. 
(337) 9 - Aisha, the wife of the Prophet (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said: "The prayer was prescribed at two raka'ts in town and while traveling. That of the journey has been maintained forever, but that of the city has been increased”. 
(338) 10 - Yahia Ibn Sa'id said to Salem Ibn Abdallah: "How painful it was for me to see your father delaying the sunset prayer while traveling"! “Salem answered him, “The sun had set, while we were still at “Zat-El-Jaich”, he then made the prayer to Al-Aqiq”. Chapter III Circumstances where the prayer is shortened. 
(339) 11 - Nafé reported: “when Abdallah Ibn Omar left for the pilgrimage, or for a pious visit, he made an abbreviated prayer to "Zoul-Houlaifa". 
(340) 12 - Salem Ibn Abdallah reported that his father (Abdallah Ibn Omar) left for “Al-Rim”; he made an abbreviated prayer during this trip”. Malek said, “That distance was, about four burods (about 24 miles). 
(341) 13 Salem Ibn Abdallah reported that Abdallah Ibn Omar left for “Zaït-El-Noussob”, and made an abbreviated prayer, while being on a trip”. Malek said: “between Zat-El Noussob and Medina, there is a distance of four burods”. 
(342) 14 - Nafe a reported that Abdallah Ibn Omar, leaving for Khaibar, made an abbreviated prayer”. 
(343) 15 - Salem Ibn Abdallah a reported that Abdallah Ibn Omar made an abbreviated prayer while traveling for a day entire”. 
(344) 16 - Nafe a reported that he traveled with Ibn Umar, traveling the length of a "barid", without abbreviating the prayer". 
(345) 17 - It was reported to Malek that Abdallah Ibn Abbas shortened the prayer when he traveled a distance equal to that which separates Mecca from Taef, or Mecca from Osfan, or Mecca from Jouddah” Malek said, "It's a distance which is equivalent to four burods, and it is ideal for shortening the prayer. Malek also said: "He who travels, should not shorten the prayer, that once he leaves the mansions of the village; on the other hand, he does it to his completeness only if he enters these dwellings, or even if he is at a close distance from them”. Chapter IV Of the prayer of the traveler unless he makes the prayers in common while staying. 
(346) 18 - Salem Ibn Abdallah a reported that Abdallah Ibn Omar said: "I make the traveler's prayer, as long as I do not have to do it in common, and even if that, will have to detain me for twelve nights". 
(347) 19 - Nafe reported that Ibn Omar remained ten nights in Mecca, shortening the prayers, except, when he had to say them, behind an imam, then he said them at their convenience. completeness, by following him. Chapter V From the imam's prayer in common when we are not traveling. 
(348) 20 - Ata Al-Khourassani reported that he heard Sa'id Ibn Al Moussaiab say: "He who travels, staying for four nights (in a city), and praying together, he must pray them completely." Malek said, "That's the best I've heard about it." Malek was asked about the prayer of a war prisoner? he answered: "it must be that of a man who is resident, unless he travels". Chapter VI Of the prayer of a traveler either that he is an imam or that he prays behind an imam. 
(349) 21 - Salem Ibn Abdallah reported from his father that he said: “When Omar Ibn Al-Khattab was traveling to La Makkah, he would make a joint prayer of two raka'ts, and say: “O inhabitants of Makkah! Complete your prayer, (with two raka'ts) because we are traveling”. (....) 22 - Zaid Ibn Aslam reported that his father said that Omar, acted thus”. 
(350) 23 - Nafé reported that Abdallah Ibn Omar, prayed in common at Mina, four raka'ts. And when he prayed alone, he prayed with two». 
(351) 24 - Safwan reported that Abdallah Ibn Omar, coming to visit Abdallah Ibn Safwan, during his illness, made a prayer of two raka'ts, then finishing it, we completed it at four”. Chapter VII The supererogatory prayer while traveling by night or day, and on a mount. 
(352) 25 - Nafé reported that Abdallah Ibn Omar, said, while traveling, with the prescribed prayer, no other prayer, neither even before it, nor after, except in the middle of the night; because he was praying on the ground or on the mount whatever his direction”. 
(353) 26 - It was reported to Malek, that Al-Kassem Ibn Muhammad, Ourwa Ibn Al-Zoubair and Abu Bakr Ibn Abdel-Rahman, made, while traveling, supererogatory prayers”. Malek was asked about the prayer supererogatory while traveling? He replied, “There is no harm in their being done, night and day. I have even been told that well-versed men act like this”. 
(354) 27 - Nafé reported that Abdallah Ibn Omar saw his son Oubaidallah Ibn Abdallah, making supererogatory prayers while traveling, and he did not disapprove of that». 
(355) 28 - Abu-Hubab Sa'id Ibn Yassar reported that Abdallah Ibn Umar said: I saw the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) praying, riding on a donkey, while he was leaving for Khaibar”. 
(356) 29 - Abdallah Ibn Umar reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) while traveling, made the prayer while being on his mount, whatever his direction” (These are supererogatory prayers)”. Abdallah Ibn Dinar added that Abdallah Ibn Omar was doing so”. 
(357) 30 - Yahia Ibn Sa'id reported that he saw Anas Ibn Malek, praying, while traveling, while riding his donkey, whose direction was other than the "qibla". He bowed and prostrated himself making gestures without resting his forehead on anything”. Chapter VIII The prayer of "Al-Douha". 
(358) 31 - Oum Hani, the daughter of Abi Taleb reported: “The year of the conquest of Mecca, the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) made a prayer of eight raka'ts, caulked with a single garment. 
(359) 32 - Oum Hani, the daughter of Abi Taleb, reported the following story: "In the year of the conquest of Mecca, I went to the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) and I found him making a lotion; his daughter Fatima hid him with a garment, greeting him, he asked: “who is it”? I answered him: “Oum Hani, the daughter of Abi Taleb”. He answered: “Welcome O Oum Hani”. Once the lotion was finished, he made a prayer of eight raka'ts while being wrapped in a single garment. When he finished the prayer, I said to him: "O Messenger of Allah Ali, the son of my mother claims that he is going to kill a man, such a man from Bani Houbaira whom I took under my protection”! He answered me: “O, Oum Hani, we save whoever you have taken under your protection”. Oum Hani added: “This visit took place at the time of “Al-douha”. 
(360) 33 - Aisha, the wife of the Prophet (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said: “I have never seen the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) praying of “Al-douha”, than I did myself. The Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) did not persevere in certain religious practices, although he liked to do them for fear that people would believe that it was prescribed for them”. 
(361) 34 - Zaid Ibn Aslam reported that Aisha, prayed the "Al-douha" prayer of eight raka'ts and said: "If I was offered to bring my father and mother back to life (to stop this prayer), I would never have abandoned her". Chapter IX The way to make the prayer of "Al-duha". 
(362) 35 - Anas Ibn Malek reported that his grandmother Moulaika had invited the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) to a meal she had prepared for him, the meal being finished, the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the mercy and peace of Allah) said to us: “Get up, so that I can pray to you”. Anas added: “I brought her a mat that was blackened from long use, and sprinkled it with water. The Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) stood there, the orphan and I behind him, and the old woman behind us. He made a prayer of two raka'ts for us, then he left”. 
(363) 36 - Oubaidallah Ibn Abdallah Ibn Utba reported: "I entered the house of Omar Ibn Al-Khattab, at the time of the heat wave, and I found him offering a prayer supererogatory, as I stood behind him, he pulled me closer to his right side. Yarfa (his servant) arriving, I stepped back and lined up with him behind Omar”. Chapter X Of the prohibition to pass in front of someone who is praying. 
(364) 37 - Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him be Allah's grace and peace) said: "When one of you pray, that he let no one pass before him, and that he push her away as much as he can. If this person insists, he must fight him because he is only a demon”. 
(365) 38 - Busr Ibn Sa'id reported that Zaid Ibn Khaled Al-Jouhani sent him to Abi Jouhaim to ask him what he heard from the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) say about the person who passes in front of someone who prays”. Abu Juhaim replied: "The Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said: "If the person who passes, in front of someone who prays, knew (the seriousness of his sin), he would have preferred to stand forty than to pass in front of him" . Abu Al-Nadar, a narrator of the hadith, added: "I don't know if he meant forty, forty days, months, or years." 
(366) 39 - Ata Ibn Yassar reported that Ka'b Al-Ahbar said, "if he who passes in front of a man who prays knew what sin he has committed, he would have preferred to be swallowed up in the earth than to pass in front of that man".
