(534) 18 - Sa'id Ibn Al-Musaiab reported: "I made the funeral prayer behind Abu Huraira over a dead child who never sinned." I heard him say, “Great Allah! Preserve him from the punishment of the grave”. 
(535) 19 - Nafé reported that Abdallah Ibn Omar, while making the funeral prayer, did not recite (the Koran)”. Chapter VII The funeral prayer in the morning at sunrise, and after asr before the sun turns yellow. 
(536) 20 - Mouhammad Ibn Abi Harmala, the slave of Abdel-Rahman Ibn Abi Soufian Ibn Houwaiteb reported that Zainab the daughter of Abi Salama died in Medina where Tarek was her governor. Then, Tarek brought the stretcher after the dawn prayer, then deposited it at Al-Baqi' (the place of the cemetery) Then he said: “Tarek used to make the prayer of dawn while it was still dark. Ibn Harmala added: “I then heard Abdallah Ibn Omar say to the parents of the deceased: “you do the funeral prayer either now, or you have to leave it until sunrise”. 
(537) 21 - Nafe a reported that Abdallah Ibn Omar prayed over the dead, after that of the asr and after that of dawn, doing the latter two at their fixed times”. Chapter VIII Funeral prayer in mosques. 
(538) 22 - Abu Al-Nadr the slave of Omar Ibn Oubaidallah reported that Aicha, the wife of the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) had ordered that pass the corpse of Sa'd Ibn Abi Waqs after his death in the mosque, in front of her, in order to invoke Allah on her. As people disavowed her request, she exclaimed, " How quickly people fall into oblivion! The Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) did not make the prayer funeral on Souhail Ibn Baida than in the mosque”. 
(539) 23 - Nafé reported from Abdallah Ibn Omar that we have performs the funeral prayer on Omar Ibn Al-Khattab, in the mosque”. Chapter IX The funeral prayer. 
(540) 24 - It was reported to Malek, that Osman Ibn Affan, Abdallah Ibn Omar, and Abu Houraira were performing the funeral prayer in Medina, with men and women all gathered together, so that the men lined up behind the imam, and the women directed towards "the qibla ". 
(541) 25 - Nafe a reported: "When Abdallah Ibn Umar was making the funeral prayer, he was making the final salutation aloud so that it would be heard by those who followed him". 
(542) 26 - Nafé reported that Abdallah Ibn Omar said, "a man does the funeral prayer only if he is in a state of ritual purity." Yahia reported, “I have heard Malek say: "I did not find one, among the versed men, to refuse to make the funeral prayer on a bastard and on the mother". Chapter X From the burial of the dead. 
(543) 27 - It was reported to Malek that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa sallam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) died on Monday, and was buried Tuesday; and the people prayed over him without being gathered behind an imam. Some said, “We will bury him near the pulpit; the others: to Al-Baqi”. Immediately Abu Bakr came and said: “I heard the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) say: "No Prophet was buried in any other place than in the place where he died"; then dug the grave. At the time of his washing, and as they wanted to take off his shirt, the men heard a voice say: "Do not take off shirt"; We thus washed the body of the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) keeping his shirt on”. 
(544) 28 - Hicham reported that his father said, “Two men were in Medina; one dug pits for the graves and the other did not. was not doing. Upon the death of the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) men said: "He who is the first to arrive, will be able to act as he is used to doing". As the digger came first, he dug a pit for the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah). 
(545) 29 - Oum Salama, the wife of the Prophet (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said: "I could not believe in the death of the Prophet (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) than when I heard the blows of the axes” (this expression means that she was surprised and amazed). 
(546) 30 - Yahia Ibn Sa'id reported that Aisha, the wife of the Prophet (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said: "I saw in a dream, the fall of three moons in my room; I told this to Abu Bakr”. When the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) died and was buried in his chamber, Abu Bakr said to him: "It is one of your moons (that you have seen) which has just fallen and it is the best" . 
(547) 31 - Trustworthy men reported to Malek, that Sa'd Ibn Abi Waqas and Sa'id Ibn Zaid Ibn Nufail died in Al-Aqiq and were taken to Medina where they were buried”. (548) 32-Hicham reported that his father said, "I don't like to be buried in Al Baqi', and I prefer to be buried elsewhere. Because if they bury me in a grave containing the remains of an unjust man, I no longer like to be with him in the same grave, and if he is a virtuous man I am not satisfied that his bones are searched. Chapter XI The act of standing up when a funeral procession passes and to sit on the graves. 
(549) 33 - Ali Ibn Abi Taleb reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) stood up when a funeral procession passed in front of him, then he sat down”. 
(550) 34 - It was reported to Malek that Ali Ibn Abi Taleb leaned against the tombs and he lay down there». Malek said, "According to different rites, it is found that it is forbidden to sit on the graves." 
(551) 35 - Abu Bakr Ibn Osman Ibn Sahl Ibn Hunaif reported that he heard Abu Ummama Ibn Sahl Ibn Hunaif say: "We attended funerals and burials, and the last comer did not sit down before making the funeral prayer. Chapter XII The ban on mourning the dead. 
(552) 36 - Jaber Ibn Atik reported: "The Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) came to visit Abdallah Ibn Thabet and found him passed out from the pain. He called him, but in vain. Then the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Be upon him the mercy and peace of Allah) said: "We belong to Allah, and it is to Him that the return will be”, then he added: “O Abu Al-Rabi'! We can't do anything for you." As the women began to scream and crying, Jaber tried to silence them, but the Apostle of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Be upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said to him “Leave them; when he passes away, let no mourner mourn him,” his daughter said: "Like I have wished to see you martyred after you had complete your preparations. The Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Be upon him the mercy and peace of Allah) said: "Allah will reward him with the reward according to his intention". Then he addressed the people and said: “Who is the martyr in your opinion”? They answered him: "He who dies fighting in the way of Allah". He replied, "The martyrs are seven in number except the one who strives in the way of Allah, are martyrs: those who die of plague, drowning, pleurisy, colic, fire, landslide, and the woman who gives birth (and dies in childbirth)”. 
(553) 37 Amra Bint Abdel-Rahman reported that she heard Aicha, the mother of the believers (telling her that Abdallah Ibn Umar said: “The dead will be punished by the tears of the people" say: "may Allah forgive Abu Abdel-Rahman (the nickname of Abdallah) he did not lie but either he forgot or he made a mistake, because, when, the Messenger of Allah (sallallahu alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) passing by a dead Jewess and seeing her parents mourn her, he said to them: "You are mourning her, but, she undoubtedly undergoes a punishment in her grave". Chapter XIII Of the expected reward when one resigns oneself during an affliction. 
(554) 38 - Abu Hurairah reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him be the mercy and peace of Allah) said: "Every Muslim, to whom the death will have kidnapped three of his children, Hell will not touch him, unless he has taken an oath without expiating it”. 
(555) 39 - Abu Al-Nadr Al-Salami reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said: “Not a Muslim, to whom death, kidnapped three children, showing patience, they will be for him a protection against the fire of hell". A woman asked: “O Messenger of Allah if there were two of them”? He replied: “even two”. 
(556) 40 - Abu Hurairah reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him be Allah's grace and peace) said: "The believer does not cease to be afflicted by the loss of his children and loved ones, so much so that by meeting Allah he will be absolved of all his sins”. Chapter XIV Hope with the conviction of reward in affliction. 
(557) 41 - Abdel-Rahman Ibn Al-Kassem Ibn Muhammad Ibn Abi Bakr reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Be upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said: "May the Muslims be relieved in their afflictions, by the afflictions that affect me". 
(558) 42 - Oum Salama, the wife of the Prophet (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) reported that the Messenger r Allah (Upon him be Allah's Grace and Peace) said: "Whoever is stricken with affliction, and who says, as Allah has commanded: “We belong to Allah, and to Him we will return, Great Allah! Grant me the reward in exchange for my affliction and give us what is best” Allah will grant it”. (Inna lillahi wa inna ilayhi rajiun. Allahumma' jurniy fi musiybatiy, wa a qibhiy khayran minha, illa faala 'llahu dhalika bihi.). Oum Salama added: "When Abu Salama died, I invoked Allah with these words, then I said to myself: 'Who would be better than Abu Salama? Allah, then destined him the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) for husband. 
(559) 43 - Al-Kassem Ibn Muhammad narrated: “One of my wives died; Muhammad Ibn Ka'b Al-Quorzi came to comfort me and said: "Among the men of Bani Israel, there was a man versed in religion and a worshiper of Allah. He had a wife he marveled at and loved madly. This woman died, and her husband felt for her a great sorrow and an unbearable grief to such an extent that he shut himself up at home, isolated himself from people and no one entered his house. A woman hearing about him came to find him saying: "I need him to advise me on a matter that concerns me and nothing only a direct interview with him will convince me". People left the house of this man, as for the woman, she remained at his door. The man was informed that a woman came to consult him about a personal matter and insisted on seeing you personally; when the people had left, she remained, not leaving the door”. The man says: “Let her come in”. She entered his house and said, “I come to ask your opinion on a problem”; he asked her, “what is this problem”? She went on: “I had borrowed jewelry from my neighbor that I had worn often and for a long time, I even lent it sometimes. we come now claim the jewellery, should I return it to them”? He replied, “By Allah! Yes". She went on: "But it's been a long time since I painted them!" He replied, "Now they have no more right to claim, as long as they have lent them to you for a long time”! The woman then said to the man “May Allah have mercy on you! You regret having returned to Allah what He lent to you; then He takes it back, well that He has more right to it than you”? The man thought of the words of the woman, realized his condition, and Allah who made these words of great use to him. Chapter XV Of those who search the tombs. 
(560) 44 - Amra Bint Abdel-Rahman reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) cursed those who search the graves: 
(561) 45 - It was reported to Malek, that Aisha, the wife of the Prophet (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said: "The sin, which a man, by breaking the bones of a dead Muslim, is equivalent in gravity to breaking them while he is alive). Chapter XVI Funerals. 
(562) 46 - Aisha, the wife of the Prophet (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) reported that she heard the Apostle of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) say before his death; while he lay her head on his chest, and she listened to him: “Great Allah! Forgive me! Have mercy on me! Join me at the highest companion. 
(563) 47 - It was reported to Malek, that Aisha said: "The Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the mercy and peace of Allah) said to me: no Prophet (salallahou alayhi wa salam) ) does not die until he has been granted the option. I heard him also say: “Great Allah! The highest companion”. Then I understood, that he was going to die». 
(564) 48 - Abdallah Ibn Umar reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said: “When one of you dies, he will be shown his (future) place morning and evening; if he is one of the elect of Paradise, he will be among the people of Paradise; if he is one of the chastened, he will be among the inhabitants of Hell, and it will be said to him: Behold your place (dwelling) that you will occupy until Allah raises you up on the day of resurrection”. 
(565) 49 - Abu Hurairah reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r Upon him the grace and peace of Allah said: "every part of the body of the son of Adam will be devoured by the earth, except for the caudal bone, for from this bone it was created and by it it will be renewed”. 
(566) 50 - Ka'b Ibn Malek Al-Ansari reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said: "the soul of the believer is not than a bird that feeds on the trees of Paradise (and she will be like that) until Allah restores her to her body on the day of resurrection”. (567) 51- Abu Huraira reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him be Allah's grace and peace) said: "Allah, the Blessed and the Most High said: "If My worshiper likes meeting me, I like meeting him and if he is reluctant to meet me, I am reluctant to meet him". (568) 52- Abu Hurairah reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him be Allah's grace and peace) said: "a man who never does an act of good said to his parents, that when he dies, let them burn his body, then let them scatter (his ashes) half on the earth, and the other half in the sea by Allah, If the Lord is able (to restore him), He will punish him with a punishment that he will never have done anyone before. When the man died, his people carried out his will. Allah then asked the earth to give back what it took, and the sea to do the same. (Once the man has been reconstituted) Allah said to him, "Why did you do this"? The man replied, "For fear of you, O Lord, and you know him well." Allah then forgave him. 
(569) 53 - Abu Huraira reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said: “every newborn, is born on the "fitra"; his parents make him either a Jew or a Christian; like camels that are born from a healthy and whole camel; do you see among these camelets only one whose limb is amputated? He was asked, “O Messenger of Allah! What do you think of those who die in infancy? He replied, "Allah knows what they would have done." 
(570) 54 - Abu Hurairah reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said: "The Supreme Hour will not will raise that when a man passing by the grave of a dead person, will say to himself: "Oh! if only I were in your place”. 
(571) 55 - Abu Katada reported that a funeral procession passing in front of the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Be upon him the grace and peace of Allah), he exclaimed: “He is delivered, and we are delivered from him”. He was told: “O Messenger of Allah! Who is the one who is delivered and the one from whom we are delivered from him”? He replied, “The believing servant, when he dies, he will be delivered from the sorrows of this world here below to enjoy the mercy of Allah. As for the pervert, men as well as countries, trees and beasts will be delivered from him”. 
(572) 56 - Abu Al-Nadr, the slave of Omar Ibn Oubaidallah reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah), when Osman Ibn Maz'oun died, and his corpse was passed near him, said: "You leave this world without having had any of its pleasures". (573) 57-Alqama Ibn Abi Alqama reported that his mother said, "I heard Aisha, the wife of the Prophet (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) narrate: “One night, the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) got up, put on his clothes and went out. I asked my servant Barira to follow him. The next she found him standing at the end (of the cemetery) of 'Al Baqi' and he stayed there as long as Allah willed, then he returned. Barira had preceded him and had come to inform me. I didn't speak to him about this except in the morning, mentioning to him the fact of yesterday; he replied, "We instructed me to go to the inhabitants of "Al-Baqi" to pray over them". 
(574) 58 - Nafé reported that Abou Houraira said: “speed up your steps by carrying the stretcher of the dead "janaza", because it is good that you precede the dead (if he was virtuous), or evil from which you unload your shoulders (if he was perverse)". MOUATTAA In the name of Allah the Merciful the Merciful Book 17 About zakat First chapter Of what is subject to zakat. 
(575) 1 - Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri narrated that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said: "The zakat is not a duty if one has less than five camels, or five ounces of silver or five awsouqs (unit of measure) of grain”. 
(576) 2 - Abu Sa'id Al-Koudri reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said: "The zakat is not a duty for anything that is quantitatively less than five awaouqs of dates, or of a number less than five ounces of silver, or five camels”. 
(577) 3 - We reported to Malek that Omar Ibn Abdel-Aziz during a written order to his prefect in Damascus dictated: "One owes zakat to the subjects of the harvest, gold, silver and herds". And from the saying of Malek: "The zakat is due only for three: the harvest, the metals of gold and silver, and the herds". Chapter II The duty of zakat with regard to gold and silver. 
(578) 4 - Muhammad Ibn Ouqba, the slave of Al-Zoubair, reported that he asked Al-Kassem Ibn Muhammad for the question, to have received a good amount of money, of a slave as the price of his liberation; does this amount require zakat? Al-Kassem replied, "Abu Bakr Al-Siddiq did not accept zakat due to a sum of money, until one year had elapsed." Al-Kassem Ibn Muhammad continued: "When Abu Bakr gave gifts to men, he asked each of them, if he had any money from which he should pay the zakah? If the answer was affirmative, the value of the zakat was subtracted from him before he received it; if this was not the case, his gift was given to him, without being touched". 
(579) 5 - Aicha bint Qudama reported from his father that he said: "Whenever I went to Osman Ibn Affan to ask for my donation, he asked, "Do you have any money that requires zakat? If my answer was 'yes', from my donation, he raised what is zakat, and if it was 'no', he gave me back my donation”. 
(580) 6 - Nafe'a reported that Ibn Shehab said: "Any sum spared, is not required to pay zakat, before it is preserved for one year”. 
(581) 7 - Malek reported that Ibn Chehab said: "The first who took zakat, donations, was Mu'awia Ibn Abi Sufian" Malek said: "This which is an undeniable tradition and followed in Medina is that the zakat must be paid for twenty dinars in gold, as well as for a sum of two hundred dirhams”. A - Malek also said: “The zakat is not obligatory for the sum of twenty dinars (in gold), if their weight is less than that of twenty real dinars; if the weight is constant to that of twenty zakat is payable. On the other hand, zakat is not payable for an amount less than twenty dinars in gold. Zakat is not likewise payable for a sum of two hundred dirhams whose weight is less than that of two other two hundred which have actually constancy of weight, and where zakat is payable. If these coins are variable, due to their weight from one balance to another, the zakat is, in my opinion, obligatorily payable”. B Malek said: “if the man has one hundred and sixty dirhams having a very constant real weight, and that in his country eight dirhams are exchanged for one dinar, he does not have to pay the zakat about them, that just when the dirhams exchanged are equivalent to twenty dinars in gold or two hundred dirhams in silver”. C - Malek said about of a man possessing five dinars which came to him from a profit or other source; this sum, bringing him a profit from a trade after the lapse of a year, which is in his possession, and according to Malek, subject to zakat. However, this new capital, will not be subject to zakat, neither a day after the lapse of a year, nor a day before; zakat is payable, after one year has elapsed, from the very day on which the capital has been trained”. D - Malek said, at about a man who, having ten dinars, then benefiting from this sum, in the field of commerce, to reach twenty dinars after the lapse of a year, he must submit this new sum to zakat without waiting for a year has elapsed from the day it was formed, because this period was elapsed when he possessed twenty dinars. Subsequent zakat is not payable until one year after the penultimate one has been paid. E - Malek added: “This what has been heard about the wages of slaves and their tribute, the wages of the poor, and the price of the release of the contractual slave, is that all these cases are not subject to zakat, and that whatever the amount, unless a year has already passed, precisely from day on which the beneficiary received the sum". F - And Malek says again: “for gold and silver which are in association, where each has a share of twenty dinars or two hundred dirhams, they owe zakat. Whoever has less than that is exempt from paying zakat. If all shares are subject to zakat, but with a variant, when the value of these shares is different from one share to another, so that some shares are lower than the sum where it is the duty to pay the zakat, as for the others, if the sum is higher, the zakat will be provided for in these last shares, also according to their values; because the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said: "zakat is not obligatory for a sum of less than five ounces of silver". Malek said, "That's the best I've heard about it." - Malek said: “if a man has gold and silver, but they are scattered among people, he must assess them so that he pays on them, the due zakat”. - And from the saying of Malek: "Whoever, by inheritance or by gift, obtains gold and silver, the zakat on their subject, is only due, before the lapse of one year" . Chapter III Metal zakat. 
(582) 8 - Rabi'a Ibn Abi Abdel-Rahman reported from many that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) had granted Bilal Ibn Al-Hareth the privilege of a territory on the coast containing the mines of Qabaliya, on the side of "Four'" (Between Medina and Nakieh). These mines are still subject to zakat”. Malek said: "I think and Allah is best informed that these buried metals are only due for zakat, when what is of their extracts is equivalent to twenty dinars or two hundred dirhams; and whatever is in excess, shall likewise be subject to zakat according to the legal assessment of zakat; in case we are unable to extract what is valuable from these metals, nothing is subject to zakat, only when what is extracted is equivalent to twenty dinars in gold or two hundred dirhams in silver, taking into account the first evaluation”. And Malek said, “metal is to be compared to crops; both are subject to zakat; what is extracted from the first is subject to zakat, without the expectation of a year passing; as for harvests, the tenth of their quantities is for zakat, and that, before one year is exceeded. Chapter IV From the zakat of buried metals called: “Al - Rikaz” 
(583) 9 - Abu Hurairah reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said: “the rikaz is subject to the fifth”. (the buried treasure) Malek said: "which is unquestionably followed in Medina, and that, moreover, I have heard from the ulema is that: the rikaz is all that is buried from the pre-Islamic era; it is all one can have without price, expense, hard work, or supplies. On the other hand, what requires an effort, or an expense, and where one has the risk of finding or not by digging, it is not rikaz. Chapter V Of what is not subject to zakat such as jewelry, gold dust and amber. 
(584) 10 - Abdel-rahman Ibn Al-Kassem reported from his father that Aicha, the wife of the Prophet (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r Upon him the grace and peace of Allah took care of his orphan nieces, who lived under his guardianship, keeping their jewelry for them, without her paying zakat on them. 
(585) 11 - Nafe' reported that Abdallah Ibn Omar, did not pay the zakat, on the objects of adornment, of his daughters and his slaves (females). Malek said: "Whoever has powdered gold or gold or silver jewelry that does not serve as adornment, must pay zakat about them, every year by taking a quarter of a tenth after weighing them, unless the value is not twenty dinars in gold or two hundred dirhams in silver, if, what he possesses is less than that , zakat is not payable. As for gold powder or broken jewelry which their owner intends to repair, then use it for adornment, they are held like furniture in a house and are not subject to zakat”. Malek also said: “neither pearls, nor musk, nor amber, are subject to zakat”. Chapter VI The subject of zakat with regard to the property of orphans, and the profit they bring in trade. 
(586) 12 • It was reported to Malek that Omar Ibn Al-Khattab said: "Make the goods of the orphans are fructified in the trade, otherwise the zakat will eat them away”. 
(587) 13 - Abdel-Rahman Ibn Al-Kassem reported from his father the following: “Aicha, looked after me and my brother, being two orphans, under her guardianship; she paid zakat, goods that we had”. 
(588) 14 • It was reported to Malek, that Aisha, the wife of the Prophet (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) exposed to trade, the money that went to the orphans, being under his guardianship". 
(589) 15 - Malek reported that Yahia Ibn Sa'id bought for his orphan nephews, living under his guardianship, property, which was later sold, bringing in a great profit”. Malek said, “There is no harm in orphans' money being traded in case the protector is permitted to do so; I don't think that the protector should thereby provide a guarantee. Chapter VII Inheritances subject to zakat. 
(590) 16 - Malek said: "When a man dies and he has not paid zakat of his property, I find that zakat be taken from a third of his inheritance, taking into account that this should in no case be more than a third. It is even necessary that the zakat be deducted from it before terminating the will, because, in my opinion. This is considered in the form of debts which must be discharged”. Malek continuing: “this is the case of a man who has already made his will; if this is not the case, it is necessary that his people do it, because it will be a good way to act; moreover, they are not obliged to do so”. Malek also said: "What is undisputed tradition and good practice (in Medina) is that someone who inherits should not pay the zakat, for any property he receives from a loan repaid to the dead, from a transaction, from a dwelling, from a slave, from a slave before one year has passed, from the day he cashes in the sum that comes to him from the sale of this property”. On the other hand, what is our tradition, says Malek, is that the heir does not owe zakat for an estate until one year has passed”. Chapter VIII Zakat due on a debt. 
(591) 17 Al-Saib Ibn Yazid reported that Osman Ibn Affan said: “This is the month of paying your zakat. He who owes a debt, let him discharge it, and when you have recovered your rights, pay the zakat on them”. (592) 18- Ayoub Ibn Abi Tamima Al-Sakhtiane reported that Omar Ibn Abdel-Aziz ordered, in writing, his prefects, who unjustly levied taxes, taxpayers, to return them by deducting from them the zakat due to the years already passed. Then he revised his opinion and prescribed that this zakat is to be collected for only one time because we no longer know, from whom these taxes had been collected, and whether or not he had to pay the zakat”. 
(593) 19 - Yazid Ibn Khoussaifa reported that he asked Suleiman Ibn Yassar at Subject of a man possessing and being indebted to the same amount of money; does he have to pay zakat for what he owns? He replied, "No". Malek said: "What is not to be discussed for the question of debts is that whoever lends does not pay zakat, only after having recovered his loan, even if the debtor owes this debt for many years; and in this case, the one who has the right, owes the zakat only once after having recovered the ready. In the event that he partially recovers the loan, this sum is not subject to zakat; but if he possesses a sum, other than the one he has just had, after recovery of his debt, this sum is subject to zakat, which will be relative and to the sum in question, and to the part of the loan which he had already recovered". Malek continued: “in case this man does not have his loan, and this is not due from a zakat, then, the zakat is not to pay; but that he remember well what he has already recovered, because when there will be an addition so that everything will be subject to zakat, he must pay it”. And Malek went on to say, “In case the sum recovered from the loan has been consumed or not, the zakat is obligatory with what he will have collected elsewhere, which with the first part is equivalent to twenty dinars in gold, or two hundred dirhams in silver. As for what he will recover later from the loan, whether little or much, the zakat in this case, will be payable relatively to the sum”. Malek resumed: “like proof of what we have just mentioned, about the debt, so that it has been recovered after a good number of years, as for the zakat, which is appropriate for it, it is payable only for one one time, - it is to be compared to a commodity, being and remaining with a merchant for several years; selling it, the merchant will only pay the zakat he owes his merchandise once. It's that the owner of the goods or the creditor no longer has to pay the zakat due on a property which, if applicable, belongs to a third person; zakat, in fact, is only required of property in material possession" Malek said finally says: “For the man who is burdened with a debt to be paid, and possesses its equivalence in merchandise, in addition to a sum of money subject to zakat; in this case the zakat is payable for the sum liquidated without taking into account what he must pay as debt, or what he possesses as merchandise; but once the sum in liquid exceeds that which he has for debt, he must pay the zakat due on this superfluity”. Chapter IX Goods subject to zakat. 
(594) 20 Zuraik Ibn Hayyan, in charge of controlling passengers entering Egypt, in the time of Al-Walid, Suleiman and Omar Ibn Abdel-Aziz, reported that Omar Ibn Abdel-Aziz ordered him in writing to observe passengers Moslems who enter, to take part of the money which they have, and of the value of their goods intended for the trade, by collecting on each sum of forty dinars, a dinar; to take into account what is less than that, until reaching the bottom of twenty dinars, and if it is still less than twenty, that is to say by a third, in this case, to perceive nothing”. As for the passengers who live under the Moslem protection, to perceive from them, a dinar out of twenty of the value of their goods which are for sale; to consider, which is less than that up to ten dinars; if it is less than ten dinars, to demand nothing, even if it is less than a third of the dinar, not to profit. To give them exchange, valid receipts, for one year, for what you perceive from them". A-Malek said: "what is practice in Medina, in the field of commerce, in case a man pays what he owes for zakat, then buys, with what he owns, a variety of merchandise; silk garments, slaves, or others and sells his purchases before a year is exceeded, this man owes nothing as zakat until one year later, from the day he paid the first zakat. On the other hand, if what he had bought remains at home, no sold, and this for several years, he will not have to pay the due zakat, even if it will last for a long time, until the sale takes place; at that time, zakat will be paid for one time only,'. B - For the subject who buys wheat, dates or other goods with gold or silver coins and keeps them to sell, but after a year has already passed, is zakat due for such goods? Malek replied: "Zakat is obligatory on the day of the sale, if the amount withheld of the sale is assessed to be subject to zakat; and that is not to be compared to the case of the harvest where the man obtains the output of his harvest, nor even to that of the cutting of the palm trees”. C - Malek said: “if the man owns money invests in the field of trade for a profit, and that is not the case, zakat is of obligation on this subject, and this by taking as point of reference a month of the year, where it will make a census by evaluating the available goods, and what it has as liquidated sum in gold or other; if the total amount is subject to zakat, it is payable”. D - Malek added: "those who practice, or not, trade, they are all the same, and only pay zakat once a year". Chapter X Of what is relative to the (buried) treasure. 
(595) 21 - Abdallah Ibn Dinar reported that he heard Abdallah Ibn Umar inquiring about the buried treasure? What is it? And response: “It is of all metals, which are not due for zakat”?. 
(596) 22 - Abu Saieh Al-Samman reported that Abu Huraira said: “Whoever has property, and does not pay for it what he owes for zakat, this property, on the day of resurrection, will take the form of a python, with a bald head, provided with two small horns, seeking the possessor of goods to capture him, saying to him: "I am your treasure". Chapter XI Of the zakat of the herds. 
(597) 23 - Yahia reported that Malek said: that he read the information prescribed by Omar Ibn Al-Khattab relating to zakat, and there he found: - For twenty-four camels, (24) or less, the zakat is one monton for every five camels. - For a number beyond twenty-four, (24) reaching thirty-five, (35) inclusive, the zakat is of a camel of one year old, otherwise, a camel of two years old. - For a number varying between thirty and five, (35) and forty and five, (45) a camel two years old. - For what is between forty and six, (46) up to sixty, (60) inclusive, a camel three years old and ready for copulation. Between sixty-one (61) and sixty-fifteen, (75) inclusive, a four-year-old female camel. - From seventy-six (76) to ninety-ten, (90) two camels of two years of age. - From eighty and eleven, (91) to one hundred and twenty, (120) two camels three years old and ready for copulation. - For all that is beyond one hundred and twenty-one, (121) a one-year-old camel for every forty (40) camels, and a three-year-old camel ready for copulation for every fifty (50). - As for the sheep: forty to a hundred and twenty (from 40 to 120) a sheep. - For between one hundred and twenty one (121) and two hundred, (200) the zakat is two sheep. - From two hundred and one (201) to three hundred, (300) three sheep. - From three hundred and one (301) and above that number, one sheep for every hundred. - On the other hand, we should not give alms, neither from a goat, nor from an old animal, nor from an animal which has lost a limb, unless the collector agrees to take it”. - One should not group two lots, nor separate a group of two lots because of the zakat. - In case there is a mixture of two lots, where they cannot be distinguished, both owners owe zakat. - With regard to money, the zakat is a quarter of a tenth if the weight is equal to or exceeds five ounces. Chapter XII Zakat from cows. 
(598) 24 - Taous Al-Yemeni reported that Mu'az Ibn Jabal Al-Ansari took from thirty cows, the zakat of a calf one year old, and forty cows, a cow three years old without collecting anything of what was less than that saying: “I have not heard anything from the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) On him the grace and the gaix of Allah as information about them, and I will ask him when I meet him”. But the envoy of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Be upon him the mercy and peace of Allah) died before Mu'az met him". A - Malek said: “What I have heard the best say about a man, owning a herd (of cows) which two or more shepherds, in different countries, had taken care of, that this man owes zakat for his reunited flock. His case is to be compared to one who possesses a sum of gold or silver, but to the holding of several persons; he must identify it and evaluate it so that he pays the zakat, if this sum is subject to it”. B - About the man owning a herd of sheep and goats, Malek said, “he has to bring them together to find out what zakat is due to them. due because this herd will be considered as made up of sheep alone, and this by referring to the letter of Omar Ibn Al-Khattab (mentioned above): "of forty sheep, one sheep". C - Malek added: “If the number of sheep is greater than that of goats, the owner of the herd owes only one sheep for the collector in charge of the zakat affair. If the goats are at a number exceeding that of the sheep, the collector takes a goat (or a goat). If the sheep and the goats are the same number, the collector will choose one as he pleases”. D - Yahia reported that Malek said: "it is the same case that arises, whether they are camels called: 'Arab', or camels with long necks called: “boukhts”. Malek said: “They are ultimately all camels; if the number of Arabs exceeds that of the boukht, and the owner owes only one more than that from Arabs, he can take a boukht; if the number is the same for the two categories, the collector takes one of the kind he chooses”. E - Malek said, "It's likewise, for the case of cows and buffaloes all put together; he said, “They are all cows. If the number of cows exceeds that of buffaloes, and the owner owes only one cow, the collector takes a cow, and if the buffaloes outnumber the cows, he takes a buffalo; if cows and buffaloes are equal in number, the collector will choose, one, of the kind he wants. Finally, if zakat is required from both genders, the collector takes one of each gender”. F - Yahia a reported that Malek said, "He who in his flock brought together camels, cows and sheep, owes no zakat until just one year has elapsed from the day on which this meeting took place. been made; unless he previously had a herd subject to zakat, consisting of five camels, or thirty cows, or forty sheep. If the man owned five camels, or thirty cows, or forty sheep, and he added to them camels, cows, sheep, which came to him either by purchase, or by gift, or by inheritance, he has to pay zakat on them when he pays her for what he had before the attached ones, even if a year had not yet passed, from the day he started to use their usufruct. In case zakat has been paid for animals that have been joined with others, he will pay zakat for them along with that of his herd. G - They are considered, and still according to Malek, as the money whose zakat was paid, then the man used this money to buy goods, while the zakat became of obligation, if he sells it; and in this case the former owner will have paid the zakat, the same day of the transaction, and the second owner the following day”. H - For the man who owned a herd of sheep not payable by zakat, to which he added other sheep, either by purchase or by inheritance, but the number of which does not call for zakat, this man don't have to pay zakat before a year is passed, just from the day when the purchase or the inheritance took place is that the man in possession of a herd of camels, sheep and cows, the number of which is not not yet sufficient, to pay zakat; it will be in case each kind (of sheep, cows, camels) reaches the number where zakat is indebted. This is what is to be considered for the payment of zakat, when one joins the herd in a small or large number of the existing genera”. 1 - And Malek has added: "For the man who owns camels, cows, or sheep where each gender makes zakat indebted, and then joins what it owns, others of the same kind, zakat is to be paid for what he has as a whole". Yahia reports that Malek said, "That's the best I've heard about it." J - Malek said: “For the animal, whose zakat is indebted: if it is a one-year-old camel and a man does not own it, he can give, in exchange, a two-year-old camel If it's a camel two years old, or one of three years old, or even four years old, and that the man does not have what he owes, it is better, that he buys it, than to give his price to the collector. K - As for, what we uses camels or cows, either to bring water or to plow the land, Malek said: "I think that of those you have to pay zakat". Chapter XIII From zakat of a herd to different kinds. 
(599) 25 - Yahia reported that Malek said, "If there is a mixture of two flocks, and one shepherd, and where there is one stallion, one pasture and one bucket, the owners of that mixed flock, are associates even if we can determine the share of each. On the other hand, if we does not know each other's share, they are not partners but co-owners". Malek said, "In case the owners are in common, zakat is payable only when the share of each is determined to be in this capacity. This is interpreted as follows: “Whoever owns forty sheep, he owes zakat; as for the other who has less, zakat is not obligatory. In the event that each share is indebted for one zakat, the two parts can be combined, to receive only one zakat. Take for example the following: If one has a thousand sheep or less, and the other forty or more, they are joint owners and each pays the zakat corresponding to his share; for the case of thousand and forty camels, their common owners will react such as those who own sheep and where each will pay the proper zakat for his share, if this is indebted for zakat; because the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said: "The zakat is not to be paid for the number of camels less than five”; and Omar Ibn Al-Khattab said, "For less than forty sheep, zakat is not payable." Malek said: “it is, on this subject, from what I, best, heard to say”. Malek added: “Omar Ibn Al-Khattaba said: "Never to join two parts, and also not to separate two parts, because of the zakat", speaking of those who own flocks. To specify much more: “Never to reunite two separate parts”; supposing that it is a question of three persons, and that each is the owner of forty sheep; in this case, the zakat that everyone owes is one sheep. Furthermore, if the three people had gathered their possession, they can trick by it, the collector, make only one sheep be of zakat; but this is categorically prohibited”. This is what is to be understood from the words of Omar Ibn Al-Khattab: never to unite two parts, and neither to separate two parts”; and "that's the best I've heard, say," Malek says. Chapter XIV Of what is said about the zakat of goats. 
(600) 26 - Soufian Ibn Abdallah reported that Omar Ibn Al-Khattab gave him the charge, to collect zakat, about newly born rafters and goats. We said to him: “why make this count, without any benefit of zakat”? Back at Omar's, Soufian reports the protests to him; thus Omar says: “Yes, one must count them rafters and goats, which are carried in the arms of the shepherd (still infants), but which are not exigible from the zakat. We don't even have to take the one that is well fed, neither the ewe that has just given birth, nor the pregnant one, nor the stallion of sheep; but the zakat is to be collected in that of two completed years or of four completed years”. "For the owner of sheep whose number is not due for zakat, and for whom the ewes were going to give birth, one day before the collector was entitled to zakat, especially since the births were going to increase the number sheep, which is payable as zakat", Malek said: “If the ewes, from the births they had made, the number of the sheep would increase, reaching a number requiring zakat, this must be paid. Because, the breeding of sheep, and the increase in the number of sheep, are quite different from the number of sheep which one has purchased, or which one has received by inheritance or by gift. It is the same case, of a commodity, the price of which is not worth, its submission to zakat, but on its sale, the owner receives a profit where the zakat is by right, therefore, it is to be paid out of the profit. But if the profit comes from a capital gain, or an inheritance, the zakat is payable after one year has passed, from the day where the interest or inheritance has been affected". Malek said: “The kids and lambs are to be compared to the profits of a capital; however, they are different, in another light namely: if the man is the owner of a sum of gold or silver which owes the zakat, to which he adds another sum; this addition is not subject to zakat when it will be paid for what it had previously, that after the passage of one year, from the day when the new sum was added. But in case the man is the owner of sheep, cows or of camels, whose category of each species is subject to zakat, and he adds a camel, a cow, or a sheep, he must pay zakat for what has been added, when he will have it paid for what he had before if the number deserves to be subject to zakat”. Malek said, "that's the best explanation I've heard about it." Chapter XV Two-year cumulative zakat. 
(601) 27 - Yahia reported that Malek said, "For the man who owns a hundred camels who owe zakat but to whose house the collector does not come to claim it until the day when the zakat became two-year cumulative; and by chance, the man must have lost what he had of camels, having only five, the beggar will not have only entitled to two sheep for zakat on the remaining five camels, in the sense that it is one sheep per year. Zakat in this case is counted only according to what the man possesses on the day when he discharges it whether the herd has perished or been increased. If zakats have been accumulated for several years, he will only pay one zakat and that on the day when it must be paid; and if in that case his herd is no more, or the number has been minimized to such an extent that he does not deserve no longer be subject to zakat, he will have nothing to pay, and no zakat is payable for what has perished from this herd even if the zakat has been accumulated for several years”. Chapter XVI Prohibition, to constrain the subjects from whom one perceives the zakat. 
(602) 28 - Aisha, the wife of the Prophet (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) reported: “Omar Ibn Al-Khattab, being passing by, near a herd of sheep which is due for zakat, noticed a sheep with large and swollen udders; he asked where this sheep came from”?; "she does part of the zakat”, they answered him; "I don't believe that her owner handed her over. willingly"! Omar retorted and added, "Never seek to embarrass people, take nothing that is so precious from Muslims, and avoid claiming from them, dairy females under zakat." 
(603) 29 - Muhammad Ibn Yahia Ibn Habban reported that two men from the tribe “Achja”, recounted, that Muhammad Ibn Maslama Al-Ansari, on his way to collect zakat, he said to the debtor: “Select the zakat of your goods”. He did not refuse a sheep that his owner thought she was an acquittal of what he owed”. Malek said, "What was followed in Medina, and that moreover, I have heard versed men say, it is not to push Muslims to coercion by claiming zakat from them and to accept from them, all good, that they handed over. Chapter XVII Alms, and those who are entitled to them. 
(604) 30 • Ata Ibn Yassar reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Be upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said: “Almsgiving is not permitted to the rich, it is actually permitted for five people: a fighter in the way of Allah, a beggar for alms, a man in debt, a man who buys it with his own money, and a man having a poor neighbor to whom alms have been given, which will be given by the latter to the rich man”. Malek said, “What is of follow-up, in the distribution of alms, is that it be made according to the choice of the governor, according to even his forecast, thus, he can deliver to one of the persons, mentioned above, according to his need, and as much as the governor thinks fit; a year or two later, he will give to other people, always considering what is necessary for them; that's what the scholars were happy to do," according to Malek's words. On the other hand, those who work for alms, says Malek, are only entitled to a specific percentage, unless the governor goes to apply any standard other than necessity”. Chapter XVIII The quest for alms and the insistence on covering them 
(605) 31 - Malek reported that Abu Bakr Al-Siddiq said: "If men refuse to give me zakat, I will fight against them, to get it". 
(606) 32 - Zaid Ibn Aslam reported that Omar Ibn Al-Khattab drank milk which he found good; he asked the man who gave it to him to drink, the origin of this milk? He told him that he was near a spring, and mentioned his name, he met a herd of animals, whose zakat was due, which was drinking. He asked for a drink, they gave him milk, which he took and filled his skin. Then Omar, put his hand in his mouth, and vomited what he had already drunk». Malek said, “He who refuses the accomplishment of one of the prescriptions, imposed by Allah and which the Muslims could not follow, they will have every right, to fight against this man until he gives it to them”. 
(607) 33 - It was reported to Malek that one of Omar Ibn Abdel-Aziz's prefects told him writes, which follows: “a man refused to perform zakat of his property”; Omar, replied to him in writing: “beware of him, and do not take part of his zakat, with Muslims”. The man, put in aware of what had taken place, fell into pain, and even became sickly; at this time, he hastened to pay his zakat; the prefect of Omar, let him know what is due to this man; Omar hardly protested and said, "Take this zakat." Chapter XIX From the estimated zakat of harvesting dates and grapes 
(608) 34 - Busr Ibn Sa'id reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Be upon him the mercy and peace of Allah) said: "lands watered by the rain and the water channels, we pay a zakat which is equivalent to one tenth of the crop; of those who are watered by water drawn from wells or through pumps, the zakat is half of a tenth”. 
(609) 35 - Ziad Ibn Sa'id reported that Ibn Chehab said: one does not take zakat from bad quality dates, called "al-jou'rour"; or “mousran-el-fara”, nor “azq ibn houbaiq”; they are counted for their owner but without being subject to zakat”. Malek said, “this is to compare to sheep, which are reckoned with goats, and these goats are in no way subject to zakat. It is about even for some fruits of which some species are not designed for alms, for example "Al-Bourdi" (one of the best qualities of dates); thus one takes neither good nor bad quality; one is in preference for what is of average quality”. Malek said: "what we esteems that among the fruits in Medina, it is especially dates and grapes, and that as soon as they are ripe and suitable for sale. It is that the fruits of palm trees and vines are eaten as fresh dates and fresh grapes. They are valued as long as they are fruits in the trees, so that their owners will be at ease and no longer in embarrassment after this valuation; then we leave to the owners the right to dispose as they see fit, of the delivery of their alms according to what has been estimated. Malek said: “For this which are fruits which are not eaten fresh, but which are used after the harvest like cereals, they are not to be valued; but we leave to their owners, and that after having harvested, treated, winnowed, so that they become grains ready to be consumed, the whole confidence in their loyalty, to give alms in case the quantity piled up, is due. And this subject is indisputable. Malek added: “what is followed in Medina is that, the palms are esteemed, while having their fruits on their trees; once these fruits ripen and whether they are displayed for sale, zakat is due from dates after cutting the bunches. If the palms are attacked with a plague after they have been esteemed, and before the bunches are cut, and the plagues deprive the palms of all their fruits, zakat, is no longer required. If, among what remains, the quantity is five 'Wasqs and beyond according to the 'sa' of the Prophet r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah), zakat is to be considered in this quantity and not in that which has been lost". The same process is to be followed for the vineyards. If we have in different places, or that one owns lots in common with others of so that the lot alone is not subject to zakat, but together, the whole becomes subject to zakat, which must be paid”. Chapter XX The zakat of grains and olives 
(610) 36 - Malek reported that he inquired about the zakat of olives, near Ibn Chehab who answered him: "it is of the tenth". Malek said: "zakat intended for the olive, is of the tenth, but after having pressed it, and that the quantity be five “Wasqs” and above; if it is less, the zakat is no longer entitled. And the olive trees are considered the palm trees, about watering: let the land planted with olive trees be watered by the rain and the springs of water, the zakat, is there of the tenth; watered by water drawn from wells or others, it is half a tenth; for the olive trees, there is no need to estimate them, whereas the olives are always on the trees». As for grains that people save to eat later, the zakat is one-tenth if the land is watered by rain or springs. water; it is half of a tenth if the watering is done by the water brought. We must take into account that the weight is five "Wasqs" according to the "sa'" of the Prophet (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (On him the grace and peace of Allah), Malek said, and always about the grains, that what is subject to them are the following kinds: wheat, barley, soult (kind of barley), maize, millet , rice, lentil, vetch, bean, sesame and other genera similar to them, and are for food use. However the zakat, intended for these grains, is of right, once they are harvested and shelled. And, people are payable at this zakat, and we accept from them whatever they give". And, Malek was asked the time, when the zakat olives, which is either one tenth or one half of the second, is to be paid; is it before or after the maintenance fee reduction? He answered: “one does not have to consider the expenses which the owners take care of, just like the case of the food and one is only interested in what is declared. He, in whom the weight of the olives is five “Wasqs” and beyond, the zakat is one-tenth of the oil, after the olive has been pressed; if the weight is less, the zakat is not due”. Malek said, “He who sells his crop of grains after they have become dry, unharmed and kept in their husks, has to pay zakat himself, and not the buyer. And the grains can only be sold after having dried up in their envelopes, and without their still needing water, to water them”. Malek said, "for the verse: 'Pay the duties on the day of harvest' Quran VI, 141, interpreting it: it is about zakat, which is to be paid, and it says -he, "which I have heard of many". Malek finally said: “He who sells his garden, or its land, which gives crops, or fruit trees, but, at the time when the fruits are not edible, it is up to the buyer to pay zakat. In case the fruits have become edible, the seller owes this zakat unless it suits the buyer”. Chapter XXI Fruits exempt from zakat. 
(611) 37 - Malek said: "for the man, who, after picking or harvesting, obtains only four Wasqs of dates, or four Wasqs of raisins, or four Wasqs of wheat, or four Wasqs of floury grains, he will not have to collect the everything, so that it is subject to zakat; because this one is due when the weight of any species, namely, dates, raisins, wheat, or floury grains, is five Wasqs, according to the "sa'" of the Prophet (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) and in accordance with the words of the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah): "for less than five Wasqs, zakat is not payable". In case, any species, previously mentioned, has a weight of five Wasqs, zakat is payable, if the weight is less, zakat is not. For more precision, suppose that the man picked five Wasqs of dates, and that independently of their gender and color; he will have to collect everything and then pay the zakat; if the weight is less than five, zakat is not paid. It is the same for wheat, brown or white, for barley, vetch, all considered one species the man must meet to pay the zakat if the weight is five Wasqs or more than five Wasqs; and if it is less than five, the zakat is not payable. As for raisins where one has black and red, which, being picked, and their weight is five Wasqs, man has to pay zakat. If the weight is less than five, zakat is not payable. As for floury grains, they are all considered as one species, just like wheat, dates and raisins without emphasizing their names or colours. Grains are said to be: peas, lentils, beans and vetches, and all that is considered by people to be floury grains. If the man had to harvest five Wasqs' according to the "sa'" of the Prophet (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) from all these grains, mixed together without distinguishing the species, he must combine them to pay the zakat, if it is due) Malek said: "And Omar Ibn Al-Khattab distinguished between mealy grains and wheat, when he collected zakat of the Nabataeans; he considered that all mealy grains constitute a single species and took from them, the tenth for zakat, and half of the tenth of the wheat and dates, always for zakat. Malek added: “If we protests saying: how to accept, the meeting of different kinds of floury grains so that the total is subject to zakat, and consequently, man can exchange from hand to hand a measure of one of these species for two of another, whereas this exchange cannot in any case take place, from hand to hand, for two measures of one kind of wheat against two of a different kind? The answer was the following: "gold and silver are brought together in order to pay zakat, and one can, on the other hand, exchange one dinar for several multiples of silver from hand to hand". Malek said: “for this which is palm trees which are owned between two men, and who pick eight Wasqs of dates from them, they do not have to pay zakat. If one of them picks five Wasqs, and the other four or less and the picking is from the same land, it is to the first that zakat is due, as for the other he is exempt. It is the same case for the associates, in the harvest of the grains obtained after the harvest, or of the dates after their cutting, or of the grape after its picking. If each of them will have five Wasqs of cut dates, or picked grapes, or grains broke, he must pay zakat on them; for the one whose share is less than five Wasqs, he is exempt from zakat, which will be paid by the one whose share is five Wasqs, and more”. Malek said, "What is followed in Medina is that for the man who has paid what he owes for zakat of the different kinds of wheat, dates, raisins, and cereals, then he retains them for a few years, after which he will sell them, the zakat is not entitled to be paid only after the lapse of one year, from the day on which the sale took place, because this is considered as for the usufruct or other and no longer for the trade. This is to be considered just like food, store of grain and commodities which man can keep for a number of years in order to sell them later for gold and silver; in this case, he will only have to pay zakat after the lapse of a year, from the very day on which the sale took place. But if these species are intended as articles of commerce, their owner must perform zakat on them, when he sells them, if he had kept them for a year, after paying zakat on the day he had already bought them”. Chapter XXII Of what is not subject to zakat, fruits, vegetables and cereals Malek said, “here that is of tradition, and which I have moreover heard said by the men paid is that not all fruits are subject to zakat such as pomegranates, plums, figs and the like, of all fruits. The same is true for vegetables and cereals, where there is no zakat until one year has elapsed from the day of their sale and the collection of the price”. Chapter XXIII From the zakat of slaves, horses, and honey. 
(612) 38 - Abu Huraira reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said: "The Muslim, is exempt from zakat in the subjects of his slave, and his horse". 
(613) 39 - Suleiman Ibn Yassar reported that the people of Syria said to Ubaidallah Ibn Al-Jarrah: "Take what is zakat for our horses and our slaves”; but he refused, then wrote to Omar Ibn Al-Khat-tab, about this, who in turn refused. Syrians insisted on zakat, to Oubaidallah, who rewrote to Omar, whose response was: "If it satisfies them, take the zakat, and return theirs, offering it to their slaves”. And Malek recalls that the slaves were understood to be the poor”. 
(614) 40 - Abdallah Ibn Abi Bakr Ibn Amr Ibn Hazm reported: "My father, being in Mina, received from Omar Ibn Abdel-Aziz a letter, which said, not to take zakat neither for the honey nor for the horse. 
(615) 41 - Abdallah Ibn dinar reported: "I asked Sa'id Ibn Al Moussaiab about the zakat of horses"? He replied, “Is there any zakat on them”? Chapter XXIV The capitation imposed on the People of the Book and the Magi. 
(616) 42 - Ibn Chehab narrated: "I was told that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the favor and peace of Allah) had received the capitation of the Magi of "Bahrain ". And that Omar Ibn Al-Khattab had perceived it from the Magi of “Persia” and Osman Ibn Affan, from the “Berbers”. 
(617) 43 - Ja’far Ibn Muhammad Ibn Ali reported from his father that Omar Ibn Al-Khattab, alluding to the Magi, said: "I don't know how behave with them”? Abdel-Rahman Ibn Auf replied: "I testify that I heard the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him be Allah's Grace and Peace) say: "Treat them like the People of the Book". 
(618) 44 - Aslam, the slave of Omar Ibn Al-Khattab reported: "Omar Ibn Al-Khattab charged tax, the owners of the gold, for a value of four dinars, as well as those of the silver forty dirhams. This was for the benefit of the Muslims to help them, and to be hospitable to travellers”. 
(619) 45 - Zaid Ibn Aslam reported that his father said to Umar Ibn Al-Khattab: "Among the mounts there is a blind camel"; Omar to answer: “To give it to a poor family to use it”; I replied, "but she is blind”; He retorted: "Let it be treated with tar"; I answered: “How then, can she feed on the grass”?. Omar asked, “is it tax goods or zakat goods ”? "She's tax goods" I said. “By Allah, said Omar, you want to eat his flesh”. - She has the tax mark,” I said. Omar then gave the order to cut his throat, and he had nine dishes which, were well filled with fruits and other foods; he sent these dishes to the wives of the Prophet (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) the last of which was given to Hafsa, the daughter of Omar, for the good reason that, if his dish had for content, which is less than in the others, he will consider that as his part. He put in these dishes, flesh of the camel and sent them to the wives of the Prophet (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) and with what remains he had a meal, to which he invited the Monhajirines and the Ansars”. Malek said, "I foresee that one should only take from the tributaries what they owe as taxes." 
(620) 46 - It was reported to Malek, that Omar Ibn Abdel Aziz had written to his governors: "To remit the taxes to the tributaries who have embraced Islam". Malek said, “He is from the sunna, not to impose the tax neither on the wives of the People of the Book, nor on their children, and that it is of obligation for pubescent men. On the other hand, the capitation is not collected from those who are protected by the Muslims, nor from the Magi, for what they possess of properties such as palm trees, vines, plantations, herds, because, the alms was in principle only wanted from Muslims, only with the aim of purifying them, and giving it to the poor, And this poll tax was imposed on the People of the Book to humiliate them, they should not, in their countries, no tribute on their own goods, because they concluded a pact of submission, that if they make commercial transactions in the countries of the Moslems, which is besides their end, one perceives the tenth of their transactions. Moreover, the poll tax was imposed on them, and they accepted it, so that they would remain in their country and defend it against the enemy. If one of them leaves his country for another where he will trade, he owes a tenth of his transactions. It is for those who are from Egypt and who leave for Syria, those of Syria for Iraq, those of Iraq for Medina, or for Yemen or other countries (Muslims), all have to pay the tenth. It is tradition that the People of the Book have no zakat, as well as the Magi, in their goods, their herds, their fruits and their plantations. They can even keep their religions, without being obliged to deny them. But, as long as they have to do business in Muslim countries, they must pay the tenth of their transactions, because this does not form a clause of the pact which they concluded, nor a favor which was granted to them. This is what I have seen, applied by the Ulemas of Medina”. Chapter XXV The tithe collected from those who enjoy the protection of Muslims. 
(621) 47 - Salem Ibn Abdallah reported from his father that Omar Ibn Al-Khatab, took from the Nabataeans, half of a tenth of their wheat and their oil, wanting to increase by this, these products in Medina. As for floury grains, he took the tenth”. 
(622) 48 - Al Saib Ibn Yazid said: "I was very young, and worked with Abdallah Ibn Utba Ibn Mass'ud in the market of Medina, in the time of Omar Ibn Al-Khattab, and one perceived the tenth of the merchandise of the Nabataeans". 
(623) 49 - Malek asked Ibn Chehab: "By what right Omar Ibn Al-Khattab took from the Nabataeans, the tenth"? He replied: "It had taken place during the pre-Islamic period, and Omar, obliged them to continue to pay it". Chapter XXI Of buying alms and giving back. 
(624) 50 - Zaid Ibn Aslam reported that his father heard Umar Ibn Al-Khattab say, “I gave alms of a purebred horse to a man, to fight in the way of Allah. The man, with whom the horse was, had it badly maintained; so I wanted to buy it myself at a good price. I asked, on this subject the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (On him the grace and the peace of Allah) who answered me: “Do not don't buy it, even at the cost of a dirham, because the one who goes back on his alms is to be compared to the dog who goes back on his vomit". 
(625) 51 - Abdallah Ibn Umar reported that Omar Ibn Al-Khattab made a horse an alms to be ridden in the fight in the way of Allah. Wanting to buy it, he asked the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) this subject, which replied, "Don't buy it, and don't go back on your alms". Malek was asked at subject of a man who gave alms, who soon afterwards found himself with another than the one to whom it was given, and what the latter wished to sell; could he afford it? He answered: “I prefer that it be abandoned”. Chapter XXVII Those for whom zakat of fitr is payable. 
(626) 52 Nafe' reported that Abdallah Ibn Omar paid the fitr zakat for his servants - who worked in Khaibar and Wadi Al Qura». (...) 'Malek said: "The best I have heard about the zakat of fitr, paid by man, is that it is paid for those whose he has the responsibility, and for whom, he must spend. And the man pays the zakat of the fitr for his contractual freedman, his posthumous freedman, his slaves present and absent, Provided that they are Muslims, or even that they serve for trade or other. As for those who are not Muslims, zakat is not payable on them”. Malek continued: “As to the runaway slave, whether his boss knows his place or not, and his absence has been for a short time, in the hope of his return and his life, I conceive that he pays zakat fitr about him. In case there is no more to hope for his return, and his absence is long, this zakat is not to be paid". And Malek who adds: “the zakat of the fitr is an obligation on the Bedouins and the townspeople; because the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) has prescribed it on everyone, whether it is a free man or a slave, a male or a female, as Muslims” . Chapter XXVIII On the value of the zakat of the fitr. 
(627) 54 - Nafe' reported that Abdallah Ibn Omar said that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) prescribed the zakat of fitr to a "sa'" of dates, or "sa'" of barley for every Muslim, male or female, free or slave. 
(628) 55 - Abou Sa'id Al-Khoudri said: "we gave for zakat at the end of the fast (of the fitr) a "sa'" of wheat, or barley, or dates, or yogurt, or raisins, according to the "sa'" of the Prophet (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah). 
(629) 56 - Nafe' reported that Abdallah Ibn Omar gave for zakat of fitr only dates, except once when it was barley”. Malek said: “All atonements, zakat of fitr, zakat of tithes, in short everything, must be commensurate with the little 'mudd' of the Prophet (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) with the exception of divorce dihar (it is the fact of saying to his wife "Be for me like the back of my mother”), in this case the expiation will be according to the world of Hisham, called the great “moudd”. Chapter XXIX Fixed time for payment of zakat of fitr 
(630) 57 Nafe' reported that Abdallah Ibn Omar sent the zakat of fitr, to whomever it should be collected, two or three days before the party took place". 
(631) 58 - Malek said: "The well versed found it appropriate that the zakat of fitr be given on the day of the feast, before going to prayer". And Malek said: "And it is a blessing, if the zakat of fitr is given even at dawn on the day of the feast of fitr, and after." Chapter XXX Of those who are exempt from the zakat of fitr 
(632) 59 Yahia reported that Malek said, “Man does not owe fitr zakat for the slaves of his slaves, nor for his worker, nor for the slave of the woman, except those who are in her service and who are necessary to her. He also does not owe the zakat of the fitr for his non-Muslim slave, if he does not embrace Islam, and uses him for trade or in other fields". MOUATTAA In the name of Allah the Merciful the Merciful Book 18 About fasting First chapter From the vision of the crescent to begin the fast, and to end it. 
(633) 1 - Abdallah Ibn Omar reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) referring to the month of Ramadan, said: "Do not fast until you have seen the crescent, and do not break the fast until you have seen it, and if it is not visible to you, make an estimate". 
(634) 2 - Abdallah Ibn Umar reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said: “The month is twenty and nine days; do not fast before seeing the crescent, and do not break the fast before this visibility takes place; and if it is not, make a calculation. 
(635) 3 - Abdallah Ibn Abbas reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) when mentioning Ramadan, said: “Do not fast until you see the crescent moon, and do not break your fast until you see it; if it is not visible, complete the month to thirty days”. 
(636) 4 - We reported to Malek, that the new moon, at the time of Osman, was seen in the afternoon. Osman continued his fast and only broke it in the evening, at sunset". Yahia reported that he has heard Malek say about the man who sees the new moon of Ramadan by himself: "He must fast, and not break his fast, knowing that this day is the beginning of Ramadan". Malek also said: "He who alone sees the moon of Shawwal should not break the fast, for people will accuse him of a lack of confidence whoever breaks his fast, saying: 'We have seen the new moon' . He who therefore sees the moon of Shawwal, during the day, must not interrupt his fast, but will continue it until the end of the day; and this moon is none other than the sign of the night that will follow”. Yahia reported again that he heard Malek say, "If people are fasting on the day of fitr, believing it to be a day of Ramadan, then they are warned that the moon of Ramadan, was visible, a day before they have started the fast and that day of their fast will be the thirty-first of the month, they must break their fast on that same day, just at the time when they have been warned, however, without they do the prayer of the party, especially if the warning took place after the sun had left the meridian”. Chapter II Of the one who has decided to fast before dawn. 
(637) 5 - Nafe' reported that Abdallah Ibn Omar said: "Fasting is only valid for those who have decided before dawn. (....) 6 - Malek reported from Ibn Chehab that Aicha and Hafsa the wives of the Prophet (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) narrated the same hadith”. Chapter III Haste to break the fast. 
(638) 7 - Sahl Ibn Sa'd Al-Sa'idi reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him be Allah's grace and peace) said: "People will be always in good, as long as they hasten the breaking of the fast (just after sunset)”. 
(639) 8 Sa'id Ibn Al-Musaiab narrated the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said: "People will be always in the good, as long as they hurry to break the fast”. 
(640) 9 - Houmaid Ibn Abdel-rahman reported that Omar Ibn Al-Khattab and Osman Ibn Affan, made the sunset prayer, while observing the darkness of the night, before breaking the fast, and that during the month of Ramadan”. Chapter IV Of the fasting of those who, on the morning of the month of Ramadan, become ritually impure 
(641) 10 - Abu Younous, Aisha's freedman, reported that she said: “I heard a man, who, at the door of the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said to him: “O Messenger of Allah! it happens to me, that I am ritually impure, in the morning, whereas, I decided to fast this day. He replied, “It happens to me too; but I purify myself and I fast”. The man objected: “O Messenger of Allah! You do not We are not like us, because Allah has forgiven you your previous and later faults”. Angered, the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Be upon him the mercy and peace of Allah) replied: “By Allah! I wish to be the man who of all fears Allah the most, and knows best the cause of my fear”. 
(642) 11 Abu Bakr Ibn Abdel-Rahman Ibn Al-Hareth Ibn Hisham reported that Aicha and Oum Salama, the wives of the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said: "It happened that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) in Ramadan, was the morning, in a state of ritual impurity, following carnal intercourse, and he fasted during the day". 
(643) 12 - Abu Bakr Ibn Abdel-Rahman Ibn al-Hareth Ibn Hisham reported: “We were, my father and I with Marwan Ibn Al-Hakam, when he was governor in Medina. He was told that Abu Huraira had said: "He who in the morning finds himself ritually impure, he must not fast." Marwan exclaimed, "I conjure O Abdel-Rahman, to go to the two mothers of the believers Aicha and Oum Salama, and ask them about this”. We went, Abdel-Rahman and I, to Aicha's; once they entered her house, Abdel-Rahman greeted her and said: "We were at the house of Marwan Ibn Al-Hakam to whom it was reported that Abu Houraira had said: "He, who is ritually impure, in the morning, will not fast by day”. Aisha replied: “O Abdel-Rahman, it's not like Abou Houraira said; unless you want to act, otherwise than the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) did”.r Abdel-Rahman answered: “no”; Aisha resumed: “I testify that it happened to the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Be upon him the grace and peace of Allah) to be ritually unclean in the morning, following carnal intercourse, and yet he fasted during the day (after making the lotion)”. We left Aicha, and we found ourselves at Oum Salama's, whom Abdel Rahman questioned about the same subject, and from whom he received the same answer as that of Aicha. Returning to Marwan Ibn Al-Hakam Abdel-Rahman gave him a sincere report of what he heard from Aicha and Oum Salama. Marwan said, “O Abu Muhammad, I conjure you to mount my mount which is at the door, and to go to Abou Houraira who is now, in his land at Al-aqiq, so that you tell him what you have heard”. Abdel-Rahman straddled the mount, and I accompanied him until we arrived at Abou-Houraira's. Abdel Rahman, conversed with him for an hour and informed him of what he had heard; Abou-Houraira answered him: “I knew nothing of all that, because for my part, it was a man who had reported it to me”. 
(644) 13 - Abu Bakr Ibn Abdel-Rahman reported that Aisha and Oum Salama, the wives of the Prophet (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) had said: "It happened that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the mercy and peace of Allah) was ritually impure the morning, following carnal intercourse, and he fasted during the day (after the lotion)”. Chapter V Of the kiss tolerated by his wife for him who is fasting.
