(645) 14 - Ata Ibn Yassar reported that a man kissed his wife while he was fasting in Ramadan. Finding himself deeply grieved, he asked his wife to find out about it. She went to Oum Salama, the wife of the Prophet (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) to whom she told of her condition. Oum Salama replied: "It happened that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the mercy and peace of Allah) kissed his wives, so that he was fasting”. Returning home, the wife reported to her husband, which she heard, which was to excite her grief, and he said: “we are not like the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Be upon him the mercy and peace of Allah) to whom Allah made lawful he wanted". His wife returned, again to Oum Salama, where the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) was. He asked Oum Salama: "What's the matter with that woman"? She informed him of her questioning. The Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Be upon him the mercy and peace of Allah) replied: "Did you not said, that I do the same". "I told him that," said Oum Salama; but once back at her husband, telling him my answer, it redoubles his sorrow, and he says: we are not like the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him be Allah's favor and peace), to whom Allah returned lawful what he willed". Hearing of this, the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam), in anger, exclaimed: “By Allah! I'm afraid Allah more than anyone else, and I know his prescriptions well. 
(646) 15 - Ourwa reported that Aisha the mother of believers that Allah the Agreed said: "It happened that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) kissed some of his wives, while fasting", then she began to laugh. 
(647) 16 - Atika, the daughter of Zaid Ibn Amr Ibn Noufail, the wife of Omar Ibn Al-Khattab, reported, that she kissed the head of Omar Ibn Al-Khattab, while he was fasting, and he did not forbid him. 
(648) 17 - Aisha Bint Talha reported that she was with Aisha the wife of the Prophet (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) when her husband Abdallah Ibn Abdel-Rahman Ibn Abi Bakr entered her home, and he was fasting. Aisha, the wife of the Prophet (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Be upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said to her: "What is prevents you from approaching your wife to kiss and cuddle her"? He replied, “kiss her, while I am fasting”? She replied, “yes”. 
(649) 18 - Zaid Ibn Aslam reported that Abu Huraira and Sa'id Ibn Abi Waqas tolerated the fasting one to kiss his Chapter VI Of the deprivation of kissing when fasting 
(650) 19 - It was reported to Malek, that Aisha, the wife of the Prophet (salallahou alayhi wa salam), speaking of how the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Be upon him the grace and peace of Allah) kissed (his wives) when he was fasting said: "Who then can control himself better than the Messenger of Allah"? Ourwa Ibn Al-Zoubair said: “I see no good for the kiss of the fasting one”. 
(651) 20 Ata Ibn Yassar reported that Abdullah Ibn Abbas was asked about the fasting person who kisses his wife? He tolerated it to the aged, and repugnant to young people”. 
(652) 21 - Nafe' reported that Abdallah Ibn Omar forbade the fasting one to kiss and have any relation. Chapter VII Fasting while traveling. 
(653) 22 - Abdallah Ibn Abbas narrated that, the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the mercy and peace of Allah) left for Mecca, the year of the conquest, in the month of Ramadan. He remained on an empty stomach, until he arrived at "Al-Kadid", where he broke it, and the people did the same. They don't were only following the most recent tradition of the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam).r 
(654) 23 - Abu Bakr Ibn Abdel-Rahman reported from some of the companions of the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Be upon him the grace and peace of Allah) that he had ordered the men, during his journey, the year of the conquest, to break their fast. And he said to them, “Be strong so that you can face your enemy”, as for him, he remained fasting”. Abu Bakr added: "Whoever told me this hadith, said: 'I saw the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the favor and peace of Allah) in "Al-Araj"", pouring water on his head from thirst and heat. Then we asked the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah): “O Messenger of Allah there is a good group of people who have fasted when you have fasted”! Arrive at “Al-Kadid”, the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) asked to bring him a glass of water, he drank it and the people suspended their fast”. 
(655) 24 - Anas Ibn Malek reported: “We were on an expedition with the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) in the month of Ramadan. Those who were fasting did not reproach those who were not and vice versa”. 
(656) 25 - Ourwa reported that Hamza Ibn Amr Al-Aslami asked the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Be upon him the grace and peace of Allah): “O Messenger of Allah! I am a fasting man; however, must I fast while traveling? He replied: “If you want, fast, otherwise you can not do it”. 
(657) 26 - Nafe' reported that Abdallah Ibn Omar, did not fast during a journey. 
(658) 27 - Hisham Ibn Ourwa reported that he was traveling with his father in the month of Ramadan; Ourwa was fasting and the others were not fasting, and yet he did not order them to fast. Chapter VIII What a man, returning from a trip or planning to start one, must do in the month of Ramadan. 
(659) 28 - It was reported to Malek, that if Omar Ibn Al-Khattab was on a trip during the month of Ramadan and returned to Medina just at the beginning of the day, he was fasting on that day. Malek said, “He who, being on a trip, and knowing that he will return to his family on the first of the month of Ramadan, and that dawn surprised him before he returned, he must return while fasting” Malek also said: "Whoever intends to travel during the month of Ramadan, and dawn has come, while he is still at home, he must fast this day". Malek said, "He who returns from a trip while he is not fasting, and his wife is likewise, following the cessation of his menses in the month of Ramadan, he can, if he wishes, have with her, carnal relations”. Chapter IX Of the expiation of the one who does not fast in the month of Ramadan 
(660) 29 - Abu Huraira reported that a man broke his fast in Ramadan, the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) ordered him to expiate his deed, by freeing a slave, or by fasting which must cover two successive months (with the exception of the month of Ramadan), or by the food offered to sixty poor people". The man replied, "I can't do either." At that moment, the Envoy was brought of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) a basket containing dates; he said to the man: “Take this, in order to to give alms» He replied: «No one needs it. more than me". The Messenger of Allah (upon him the grace and peace of Allah) laughed, so much so that his canines appeared, and said to the man: "Eat some." 
(661) 30 • Sa'id Ibn AI Musaiab reported that a Bedouin came to the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) by beating his chest, pulling her hair and saying, "I'm lost." The Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Be upon him the grace and peace of Allah) asked him: "what is the matter with you"? "I just had carnal intercourse with my wife while fasting at month of Ramadan" answered the man. The Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Be upon him the mercy and peace of Allah) said to him: "Are you able to free a slave." No," replied the man. “Can you sacrifice a camel”? - "No" answered the man. "Sit down, then"; we brought, to the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Be upon him the grace and peace of Allah) at this time a basket of dates; he gave it to the man saying to him, "Take this and make one alms". The Bedouin says: “No one needs it more than me”. The Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Be upon him the favor and peace of Allah) said: "Eat it, but to fast one day as expiation for what you have committed". -Ata asked Sa'id Ibn Al Moussaiab: "what was the weight of the dates contained in this basket"? He replied: "A matter of fifteen to twenty sa's." Malek said, "I have heard versed men say: "He who, for having had carnal intercourse with his wife, or for any other cause, has broken a day of fasting in the month of Ramadan, will not have to make expiation, as moreover, it was mentioned by the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) about the one who has already had reports during the day; but he will have to compensate on that day, in other months of the year”. That's the best I've heard said about it. Chapter X He who in a fasting state practices bloodletting. 
(662) 31 - Nafe'a reported that Abdallah Ibn Omar allowed himself to be bled while he was fasting. Soon after, he stopped doing it; and if he did the fast, there was no more bleeding until after the breaking of the fast (in the evening)”. 
(663) 32 - Ibn Shehab a reported that Sa'd Ibn Abi Waqas and Abdallah Ibn Omar allowed themselves to be bled while they were in a state of fasting. 
(664) 33 - Hisham Ibn Ourwa reported that his father allowed himself to be bled while fasting, then did not suspend his fast”. And he said, "And I only saw him do that when he was fasting." Malek said: “We disapproves of bloodletting the faster, for fear that he will become weak; and apart from that cause, it is not to be refused. Corn if a man wants to do it without it weakening him, there is no harm in it, and I do not find that he should fast on any other day, except the month of Ramadan, because this bloodletting is considered cause valid for breaking the fast, if it weakens it. The one, so who wants to do a bloodletting while fasting, and intends to be so until the evening, there is nothing wrong with that, and he will not have to compensate by another day". Chapter XI Fasting on the day of Achoura. 
(665) 34 - Urwa reported that Aisha, the wife of the Prophet (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him be Allah's grace and peace) said: "On the day of Ashura, was a day of fasting for the Quraishites, in the period pre-Islamic, and it was the same for the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah). And when the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the mercy and peace of Allah) was in Medina and the day of Achoura, he fasted it, and commanded it to be fasted. But when the fast of Ramadan was prescribed, it was considered the only fast that should be followed, and the fast of the day of Achoura was suspended, leaving people the freedom to fast it”. 
(666) 35 - Houmaid Ibn Abdel-Rahman Ibn Awf reported that he heard Mu'awia Ibn Abi Sufian, the year he made the pilgrimage, say, on the day of Ashura, while being in the pulpit: “O Médinois! where are your versed men? I heard the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (On him the grace and peace of Allah) say, about this day: "It is the day of Ashura, and Allah has not prescribed it for you, a day of fasting. For me, I fast it, for you others, you can fast it or not”. 
(667) 36 - It was reported to Malek, that Umar Ibn Al-Khattab sent word to Al-Hareth Ibn Hisham: “Tomorrow is the day of Ashura, fast it and order your family to do the same”. Chapter XII From the fast of the two days the fitr and al-adha, and from the omnitemporal fast. 
(668) 37 - Abu Huraira reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him be the mercy and peace of Allah) forbade fasting both days of fitr (suspension of the fast) and al-adha (the day of sacrifice)”. 
(669) 38 - Malek reported that he has heard, versed men say, "There is no harm in fasting continually, but except fasting for two days which it has moreover been forbidden to fast namely the day of fitr, and that of al-adha; this is what has come down to us”. Malek added: this is my favorite thing”. Chapter XIII From the prohibition of continuous fasting (for two ensuing days) 
(670) 39 - Abdallah Ibn Omar reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam), has forbidden to follow the fast for two continuous days”. We him said: "O Messenger of Allah, but you are fasting for two continuous days"? He replied, "I am not like you, for Allah feeds and waters me." 
(671) 40 - Abu Huraira reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him be Allah's grace and peace) said: "Beware of fasting for two days in a row, take care not to fast for two days in a row”! He was told: “but you, you are fasting, O Messenger of Allah”? He replied, “I am not like you; I sleep well fed and watered (by my Allah)”. Chapter XIV From the fast of the one who, by mistake commits a murder or the one who compares his wife "to the back of his own mother". 
(672) 41 - Malek said, "The best words I have heard about one who will fast for two months in a row, as an atonement, for not having, by mistake killed another man or by reason of having compared his wife to the back of his own mother in case he is suffering from a disease which obliges him to suspend his fast, to have to postpone the fast until he is cured, and to resume the fast taking into account the days he has already fasted". It is the same for the woman who owes this fast, if by mistake she kills a person, she a to suspend her fast during the period of her menses, then once purified, that she resume the fast without any delay taking into account the days she has already fasted”. And there is no cause, for the one who must fast for two consecutive months, - as it was mentioned in the Book of Allah - to break his fast if it is not for a cause of illness, or for the question of menses; therefore , he must not travel so that he does not break his fast”. And Malek said, 'that's the best I've heard about it'. Chapter XV What the patient should do regarding his fast. 
(673) 42 - Malek said: "What I have heard men versed in religion say about one who is stricken with an illness, in such a way that his fast seems to him so painful and tiring, even to give up his unbearable state, that he can suspend his fast. It is the same for the sick person who cannot say his prayers on his feet because of his illness; and Allah knows better than anyone his condition, and the seriousness of his illness, therefore, he can pray while sitting, because the religion of Allah is to facilitate the practice”. On the other hand. Allah has The traveler is tolerated to miss the fast, although he is much more capable of doing so than the patient. Allah, the Most High said in his Book: “Whoever among you is sick, or who travels, shall then fast an equal number of days”. Koran II, 184. Allah, therefore, has tolerated for the traveler, the breaking of the fast, although he is much more capable than the sick person of fasting”. This is what I heard from God, and this is what is traditionally followed”. Chapter XVI Of the vow to fast and fasting on behalf of the dead. 
(674) 43 - Sa'id Ibn Musaiab was asked about a man, who took a vow to fast for a month. Can he fast on other days (as a supererogation)? He replied, "Let the vow be performed first, and then fast other fasts." Malek said: “It was the same opinion of Suleiman Ibn Yassar”. Malek said, “He who dies before fulfilling a vow to free a slave, or perform a supererogatory fast, or pay the zakat of a camel, and that he stipulates in his will, his successor must execute it in the inheritance, and which is equivalent to a third of what the man has bequeathed; and this is to be considered as a priority, of all other stipulations unless there is such a thing. Because of all that he has done as a vow or otherwise, nothing is obligatory, and is not even to be considered as a supererogatory act which can only be taken from a third of what he bequeathed, without touching the capital. If it has him been allowed, the dead would have delayed this until the moment when death presents itself to him and the property will go to his successors, he will have designated all these things that no one has the right to claim them except after a dispute brought to justice and in this way, this dead could designate all this until death, presenting itself to him to dispose of all his capital, which he will not have the right to do”. 
(675) 44 - It was reported to Malek whom Abdallah Ibn Omar was often asked "Is it permissible for a man to fast for another, or to pray in place of another". He replied: “No one can fast or pray in place of another”. Chapter XVII Of fasting on days other than Ramadan and their atonement. 
(676) 45 - Khaled Ibn Aslam reported that Omar Ibn Al-Khattab, suspended his fast on a day of Ramadan, as the sky was cloudy, and believing that the sun had disappeared. A man came and said to him: “O prince of believers! The sun has appeared”; Omar answered: "what I have just done is not serious, and I only made the application of my own lights". And Malek, wanting to explain the above said: “Omar, designate by "it does not matter", that he intends to compensate for the day on which the fast was broken, by another, because it is only a question of a single day which is so easy to fast”. And Allah is most knowledgeable about this.” 
(677) 46 - Nafe’a reported that Abdallah Ibn Omar said: "He who must fast for several days in compensation for other days of fasting broken in Ramadan, for causes of illness or travel, he must fast uninterruptedly". 
(678) 47 - Ibn Chehab a reported that Abdallah Ibn Abbas and Abu Huraira had argued over compensation for the fast, for breaking it for a few days in Ramadan. One said to himself, "He must fast them consecutively, the other: he can fast them separately”. The reporter added: “I don't know which of them said: 'He can fast them separately'. 
(679) 48 - Nafe’a reported that Abdallah Ibn Umar said, “Whoever vomits voluntarily, while fasting, must fast another day. As for the one who cannot hold back his vomit, he can dispense”. 
(680) 49 - Yahia Ibn Sa'id heard Sa'id Ibn Al-Mussaiab ask about compensation for fasting. He replied: “If a man has to fast a few days, to compensate for others in the month of Ramadan, I prefer that he fast them, without interruption”. Yahia reports that he has heard Malek say: “He who fasts several days in order to compensate for other days of the month of fasting, by separating them, must not do them again without interruption; what he has done is sufficient, although I prefer that the compensated fast be done without interruption”. Malek said, "He who inadvertently or by forgetfulness, in Ramadan or even, during a compensated fast, will go to eat or drink, he must fast on other days by acquittal”. 
(681) 50 - Malek a reported that Houmaid Ibn Qais Al-Makki related to him: "I was with Mujahed, in a processional tour around the Ka'ba, when a man came to ask him about the fasting days of atonement, if they are to be done without interruption or separated? Houmaid replied: "Certainly he can separate them by fasting." But Mujahed added: “He must, fast them without interruption, because according to the recitation of Ubai Ibn Ka'b, they must be three days in a row”. Malek added: “It is better that they be fasted without interruption, as revealed by Allah in the Qur'an". Malek was asked at about a woman who while fasting, in Ramadan, had a flow of blood in the morning, without it being her menses, then waits for the evening to see if she will be in such a state, but she does not see none of that. Then the next morning, she will have a flow, less than the first, which stops even before a few days of her menses, what should this woman do and for her fasting and her prayer”? He replied, “This flow is due to menstruation, so she must break her fast, and will have to compensate for these days later after the month of fasting. Once her menses stop let her make her lotion and fast”. Malek was asked about a man who just on the last day of Ramadan converted to Islam. Should he fast only the day of his conversion to Islam, or every day of this month”? He answered: “He does not have to fast the days that have passed, by way of compensation; but he must fast the days that follow them, although I prefer that he fast on the day he converted to Islam”. Chapter XVIII Of the acquittal of voluntary fasting. 
(682) 51 - Ibn Chehab reported that Aisha and Hafsa, the wives of the Prophet (salallahou alayhi wa salam) I (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) was fasting voluntarily, when, in the morning, they were presented with food, they broke their fast. The Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Be upon him the grace and peace of Allah) entering their home, Aisha said: “Hafsa, who looked like his father (Umar) took the initiative and asked the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah): “O, Messenger of Allah, I was performing a voluntary fast, with Aicha, when, having received a food, we broke our fast”? He replied, "Fast by substitution another day." Yahia reported that he has heard Malek say: "Anyone who, doing a voluntary fast, has, by mistake or forgetfulness, eaten or drunk, may continue his fast for the rest of the day without being obliged to fast another day. Thereby, one who fasts voluntarily and who breaks his fast for any reason, will not have to fast another day; for the breaking of the fast is due to a valid cause without it being by his will. On the other hand, the one who makes a voluntary prayer and who accidentally, became impure, in such a way that he must redo his ablutions to continue his prayer, can dispense with this prayer". Malek added: "It is not suitable for a man who, practicing religious works (al-amal as-saliha) of those which are obligatory such as prayer, pilgrimage, fasting and any other worship practice, when he performs them as supererogatory works, not performing them as obligations, when he does them as supererogatory as in the case where, he makes the takbir without accomplishing the two raka'ts, likewise the voluntary fast which he breaks before the evening, he makes the talbiat of the pilgrimage and returns home before he completes it, finally he makes the processional rounds (Tawaf) before completing the seven rounds. It is improper for him to omit a rite before he performs it to perfection, unless something happens to him that constrains him such as illness and the like. valid excuse. For Allah the Exalted said in his Book: "Eat and drink until one can distinguish at dawn a thread white with a black wire. Then fast until nightfall. Koran II, 187. Man must fast. Allah also said: "Do for Allah the small and the great pilgrimage" (Koran 11,196). If a man performs the talbiat of a voluntary Hajj when he has performed the obligatory pilgrimage, he is not allowed to leave his irham before he completes his pilgrimage. And any man beginning a supererogatory work must complete it, as if it were a prescribed obligation. That's the best interpretation I've heard about it." Chapter XIX Of the redemption of those who do not fast in Ramadan, for a valid cause 
(683) 52 - Malek reported that Anas Ibn Malek, paid the fidya (he redeemed himself) when he reached old age, and he could no longer fast. Malek added: "I don't I don't think it's obligatory and I prefer that he fast if he is able to do so. For he who redeems himself must give food, for each day to the poor, a mudd of food according to the mudd of the Prophet (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah). 
(684) 53 - We asked Abdallah Ibn Omar about the pregnant woman who fears for her fetus, if fasting causes her weakness? He answered: “Let her stop fasting and that she gives food to the poor, for each day, a mudd of wheat which is equivalent to the mudd of the Prophet (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (On him the grace and peace of Allah). Malek said: “Men paid provide that she must fast other days by way of compensation, in accordance with the words of Allah to Him the power and the glory: "Whoever of you is sick or travels, then shall fast an equal number of days." Coran II, 184. They consider that her pregnancy and her fear of her child are only a disease”. 
(685) 54 - Abdel Rahman Ibn al-Kassem reported that his father said: “He who had to fast for a few days and he has not done so, until the advent of the following Ramadan, he must give, for each day, to eat to the poor, a moudd of wheat, while fasting what he must of days". (...) 55 - It was reported to Malek that Sa'id Ibn Joubair was of the same opinion». Chapter XX Of the acquittal of the fast. 
(686) 56 - Abu Salama Ibn Abdel-Rahman reported that he heard Aicha, the wife of the Prophet (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) say: "I happened to have to days of fasting in the month of Ramadan, and I could only fast them in the month of Sha'ban". Chapter XXI From the fast of the day that one doubts. 
(687) 57 - Malek a of course, men versed in religion, prohibit fasting on the day of which one doubts in the month of Cha'ban, if one intends to consider it the first day of Ramadan. And, they considered that the one who will have fasted it without the vision of the new moon (of Ramadan) following which, one comes to assure that it is, in fact, the first day of Ramadan, he must fast it on another day, and they find no harm in fasting this day as supererogatory”. And Malek adds: “Such is what is our traditions, and which was moreover followed in Medina”. Chapter XXII Fasting and its merit. 
(688) 58 - Abu Salama Ibn Abdel Rahman reported that Aisha, the wife of the Prophet (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said: “The Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) used to fast so much that one said that he did not break the fast, and ate what one said he was not fasting. And I have never seen the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him be the grace fast and the peace of Allah) fasting completely for a month except Ramadan. His voluntary fast was often done in the month of Sha'ban. (689) 59- Abu Huraira reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him be the mercy and peace of Allah) said: “Fasting is protection. If any of you is fasting, let him not speak indecently, let him not commit unseemly acts; if anyone insults or attacks him, let him say: “I am fasting, I am fasting”. 
(690) 60 - Abu Hurairah reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him be Allah's grace and peace) said: "By him who holds my soul in his hand, the smell of the mouth of the fasting person is more fragrant with Allah than the smell of musk. He discarded his desire, his food and his drink for Me. Fasting belongs to Me and it is Me who gives the reward. Any good deed will be multiplied tenfold and can go up to seven hundred multiples; as for fasting, it belongs to Me and it is I who will determine the reward”. 
(691) 61 - Abu Houraira said: "When it is the month of Ramadan, the gates of Paradise open, the gates of Hell close, and the demons are chained". 
(692) 62 - Malek a of course, men versed in religion, do not prohibit the use of siwak (rubbing teeth made from a branch of an "arrak" wood) in the month of Ramadan, during the day, neither at its beginning nor at its end. And, none of them have it repulsed. For the question, the six-day fast, (namely at Shawwal) following the month of Ramadan, Malek said, “That he saw no ulema and no religiously educated man fasting them; and he was not even informed of this question by a predecessor. Even men shy away from it lest the ignorant and the common people attribute to the month of Ramadan, which is unsuitable and strange to it, which will be a innovation, especially if they argue by permission of men versed in religion”. Yahia reported that he has heard Malek say, "I have never heard, none of the men versed in religion, neither of those who are learned, nor of those who are follows, prohibit the fast of the day on Friday; and his fasting is beneficial; I even saw some of them fasting for it while looking for it». MOUATTAA In the name of Allah the Merciful the Merciful Book 19 The spiritual retreat First chapter The spiritual retreat. 
(693) 1 Aisha, the wife of the Prophet (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said: "When the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) was retreating spiritual, he held out his head to me to clean and comb it. And he only came home for the satisfaction of a natural need. 
(694) 2 - Amrah Bint Abdel-Rahman reported: "when Aicha was doing the retreat, she asked for news of the sick while walking, without stopping." Malek said, "He who makes a spiritual retreat, must not take care of any personal business, nor go out to seek him, nor help anyone in any work, but he can only leave the mosque for the satisfaction of a natural need. And if he were allowed to go out, from the place of retreat, he could visit a sick person, or follow a funeral procession and pray over a dead person». And Malek added: “he who does itikaf is only said in itikaf, only if he abstains from avoiding what a man who does not make this retreat should occupy, namely visiting a sick person, following a funeral procession by saying the funeral prayer, and satisfying a natural need by entering his home”. 
(695) 3 - Malek a asked Ibn Chehab about the man who is in retreat, is it permissible for him to enter a covered place for the satisfaction of a need? He replied, "Yes, there is nothing wrong with that." Malek said, “What is indisputable is that there is no harm in performing itikaf in any mosque where Friday services are held. The aversion is, that the moutakif (in spiritual retreat) leaves the mosque where he was doing his retreat, for another where the Friday prayer is performed, or that he neglected. If it is a mosque where the common Friday prayer is not performed, and the one who makes his retreat there is not obliged to leave it for another mosque where the Friday prayer is performed, I find no harm in this, for Allah the Blessed and the Most High has said (meaning): "When you are in retreat in the mosque" Koran II, 187. And Allah, in this verse mentioned all the mosques, without any particularity”. And Malek said, “so, it is concluded that it was permissible for the man to make his retreat in the mosque where the Friday service was not held, and could not leave this mosque to go to the one where Friday prayers were held?. Malek also said: "the retiree will spend the night only in the mosque where he had made his retirement unless it is in one of the squares of this mosque. And I never heard that the pensioner will put up a tent where he will spend his night; because he had to stay in the mosque or in one of its courts”. And which shows that the pensioner was to spend the night only in the mosque, these are the words of Aicha: "When the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) was in a retreat spiritual, he only returned home to satisfy a natural need. On the other hand, one should not make the retreat either on the roof of a mosque, or in its turret”. Malek added: “The retiree enters the place he has chosen to be the place of his spiritual retreat and this before sunset, of the first night when he has decided to begin his retreat so that he is ready to receive his first night, while being in retreat, without it being preoccupied with some other matter such as trade or the like. There is no harm in him entrusting others with his affairs concerning his own property or that of his family, even to allow them to sell what he owns, or something else that does not require his intervention. There is no harm in him entrusting a third person with taking care of all this”. Malek adds: "I have no never heard anyone of the men versed in the religion, underline a precise condition to make the spiritual retreat, because, this one is nothing but one of the religious practices just like prayer, fasting, pilgrimage and other similar practice, in short, prescribed either it or supererogatory. Thus, whoever decides to exercise such a practice, must follow the predecessors without involving an innovation that Muslims have not made, nor imposing something on others or on himself. The Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) made this retreat and Muslims knew how it should be practiced”. Malek finally concluded, that the retreat and the stay in the mosque are similar and can be practiced by a city-dweller and a Bedouin, in the same way”. Chapter II of what cannot be neglected as a religious obligation in the spiritual retreat (itikaf). 
(696) 4 - We reported to Malek, that Al-Kassem Ibn Muhammad and Nafe', the freedman of Abdallah Ibn Omar, said: "No spiritual retreat is feasible, without fasting", and this by reference to the words of Allah the Blessed and The Most High (meaning): “Eat and drink until a white thread can be distinguished at dawn from a black thread. Then fast until nightfall. Have no relation with your wives when you are retired in the mosque” Koran II, 187. Allah, in this verse, mentioned retirement with fasting”. Malek said: "It is, moreover, what we have followed, that there is no retreat except with fasting". Chapter III The exit of the retired moutakif to attend the party. 
(697) 5 - Soumai the freedman of Abu Bakr Ibn Abdel-Rahman reported that Abu Bakr Ibn Abdel-Rahman, being in his spiritual retreat, went out to do its natural need under a roof in a closed room, in the residence of Khaled Ibn Al-Walid. He only returned to his family to attend the feast prayer with the Muslims”. 
(698) 6 - Malek a reported, that he saw the men versed in the religion, making their spiritual retreat in the last decade of Ramadan, and returning home, only to attend the prayer of the feast of the fitr with the people”. Malek added: “It I have also been told about the virtuous men who have gone before us; and that's my favorite thing I've heard". Chapter IV Of the payment of the pension. 
(699) 7 - Aisha reported: "Wanting to make his spiritual retreat (itikaf), the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) went to the place of his retreat, and he was surprised by the presence of the tents erected, among others, the tent of Aicha, and that of Hafsa. Seeing them, he went to find out, and they said to him: "This is Aicha's tent, this other of Hafsa, and finally that of Zainab". The Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Be upon him the mercy and peace of Allah) said: "You believe that you do thereby a pious work?”; then he left the place without beginning his retreat, and made it later in a decade of the month of Shawwal”. Malek was asked, about a man who went to the mosque for spiritual retreat in the last decade of the month of Ramadan; he remained there for a day or two, then fell ill, and left the mosque. Should he make the retreat for what remains of the ten days, if he is cured, or is it dispensed with”? Malek replied: “He has to pay the remaining days of the retreat, if he is cured in Ramadan, or even after, this month ended. And I was told, that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) wanted to make a retreat spirituality in the month of Ramadan, then he returned without accomplishing it, so that, once this month had ended, he left to make his ten-day retreat in the month of Shawwal". On the other hand, the one who voluntarily makes a spiritual retreat, and the one who has to fulfill it, are the same concerning what is ritual to follow, or what is not ritual. And I have not been told that the volunteering of the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) concerning the spiritual retreat was only supererogatory”. about the woman, who doing her spiritual retreat, during which, she had her mentrue, Malek said, “She must break her retreat and go home; she will make her purification lotion, and will be at the mosque again as soon as she has purified herself; thus, she will continue, the days that remain to her of her retirement taking into account the days of her menses. It is the same case of a woman, who has to fast for two successive months; having her period, she will purify herself and then continue her fast, considering the days she had already fasted; and it is better that it does not delay them”. 
(700) 8 - Ibn Chehab reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) during his retreat, went home, in case he had a need to satisfy". Malek said: “Who is in spiritual retreat (itikaf) does not have to come out of his retreat, so that he follows the funeral procession of his parents or others”. Chapter V Marriage during spiritual retreat. Malek said, “Nothing does not prevent concluding a marriage during the spiritual retreat, provided that there are no carnal relations; it is the same for the retired woman, who can be asked to marry, without there being any cohabitation. The retiree is prohibited from having relations with his wife, both during the night and during the day. And Malek added: “He A retired man is forbidden to touch his wife, nor even to kiss her. And I did not hear, prohibit a woman and a retired man from concluding a marriage, as long as there are no carnal relations; at this time, it is to be prohibited. All the same, nothing prevents the faster from concluding a marriage during his fast. On the other hand, there is a distinction to be made between the marriage concluded by a man in retirement, and that which is made by a man in Ihram. The latter can eat, drink, visit a sick person, attend funeral processions, but does not wear perfume. On the other hand, women and men on retreat (itikaf) can anoint themselves, perfume themselves, and comb their hair, but rarely attend funeral processions, do not pray over the dead, and do not visit the sick. Thereby the conditions of marriage differ from one to another, and this is moreover what is traditionally followed for the question of marriage for the one who is in the state of Ihram, to the one who is in itikaf, and finally to the faster. Chapter VI The Night of Destiny. 
(701) 9 - Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri reported: "The Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) had made the retreat spiritual in the second decade of the month of Ramadan, for one year; on the twenty-first night, and that is the night when in the morning he leaves his place of retreat, he says to the faithful: “whoever began his retreat with me, let him be there for the last decade of Ramadan; for Allah made me actually see it, and afterwards He made me forget it (speaking of the night of Destiny). And I saw myself, prostrate, in the morning in water and mud. Ask for it, therefore, in the last ten odd nights of the month of fasting”. Abu Sa'id added: "The rain that night was about to fall, and the roof of the mosque, formed of the tails of palm trees, let the water in. I saw, with my own eyes, the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) to leave the mosque, the face all covered with rain and mud. It was the morning of the twenty-first day of Ramadan”. 
(702) 10 - Urwa reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him be Allah's grace and peace) said: “Seek the night of Destiny, in the last decade of Ramadan”. 
(703) 11 - Abdallah Ibn Umar reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said: the night of Destiny, in the last seven days of Ramadan”. 
(704) 12 • Abdallah Ibn Ounais Al-Jouhani asked the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah): “O Messenger of Allah I am a a man who lives a long distance from the mosque. Show me a night when I can go there (so that I can pray all night»). He replied: “Be present on the twenty-third night of Ramadan”. 
(705) 13 - Anas Ibn Malek reported: "The Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) came to see us during the month of Ramadan and said to us: "I was shown this night (implying the night of Destiny) in Ramadan,. As two men quarreled it was removed from me. Ask for it in the ninth, or seventh or fifth night” (after the twentieth of the month). 
(706) 14 - Ibn Omar reported that some companions of the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) saw the night of Destiny, during their sleep, and this during the last seven nights of Ramadan. The Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Be upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said: "I see that your visions refer to the last seven days of Ramadan. So let him who seeks it fixate himself on the last seven nights. 
(707) 15 - Malek reported that he heard from scholars in whom one trusts: "one made show to the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (On him the grace and the peace of Allah) the ages of the men who have it preceded by life, or what Allah wanted to show him. As he found that the ages of the men of his community are so short compared to the works they have to accomplish, just like those who have preceded, enjoying a longevity of age. Allah, granted him the night of Destiny, which is better than a thousand other months. 
(708) 16 - It was reported to Malek that Sa'id Ibn Al Moussaiab said: "He who makes the evening prayer together, on the night of Destiny, has already benefited from the merit of this night". MOUATTAA In the name of Allah the Merciful the Merciful Book 20 The pilgrimage Chapter 1 The act of making lotion in order to put oneself in a state of ihram. 
(709) 1 - Abdel Rahman Ibn Al-Kassem reported from his father that Asma Ibn Oumais gave birth to Muhammad Ibn Abi Bakr in "Al-Baida". This was transmitted by Abu Bakr to the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him grace and peace of Allah) who says: "Order him to make a lotion, after which she can put herself in the state of ihram, and do the talbiat”. 
(710) 2 - Said Ibn Al Moussaiab reported that Asma Bint Oumais gave birth to Muhammad Ibn Abi Bakr in "Zoul Houlaifa". Abu Bakr ordered him to make a lotion, then to put oneself in a state of ihram and to do the talbiat”. 
(711) 3 - Nafe' reported that Abdallah Ibn Omar made a lotion before putting himself in the state of ihram, and for his entry into Mecca and to be in status on the eve of Arafa”. Chapter II Performing great ablutions (ghusl) in the state of ihram. 
(712) 4 - Ibrahim Ibn Abdallah Ibn Hunain reported from his father that Abdallah Ibn Abbas and Al-Miswar Ibn Makhrama quarreled in 'Al-Abwa', about the lotion of one who is in the state of ihram. Abdullah said: "He can wash his head” and Al-Misswar Ibn Makrama retaliates: “He cannot wash his head”. The reporter added: “Abdallah Ibn Abbas sent me to Abu Ayoub Al-Ansari (to put an end to this subject); I found him, doing his lotion beside the two posts, while wrapping himself in a garment. I greeted him and asked me: "Who is this"? I answered him: “Abdallah Ibn Hunain, Abdallah Ibn Abbas sent me to ask you how the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) washed his head, while being in ihram”? Abou Ayoub put his hand on the garment and lowered it, so that his head was visible to me, then he told a man to pour water on him. head, while saying: "Pour the water, and Abou Ayoub rubbed his head with his hands, moving them from behind to front and vice versa, then said: "This is how I saw it done, the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah). 
(713) 5 - Ata Ibn Abi Rabah reported that Omar Ibn Al-Khattab told Ya'la Ibn Mounia, that he poured water on his head, while he was making a lotion Ya'la replied, "Do you want me to be solely responsible for this?" “If you order me, I will do it”. Umar Ibn Al-Khattab replied, "Pour the water, because it will only ruffle my hair." 
(714) 6 - Nafe'a reported that Abdallah Ibn Omar, arriving near Mecca, he remained spending the night at "Zi-Touwa", between the two narrow passages of this mountain, and remained such until morning. Then he did the dawn prayer to then enter Mecca by following the highest passage, and was not in this city for the pilgrimage or for a pious visit, that after having made a lotion to Zi-Touwa, and ordered the Muslims who are with him to do the same". 
(715) 7 - Nafe' reported that Abdallah Ibn Omar washed his head, when he was in a state of ihram, only during a ritual impurity”. Malek said, “I have heard, versed men say that it is doable that a man, being in the state of ihram, washes his head with cleanser after throwing the stones at the pillar of "Al-Aqaba", and before shaving his head. It is that, having thrown these pebbles, he is already permitted to kill lice, to shave his head, to get rid of impurities and to put on clothes”. Chapter III What is forbidden to put on for clothes while being in ihram. 
(716) 8 - Abdallah Ibn Omar reported that a man asked the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him be Allah's Grace and Peace) what clothing should one who is in the state of ihram wear? The Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Be upon him the grace and peace of Allah) replied: "Do not wear shirt, turban, trousers, bournos, or boots. If someone can't find sandals, put on boots, cutting them down to just below the ankles. And above all, do not wear clothes affected by saffron or yellow dye. Malek was asked about the words reported by the Prophet (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Be upon him the grace and peace of Allah) who would have said: "If the man does not don't find an izar, let him put on pants". Malek replied, "I have not heard this hadith, and I do not believe that a man can put on pants, because the Prophet (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) had forbidden them, among so many other clothes without any exception made like: this was done for the boots”. Chapter IV On the prohibition of putting on colored clothes in the state of ihram. 
(717) 9 - Abdallah Ibn Umar reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the mercy and peace of Allah) forbade one who is in the state of ihram, to put on clothes dyed with saffron or yellow dye, and said: "whoever cannot find sandals, put on boots by cutting them down to below the ankles". 
(718) 10 - Nafe' reported that he heard Aslam the freedman of Omar Ibn Al-Khattab tell Abdallah Ibn Omar that Omar Ibn Al-Khattab saw Talha Ibn Oubaidallah put, in state of ihram, a garment colored; he said to her: “why are you wearing such a garment, Talha”? He replied: “O prince of believers! This color is only mud”! Omar resumed: “you, who are a minority, you are only models to be imitated by people; if an ignoramus had seen such a garment, he would have to say: "Talha Ibn Oubaidallah, put, in state of ihram, colorful clothes! so don't put on those colorful clothes." 
(719) 11 • Ourwa reported that Asma the daughter of Abu Bakr, when she was in the state of ihram, put on well-dyed clothes of safflower and not of saffron”. Malek for the question of a garment affected by perfume, after which the smell of this perfume has dissipated, is it to be put in a state of ihram? He replied, "Yes, unless it is dyed with saffron or yellow dye." Chapter V On the prohibition of wearing a belt in the state of ihram. 
(720) 12 - Nafe' reported that Abdallah Ibn Omar refuted that a man puts, in state of ihram a belt”. 
(721) 13 - Yahia Ibn Sa'id reported that he heard Sa'id Ibn Al-Musaiab say that a man in the state of ihram, may, if need be, wear a belt under his clothes, if he reduces his extremities to fringes attached to each other”. Malek adds, "That's the best I've heard about it." Chapter VI From covering one's face while in a state of ihram. 
(722) 14 - Al-Fourafissa Ibn Oumair Al-Hanfi reported that he saw Osman Ibn Affan, (in Al-Arj), veiling his face while in ihram state. 
(723) 15 - Nafe' reported that Abdallah Ibn Omar said: "one who is in the state of ihram should not veil his face above the chin". 
(724) 16 - Nafe' reported that Abdallah Ibn Umar buried his son Waked Ibn Abdallah who died in “Al-Jouhfa”, while being in a state of ihram. He veiled her head and face and said, "If I was not in the state of ihram, I would have scented it." Malek said: “man does not ceases to work while alive; but once he is dead, his work ends”. ^ 
(725) 17 - Nafe' reported that Abdallah Ibn Omar said: "In the state of ihram, the woman does not have to veil herself, nor to wear gloves". 
(726) 18 - Hisham Ibn Ourwa reported that Fatima bint Al-Mounzera said: “Asma bint Abi Bakr Al-Siddiq and we veiled our faces, while being in a state of ihram. Chapter VII Perfume during the pilgrimage. 
(727) 19 - Aisha, the wife of the Prophet (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said: "I perfumed the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) for his sanctification before he is in a state of ihram, and for his desacralization before he makes his processional rounds around the House". 
(728) 20 - Ata Ibn Yassar reported that a Bedouin, putting on a shirt covered with perfume came to the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the mercy and peace of Allah) when he was in Hunan. He said to him, “O Messenger of Allah! I made the talbiat for a pious visitation, how should I accomplish it”? The Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) answered him: "Go and take off your shirt, and get rid of the traces of the perfume, then make the rites of the pious visit as you have to do them for a pilgrimage". 
(729) 21 Islam, Omar's freedman Ibn Al-Khattab reported that Omar smelled perfume while he was in "Al-Shajara"; he says: "Where does this smell come from"? Moua'wia Ibn Abi Soufian answered him: "It is from me that it comes, O prince of believers". Omar replied, “From you? By Allah”. Moua'wia added: "It is Oum Habiba who perfumed me, O prince of believers". 
(730) 22 - Al Sait Ibn Zoubaid reported from various sources of his people, that Omar Ibn Al-Khattab felt, being in "Al-Chajara", the smell of a perfume and at his side, was Kathir Ibn Al-Salt. Omar exclaimed, "Where does this perfume come from?" Kathir replied, “It is of me, O prince of believers; I pomaded my head and I didn't want to shave it”. Omar said to him: "Go near the trunk of a palm tree, rub your head in order to wash". And Kathir Ibn Al-Salt, accomplishes what he has to do”. Malek says, "It's a little ditch in the trunk of a palm tree." 
(731) 23 - Malek a narrated from Yahia Ibn Sa'id, Ahdullah Ibn Bakr and Rabi'a Ibn Abi Abdel-Rahman that Al-Walid Ibn Abdel-Malek asked Salem Ibn Abdallah and Kharija Ibn Zaid Ibn Thabet for the issue of perfume, after having threw the stones of the Jamara, after having shaved his head, and before surging? Salem forbade him, but Kharija ibn Zayd allowed it”. Malek said: “It is not forbidden for a man to take care of a product but devoid of the fragrance before it puts itself in a state of ihram, before surging from "Mina", after throwing the stones of the Jamara". Malek was asked about a dish containing saffron, can it be eaten by a man in a state of ihram? He replied, "Yes, yes, it was cooked in the fire, it can be eaten by a man in the state of ihram, and if it has not been cooked it cannot be eaten by a muhrim”. Chapter VIII Places where you have to do the talbiat. 
(732) 24 - Abdallah Ibn Omar reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said: "the people of Medina enter ihram the talbiat to "Zoul-Houlaifa", the inhabitants of Syria to "Al-Jouhfa", and those of Najd to "Karm". Abdallah Ibn Omar added: “I was told that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said: “the inhabitants of Yemen make the talbiat to “Yalamlam”. 
(733) 25 - Abdallah Ibn Umar said: "The Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) ordered the people of Medina to make the talbiat the entry into ihram in “Zoul-Houlaifa”, the inhabitants of Syria in “Al-Jouhfa”, and those of Najd in “Karn”. 
(734) 26 - Abdallah Ibn Omar said: "What I stated above, I heard it from the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah); and I was further informed that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said: "and the inhabitants of Yemen have to do the talbiat in Yalamlam". 
(735) 27 - Nafe' reported that Abdallah Ibn Omar made the talbiat at "Al-Four". (736) 28- Malek reported from trusted men that Abdallah Ibn Umar performed talbiat at “Iliyaa” al Quds. 
(737) 29 - It was reported to Malek that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) made the talbiat to "Al-Ji'rana" during a pious visitation". Chapter IX From the practice of the talbiat. 
(738) 30 - Abdallah Ibn Umar said: "that the talbiat of the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) was the following: "Great Allah! Here I am answering your call. You don't have a partner. Praise and grace are yours as well as royalty. You don't have a partner. lak. Labayk, Allahumma labayk, the sharika laka labayk. Inna'l-hamda wa'n-nimata laka wa'l-mulk, the sharika Abdallah added to this talbiat: “Here I am answering your call; I submit to you once after another. The good is in your hands, the desire is directed towards you as well as the beneficial works”. Labayk, labayk, labayk wa sadayka wa'l-khayr biyadayka labayk wa'r-raghba'u ilayka wa'l-amalu. 
(739) 31 - Urwa reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) made two raka'ts while praying in the mosque of "Zou-Houlaifa", and once his mount was raised, he began to do the talbiat". 
(740) 32 - Salem Ibn Abdallah reported that he heard his father say: "This "Baida" part of the desert on which, you lie by saying that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) made the talbiat, when in reality he only made it from of the mosque and precisely the mosque of “Zoul-Hulaifa”. 
(741) 33 - Oubaid Ibn Jouraij reported that he said to Abdallah Ibn Omar: "O Abu Abdel-Rahman, I have seen you achieve four, which none of your companions did; he asked him: “What are these four O Ibn Jouraij”? He replied, "I have only seen you touch corners, except Yemenite corners (we mean the corners of the Ka'ba), put on nothing but depilated leather sandals, only embalm yourself with saffron, and I saw, that if you were in Mecca, while people were doing talbiat at the vision of the moon, you, you did it only on the day of the “Tarwaya”. Abdallah Ibn Umar replied: "so, as for the corners, I have not seen the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) touch, that the two Yemenites; as for the sandals (of which you speak), the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him be Allah's Grace and Peace) only put on those made of depilated leather, and even perform ablution while wearing them; and for my part, I like to wear them; for the saffron, the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) used it and in turn, I like to imitate him; and for the talbiat, I did not see the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Be upon him and the peace of Allah) to do it, only when his mount was lifted up". 
(742) 34 - Nafe' reported that Abdallah Ibn Omar said the prayer in the mosque of "Zoul-Houlaifa", then he left so that, once his mount was raised, he put himself in a state of ihram". 
(743) 35 - It was reported to Malek that Abdel Malek Ibn Marwan made the talbiat from the mosque of Zoul-Houlaifa, while his mount was raised, and that Abban Ibn Osman, had advised him to do so". Chapter X From the talbiat made aloud. 
(744) 36 - Khaled Ibn Al-Saib Al-Ansari reported from his father that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Be upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said: "Gabriel came to me seek and instructed me to ordain my companions or those who were with me, to raise their voices when doing the talbiat or when they are in the state of ihram”. 
(745) 37 - Malek a reported that he heard versed men say: “women don't have to raise their voices during the talbiat; they must hear themselves without more”. Malek said, “one who is in the state of ihram does not have to raise his voice while doing talbiat in the mosques where people are, to make himself hear, and make others hear. But he will raise his voice in the sacred mosque and that of Mina”. Malek has also reported that he heard the men versed say that it is preferable to make the talbiat after each prayer and in any high place on earth". Chapter XI A pilgrimage accomplished alone. 
(746) 38 - Aisha, the wife of the Prophet (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) reported: “We left, the year of the pilgrimage farewell, with the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah); some of us made the talbiat of the pious visit, others that of the pilgrimage and that of the visit pious at the same time, others finally made quite simply for a pilgrimage. The Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the mercy and peace of Allah) on his part, made the talbiat for the pilgrimage. Thus, those who made the talbiat for a pious visit, left the state of ihram. (after having performed the umrah) On the other hand, those who made it for a pilgrimage alone, or for a pilgrimage and a pious visit at the same time, left the ihram only on the day of the sacrifice”. 
(747) 39 - Abdel-Rahman Ibn Al-Kassem reported from his father that Aisha, the mother of the believers said: “the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) made the talbiat for a pilgrimage alone”. 
(748) 40 - Ourwa Ibn Al-Zoubair reported the same hadith quoted above”. 
(749) 41 - Malek reported that he heard versed men say: "He who makes the talbiat to perform a pilgrimage alone, then he felt like doing the one of a pious visit, he has no right to make it. And Malek adds: "this is what, moreover, the men did in Medina". Chapter XII From combining a pilgrimage and a pious visit. 
(750) 42 - Ja'far Ibn Muhammad reported from his father that Al-Mikdad Ibn Al-Aswad entered the house of Ali Ibn Abi Taleb at "Al-Soukia" when he gave his camelets to drink, and made them eat leaves of parched trees by wetting them with water. He said to him: "Here is Osman Ibn Affan who forbids any combination made between a pilgrimage and a pious visit". Then Ali Ibn Abi Taleb came out, and I saw his hands all covered with the traces of the food of the camelets, up to the arms, to go to Osman Ibn Affan; he said to him: “Are you the one who forbids the combination of a pilgrimage and a pious visit”? Osman replied, “Such is my opinion”! Ali, carried away with anger, went out saying: “Ya Allah! Here I am answering your call to make a pilgrimage and a pious visit at the same time”. Malek added: “From the followed tradition is that, whoever combines a pilgrimage and a pious visit at the same time, will not have to cut his hair, nor to leave the state of ihram, until he accomplishes his sacrifice if he has an animal to sacrifice, and therefore he will desecrate it on the day of the sacrifice at Mina”. 
(751) 43 Suleiman Ibn Yassar reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) the year of the pilgrimage of Allah, went out to make the pilgrimage to Mecca. Among his companions were those who made a pilgrimage and a pious visit to the times, who did not leave the state of ihram and those who had made it for a pious visit and who had left the state of ihram". 
(752) 44 - Malek reported that he heard versed men say: "He who makes the talbiat for a pious visit and still wants to perform a pilgrimage, may do so as long as he has not yet made the processional rounds around the House, nor the route between Al-Safa and Al-Marwa. Moreover, Ibn Omar did the same by saying: "if they push me away from the House, I will do as we did with the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah). Then Ibn Omar turns to his companions and said: "their situation is one, and I take you to witness that I tolerate the pilgrimage and the pious visit in common". Malek said: “The companions of the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah), the year of the pilgrimage of AAllah, made the talbiat for a pious visit”. Then the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Be upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said to them: "Whoever already possesses his offering, that he makes the talbiat for the pilgrimage and the pious visit in common, then that he does not leave the state of ihram before his rites are fully accomplished”. Chapter XIII Of the interruption of the talbiat 
(753) 45 Muhammad Ibn Abi Bakr Al-Thaqafi reported that he asked Anas Ibn Malek, on their morning departure from Mina destined for Arafat: "How did you act, this day at the time when you were with the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah)”? He replied: “Some of us did the talbiat without going back on our act, others proclaimed the greatness of Allah without being blamed”. 
(745) 46 Ja'far Ibn Muhammad reported from his father that Ali Ibn Abi Taleb performed talbiat during his pilgrimage, until the sun rose. disappeared on the day of Arafat, at which point he interrupted him”. Malek said, "This is what the learned men of Medina keep following." 
(755) 47 Abdel Rahman Ibn Al-Kassem reported from his father that Aicha, the wife of the Prophet (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) broke the talbiat when it returned to Arafat. 
(756) 48 Nafe reported that Abdallah Ibn Omar would rush the talbiat during the Hajj (pilgrimage) once he arrived at the Haram to make the processional tour, and the route between Al-Safa and Al-Marwa. Then he took over the talbiat until his departure from Mina for Arafat. But as soon as he left, he broke the talbiat, and did the same during a pious visitation when he entered the Sacred House. 
(757) 49 Ibn Chehab said that Abdallah Ibn Omar did not perform the talbiat while performing the processional tour around the House. 
(758) 50 Alqama's mother reported that Aisha, umm al-muminin the mother of believers, descended to "Namira" leaving 'Arafa', then went to a place called 'Al-Arak'. She also reported that Aicha was doing the talbiat as long as she was at home, and those who were in her company did the same; but once, mounted to head for the station, she stopped the talbiat. She similarly reported: “Aicha made the pious visit after the pilgrimage to Mecca in the month of Zoul-Hijja. Later, she stopped doing it, and she went out before the appearance of the new moon of Al-Muharram to go to Al-Jouhfa where she camped until the vision of the crescent of the month of Al-Muharram. Once the croissant appeared, she made the talbiat for a pious visit”. 
(759) 51 Yahia Ibn Sa'id reported that Omar Ibn Abdel Aziz left Mina early on the day of Arafa. He heard the takbir done so loud; that he sent his guards alerting (or warning) the people to tell them "O people, this is the talbiat you must do". Chapter XIV Of the talbiat of the inhabitants of Mecca and of those who find themselves there. (760) 52- Abdel Rahman Ibn Al-Kassem reported from his father that Umar Ibn Al-Khattab said, “O inhabitants of Mecca! What do they have the people arriving the heads bewildered as to yours, are they pomaded? Do the talbiat as soon as you see the new moon”. 
(761) 53 - Hisham Ibn Ourwa reported that Abdallah Ibn Al-Zoubair, remained in Mecca for nine years, making the talbiat for the pilgrimage at the sight of the new moon of Zul-Hijja, and Ourwa Ibn Al-Zoubair did the same”. Malek said: "The inhabitants of Makkah and others who are there, make the talbiat for pilgrimage and those who are in Makkah and who are not not Meccans, do it where they are without however leaving the sacred enclosure". Malek added: “Those who do the talbiat for the pilgrimage from Mecca, must postpone the processional tour around House, and the route between Al-Safa and Al-Marwa until their return from Mina. And that's what Abdallah Ibn Omar was doing. Malek was asked about those who do the talbiat during the pilgrimage, of the Medinans or others, at the vision of the moon of Zul-Hijja, how should they make the processional tour? He replied, "for the processional tour which is of obligation, it is to be delayed; and she is the next one the route between Al-Safa and Al-Marwa. However, they can make excess rounds as much as they want, performing two supererogatory raka'ts at the end of every seven rounds. Besides, the companions of the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) did the same, when performing the talbiat for the pilgrimage and delayed the processional tour around the House, and the journey between Al-Safa and Al-Marwa until they return from Mina. Thus did Abdallah Ibn Omar”. Malek was asked about a Makkan man; can he make the talbiat for a pious visit from Mecca”? He replied: "He must rather leave the sacred precincts to perform the talbiat". Chapter XV Ihram does not prohibit the adornment of animal victims. 
(762) 54 - Amra Ibn Abdel-Rahman reported that Ziad Ibn Abi Sufian wrote to Aisha, the wife of the Prophet (Upon him be Allah's grace and peace): "Abdallah Ibn Abbas said: 'Whoever sends an animal to be sacrificed, must abstain from anything from which a pilgrim abstains, until that animal is sacrificed. And as I have already made my offering, let me know in writing, or inform the one who brings this offering”. Amra added: “Aicha replied: “It is not like Ibn Abbas said; myself, I braided with my own hands the garlands of the sacrificed animal of the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (On him the grace and peace of Allah), then in turn he put them around the neck of the animal, and he sent it to be guarded by my father. The Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) did not forbid himself from everything what Allah made lawful for him until he sacrificed his animal. 
(763) 55 - Yahia Ibn Sa'id reported: "I asked Amra Bint Abdel Rahman, about the man who sends his offering while he remains, will he have to refrain from something? Amra replied that she heard Aicha say: "Nothing is forbidden to him who is not yet in the state of ihram, and who has not yet made the talbiat". 
(764) 56 - Rabi'a Ibn Abdallah Ibn Al-Houdair reported that he saw, in Iraq, a man behaving like a pilgrim. He asked about him, people who said to him: "He ordered that his sacrificial animal be adorned for him, and from then on he behaved like that”. Meeting Abdallah Ibn Al-Zoubair, I reported to him what was said; he exclaimed: “It is an innovation; and I swear it in the name of the Lord of the Ka'ba". Malek was asked at subject of a man who himself brings his offering by making a bleeding and adorning it at Zoul-Houlaifa, without it being in a state of ihram until its arrival at Al-Jouhfa? He replied, "I don't like not that, and I don't think that man followed what is traditional, because it is not permissible to do that except to a man who adorns his animal for the sacrifice, by bleeding it during the talbiat, and who does not intend to make the pilgrimage, and in this case he sends it and remains with his own”. We also asked to Malek, about the man who brings the beast victim without him still being in a state of ihram"? He replied, "There is nothing wrong with that." And we asked him again for the question of the man who does not want to perform either the pilgrimage or the pious visitation; should he be in ihram state to adorn the sacrificial beast, because this matter has created a debate among people”? He replied: "We will have to follow, the hadith narrated by Aisha, the mother of the believers, where it is said that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) had sent his sacrificed beast then he remained without forbidding himself from the things that Allah made lawful for him until the beast was sacrificed”. Chapter XVI What should a woman who has her period during the pilgrimage do? 
(765) 57 - Nafe' reported that Abdallah Ibn Omar said: "The woman who has her period and who does the talbiat for a pilgrimage or a pious visit, may, if she wishes, perform it, but she will not make the processional tour around the Sacred House, nor the route between Al-Safa and Al-Marwa. She can perform all other rites with people, except doing the tour and the route, and she cannot go to the mosque until she has become pure". Chapter XVII Of the pious visit during the months of pilgrimage. 
(766) 58 - It was reported to Malek that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the mercy and peace of Allah) made three visits pious: the year of Al-Houdaiba, the year of the convention� , and that of Al-Jou'rana". � Umrah el Kada is the Umrah concluded in the Al-Houdaiba agreement (It is a pact that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) had concluded with the Quraishites, aiming to return the following year to Mecca for a pious visit and to stay there for three days.) the Muslims were to return the Next year 
(767) 59 - Urwa reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) made only three visits pious: one was in the month of Shawwal and the other two during Zul-Ka'da". 
(768) 60 - Abdel-Rahman Ibn Harmala al-Aslami reported that a man asked Sa'id Ibn Al Moussaiab: "May I pay a pious visit before the pilgrimage"? He replied: "Certainly, yes, because the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) had made a pious visit before the pilgrimage". 
(769) 61 - Sa'id Ibn al-Musaiab reported that Omar Ibn Abi Salama asked permission from Omar Ibn Al-Khattab, to make a pious visitation in the month of Shawwal, and he got permission. Having made the pious visitation, Omar Ibn Abi Salama returns to his family, without performing the pilgrimage”. Chapter XVIII Of the interruption of the talbiat during the pious visitation. 
(770) 62 - Hisham Ibn Ourwa reported that his father would break the talbiat if he entered the sacred enclosure while making a pious umra visitation”. Malek said about one who is in the state of ihram, in "Al-Tan'im": "that he must break the talbiat at the sight of the Sacred House". We asked to Malek about the man who would like to do his irham for a pious visit from one of the mikat being a Medinan or other? When should he break the talbiat”? He replied, "Whoever is in the state of ihram from one of the two mikat, must interrupt the talbiat once he arrives at the Sacred House”. And he adds: “I was told that Abdallah Ibn Omar was doing this”. Chapter XIX El Hajj at Tamattou 
(771) 63 Mouhammad Ibn Abdallah Ibn Al-Hareth Ibn Abdel-Mouttaleb reported that he heard Sa'd Ibn Abi Waqas and Al-Dahaq Ibn Qais, the year that Mu'awia Ibn Abi Soufian made the pilgrimage alluding to at Tamattou ( the enjoyment of a normal life between the pious visitation and the pilgrimage.) Al-Dahaq Ibn Qais said, "It will only be done by one who is ignorant of Allah's command to Him be power and glory." Sa'd to reply: “it is not correct what you have just said, o son of my brother”. al-Dahaq answered him: "Now, Omar Ibn Al-Khattab forbade it"; Sa'd continued: "The Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah), did this, and we have accomplished it with him”. 
(772) 64 - Sadaqa Ibn Yassar reported that Abdallah Ibn Umar said: “By Allah! Do a pious visit and offering a sacrifice before the pilgrimage, is more pleasing to me than making a pious visit, following the pilgrimage in the month of "Zoul-Hijjà". 
(773) 65 - Abdallah Ibn Dinar reported that Abdallah Ibn Umar said: "He who does the pious visit in the months of Chawal or Zoul Ki'da or Zoul-Hijjà, before the pilgrimage then resides in Mecca until the time of the pilgrimage, can enjoy a normal life if he makes the pilgrimage. And he will sacrifice the offering which is easy for him to have; if he can't find it, let him fast for three days during the pilgrimage, and seven when he returns home”. Malek has interpreted this by saying, "If he resides to Mecca until the pilgrimage, and makes his pilgrimage the same year". Malek, about a Meccans who leave this city to reside elsewhere, then return to make a pious visit during the month of the pilgrimage and stay in Mecca, from where he will begin the pilgrimage - said: "this man will have enjoyed a normal life and will have to make the offering or fast if he does not possess no offering, and so shall be considered a Meccans." Malek was asked about a man who was not a Meccans, but went to Mecca for a pious visit pilgrimage and deciding to stay there until making the pilgrimage. Will he be taken for a man who enjoys a normal life? He answered: “Yes, certainly he will have a normal life, but he is not considered a Meccans, even if he decides to stay there. And this, because he entered Mecca although he was not one of its inhabitants, and sacrifice and fasting are obligatory for those who are not Meccans. And this man wants to stay there, but he doesn't know if he will be able to stay there with certainty, not being a Meccans. 
(774) 66 Ibn Sa'id reported that he heard Sa'id Ibn Al-Musaiab say: “He who pays a pious visit to the months of ChawaI, or Zoul-;Ki'da or Zoul-Hijja, then resides in Makkah until the pilgrimage takes place, he can enjoy a normal life in case he will make the pilgrimage. He will make the offering if it seems simple to him, or he will have to fast for three days during the pilgrimage and seven when he returns home". Chapter XX Circumstances in which hajj at Tamattou is not obligatory 
(775) 67 Malek said: "Whoever pays a pious visit to the months of Shawwal, or Zul-Ki'da or Zul-Hijja, then returns to his own, and fulfills the same year the pilgrimage, will not have to make an offering: because the offering is obligatory for the one who has made a pious visit in the month of the pilgrimage then he remains (in Mecca) until the period of the pilgrimage, for perform it. And anyone who goes to Makkah from all directions, to stay there, so that he makes the pious visit during the month of pilgrimage and then performs the pilgrimage, he is not held as one who enjoys 'a normal life; therefore, he does not have to make any sacrifice, nor to fast, and he is considered just like a Meccans if he lives in Makka during this period”. Malek was asked, About a Meccans who left to be at the border, or for some trip, then returned to Mecca, wanting to stay there, whether there were relatives or not; he entered Mecca to perform Umrah, and his pious visit was begun to the places which were determined by the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) or closer than that. In this case, will he be like the one who enjoys a normal "tamattou" life? He replied, "He does not need to make an offering or fast like one who enjoys a normal life, for Allah, the Blessed and Most High said in His Book (meaning): "This is for the one who does not have a family near the mosque Sacred”. Quran II.v 196 Chapter XXI About pious visitation. Umrah 
(776) 68 - Abu Huraira reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the Grace and Peace of Allah) said: "From one 'Umrah' to another 'Umrah' the sins committed between these two 'Umrah's are blotted out and the piously accomplished 'Hajj' pilgrimage is not has as a reward only Paradise". 
(777) 69 - Abu Bakr Ibn Abdel-Rahman reported that a woman came to the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) and said to him: "I was quite ready to perform the pilgrimage, when it was impossible for me". He him answered: "Make a pious visit in the month of Ramadan, because it will be considered for you, as a pilgrimage". 
(778) 70 - Abdullah Ibn Omar reported that Omar Ibn Al-Khattab said: "Separate between your pilgrimage and your pious visitation, because it makes your "Hajj" pilgrimage more perfect, and also your pious "Umrah" visitation more perfected, if you perform it excluding the months of the pilgrimage". (....) 71 - It was reported to Malek that Osman Ibn Affan, sometimes while making his pious visit, he did not descend from his mount, until his return”. - Malek said: "Pious visitation is a sunnah, and I don't even know a Muslim who has tolerated abstaining from it". - Malek has also said: "I do not see that a man should repeatedly make in a year, the pious visit". - He even says: "The one who, making a pious visit, trading with his wife, must make an offering. And he has to make another pious visit, starting it, from the moment he missed the previous one, and to be in a state of ihram from the same place where he began his failed first pious visit, unless that place is a little further than the designated places; in this case he will put himself in a state of ihram from the place where he will begin his visit recovering first”. - And Malek adds: "Whoever enters Mecca, to perform a pious visit, making the processional rounds around the Sacred House, and the journey between Al-Safa and Al-Marwa, while being in ritual impurity, or even without having made his ablutions and then traded with his wife, and let him remember it", Malek says: "Let him make lotion or his ablutions, then return to do the processional rounds again, as well as the journey between Al-Safa and Al-Marwa, then he performs a pious visit and sacrifices an offering.
