As for the woman, who, had carnal intercourse with her husband, while she was in the state of ihram, she will act similarly to the man”. - Malek finally said: “The pious visit must be started from "Al-Tan'im", the one who leaves the sacred precinct to be afterwards in a state of ihram, this will be admitted if Allah wills; however, he has much more merit, to start doing the talbiat from the very place than the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) had designated, or another that is much further than Al-Tan'im". Chapter XXII From the marriage of one who is in the state of ihram. 
(779) 72 - Suleiman Ibn Yassar reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) sent Abu Rafe and a man of the Ansars to ask him to marry Maimouna Bint al-Hareth while he was in Medina before leaving it". 
(780) 73 - Noubaih Ibn Wahb, the brother of Bani Abdel-Al-Dar, reported that Omar Ibn Oubaidallah sent word to Aban Ibn Osman, and he was, at that time, the prince of the pilgrimage, both being in a state of ihram, he wanted to ask, the daughter of Chaiba Ibn Joubair in marriage to Talha Ibn Omar, asking him to be present. Aban refused what Omar wanted, and said: “I heard Osman Ibn Affan say: “the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said: "A man in the state of ihram should neither complete a marriage pact, nor propose in marriage, nor celebrate an engagement". 
(781) 74 • Abu Ghatafan Ibn Tarif Al-Marii reported that his father Tarif married while in ihram state. Omar Ibn Al-Khattab had denied it to him”. 
(782) 75 - Nafe' reported that Abdallah Ibn Omar said: "A man in the state of ihram can neither marry nor ask, either for himself or for another, a girl as an engagement". 
(783) 76 - Sa'id Ibn Al-Musaib, Salem Ibn Abdallah, and Suleiman Ibn Yassar were asked if it is permissible for a man in state of ihram to get married? They replied, "He can neither marry nor be asked to marry." Malek said, "The man in the state of ihram can return to his wife, if he wants, as long as she is still in iddnance." Chapter XXIII Of the bloodletting done to a man in a state of ihram 
(784) 77 - Suleiman Ibn Yassar reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) was made, on the bloodletting, while in a state of ihram, at "Lahiai-Jamal" a place on the road to Makkah". 
(785) 78 - Nafe' reported that he heard Abdallah Ibn Omar say: "The man in the state of ihram, will only bleed what is necessary". And Malek says: "the man in state of ihram, will make a bloodletting, only where it is necessary". Chapter XXIV Of what a man in the state of ihram can eat game from the hunt. 
(786) 79 - Abu Katada Al-Ansari reported that he was in the company of the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Be upon him the grace and peace of Allah) When they took one of the roads of Mecca they found themselves left behind, all his companions were in a state of ihram, except him. He saw an onager, so he readjusted himself on his horse, and asked his companions to whip him; but they refused; he asked them for his spear, which they again refused him; then he took it and rushed with all his might against the onager and the you are. Some of the companions of the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the mercy and peace of Allah) ate of his flesh, when to others they refused. Once, arrived at the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Be upon him the mercy and peace of Allah) they asked him about the flesh of the evening primrose, is it to eat”? He answered them: "Besides, it is only a food that Allah has granted you". 
(787) 80 - Hisham Ibn Ourwa reported from his father that Al-Zoubair Ibn Al'-Awam ate desiccated meat, while being in a state of ihram". And Malek added: "This is the meat of a dried deer." 
(788) 81 - Zaid Ibn Aslam reported the same Hadith, about the evening primrose, quoted in the foregoing, reported by Abu Katada (Hadith 786). Corn in the report of Zaid Ibn Aslam, it is added that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) said: "Do you still have some pieces of his flesh"?. 
(789) 82 – Al-Bahzi reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) went to Mecca, being in ihram, on arriving at "Al-Rawha", we met an onager whose hocks were cut off. This was reported to the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Be upon him the mercy and peace of Allah) who replied: "Let him, because I think its owner will come, the owner went to the Prophet (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) and said: "O Messenger of Allah this zebra belongs to you”. So, the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Be upon him the grace and peace of Allah) ordered Abu Bakr to share his flesh with all the Companions, then continued on his way. Arriving at "Al-Outhaba" place between "Al-Rouaitha" and "Al-Arj", he found a gazelle, hit by an arrow and lying in the shadow, Al-Bahzi adds: “the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Be upon him the grace and peace of Allah) ordered a man to guard the gazelle so that no one touched him, until they had passed”. 
(790) 83 - Sa'id Ibn Al-Musaiab reported that Abu Huraira came from Al-Bahrain, so arriving at “Al-Rabaza” he came across people from Iraq in state of ihram. They asked him about the meat they have found among the inhabitants of “Al-Rabaza”. He replied that they can eat it." Abou Houraira continues: “then I doubted what I told them; thus, having arrived in Medina, I reported this to Omar Ibn Al-Khattab who answered me: “what did you order them to do”? I tell him: “I ordered them to eat it”. Omar replied, "If you had ordered them to do otherwise, I would have done such and such a thing to you", threatening him". 
(791) 84 - Salem Ibn Abdallah reported that he heard Abu Houraira tell Abdallah Ibn Omar that he, in “Rabaza”, passed by people, in ihram, who consulted him for the meat of a hunted animal, which was eaten by people in ihram. He ordered them to eat it. Abu Houraira, went on to say: “then I went to Omar Ibn Al-Khattab, in Medina, and I reported to him what is done, and he asked me: “what did you order them to do”? I said, "I told them to eat it." Omar said, "If you had told them otherwise, I would have beaten you." 
(792) 85 - Ata Ibn Yassar reported that Ka'b Al-Ahbar came from Syria accompanied by horsemen, who, being on the way, found the flesh of a hunted animal. Ka'b allowed them to eat it. Ata continues: “On arriving at Omar Ibn Al-Khattab, in Medina, they report to him what has been done”. Omar asked, “Who authorized you”? They replied, "Ka'b." Omar resumed: “So I command you at the head of your troop, until your return”. Shortly afterwards, being on their way to Mecca, this troop came across a flight of locusts, and Ka'b proposed to capture them and eat them. Back at Omar Ibn Al-Khattab, the troops reported to him what had been done”. Omar challenged Ka'b: "who carried you, to allow them Grasshoppers"? He replied, "These grasshoppers are sea peaches." Omar asks him: “who told you that”? Ka'b replies, “O prince of the believers! By him who holds my soul in His hand, they are but the sneezes of a whale which can only be found twice a year”. We asked to Malek about the meat of game from the hunt, which is found on the way to Mecca; a man in the state of ihram, can he buy it? He answered: “that the pilgrim seeks purposely this meat of the game of the hunt, I dislike him; but for what he finds by chance, he can buy it, and there is no harm in that”. Malek added, “one who is in the state of ihram, and who has meat from what he has hunted, or from what he has bought, he will not have to get rid of it, and there is no harm in keeping it at home. . For the fishing of fish, in the sea, in the rivers, in the ponds, or in the like, that is lawful, and the man in the state of ihram can fish them”. Chapter XXV From hunting forbidden to one who is in a state of ihram. 
(793) 86 - Abdallah Ibn Abbas reported that Al-Sa'b Ibn Jathama offered to the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) an onager, while he was in Al-Abwa or Waddan”. The Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam), returned it to him. But as soon as the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Be upon him the mercy and peace of Allah) saw how the figure of Al-Sa'b, he said to him: "I refuse it to you only because I am in a state of ihram". 
(794) 87 - Abdel-Rahman Ibn Amer Ibn Rabi'a reported: “I saw Osman Ibn Affan in Al-Arj, in a state of ihram, in a summer day, covering her face with a purple velvet cloth. Bringing him the meat of a hunted animal, he said to his companions: “eat it” They said to him: “And you, you don't eat”. He replied, “I am not like you; although it was hunted for me". 
(795) 88 - Ourwa reported that Aisha, the mother of the believers, said to him, “O son of my sister! They are only ten nights (to be in ihram). If your soul concerned about something questionable, leave it. And it implied the meat of the hunt”. Malek said, “The man in the state of ihram, for whom they hunt, and they prepare food for him, and let him eat it, knowing that this hunt was made for him, he commits an offense for this hunt and must atone for it”. Malek was asked, about the man who in state of ihram is compelled to eat the meat of a dead animal? Can he hunt and eat from his hunt, or will he be able to eat meat from the dead animal? He replied: "Let him eat the meat of the dead animal because Allah the Blessed and the Most High has not allowed the one who is in the state of ihram neither to eat of the game, nor to to have part whatever the circumstance; but He tolerated the meat of the dead animal when necessary”. And Malek to say: "He is not permitted. for anyone whether in irham state or not to eat game hunted or sacrificed by someone in irham state And I have heard this said, from more than one person. who kills what he hunts and then eats it, he owes one atonement, and he is like he who kills and does not eat. Chapter XXI Of the offense of hunting in the sacred enclosure. 
(796) 89 - Malek said: "all that is game hunted in the sacred enclosure, or maintained by a dog to be killed in a free environment is by no means lawful to eat. And whoever commits this offense must expiate it. On the other hand, he who sends his dog to a free environment, finding the game only in the sacred enclosure, it is neither lawful to eat, nor to repair unless this game is near the sacred enclosure when it has sent his dog; in this case, he must repair his crime”. Chapter XXVII Judgment on hunting. 
(797) 90 - Malek said: "Allah, the Blessed and Most High has said: 'O believers! Do not kill game while you are holy. Whoever among you deliberately kills any, let him compensate, either by some animal of the herd, similar to what he has killed, of which two of yourselves, people of integrity, will judge, and it will be like an offering that one makes to attain the Ka'ba either by expiation, by feeding the poor, or by the equivalent of fasting. This so that he tastes the consequence of his act”. Koran V, 95. Malek has continued: “He who hunts, being in sanctification, then kills the hunted beast while he is in state of ihram, is comparable to someone who buys it in a state of ihram and then kills it. And Allah having forbidden this, the man must in these conditions repair this crime”. And he who then kills what he has hunted, while being in ihram, must be judged”. - Malek added: “this what I have heard best about the one who kills what he hunts is that he is judged by his title in such a way that he valorizes the hunted beast; one fixes what he owes to make eat with all poor of approximately one mudd, or to fast one day by compensation with each mudd. Then one determines the number of the poor if they are at ten, he must fast for ten days, at twenty he must fast for twenty days, as much therefore their number, even if it is at sixty poor. Malek finally said, “I have likewise heard that whoever kills game within the sacred precincts while it is being desacralized, will be judged. similarly to one who is in a state of ihram and kills game in the sacred enclosure”. Chapter XXVIII Animals that can be killed by one who is in a state of ihram 
(798) 91 - Abdallah Ibn Umar reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said: "among the animals, five, can be killed by man in state of ihram, without being considered at fault: the crow, the hawk, the scorpion, the mouse and the rabid dog". 
(799) 92 - Abdallah Ibn Umar reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Be upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said: "five animals, if they are killed by one man in ihram, he is not accused of a crime: the scorpion, the mouse, the crow, the hawk and the rabid dog". 
(800) 93 - Urwa reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him be Allah's grace and peace) said: "five harmful animals, are to be killed in the sacred enclosure: the mouse, the scorpion, the crow, the hawk and the rabid dog”. 
(801) 94 - Ibn Chehab reported that Umar Ibn Al-Khattab ordered the killing of the snakes in the sacred enclosure”. Malek said: "Any animal that bites, injures, and attacks people is considered just like a mad dog to be killed in the sacred precincts: the lion, the tiger, the leopard, and the wolf. But the wild beasts which do not attack such: the hyena, the fox, the cat and animals similar to them, they are not not to be killed by a man while being from ihram. And if he kills them, he must expiate them. On the other hand, harmful birds are not to be killed by man in a state of ihram except those which have been mentioned by the Prophet (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) such as: the crow and the hawk. And if it is done that the man in the state of ihram kills any other than these two kinds of birds, he must atone for it”. Chapter XXIX Acts which are permissible for a man in the state of ihram to perform. 
(802) 95 Rabi'a Ibn Abi Abdallah Ibn Al-Houdair reported that he saw Omar Ibn Al-Khattab, while wearing ihram, removing ringworm from his camel, in the mud at “Al-Soukia”. Malek said, "As for me, I loathe that." 
(803) 96 - Alqama Ibn Abi Alqama reported that his mother heard that Aisha, the wife of the Prophet (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) was asked about the man in the state of ihram, can he scratch his skin? She replied, "Yes, let him scratch it, and rubbing it to such an extent that if my hands had been tied and my only means were my feet, to scratch my skin, I would wear them out”. 
(804) 97 - Ayoub Ibn Moussa reported that Abdallah Ibn Omar looked in the mirror for a pain caused to him by his eyes, while being in ihram”. (...) 98 - Nafe' reported that Abdallah Ibn Omar was loath to have a man in the state of ihram remove harmful insects and ringworm from his camel». Malek adds, "That's the best I've heard." 
(805) 99 - Muhammad Ibn Abdallah Ibn Abi Mariam reported that he asked Sa'id Ibn Al-Musaiab if he can cut his broken fingernail, while being in ihram”? Abdallah Ibn to answer: "Certainly, cut it". - Malek was asked at the about a man complaining of pain in his ear. Can there pouring sap from a tree which is not fragrant while being in ihram”? He replied, "I don't see any harm in that, even he can drink it too." Malek added, "I don't find it wrong for a man in ihram to burst an abscess, burst a pustule, and cut a vein if it is necessary." Chapter XXX Of the accomplishment of the pilgrimage by substitution for the one who cannot do it. 
(806) 100 - Abdallah Ibn Abbas reported: “Al-FadI Ibn Abbas rode on the back of the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah), when a woman came from "Khat'am", consult the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah). Al-Fadl stared at her and she stared back at him; the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him be Allah's Grace and Peace) caused Al-FadI's face to turn to the other side. The woman said, “Oh. Messenger of Allah, the prescription of Allah, in pilgrimage, is a difficult obligation for my father who has reached a certain age, and he can no longer maintain himself on the back of a mount. Can I perform the pilgrimage in his place? He replied: “Yes, certainly”. This happened during the Farewell Pilgrimage”. Chapter XXXI Of the pilgrim held back by the enemy. 
(807) 101 - Malek said, “the pilgrim restrained by an enemy, so that he cannot reach the Holy House, is released from his irham, he cuts the throat of his offering, shaves his head where he is restrained; and therefore, he has nothing to pay”. (....) 102 - Malek said that it was reported to him that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) and his companions left the state of ihram, while they were at "Al-Houdaibia", slaughtered their sacrifices, shaved their heads, desacralized themselves long before making their processional tour around the Sacred House, and even before the offering has arrived at its place of sacrifice. Then we weren't informed, if the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the mercy and peace of Allah) had ordered one of his companions, nor any of those who were with him, to acquit sooner or later, nor to repeat any rite". 
(808) 103 - Nafe' reported that Abdallah Ibn Umar, leaving for a pious visit to Mecca, during the conflict, (between al-Hajjaj ibn Yusuf and Zubair ibn al-Awwam) said: "If I am going to be forbidden to come to the Holy House, I will do, what we have already done with the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah). Thus, he made the talbiat for a pious visit, because the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) had made the talbiat for a pious visit in the year of Houdaibia”. Then Abdallah, thinking about what he has done. said: "The pilgrimage and the pious visit are both the same duty. Then addressing his companions he said to them: "Since both are the same duty, I take you to witness that I have given the order to bring together the pilgrimage and the visit pious”. Then he succeeded in gaining access to the Sacred House, completed the tawaf, finding that he had accomplished the rites, he sacrificed his victim”. Malek said: “such is this which is traditionally followed, by one who is restrained by an enemy, just like the case of the Prophet (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him be Allah's grace and peace) and his companions. As for the one who is retained in other conditions (or situations), he cannot be desacralized if he has not arrived at the Sacred House”. Chapter XXXII Of the Pilgrim retained by another cause than the enemy. 
(809) 104 Salem Ibn Abdallah reported that Abdallah Ibn Umar said: "The pilgrim detained because of an illness should not leave the ihram, before he made the processional tour around the Sacred House, and the route between Al-Safa and Al-Marwa. And if it happens obliged to wear clothes as usual, by necessity, or even to take medicine, that he does this, but by redeeming himself by an offering”. (810),105 - It was reported to Yahia Ibn Sa'id that Aisha, the wife of the Prophet (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said: "The man who is in the state of ihram, can not be desacralized until after his arrival in the Sacred House". 
(811) 106 - Ayoub Ibn Abi Tamima Al-Sakhtiani reported that a man from the inhabitants of "Basra", in time, said: "having taken the road to Mecca, it happened to me, on the way, to have a fractured my thigh. I sent a messenger to Makkah where Abdallah Ibn Abbas, Abdallah Ibn Umar and others were consulting them about me. No one allowed me to leave ihram. So I stayed all near the water source for seven months (where I broke my thigh), until I was healed; so I left the ihram after having made a pious visit”. 
(812) 107 - Salem Ibn Abdallah reported that Abdallah Ibn Omar said: "He who, having fallen ill, finds himself unable to arrive at the Sacred House, should never leave the ihram before he has completed the processional tour around the Sacred House, and traveled the route between “Al-Safa” and “Al-Marwa”. (....) 108 - Suleiman Ibn Yassar reported that Sa'id Ibn Huzaba Al-Makhzouni, becomes ill en route to Mecca, while being in ihram. He inquired about those who were near the water source, and met Abdallah Ibn Omar, Abdallah Ibn Al-Zoubair and Marwan Ibn Al-Hakam. Telling them what had happened to him, they all order him to remedy what he needs, and to make an offering. Once, feeling cured, he will have to make the pious visit then he will desacralize himself, waiting for the pilgrimage of the following year to accomplish it, and make the offering which seems easy to him». - Malek said: “this is what which is, for us, traditionally followed, for the one who is prevented, for another cause than that of the enemy. And Omar Ibn Al-Khattab, had ordered, Abu Ayoub Al-Ansari, and Habbar Ibn Al-Aswad, who missing the pilgrimage and arriving on the day of the sacrifice, to desacral themselves after a pious visit, then return home, still in a state of desacralization. Then, the following year, they will have to make the pilgrimage and offer their victims; in case they cannot be found for them, they will have to fast for three days while on pilgrimage, and for seven days once they are at home”. Malek added, “one who is in a state of ihram and who shall be inhibited from the pilgrimage either by reason of illness or other cause, or by error in counting the days, or by the invisibility of the crescent, being held as impeded, he shall discharge the same obligations as the pilgrim stop". Malek was asked about a Meccans who made the talbiat for a pilgrimage, then suffered a fracture, or diarrhea, or that his wife had to give birth, what would he do”? He says, “Whoever is subject to these conditions is already taken for granted. As a result, he will have to fulfill all the obligations that are applied to everyone”. Malek said: "for the man, who arrives, in the months of the pilgrimage, to make the pious visit, who once this is finished, he will make the talbiat of the pilgrimage from Mecca, then he suffers a fracture or something that prevents him from being at the same station with the other people", "I think, he said, he must persist until whatever it is restored, where he will go out to the free territory and then return to Mecca, make the processional tour around the Sacred House, and the route between Al-Safa and al-Marwa, after which he will go out of the state of ihram. He will have to make the pilgrimage the following year and will offer a victim”. Malek was asked about the one who does the talbiat for a pilgrimage from Mecca, then completes the processional tour around the Sacred House, and the journey between Al-Safa and Al-Marwa, after which he falls ill, and cannot manage to be at the same station with people”. Malek answered: "if this man has missed the pilgrimage, if he succeeds, he goes out to the free territory, will enter for a pious visitation, will make the processional tour around the Holy House and the route between al-Safa and al-Marwa, as his first tour was not for a pious visitation. For this, he must complete the rites mentioned, and will make the following year, the pilgrimage and the offering is to be sent. But if he is not one of the inhabitants of Mecca, and he suffers from an illness that keeps him away from the pilgrimage, he makes the processional tour around the House and the route between Al-Safa and Al- Marva. Then he is in a state of ihram for a pious visitation, made a processional tour around the House and the route between Al-Safa and al-Marwa, as his first tour and run was for pilgrimage only. The following year, he will have to do a pilgrimage and make an offering". Chapter XXXIII Of the construction of the Ka'ba. 
(813) 109 Abdallah Ibn Umar reported that the Prophet (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him be Allah's grace and peace) said to Aisha: “Have you not noticed that your fellow citizens in building the Ka'ba, did not follow the foundations of Ibrahim”? Aisha replied, “O Messenger of Allah! Are you not going to rebuild it according to the foundations of Ibrahim”? He replied, "If your fellow citizens were not so close to the time of polythesis, I would have done it". Abdallah Ibn Omar added: “if Aicha had heard these words from the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) I do not think that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) would have neglected the fact of touch the two Yemenite columns that directly follow the Black Stone. But the House has not been restored according to the foundations of Ibrahim”. 
(814) 110 Ourwa reported that Aisha, the mother of believers said: "I don't care whether I pray in the enclosure or in the House". 
(815) 111 Ibn Chehab reported that he heard some scholars say, "The compound was surrounded by a wall, behind which people were making the processional tour, only for the purpose that all the people could make the tour around it. the House". Chapter XXXIV Accelerated pace during the processional tour 
(816) 112 Jaber Ibn Abdallah reported that he saw the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam), r perform three rounds with an accelerated step around the House, considering the Black Stone as a point departure". Malek said, "it keeps on being followed in Medina." 
(817) 113 - Nafe' reported that Abdallah Ibn Omar made three rounds at accelerated pace starting from the Black Stone, then four other rounds at ordinary pace. 
(818) 114 - Hisham Ibn Ourwa reported that his father, while performing the three rounds around the House at a rapid pace, he recited in a low voice: "Nobleman! There is no Allah but You, You raise us up after having made us die”. 
(819) 115 Ourwa reported that he saw Abdallah Ibn Al-Zoubair put himself in a state of ihram from “Al-Taniim” to make the pious visit”. And Ourwa continues: “I also saw him, making the three processional rounds around the House. 
(820) 116 Nafe' reported that Abdallah Ibn Omar, once he put himself in the state of ihram, did neither the processional tour nor the route between Al-Safa and Al-Marwa, only when he returns from Mina; and he didn't the fast processional tour, in case he puts himself in a state of ihram in Mecca”. Chapter XXXV From touching the Black Stone during processional tours. 
(821) 117 It was reported to Malek that when the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) had finished his rounds processionals around the House, made the two raka'ts, and wanted to make the journey between Al-Safa and Al-Marwa, he touched the Black Stone, before leaving the House". 
(822) 118 - Urwa reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said to Abdel-Rahman Ibn Auf: “O Abu Muhammad! What have you done, finding yourself near the Black Stone? He replied, "I touched her (and kissed her if that was possible for me) and I waved to him with my hand (when it was impossible for me to approach him because of the crowd of pilgrims) the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) replied: "You have done very well". 
(823) 119 - Hisham Ibn Ourwa reported that his father, while making the processional tour around the Sacred House, touched every corner of the Black Stone, except when it seemed too difficult for him to do so. make". Chapter XXXVI From kissing the Black Stone by touching it. 
(824) 120 - Ourwa reported that Omar Ibn Al-Khattab, while touring around the House said (addressing the Black stone): “You are but a stone; and if I had not previously seen the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the mercy and peace of Allah) kiss you, I would not have done it”. Then he kissed her”. Malek said, "I have heard some men versed in the religion, say, about the one who makes the rounds around the Kaba, that it is better, for him, after having touched the Black Stone with his hand, let him put it in his mouth”. Chapter XXXVII About the two raka'ts after the tour around the Kaba. 
(825) 121 - Hicham Ibn Ourwa reported that his father did not perform two sacred house tawaf sequences without praying between them. Corn, accomplished the seven rounds, he did the two raka'ts near the station, or elsewhere". - Malek was asked, if it will be easier for the man to make a supererogatory prayer and this after having combined for two weeks or more, seven rounds, then he will do the raka'ts he had to perform, all at once after his tours”? He replied: "No, you should not do so, because it is the tradition followed, to make two raka'ts once the seven rounds are completed". - Malek said about of the man, who, distracted, will make eight or nine processional rounds, instead of seven, that he must break these rounds, if he is aware of the surplus, then make two raka'ts without taking into account the rounds made in addition. On the other hand, he does not have to consider the nine rounds already made after which he will make the prayer. Because he must do two raka'ts for every seven rounds completed. Malek added: “The one who doubts the number of his processional rounds, after having made two raka'ts, must start his rounds again to be sure of their exact number which is seven, then that he redo the two raka'ts, because any prayer made does not will be admitted only if the seven rounds have been completed”. -Malek finally said: "Whoever accidentally suffers, which may make him impure, while making his processional rounds around the House, or even during the journey between Al-Safa and Al-Marwa, or between these two rites, in such a way that his rounds are almost partially or totally accomplished, and that he has not yet done the two raka'ts, he must redo his ablutions, in order to continue his rounds and do his prayer. As for the path between Al-Safa and Al-Marwa, this impurity is not too much to consider to carry it out, but it is better to be ritually pure”. Chapter XXXVIII About the prayers after those of the dawn and the asr during the processional tour. 
(826) 122 Houmaid Ibn Abdel-Rahman Ibn Auf, reported that Abdel-Rahman Ibn Abdel-Qari told him that he did Tawaf around the House with Omar Ibn Al-Khattab after the dawn prayer. Having completed his rounds, Omar realizing that the sun had not yet risen, mounted his mount and left for Zat-al-Tiwa, where he stopped to make two raka'ts”. 
(827) 123 Malek reported that Abu Al-Zoubair Al-Makki told him: “I saw Abdallah Ibn Abbas doing Tawaf after the Asr prayer. Then he went to his apartment, but I don't know what he was doing there. 
(828) 124 - Malek reported that Abu Al-Zoubair Al-Makki said: "The Sacred House was deserted after the dawn prayer, and after the asr prayer, without let there be a person, making the processional tour all around”. Malek said, “He who partially completes his seven rounds around the House, then whether there is the call to the dawn prayer or to that of the asr, he must obligatorily break his rounds and pray with the imam (for these two moments: dawn and asr). When the prayer is finished, he will consider the number of rounds already made to complete them at seven. Then, he will not have to pray except just when the sun rises or sets”. And Malek has added: “and if he wants to delay the prayer after sunset, he can do so”. Malek finally said, “There is no harm in a man doing Tawaf after the dawn prayer, and the asr prayer provided he does not perform only seven rounds, and to delay the two raka'ts of the prayer, until the sun rises. Moreover, this is what Omar Ibn Al-Khattab did. He can delay them after the asr until sunset; the latter lying down, he can, if he wishes, pray to them, otherwise he can still delay them so that he can say the sunset prayer, and there is no harm in that”. Chapter XXXIX About the farewell to the House. 
(829) 125 - Abdallah Ibn Omar reported that Omar Ibn Al-Khattab said: "Let no pilgrim leave the Sacred House before making the processional tour all around the House because the last rite is to do this tour. Malek said, interpreting the proposals of Omar Ibn Al-Khattab: "what we think, about this tour, and Allah is Most informed of it, that it is the last rite, in accordance with the words of Allah: "Here is! And whoever exalts the emblems of Allah, yes, it is an effect of the piety of the hearts” Coran XXII, 32. Allah also said: “Towards the Ancient House is their place of immolation” Coran XXII, 33. The place of all these rites, and their acquittal is therefore the Ancient House”. 
(830) 126 - Yahia Ibn Sa'id reported that Omar Ibn Al-Khattab sent back a man from “Mar-El-Zahran” to bid farewell (tawaf al wada) to the Sacred House, because he had not done so”. 
(831) 127 - Hisham Ibn Ourwa reported that his father said, “Whoever makes the extra tour, Allah considers him his pilgrimage complete. But, if he is detained for any reason, the tour around the Sacred House must be the last rite he has to perform. But if he is restrained by something, or forbidden to do so. Allah will consider his pilgrimage accomplished. Malek finally said: "For the man who does not know that the last rite to perform is to walk around the House, and he is not aware that after leaving the holy places, I think he will not have nothing to do unless he is still very close to these places; then he must return to do the tour and then leave the Sacred House once the farewell tour has been completed”. Chapter XL From the subject of “processional tours”. 
(832) 128 - Oum Salama, the wife of the Prophet (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) reported: "as I complained to the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) feeling unwell, he said to me: "Go around behind people while remaining on your mount". She continues: “I made the tour, while being on my camel, while the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) prayed beside the Sacred House, reciting: "By the Mount, And by a transcribed Book" Koran LII: v: 1 and 2 
(833) 129 - Abu Ma'ez Al-Aslami Abdallah Ibn Sufian, narrated: “I was sitting with Abdallah Ibn Omar, a woman came to consult him saying: "I came to do the tour around the House; but arriving at the door, I had my period; I came back, remaining until I was purified. Then coming back to the House, and arriving at the door, I found myself impure again, so that I turned back and stayed at home until I was in purity; become pure, for the third time, here I am returning to the House, and again arrived at the door, the blood flowed.” which flows, is only the thrust of the demon. Do ghousl (the great ablutions), put on a cloth, and make the processional round”. 
(834) 130 - It was reported to Malek that Sa'd Ibn Abi Waqas entered Makkah late, and went straight to Arafa, before starting the processional rounds, and before making the journey between Al-Safa and Al-Marwa: He started the tour around the House after”. And Malek interpreting this said: “Such is one of the graces of Allah”. Malek was asked: "A man walking around the House, can he stop to have an interview with another”? He replied, "I hate that." Malek said: “No one does not make the tour around the House, nor the course between Al-Safa and Al-Marwa, if it is not in a state of purity”. Chapter XLI Start the "say" course of Al-Safa. 
(835) 131 - Jaber Ibn Abdallah reported that he heard the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) say, while leaving the House heading towards Al-Safa: "We begin with the place that Allah has designated as first". 
(836) 132 - Jaber Ibn Abdallah reported: "When the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) stood on Al-Safa, he made for three times the takbir, and said, “There is no god but Allah, the Unique, He has no partner. Kingship and Praise belong to Him, He is powerful over all things”. He repeated this for three times, then invoked Allah. He acted similarly on Al-Marwa”. 
(837) 133 - Nafe' reported that he heard Abdallah Ibn Umar, while being on Al-Safa, say: “Yah Allah! You said, "Call on Me, I will answer you" Quran S:Ghafir, v:60; and: "You don't break your promise do you" Koran III, 194.” I ask You, as You have guided me towards Islam, not to take it away from me so that You may collect my soul as a Muslim”. Chapter XLII How to do the course. 
(838) 134 - Ourwa a reported: “being still a teenager, I said to Aisha, the mother of the believers: “what do you think of the words of Allah Blessed and Most High: “Al-Safa and Al-Marwa are truly among the sacred things of Allah. He who makes the pilgrimage to the House or the pious visit does not commit of sin if he completes the ritual circuits here and there” Koran II, v.158. Thus, man is not to be judged if he does not make the journey between Al-Safa and Al-Marwa”. Aicha replied: “No, you misunderstood this verse; for if it were so, it would have been revealed in the way following: "It will not be a subject of offense if the man does not make the journey between these two localities". Continuing, Aicha says: “So this verse was revealed about the Ansar who were doing the talbiat au, name of "Manat" (adored statue) located in front of Koudaid and they bothered to make the journey between Al-Safa and Al-Marwa. Being converted to Islam, they asked the Apostle of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the mercy and peace of Allah) about it. This is as well as Allah the Blessed and the Most High made this revelation: "Al-Safa and Al-Marwa count truly among the sacred things of Allah. Whoever makes the pilgrimage to the House or the pious visit does not commit a sin if he accomplishes the ritual circuits here and there”. 
(839) 135 - Hisham Ibn Ourwa reported that Sawda bint Abdallah Ibn Omar was with Ourwa Ibn Al-Zoubair. She was going, on foot, to make the journey between Al-Safa and Al-Marwa for a pilgrimage or for a pious visit. As she was an obese woman, she arrived at the time when people were coming to finish the evening prayer, without her having already finished the course, than when the dawn prayer was called. His journey was completed between the evening prayer and that of the dawn (evening and night)”. Ourwa seeing people to do the course, seated on their mount, prohibited them. They claiming, out of shame, to be sick, Ourwa told us in secret: “these have failed, and are lost”. Malek said, “He who, during a pious visit, forget the route between Al-Safa and Al-Marwa, and only remembered that once away from Makkah, he has to come back and do this course. And if he had sex with his wife .that he return to make the journey between Al-Safa and Al-Marwa, so that he completes all the rites of the pious visitation; then he must make another pious visit the following year, and sacrifice an offering”. Malek was asked at about a man, who, meeting another, in the course between Al-Safa and Al-Marwa, stops to converse with him”? He replied, "It doesn't please me." Malek said, "He who forgets the number of processional tours made around the House, or who suspects the number, and only remembers it by making the route between Al-Safa and Al-Marwa, he must break his route, to complete the processional rounds, which he missed, around the House, considering the rounds already accomplished, then will make two raka'ts after the rounds, and he will start his route again between Al-Safa and Al-Marwa. 
(840) 136 - Jaber Ibn Abdallah narrated that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah), walked down from Al-Safa and Al-Marwa, and would run lightly when he reached the bottom of the valley”. Malek said about of a man who, ignorant of the rites, had begun to make the journey between Al-Safa and Al-Marwa, before the processional rounds around the House, that he must return to complete the rounds and then make the course. And if he is unaware of this, and has already left Mecca, being far from this city, let him return there, perform the processional rounds around the House, and make the journey between Al-Safa and Al-Marwa. If he had had relations with his wife, let him turn back, make the tour around the House and the route between Al-Safa and Al-Marwa to complete what he had to accomplish with his pious visit, he will have to also make another pious visit the following year, and the sacrifice of an offering”. Chapter XLIII Fasting on the day of Arafa. 
(841) 137 - Umm Al-FadI Bint Al-Hareth reported that people, on the day of Arafa, were discussing about the fasting of the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the mercy and peace of Allah) for this very day. Each say he is fasting, others say he is not". She went on, and said, "I then sent him a bowl of curdled milk, sitting on his immobilized mount, he drank it." 
(842) 138 - Al-Kassem Ibn Muhammad said "May Aisha, the mother of the believers, fasted on the day of Arafa". Al-Kassem continued: “I I saw her the day before Arafa, when the imam came out with the people, to stop until there is no one left, to order that drink be brought to him to break the fast". Chapter XLIV The fasting of the days of Mina. 
(843) 139 - Soulaiman Ibn Yassar reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) forbade fasting on the days of Mina”. 
(844) 140 - Ibn Chehab reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him be Allah's grace and peace) had sent Abdallah Ibn Houzafa, tell people, the days of Mina: “These days are for eating, drinking and calling on Allah”. 
(845) 141 - Abu Hurairah narrated that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the mercy and peace of Allah) forbids fasting two days: the day of fitr and the day of sacrifice. 
(846) 142 –Oum Hani a reported that Abdallah Ibn Amr Ibn Al'as told him that he entered his father's house, and found him eating and his father invited him", he replied, "I am fasting". He replied: "The Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the mercy and peace of Allah) has forbidden us to fast during those days, and commanded us to eat and drink during those days. Malek said: “It implies, the so-called 'Al-Tachriq' days. Chapter XLV What is permitted as animals for ritual sacrifice."Hady" 
(847) 143 - Abdallah Ibn Abi Bakr Ibn Muhammad Ibn Amr Ibn Hazm reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah), has, during a pilgrimage or a pious visit, sent for sacrifice, a camel which belonged to Jahl Ibn Hisham”. 
(848) 144 - Abu Huraira narrated that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the mercy and peace of Allah) saw a man bringing a camel. He said to her: "Mount her". He replied: “O Messenger of Allah, it is an offering”! The Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Be upon him the grace and peace of Allah) exclaimed: “Woe to you! Mount her”, repeating this to her for two or three times”. 
(849) 145 - Abdallah Ibn Dinar reported that he saw Abdallah Ibn Omar make during the pilgrimage, an offering of two camels, and for the pious visit, a camel. He continued: “I saw him, during a pious visit, slaughter a camel which was in the residence of Khaled Ibn Oussaid, where he lived. I saw him likewise slit the throat of a camel with a spear, driving it through the neck and pulling it out above the shoulder". 
(850) 146 - Yahia Ibn Sa'id reported that Omar Ibn Abdel-Aziz, sent for sacrifice, a camel, during either a pilgrimage, or a pious visit”. 
(851) 147 - Abu Ja'far Al-Qari reported that Abdallah Ibn Ayach al-Makhzoumi sent for offering two camels, one of which was "Bokhtia" (two-humped). 
(852) 148 - Nafe' reported that Abdallah Ibn Omar said: “If a camel gives birth (and let her be an offering) let her camel be brought on a litter so that it is sacrificed with her; in case we don't find a litter, let it be carried on its mother's back". 
(853) 149 - Hisham Ibn Ourwa reported that his father said: “If it is necessary for you to ride your camel, do it but without tiring her; if you need of her milk, drink it, after her camel has been satisfied and when you sacrifice her, let her camel be with her”. Chapter XLVI On how to bring animal offerings for ritual sacrifice."Hady" 
(854) 150 - Nafe' reported that, if Abdallah Ibn Omar, sent his offering from Medina, he adorned and marked it in Zul-Houlaifa; he adorned it before to mark it and that in the same place, directing it towards the Ka'ba. He adorned it with two shoes (all around the neck) and marked it with a wound on the left side of the hump; then he would bring him with him until he was stationed with the people at Arafa. Afterwards he would push her in front of him when the people surged forward. Thus, arriving at Mina on the morning of the day of the sacrifice, he cut his throat before shaving or cutting his hair. And he slaughtered his offerings with his own hand by standing them in a row, directing them towards the Qibla, then he ate and gave others to eat of their flesh”. 
(855) 151 Nafe’a reported that Abdallah Ibn Umar, practicing the wound on the hump of his offering, he said: “In the name of Allah! God is great". 
(856) 152 Nafe' reported that Abdallah Ibn Omar said: "Is an offering, any animal adorned, marked and which was accompanied to the station of Arafa". 
(857) 153 Nafe' also reported that: "Abdallah Ibn Omar covered his offerings with a fine linen cloth called "Qoubati", and sent to the Ka'ba, the carpets and the cover by which he wrapped it". 
(858) 154 Malek reported that he asked Abdallah Ibn Dinar: "What did Abdallah Ibn Umar do with the caparisons of his offerings, as long as the Ka'ba was converted from the cover"? He answered: "He gave alms of it". 
(859) 155 • Nafe' reported that Abdallah Ibn Umar said, "offerings and sacrificed animals must be at least three years old." 
(860) 156 - Nafe' also reported that Abdallah Ibn Omar only split the caparisons of his sacrificed animals, nor covered them, when he was about to leave, in the morning, from Mina to Arafa”. 
(861) 157 - Hisham Ibn Ourwa reported that his father said to his sons: “O son! that none of you offers for sacrifice what he is ashamed to offer to a generous man, for Allah is more generous than the generous, and He is the best to whom we make an offering. Chapter XLVII Of what to do for the animals sacrificed if they are unhealthy or lost. 
(862) 158 - Ourwa reported that the man in charge of keeping the offerings asked the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him be Allah's Grace and Peace): "O Messenger of Allah what shall I do with the animals of the offerings which have become ill"? He replied, “Any sacrificed animal that becomes sick must be slaughtered; then one throws his ornamental necklace in his blood, and one abandons it to be eaten by people”. 
(863) 159 - Ibn Chehab reported that Sa'id Ibn Al-Musaiab said: "The one who, voluntarily brings offerings and which are attacked by any evil, let him slaughter them, and leave them to be eaten by people; he owes nothing; but if he himself eats of their flesh or commands those who eat it, he must expiate this sin”. 
(864) 160 - Malek narrated from Thawr Ibn Zaid Al-Dayli and Abdallah Ibn Abbas, the same hadith”. 
(865) 161 - Malek reported that Ibn Shehab said: "Whoever makes an offering of an animal, as a fine or a vow, or an offering of a pleasure, and that this animal is, on the way, attacked by a evil, must in exchange, offer another. 
(866) 162 - Nafe' reported that Abdallah Ibn Omar said: "Whoever sacrifices a beast, then let it go astray or perish, if it is a wish, it is to be exchanged for another, and if it is offered voluntarily, he can, if he wishes, either exchange it for another, or do nothing". 
(867) 163 - Malek reported that he heard, versed men say: "He who makes an offering, as a sanction or sacrifice, cannot eat anything of his flesh". Chapter XLVIII Of the offering, of the one who in ihram trades with his wife. 
(868) 164 - Reported to Malek that Omar Ibn Al-Khattab, Ali Ibn Abi Taleb and Abu Houraira were asked about a man who had sex with his wife while in ihram”? They replied, "They will continue the rites of the pilgrimage until accomplishing it; but on the other hand they will have to make, the following year, another pilgrimage, and to offer an animal in expiation”. Ali Ibn Abi Taleb added: "If they do the talbiat for a pilgrimage the following year, they must remain separated until the accomplishment of the pilgrimage”. 
(869) 165 - Yahia Ibn Sa'id heard Sa'id Ibn al-Musaiab say (while speaking to devotees): “what do you think of a man who, in a state of ihram, had sex with his wife? As their response was suspended, Sa'id continued, "A man who while being in ihram had sex with his wife; he sent to consult the versed men in Medina. Some said: “they must separate until the following year”. Sa'id said, "Let them perform the rites of pilgrimage which their lack; end, let them go home." If they are able to make, the following year, the pilgrimage, that they accomplish it and that they advance an offering. They will make the talbiat of the place where they had begun their wasted pilgrimage, the year previous one, and will separate until their pilgrimage is completed". - Malek added, “They will come forward for an offering, a camel.” - Malek said about of the man, who had intercourse with his wife, during the pilgrimage, when he was at a distance between the surging of Arafa and the throwing of the pebbles, "that he must offer a sacrifice, and make the following year a pilgrimage". And he has added: "If he had intercourse with his wife after throwing the pebbles, he will have to make a pious visit, and an offering, without on the other hand having a subsequent pilgrimage". - Malek also said: “He who spoils his pilgrimage or his pious visit because of his relations with his wife, he owes an offering even if there has not been an ejaculation. If there was one, he owes an offering in the same way”. - Malek finally says: “If the man ejaculates without having carnal intercourse (having thought or looked at his wife) he owes nothing. If the man kisses his wife without ejaculation, he only owes an offering. On the other hand, the woman with whom her husband had carnal intercourse, while she was making a pious visit or a pilgrimage, thereby obeying his orders, she owes an offering, and a subsequent pilgrimage, if these reports took place either during the pilgrimage, or during a pious visitation. She owes another pious visit, catching up with the one who was wasted, and an offering”. Chapter XLIX Of the offering of one who misses a pilgrimage. 
(870) 166 - Soulaiman Ibn Yassar reported that Ayoub Al-Ansari went on a pilgrimage. Arriving at "Al-Nazia" on the road to Mecca, he lost his animals. On the day of the sacrifice, he came to Omar Ibn Al-Khattab and told him of the event. Omar said to him: “Perform the rites, which a man does during a pious visitation, and restore yourself to a state of desacralization. If, the following year, you are fit to make the pilgrimage, to accomplish it and to make the offering that will be possible for you”. 
(871) 167 Soulaiman Ibn Yassar reported that Habbar Ibn Al-Aswad came, on the day of the sacrifice, while Omar Ibn Al-Khattab was slaughtering an offering, and he said, “O prince of believers! We erred in counting, thinking that day was station day at Arafa! Omar answered him: “Go to Mecca, make with your companions, the processional rounds, and cut the throat of the offerings if you have some with you. Then shave, cut your hair and come home. As soon as the subsequent pilgrimage has arrived, make it and offer the offerings. Yes you do not find them, fast for three days during the pilgrimage, and seven more when you are at home”. Malek said, "He who combines the pilgrimage and the pious visit, then that he misses the pilgrimage, he must subsequently perform another one, combining the pilgrimage and the pious visit, and advancing two offerings: one for having combined the pilgrimage and the pious visit, the other for the pilgrimage which he had already missed» . Chapter L About the one who had sex with his wife before "tawaf el ifada" 
(872) 168 - Ata Ibn Abi Rabah reported that Abdallah Ibn Abbas was asked about a man who traded with his wife while he was in Mina, before breaking “tawaf el ifada””? He ordered him to slaughter a camel”. 
(873) 169 • Ikrima, the slave of Ibn Abbas reported: "I believe it was only Abdallah Ibn Abbas who said: 'He who had intercourse with his wife, before the flood "tawaf el ifada", that he makes a pious visit and an offering". 
(874) 170 - Malek said: “That he heard Rabi'a Ibn Abi Abdel-Rahman say that he is of the same opinion as Ibn Abbas, about what is narrated by Ikrima. Malek added: "That's the most pleasant thing for me to hear." Malek was asked at about a man who forgot the surge until he left Makkah and returned home”? He replied, “I think if he hasn't had intercourse with his wife, let him come back surging. Corn if he has had relations with his wife, let him come back to do the "tawaf el ifada", then let him make a pious visit and an offering. And he is not permissible that he buy his offering from Mecca and slay it there. However, if he had not brought it with him, from the place where he made the talbiat for a pious visit, he can buy it at the Mecca. Then he brings her outside the sacred enclosure for the take him back to Mecca to kill him there". Chapter LI Of the easiest offering. 
(875) 171 - Ja'far Ibn Muhammad reported from his father that Ali Ibn Abi Taleb said: "The simplest offering is a sheep." 
(876) 172 - It was reported to Malek that Abdallah Ibn Abbas said: "The simplest thing that can be offered as an offering is a sheep". Malek added: “It is which is most satisfying to me to have heard, for Allah the Blessed and Most High has said in His Book (meaning): “O you who believe! Do not kill game when you are in a state of sacredness. Whoever among you intentionally kills any, will send to the Ka'ba, as compensation, an animal from his herd, equivalent to the game killed, according to the decision of two honest men among you. An equivalent reparation will still consist in feeding a poor person or in fasting” Koran V, 95. And of all that is considered as offerings of compensation, the sheep, is among what Allah has called offering. And this is indisputable, moreover, how can anyone doubt that? Any compensation that would not be a camel or a cow, should at least be a sheep; and if this compensation does not require a sheep, then one must redeem oneself by a fast or by the food of the poor”. 
(877) 173 Nafe' reported that Abdallah Ibn Omar said: "The sacrifice easy to advance, will be a camel, or a cow". 
(878) 174 Abdullah Ibn Abi Bakr reported that a slave of A'mra, daughter of Abdel-Rahman, called Rouqaya told him that she went to Mecca with A'mra. She said, “A'mra entered Makkah on the day of 'Tarwia' and I entered with her. She made the processional tour around the House and the route between Al-Safa and Al-Marwa, then she entered the bottom of the mosque and asked me: "Do you have scissors"? I replied, "No, I don't." She replied, "Go, get me some." I found some, and gave them to him, she cut the plaits of her hair, and on the day of the sacrifice, she sacrificed a sheep. Chapter LII General offerings: 
(879) 175 - Sadaqah Ibn Yassar al-Makke reported that a man from Yemen with braided hair came to Abdallah Ibn Umar and said, “O Abu Abdel-Rahman! I am simply coming to pay a pious visit». Abdallah Ibn Omar answered him: "If I was with you, or if you had asked me, I you would have ordered to join her in a pilgrimage". The Yemenite replied: “I do what I do”. Abdallah Ibn Umar said to him: "For what has been cut from your hair, make an offering". A woman from Iraq asked him: “What should be his offering O Abou Abdel-Rahman”? He wondered, "His offering"? "Yes," she said. Abdallah Ibn Omar retorted: "If I find only one sheep to immolate, that will be preferable to me than to fast". 
(880) 176 Nafe' reported that Abdallah Ibn Omar said: "A woman in the state of ihram when she leaves her ihram cannot comb her hair until she cuts off a piece of the braids of her hair. And if she has an animal to sacrifice, she cannot cut her hair before she has immolated her sacrifice”. 
(881) 177 - Malek a reported that he heard some learned men say, “Man and woman should not associate for one offering (a cow or a camel); everyone must offer one”. Malek was asked at about him, to whom an offering has been entrusted, to be immolated during a pilgrimage, the latter; will he be able to immolate, after having completed his pious visit Umrah or will he have to delay it until he completes his pilgrimage and desacralizes himself from his pious visit? He replied, "indeed, he must delay her so that he immolates her during the pilgrimage, and once he has desacralized himself from his pious visitation". Malek also said: “he who owes an offering in order to expiate a hunt, or owes such offering for any other reason, his offering will only be sent to Makkah, and this is in accordance with the words of Allah Blessed and Most High (meaning) “He will send an offering to the Ka'ba”. But what is equivalent to the offering such as fasting or almsgiving, he can perform them outside of Mecca, where it seems good to him to perform them”. 
(882) 178 - Abu Asma, Abdallah Ibn Ja'far's slave reported that he was with Abdallah Ibn Ja'far, when they left Medina and passed by Hussain Ibn Ali, visited him, while he was sick in "Al-Souqia". Abdallah Ibn Ja'far remained with Houssein, and fearing to miss (the pilgrimage) he left him and sent to summon Ali Ibn Abi Taleb and Asma Bint Oumaiss who were in Medina. When they arrived, Houssein made a sign for his head, Ali thus ordered that it be shaved for him, then he sacrificed in his place at Al-Souquia by sacrificing a camel”. Yahia Ibn Sa'id a added: “And Houssein had at that time, accompanied Osman Ibn Affan for a trip to Mecca”. Chapter III Stations at Arafa and Muzdalifa 
(883) 179 - It was reported to Malek that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) said: “The whole mountain of Al-Safa is a station; be lifted up beyond the middle of Ourana. The whole mountain of Mouzdalifa is a station; rise beyond the middle of Muhassar”. 
(884) 180 - Hicham reported that Abdallah Ibn Al-Zoubair said: “Know that Arafa in its whole is a station, except the valley of Ouranna; and that Al-Muzdalifa is entirely a station, except the valley of Mouhassar”. Malek said: “Blessed and Most High Allah has said the meaning: “The pilgrim should abstain from any cohabitation with a woman, from perversity and disputes” Koran II, 197 . The cohabitation is besides any carnal relationship with the woman and it is Allah who is the most informed. Allah also said: the meaning "cohabitation with your wives is permitted to you during the night following the fast". Koran II, 187 . And the evil is everything that has been slain on standing stones and it is Allah who knows more than anyone, for he also said the meaning: "And what through evil was sacrificed to other than Allah". Koran VI, 145. As for disputes (jidel) during the pilgrimage, it is a fact that the Quraishites made a station near the sacred monument to Mouzdalifa in a place called Quzah, while the Arabs made the station to Arafa. They argued, some saying, “We are on the straight path,” others claimed, "no, it's us rather who are on the right path". "Allah Blessed and Most High, about them, said the meaning: “We have instituted a rite for each community; its members observe it. So let them not discuss with you the order received, Call on your Lord! You are on a straight path”. Koran XXII, 67, 68 .This is what disputes (jidel) refer to, which we regard as such and Allah is most informed. This is what I have heard of well-versed men”. Chapter LIV Various stations of man in a state of impurity and on his mount. 
(885) 181 - Malek was asked: "Can a man, being impure, make a station at Arafa, or at Muzdalifa, or throw the pebbles, or do the route between Al-Safa and Al-Marwa”? He answered: “All that a woman having her period can do, can also be done by a man in the state of ritual impurity; and he shall thereafter, no obligation. It is preferable for man to be ritually pure in performing these rites, and it is not becoming to him to be otherwise by doing it of his own free will. Malek was asked at subject of the man who makes the station, being on his mount; should it come down or will it stay up? He replied, "It is better that he be ridden, unless he or his mount is in trouble, for Allah accepts excuses." Chapter LV Of the one who misses the station at Arafa during his pilgrimage. 
(886) 182 Nafe’a reported that Abdallah Ibn Omar said: “He who, on the eve of Muzdalifa, before the appearance of the dawn, was not stationed in Arafa, will have missed his pilgrimage. And whoever makes the station at Arafa on the eve of Muzdalifa before the appearance of the dawn, will have accomplished his pilgrimage”. 
(887) 183 - Hisham Ibn Ourwa reported that his father said: "He who sees the appearance of the dawn, of the night of Muzdalifa, without having made the station at Arafa, will have missed his pilgrimage, the one who makes the station in Arafa, the night of Muzdalifa, before the appearance of the dawn, will have completed its pilgrimage”. - For the slave who is freed during the station at Arafa, Malek said: "This postage does not take the place of a pilgrimage, unless he has not already been in state of ihram, then he must be in state of ihram once freed, then he will make the station at Arafa, the same night, before the appearance of dawn. If he has done this, his pilgrimage will be admitted. But if he is not in the state of ihram before the appearance of the dawn, he will be just like the man who missed his pilgrimage. If he fails to make the station at Arafa before the appearance of the dawn on the night of Muzdalifa, this slave must do the pilgrimage later. Chapter LVI Of sending forth children and women. 
(888) 184 - Salem and Oubaidallah, the sons of Abdallah Ibn Omar, reported that their father sent his wives and children ahead of Muzdalifa to Mina, to perform the dawn prayer at Mina, and to throw the pebbles before the crowd". 
(889) 185 - Ata Ibn Yassar reported that a slave of Asma Ibn Abi Bakr told him: “We came to Mina, with Asma the daughter of Abu Bakr, while it was still night. I say to Asma: “we have arrived, and it is still night”? She answered me: “We did that, however, with a person who was better than you”. 
(890) 186 - It was reported to Malek that Talha Ibn Ubaidallah was sending his wives and children forward from Muzdalifa to Mina”. 
(891) 187 - Malek a reported that he heard some wise men say, that it is disapproved to cast the pebbles before the dawn of the day of the sacrifice has risen, for he who cast the pebbles, he shall be permitted to make the sacrifice of his offering (hady)". 
(892) 188 - Hisham Ibn Ourwa reported that Fatima Bint Al-Mounzer told him that she saw Asma, the daughter of Abu Bakr in Muzdalifa, ordering, the one who presided over the dawn prayers, to her as well as to her companions, to offer the dawn prayer at the appearance of dawn; then she climbed, leaving for Mina, without stopping”. Chapter LVII From the pace of the surge from Arafa to Mouzdalifa. 
(893) 189 - Ourwa reported that his father said, "I was sitting with Osama Ibn Zaid, he was asked how the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him be the grace and peace of Allah) looked during the Farewell Pilgrimage, in descending from Arafa to Muzdalifa”? He answered: "He went at first, at a slow pace, but when he found a space, he quickened his pace". 
(894) 190 • Nafe' reported that Abdallah Ibn Omar, hastened his mount when he was in the valley of Muhassar, at the speed of a thrown stone”. Chapter LVIII Sacrifice during the pilgrimage. 
(895) 191 - It was reported to Malek that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) being in Mina, said: the place of sacrifice, and every place in Mina is a place of sacrifice”. He also said, during a pious visit: "This is the place of the sacrifice" designating by this Al-Marwa, "And all the ways spacious areas of Mecca and its paths are places of sacrifice. 
(896) 192 - Amra Ibn Abdel-Rahman reported that Aicha, the mother of the believers said: "We left with the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) the last five nights of Zoul-Ka'da, only wanting the accomplishment of a pilgrimage. When we had arrived in Mecca, the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r ordered those who had not brought offerings to desecrate themselves after the processional rounds around the House and the route between Al-Safa and Al-Marwa". Aicha added: “On the day of the sacrifice, we were brought beef. I asked: “where does this come from”? I was answered: “The Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) had sacrificed this ox for his wives”. Yahia Ibn Sa'id said: “I related this hadith (the previous one to Kassem Ibn Muhammad who says: "She has brought you, by Allah, this complete hadith." 
(897) 193 - Abdallah Ibn Umar reported that Hafsa, the mother of believers said to the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah): "Why did people leave ihram for the pious visit, while you did not"? He replied: "I have felted my head and adorned my offering, but I cannot leave the ihram before I immolate it". Chapter IX Moments to immolate 
(898) 194 Ja'far Ibn Muhammad reported from his father that Ali Ibn Abi Taleb said that "the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the mercy and peace of Allah) immolated a part of the offerings and another sacrificed the remaining part". 
(899) 195 Nafe’a reported that Abdallah Ibn Umar said: "Whoever makes a vow of an offering, must surround his neck with two sandals, and make a wound on the hump and then he must immolate him near the House or at Mina on the day of the sacrifice, for there is no place for immolation except these two places. One who makes a wish to sacrifice a camel or a ox, can immolate him where he wants". 
(900) 196 - Hisham Ibn Ourwa reported that his father sacrificed the standing camel». Malek said, “He is not allowed no one to shave his head before sacrificing his sacrifice. On the other hand, it is not becoming to anyone to immolate his victim before dawn on the day of the sacrifice. No works such as immolation, putting on clothes, getting rid of filth and carving hair, is to be accomplished before the day of the sacrifice". Chapter LX The act of shaving one's hair. 
(901) 197 - Abdallah Ibn Umar reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him be Allah's grace and peace) said: “O Allah! Do mercy to those who have shaved”. His Companions added: "And those who have shortened their hair, O Messenger of Allah." He replied, “O Allah! Have mercy on those who have cut their hair. They continued: “and those who have shortened their hair, O Messenger of Allah”. It says to them for a third time: “and to those who are shortened”. 
(902) 198 - Abdel-Rahman Ibn Al-Kassem reported that his father entered Mecca at night, on a pious visit, made the processional rounds around of the Sacred House, and the journey between Al-Safa and Al-Marwa, was delayed until the morning, the fact of cutting their hair”. Then he added: “But he only returned to the Sacred House to make the processional rounds after having shaved his head”. And, he says, "He may have gone to the House, to pray an odd raka't, without coming near the House." Malek said, "At-tafath is cutting the hair, putting on the clothes, and any other act of that nature." Yahia said, “We asked to Malek about a man who forgot to shave or cut (his hair) at Mina in the pilgrimage. Is it permissible for him to do so in Makkah? He replied, "It is permissible for him, although it is preferable to me that it be done in Mina." Malek added: “What is indisputable to us, that no one shall shave his head or cut his hair before he has immolated his offering, if he possessed it. He is not permitted anything, which was forbidden to him before he left ihram. at Mina on the day of the sacrifice; and this is consistent with which is said by Allah Blessed and Most High: "Do not shave your head before the offering has reached its destination". Koran II, 196. Chapter LXI Shortening the hair. 
(903) 199 - Nafe' reported that Abdallah Ibn Omar, when he had finished fasting for the month of Ramadan, and intended to make the pilgrimage, he did not shorten (the hair) nor shave (the head) before he had performed the pilgrimage”. Malek said: “This is not an obligation for people”. 
(904) 200 - Nafe' reported that Abdallah Ibn Omar, during a pilgrimage or a pious visit, he shortened his beard and mustaches”. 
(905) 201 - Rabi'a Ibn Abdel-Rahman reported that a man came to al-Kassem Ibn Muhammad and said to him: "I made the Farewell tour with my wife, and I left the House, to go camping in the narrowness of a Mountain. Wanting to trade with her, she asked me: "I haven't shortened my hair yet." I cut off a lock of my teeth and then I lived with him”. Al-Kassem then began to laugh and he replied: "Order him to use the scissors to cut his hair". In this regard, Malek has said: "I prefer in this case, to sacrifice an offering", because Abdallah Ibn Abbas said: "Whoever forgets any rite, must make an offering". 
(906) 202 - Nafe' reported that Abdallah Ibn Omar, met one of his relatives named Al-mujabbar, who had already made the rounds of farewell tawaf al-ifada, without shaving or shortening himself out of ignorance. Abdallah ordered him to return to shave and shorten, then to be at the Sacred House again, to do the farewell rounds. 
(907) 203 - It was reported to Malek that Salem Ibn Abdallah, if he wanted to put himself in a state of ihram, had scissors brought, trimmed his mustaches and beard before going upstairs, and did the talbiat while being in ihram”. Chapter LXII Head felting. 
(908) 204 - Abdallah Ibn Omar reported that Omar Ibn Al-Khattab said: "Whoever wants to braid his hair, let him cut it, and let the braiding not don't be the same as the mix 
(909) 205 - Sa'id Ibn Al-Mussaiab reported that Umar Ibn Al-Khattab said, "Whoever ties his hair, or braids it or mixes it, will have to cut it." Chapter LXIII Of the prayer in the House of the shortening of the prayer and the celerity of the sermon on the day of Arafa. 
(910) 206 - Abdallah Ibn Umar narrated that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the mercy and peace of Allah) entered the Ka'ba, with Osama Ibn Zaid, Bilal Ibn Rabah and Osman Ibn Talha Al-Hajabi, closed the door and stayed there”. Abdallah added: “I asked Bilal who came out, what was the Messenger of Allah doing (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah)”? He replied, "He stood while having a column on his right, another on his left, and three others behind him. The House, at that time, was built with six pillars. Then he prayed”. 
(911) 207 - Salem Ibn Abdallah reported that Abdel-Malek Ibn Marwan wrote to Al-Hajjaj Ibn Youssef to follow the regulations of Abdallah Ibn Omar to the letter regarding the pilgrimage”. When it was the day of Arafa, Abdallah Ibn Omar came to AI-Hajjaj and I came with him, when the sun had already left the meridian. He stood near his tent, crying out, “Where is that man”? Al-Hajjaj came out, wrapping himself in a large veil dyed red and asked him: “What is the matter with you? O Abdel-Rahman”? He him answered: "It is the departure, if you want to follow the prophetic sunna". Al-Hajjaj to respond: "At this hour"? “Yes: said Abdallah”. “Well, wait until I pour some water on my head, then I go out,” replied Al-Hajjaj. Abdallah alighted from his mount awaiting Al-Hajjaj's exit; being among us, and walking between me and my father, I said to Al-Hajjaj: "if, today, you really want to follow the sunna, you will have to restrict the sermon and hasten the prayer". Al-Hajjaj then stared at Abdallah Ibn Omar, waiting for him to agree to my words. Abdallah, noticing this, said to him: Salem is right. ChapterLXIV Prayer in Mina on the day of "Tarwia" and that of Friday in Mina and Arafa. 
(912) 209 - Nafe’a reported that Abdallah Ibn Omar said the noon, asr, sunset, evening and dawn prayers in Mina, then left for Arafa at sunrise. Malek said, “What is unquestionably followed by us is that the imam will not have to recite aloud, the Koran, during the midday prayer in Arafa, and will do the Khutba in Arafa; besides, the prayer at Arafa is only that of midday; and if the day is suitable for a Friday, it will be a noon prayer but it has been shortened for travel reasons". Malek also said, "If Friday falls on a day of Arafa, or a day of sacrifice or one of the days of 'Al-Tachriq', the Imam should not perform it as a Friday prayer. ". Chapter LXV Prayer to Muzdalifa. 
(913) 209 - Abdallah Ibn Umar reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) joined the sunset and evening prayers, in Muzdalifa . 
(914) 210 - Kuraib, the slave of Ibn Abbas reported that he heard Osama Ibn Zaid say: "Running down from Arafa, and arriving at the defile of a mountain, the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) descended, urinated then made ablutions but not integral. I said to him: “Will you pray, O Messenger of Allah”. He answered me: “The prayer will be made in front of you”. He went up, and arriving at Muzdalifa, he descended and performed complete ablutions. Once the prayer is called, he performs that of sunset, then each of us stopped his horse at home. The Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) was then called to the evening prayer. (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) accomplishes it, without making any prayer between the two prayers”. 
(915) 211 - Abdallah Ibn Yazid Al-Khatmi reported that Abu Ayoub Al-Ansari told him that he did with the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) during the pilgrimage of Farewell, the two prayers of sunset and evening joined, in Muzdalifa”. 
(916) 212 - Nafe' reported that Abdallah Ibn Omar performed both sunset and evening prayers, e joined with Muzdalifa”. Chapter LXVI Prayer to Mina. 
(917) 213 - Malek reported that the inhabitants of Mecca, made in Mina, during the pilgrimage, two raka'ts until their departure to Mecca". 
(918) 214 - Ourwa reported from his father, that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) made the prayer, which in principle was four raka'ts, two raka'ts at Mina, and Abu Bakr as well as Omar Ibn Al-Khattab had done the same. Osman did it, likewise, from two raka'ts in Mina, at the beginning of his caliphate, but soon after he completed it at four. 
(919) 215 - Sa’id Ibn Al-Musaiab reported that when Umar Ibn Al-Khattab came to Makkah, he presided over the prayer making two raka'ts. Completing the prayer, he said to the faithful: “O Meccans! complete your prayer! As for us, we travel" Then Omar made two raka'ts in Mina without offering anything to the faithful". 
(920) 216 - Zaid Ibn Aslam narrated from his father that Omar Ibn Al-Khattab made in Mecca, a prayer of two raka'ts. Finishing the prayer, he addressed the faithful saying: “O Meccans, complete your prayer, for the rest of us we travel. Then he made two raka'ts to Mina, without saying anything to the faithful”. Malek was asked: “What was the number of the raka'ts of the prayer made by the Meccans at Arafa? Two or four raka'ts? What did the prince of the pilgrimage do if he was a Meccans? Did he pray the noon and asr prayers to Arafa, four or two raka'ts? How was the prayer of the Meccans on the days of the pebble pier? He replied, “As long as the Meccans were in Arafa and Mina, they would perform a two-raka't prayer, shortening the prayer until they returned to Mecca; and he was the same for the prince of the pilgrimage, if he were a Meccans; he shortened the prayer in Arafa, and during the days of Mina. But if someone lived in Mina, or stayed there, he made a complete prayer. On the other hand, the one who lived in Arafa, or who lived there, he also made a prayer of four raka'ts”. Chapter LX VII The prayer of the one who dwells in Mecca and Mina 
(921) 217 - Malek said: "Whoever arrives in Mecca in the month of Zou-Hijja and makes the talbiat for a pilgrimage, must make a complete prayer until he leaves Mecca for Mina where he shortens the prayer. This is due to the fact that he decided to stay in the same locality for more than four nights”. Chapter LXVIII From Takbir the days of “Tachrik” 
(922) 218 - Reported to Yahia Ibn Sa'id that Omar Ibn Al-Khattab, came out on the morning of the day of the sacrifice at the first ray of sunrise. He made the takbir and the people also did theirs. Then he came out again, the same day, while it was broad daylight, made the takbir, and the people did it the same way. Finally, he came out for the third time when the sun had disappeared, made the takbir and the people likewise did it, in such a way that this takbir being so high, he reaches Home. So we knew that Omar had come out to throw the stones. - Malek said, “What is traditional is that the takbir comes after the prayers. The first takbir is done by the imam and people accompany him after the midday prayer of the day of the sacrifice. As for the last, it is that of the imam in company of the faithful. This takbir is after the dawn prayer, on the last day of the “tachrik”, after which this takbir ceases”. - Malek added: "Takbir, should be done by men as well as women, on the days of the tachrik, whether you are in a group, or alone in Mina or elsewhere in any place. It is an obligation. And people to follow the imam of pilgrimage, and the people in Mina, because in case the latter return and leave the ihram, the others will be just like them, and will be desacralized. But he who does not make the pilgrimage, will not have to imitate them, making the takbir only during the days of the tachrik”. Malek said, "The days mentioned by Allah in the Quran are the days of the tachrik." Chapter LXIX From the prayer of "Al-Muzdalifa" and "Al-Muhassab" 
(923) 219 - Abdallah Ibn Umar reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the mercy and peace of Allah) made kneel his mount to “Al-Batha” in Zoul-Houlaifa, and prayed. Nafe' added: "Abdallah Ibn Omar did the same". Malek said, “He is not allowed no one to pass through "Al-Mu'arass", returning from the pilgrimage, without praying there.
