He also said: “He of you who fears debauchery” Coran IV, 25. Malek added, "Debauchery is adultery." Chapter XIII The man who marries a war captive and separates from her 
(1140) 31 - Abu Abdel-Rahman reported that Zaid Ibn Thabet said: “The man who absolutely repudiates a woman, captivates of war, then buys her, he cannot marry her again, before she has been married to another". 
(1141) 32 It was reported to Malek that Sa'id Ibn Al-Musaiab and Suleiman Ibn Yassar were asked about a man who made his slave marry a slave, after which the slave permanently repudiated her, and his master offered her to him (by releasing her); will he be able to marry her again as a captive of war? They replied, "No, he cannot have her in marriage until she has been married to someone else." 
(1142) 33 Malek reported that he asked Ibn Chehab on the subject of a man who had a wife, a captive of war whom he had for once repudiated, then he had bought, will he be able to marry her? He answered: “He can marry her, being a captive of war, and as long as he has not definitely repudiated her. But, in case she had been, he could not marry her, unless she was married to someone else”. - About the man who marries a slave (who was not of his affiliation) and who gives him a child, then he buys it for himself, Malek said: "She is not considered the mother of his child, having given it to him, while belonging to another . But if she will give him a child, she, captive of war but already of his belonging to him, after he has bought her, she will be legally the mother of his child”. - Malek added: "If the man buys himself a captive of war pregnant with him, and she will give birth to a child, she will be considered the legal mother of this child. What we think about it, and it is Allah who is Most informed». Chapter XIV The repulsion to have two women-sisters captives of war, or even of a mother and her daughter at the same time 
(1143) 34 - Utba Ibn Mas'ud reported according to his father, that Omar Ibn Al-Khattab was questioned about a woman and her daughter, captives of war, that a man cohabits one after the other”? He answered: "I don't like that we live together", and he forbids this fact". 
(1144) 35 - Kabissa Ibn Zouaib reported that a man had asked Osman Ibn Affan about two sisters, prisoners of war, can we have them together, both for wives”? Osman replied, “One verse authorizes it, another forbids it. As for me, I reject this doing”. Note: The verse which authorizes, and the other which prohibits are successively: “Women of good condition unless they are captives of war” Koran IV, 24. And “You are still forbidden two sisters together…” Koran IV, 23. Malek continued: "The man came out of Osman's house, and met one of the companions of the Messenger of Allah r (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him be Allah's Grace and Peace) whom he asked on the same subject. He answered him: “If this business belongs to me in person, and that I found someone doing that, I should have made him an example (not to be imitated by others, and to chastise him). Ibn Chehab added: "I think this companion was Ali Ibn Abi-Taleb". 
(1145) 36 - It was reported to Malek that al-Zoubair Ibn Al-Aawam was of the same opinion as Ali Ibn Abi Taleb. Malek said, "For the slave woman who belongs to a man who married her, and that he intends to do the same with his sister, the latter is forbidden to him as wife until her sister has been given in marriage to another, or until she has been completely freed from it, or until her freed either executed for the benefit of a sum provided and that by marrying her off with a slave who belongs to her, or belongs to another. Chapter XV The refusal of a man to marry a slave who was his father's wife 
(1146) 37 - It was reported to Malek that Omar Ibn Al-Khattab had offered a slave girl to his son, and told him, "Do not touch her, for I had already looked at her shameful parts." (.....) 38 - Abdel-Rahman Ibn Al-Mujabbar has reported that Salem Ibn Abdallah offered a slave to his son, and said to him: "Do not approach her, for I looked at her shameful parts, having longed to live with her". 
(1147) 39 - Yahia Ibn Sa'id reported that Abu Nahchal Ibn Al-Aswad said to Al-Kassem Ibn Muhammad: "I saw one of my slaves naked in the moonlight, wanting to have carnal intercourse with her, she cried: "I have my menstruation", I up, without touching her. Can I give it to my son to marry her? Al-Kassem forbids it. (.....) 40 - Ibrahim Ibn Abi Abla reported that Abdel Malek Ibn Marwan had offered one of his slaves to a friend. Asking her about it, he replied: “I wanted to give it to my son so that he could have such and such a relationship with her”. Abdel Malek answered him: “In fact Marwan was much more virtuous than you, he had offered his son a slave, saying to him: “Do not approach her, because I saw her legs all uncovered”. Chapter XVI The ban on marrying the slaves of the people of Livre (1148) - Malek said: "He is not lawful to marry a Jewish or Christian slave, for Allah Blessed and Most High has said in His Book: "The union with women believers and of good condition, and with the women of good condition belonging to the people to whom The Book was given before you” Koran V,5. They are indeed, free Jewish women and Christians. Also, Allah Blessed and Most High said: “Whoever among you cannot afford to marry believing women and in good condition, will take believing captives of war» Koran IV, 25. They are the believing captives». Malek added: “So then I think Allah has permitted the marriage of believing slaves, and prohibited the slaves of the People of the Book, namely, Jews and Christians”. These, Malek continues, are permitted to their masters, being war captives, but it is not permitted to marry a Magus-slave even if she is a war-slave. Chapter XVII Concerning women of good condition 
(1149) 41 - Ibn Chehab reported that Sa'id Ibn Al-Musaiab said: “The women said to be of good conditions are those who have given themselves for a legal marriage, and this amounts to the fact that Allah has forbidden fornication. 
(1150) 42 - It was reported to Malek that Ibn Chehab and Al-Kassem Ibn Muhammad said: "If the free man marries a slave and has had relations with her, she engages him in marriage". Malek said, "And anyone I've known said similarly, that the slave engages the free man in marriage. If he marries her, having carnal intercourse, she engages him in marriage”. Malek added: “A slave who marries a woman free by having relations with her, he engages her in marriage. But a free woman who marries a slave does not commit him in marriage, unless he is freed, and once he is, she can have him as a husband. But if he separates from her before he is freed, he is not engaged for marriage, waiting for him to be freed and marry a woman (whether free or slave ). - Malek also said: "If a slave woman finds herself the wife of a free man, who separates from her, before he liberated, her marriage to her, cannot make her a woman of good condition, as long as she is not liberated and her husband lives with her after his liberation, and this is the case which engages this slave in the marriage. Yet, a slave married to a free man, and freed while being his wife, even before he separated from her, he makes her a woman of good condition if he separates from her, he makes her a woman of good condition if he releases her as long as she is his wife, and he has had intercourse with her, after 'he had freed him'. - Malek finally said, "The free Christian woman or Jew, and the Muslim slave woman, engage the free man in marriage, if he marries one of them, and with whom, he has had reports". Chapter XVIII The marriage of enjoyment 
(1151) 43 - Ali Ibn Abi Taleb, may Allah be pleased with him, reported that the Messenger of Allah r (sallallahu alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) forbade the marriage of enjoyment, the day of Khaibar, and the eating of the flesh of domestic donkeys”. 
(1152) 44 - Urwa Ibn Al-Zoubair reported that Khawla Bint Hakim returning to Omar Ibn Al-Khattab, said to him: “Rabi'a Ibn Omaya made a temporary marriage with a woman and made her pregnant”. Omar Ibn Al-Khattab, went out, terrified, dragging his garment and said: “It is indeed the marriage of enjoyment; and if I had not preceded another to decide it, I would have knocked out the author”. Chapter XIX Marriage of slaves 
(1153) 45 - Yahia reported from Malek, that he heard Rabi'a Ibn, Abi Abdel-Rahman say: "A slave can marry four wives (just like a free man)". Malek said, "That's the best I've heard about it." - Malek also said: "The slave is different from the one who allows himself marriage, if his master allows him to marry (for four times), these marriages are legal, otherwise, the one who allows himself marriage can separate the slave from his wives, annulling these marriages so that they are legally concluded”. For the slave whose wife owns (either by gift, either by inheritance) or for the man who owns his wife, Malek said: “As long as one is the possession of the other, there will be separation and no longer divorce, but if each of them reverts to the other for the purpose of legal marriage, the separation between them will not is in no way considered a divorce”. - Malek finally said, “The woman who owns a slave, and is at the same time her husband, if she releases him while she is in her waiting period, the two separated, one of them can only come back to the other according to a new marriage”. Chapter XX Marriage of the polytheist in case his wife followed Islam before him 
(1154) 46 - Malek narrated from Ibn Chehab about women, who in the time of the Messenger of Allah r (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah), had followed Islam while being in their countries, and without them even having emigrated, whereas their husbands, when they had followed Islam, were impious. We cite among others, the daughter of Al-Walid Ibn Al-Moughira who was the wife of Safwan Ibn Oumayya. She had followed Islam on the day of the conquest (of Mecca) when her husband Safwan Ibn Oumayya had fled the land of Islam. The Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) sent his cousin Wahb Ibn Umair to him, giving him his own garment as security for Safwan Ibn Umayya, and the Messenger of Allah r (sallallahu alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) invited him to conversion to Islam and to come and find him, leaving him the choice to respond to this invitation or to have two months to deliberate. When Safwan had arrived, near the Messenger of Allah r (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Be upon him the grace and peace of Allah), putting on his garment, he called to him in front of everyone, saying: “O Muhammad! it is well, Wahb Ibn Oumair who brought me your garment claiming that you summoned me to your side by offering me two choices: either that I respond to your invitation (for follow Islam) or that I have two months to make up my mind". Ship it of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) exclaimed: "Come down, Abou Wahb (nickname of Safwan), the latter replied: “No by Allah, I will not come down until you clear up this matter”. The Messenger of Allah r (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) replied: "I rather grant you four months to make up your mind". The Messenger of Allah (sallallahu alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) went on an expedition to Hunain and went down to the Hawazin tribe. He asked Safwan to lend him a shield and a helmet. Safwan answered him: "Should I give them to you willingly or in spite of myself". The Messenger of Allah (sallallahu alayhi wa salam) (Upon him be Allah's Grace and Peace) replied, "Rather willingly," so Safwan lent him the shield and helmet he had, and then went out accompanying the Apostle of Allah r (sallallahu alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah), while being impious, and lived as a witness the battle in Hunain and Taif, refusing Islam, while his wife had already followed him (Islam) , without the Messenger of Allah r (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) cause Safwan and his wife to separate until he follows Islam and his wife remains with him for the purpose of marriage”. 
(1155) 47 - Malek reported that Ibn Chehab said: "A month passed between Safwan's conversion to Islam and that of his wife." • Ibn Chehab continued: "And we were never reported that a woman had emigrated to Allah and His Messenger, while her husband remained with the impious, without her emigration having separated between her and her husband, except if her husband had emigrated, before his wife's period of waiting had not ended". 
(1156) 48 - Ibn Chehab reported that Umm Hakim Bint Al-Hareth Ibn Hisham was the wife of Ikrima Ibn Abu-Jahl, and followed Islam, the day of the conquest of Mecca, her husband Ikrima fled from the country of Islam, and went to Yemen ,Oum Hakim left to join her husband in Yemen where she invited him to convert to Islam and he converted to it. He came to the Messenger of Allah r (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (On him the grace and peace of Allah) the year of the conquest of Mecca, the seer, the Messenger of Allah r (sallallahu alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) welcomed him with joy, without even putting on his coat Safwan made him an oath of allegiance and the Messenger of Allah r (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) preserved their marriage”. - Malek said: "If a man follows Islam before his woman, and that he invites her to convert to it, when she refuses to do so, they must be separated, for Allah Blessed and Most High has said in His Book: "Do not hold back by marrying those who are unbelievers" Coran LX, 10. Chapter XXI The wedding meal 
(1157) 49 - Anas Ibn Malek reported that Abdel Rahman Ibn Awf, came to the Messenger of Allah r (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) and a "Sofra" ( kind of perfume) enveloped him. The Messenger of Allah (sallallahu alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) asking him about this, he replied that he had married, The Messenger of Allah r (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said to him: "What was his dowry"? Abdel Rahman replied, "The weight of a gold core." The Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) replied: “Let the wedding meal, to be given, be at least of a sheep”. 
(1158) 50 - Yahia Ibn Sa'id narrated: "I was informed that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) gave meals where no found neither bread nor meat. 
(1159) 51 - Abdallah Ibn Omar reported that the Messenger of Allah r (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said: "When one of you is invited to a wedding feast, let there assist”. 
(1160) 52 - Al-Araj reported that Abu Huraira said: “The worst meal is that which is given at weddings, to which the rich are invited, and the poor are excluded. And he who, invited, does not go there, will have disobeyed Allah and His Messenger". 
(1161) 53 - Anas Ibn Malek reported: “A designer had invited the Messenger of Allah r (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) to a meal he had prepared for him. Anas continues: "I surrendered in the Messenger of Allah r (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) and accompanied him to this meal. He brought him some barley bread and a dish containing the squash. Anas said, I, saw the Messenger of Allah r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) look for the gourds around the dish, and since then, I have never ceased to love gourds». Chapter XXII The wedding 
(1162) 54 - Zaid Ibn Aslam reported that the Messenger of Allah r (sallallahu alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said: "When one of you marries a woman, or buys a slave, let him hold her by the forelock and call on Allah to bless her. And if he buys himself a camel, let him hold it by the top of its hump and take refuge with Allah from the demon”. 
(1163) 55 Abu Al-Zubair Al-Makki reported that a man betrothed his sister by confessing that she had committed adultery. Reporting this to Umar Ibn Al-Khattab, he called him and hit him, or as it is said, was going to hit him, saying: "What are you looking for in recounting this event"? 
(1164) 56 - Rabi'a Ibn Abi Abdel Rahman has reported that Al Kassem Ibn Muhammad and Ourwa Ibn Al-Zoubair said about the man who, married with four wives, having definitively repudiated one of them, can marry another if he wants, without him being obliged to wait for the waiting period of the person he dismissed to expire”. 
(1165) 57 Rabi'a reported, always about of the hatith above, which Al-Kassem Ibn Mouhammad and Ourwa Ibn Al Zoubair, gave to Walid Ibn Abdel Malek, the year of his arrival in Medina, their opinion, however Al-Kassem Ibn Muhammad added: "The man divorced his wife in several circumstances (varying therefrom, the term: definitely)” 
(1166) 58 - Yahia Ibn Sa'id reported that Sa'id Ibn Al Moussaiab said: “Three subjects, where one forbids to laugh, namely: Marriage, divorce, and postage”. 
(1167) 59 - Ibn Chehab reported that Rafe' Ibn Khadij had married the daughter of Muhammad Ibn Muslima Al-Ansari, and she had stayed with him until she had reaches a certain age. Marrying another younger, and having fallen in love with her, his former wife adjured him for divorce, so he did it once, then he neglected it, waiting for it to be lawful to him again, and took it back. But being of preference for the young, she asked him for a divorce, and he did it for only once, then again, resumed. Being much more affectionate for the young girl, she again asked him for the divorce, he said to her: "at your pleasure, however, there remains only one time for your repudiation to be final, so, if you want, you can stay at home even though I I'll always prefer the young one, otherwise I'll simply separate myself from you. She answered: “Rather, I stay with you in spite of everything, and for that, he keeps her”. Commenting on this Rafe' said: “I don't see that he has committed a sin by that”. MOUATTAA In the name of Allah the Merciful the Merciful Book 29 Final divorce. 
(1168) 1 - It was reported to Malek that a man said to Abdallah Ibn Abbas: “I divorced my wife by telling her you are divorced for a hundred times? What do you say about it”? He replied, "She was divorced after the third time, and for the ninety-seven times, you have sought thereby to defy the verses of Allah". 
(1169) 2 It was reported to Malek that a man coming find Abdallah Ibn Mass'oud, said to him: "I have divorced my wife for eight times". Ibn Mas'ud answered him: "What did they say to you in about it”? He replied, "I have been told that I cannot have her again until she marries another." Ibn Mas'ud continued: “They are right, because whoever divorces his wife according to what Allah has prescribed, he has complied with the clearly prescribed words. On the other hand, the one who gets lost in confusion, we attribute it to him. For that, don't lose yourselves in the confusion, and the rest of us will have to assume the responsibility. Your wife is already for you, just like what you were told”. 
(1170) 3 - Abu Bakr Ibn Hazm reported that Umar Ibn abdul Aziz said to him: "What do people say about the final divorce"? Abu Bakr replied: “I told him that Aban Ibn Osman held in consideration the first time the divorce is resolved. Omar Ibn Abdul Aziz replied, “If the divorce was resolved for a thousand times, the one that is final would have left nothing. Whoever pronounces the final divorce, will have already achieved his goal”. 
(1171) 4 - Ibn Chehab reported that Marwan Ibn Al-Hakam judged that the one who pronounces the final divorce from his wife, will have to pronounce it for three times”. Malek said, "That's the best I've heard." Chapter II Of the case of the abandoned and the disavowed and other similar cases 
(1172) 5 - Malek reported that we had done, for writes, namely to Omar Ibn Al Khattab, about a man in Iraq who said to his wife: “You are free”. Omar Ibn Al-Khattab wrote to his prefect: "Order this man, to find me in Mecca during the pilgrimage". As Omar made the processional tour around the House, the man passed him and greeted him. Omar said to him, “Who are you”? The man replied, "I am the one you ordered to meet you." Omar resumed: “I conjure you by the Lord of this House (The Ka'ba), what did you want to say to your wife by: “You are free”. The man answered her: "If you had conjured me in another place, I would not have told you the truth, I meant by that, divorced from her". Omar Ibn Al-Khattab retorted: "That is, in fact, what I wanted to know." 
(1173) 6 - It was reported to Malek that Ali Ibn Abi Taleb said, concerning the man who says to his wife: "You have forbidden me", that it is a divorce from her made for three times". Malek said, "That's the best I've heard about it." 
(1174) 7 - Nafe' reported that Abdallah Ibn Omar said concerning the cases of the abandoned and the disavowed, that it is a question of divorcing each of them, three times". 
(1175) 8 - Al-Kassem Ibn Muhammad reported that a man having a slave wife, said to his parents (of the woman): “She belongs to you”. People considered it a one-time divorce. 
(1176) 9 - Malek reported that he heard Ibn Chehab say about the man saying to his wife: "I disavow you and you disavow me" that it is about a divorce made three times, equivalent to a final divorce. Malek said of the man telling his wife: “You are abandoned, or disavowed or even repudiated, that it is a question of a divorce made for three times for the woman he cohabited, and we holds on to his confidence in the woman with whom he has not had relations, whether it is for a divorce of one or three times. Thus, if he is for the divorce made for one time only, he has to take an oath, and is in this case considered, as a suitor who has asked a woman in marriage. Because, for the woman with whom the husband had relations, she will only be divorced or disavowed three times. On the other hand, the one with whom he has not had relations, she will be abandoned, disavowed and divorced, for only once”. Malek said, "That's the best I've heard about it." Chapter III Leaving the subject of divorce to the wife 
(1177) 10 - It was reported to Malek that a man came say to Abdallah Ibn Omar: “O Abu Abdul-Rahman! As I had left the divorce to my wife, she divorced me. So what do you say on this subject"? Abdallah Ibn Omar answered: "I find that this divorce is final". The man resumed: “No! O Abu Abdul-Rahman, do not say that!” Abdallah Ibn Omar replied, “I didn't say that! It is rather you who assured it”. 
(1178) 11 - Nafe' reported that Abdallah Ibn Omar said: "Once a man charges his wife with divorce, the fate will be as she decides, unless the man disavows it by saying: “I only put her in charge of the divorce once, swearing to that fact, and in that case he can take her back, as long as she is in her waiting period”. Chapter IV Of the divorce done for once when this right is granted to the woman 
(1179) 12 - Kharija Ibn Zaid Ibn Thabet narrated: “I was sitting with Zaid Ibn when Thabet Muhammad Ibn Abi Atiq came to him with tears in his eyes. Zaid exclaimed, "What's the matter with you?" He replied, "I had given my wife the right of divorce, she divorced me." Zaid resumed: "What made you do that"? The man, to answer: "It's fate". Zaid replied, "You can do it again, come back, if you want, because it's just a divorce done for only once, but that being the case, you have the right to do so”. 
(1180) 13 - Abdul Rahman Ibn Al-Kassem reported according to her father, that a man "from Thaqif" had given his wife the right to divorce. She said to him, "I'm divorcing you." afterwards she said to him: "I divorce you", and he said to her: "Let the stone be in your mouth". Then she says, "I'm divorcing you." He replied, "Let the stone be in your mouth". They argued and went to Marwan Ibn Al Hakam who asked the man to swear, the latter declared that he only gave the right of divorce to his wife. for just once. Marwan asked him to bring her back to his house”. Abdul Rahman says, "Such a judgment pleased Al-Kassem and found it the most satisfying of all he heard about it." - Malek said, "And that's the best I've heard about it, and I liked it." Chapter V The case when giving the wife a divorce is inadmissible 
(1181) 14 - Abdul Rahman Ibn Al-Kassem reported according to his father that Aicha the mother of the believers had asked in marriage to Abdul-Rahman Ibn Abu Bakr, Qouraiba, the daughter of Abi Oumayya. He married her, however Quraiba's parents reproached Abdul Rahman and said, "We only agreed to this marriage because Aisha took the initiative (in the sense that Quraiba's parents admired the good character of Aisha)”. So Aicha went to bring back this which was said to Abdul Rahman who charged Quraiba with the law of divorce. Having accepted this marriage, she found herself engaged. 
(1182) 15 - Abdul-Rahman Ibn Al-Kassem reported according to his father, that Aisha, the wife of the Prophet (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) had made the marriage of Hafsa, daughter of Abdul Rahman with Al-Mounzer Ibn Al-Zoubair, while Abdul Rahman was in Damascus. Upon returning, Abdul Rahman said: “Can anyone afford to do this to me? Can we to be so indifferent in my opinion”? Aicha spoke about this matter to Al Mounzer Ibn Al-Zoubair who replied: "All that belongs to Abdul-Rahman". There Abdul Rahman says, "I never want to put off any business you have decided." This marriage was granted, without being considered a form of divorce”. 
(1183) 16 - It was reported to Malek that Abdallah Ibn Omar and Abou Houraira were solicited about the man, who giving the right of divorce to his wife, gives it back to her in turn without using it”? They replied: “This is not the case with a divorce”. (.....) 17 - Yahia reported that Sa'id Ibn Al Moussaiab said: "If the man grants the right of divorce to his wife, and that this one does not use this right, not even leaving her husband, it is not the case of a divorce" . Malek said: "A woman to whom the husband has given the divorce law, then they separate, without her admitting anything of this fact, the fact of divorcing is no longer up to her, but she can at the rigor to use it as long as they share the same habitat”. Chapter VI The annulment of the marriage was due to the solemn promise made to prohibit relations with the wife 
(1184) 18 - Ja'far Ibn Muhammad reported according to his father that Ali Ibn Abi Taleb said: "When a man undertakes by oath to abstain from his wife, he does not have to keep account of the divorce, even after the lapse of four months (considered for waiting period) as long as this man does not decide this fact. Thus, either he divorces, or he retains his marriage”. Malek said, "That's what's traditionally followed." 
(1185) 19 - Nafe' reported that Abdallah Ibn Omar said: “Any man who makes a solemn promise to deny himself his wife, after the four months have elapsed, he will be judged: either he divorces, or retains his marriage. And he does not have to pronounce the divorce if the four months have passed, unless he is judged”. (.....) 20 - Ibn Chehab reported that Sa'id Ibn Al Moussaiab and Abou Bakr Ibn Abdul Rahman said about the man who makes a solemn promise to forbid his wife: "If the four months of the waiting period have passed, his wife is already in divorce. And it is up to her husband to bring her back again, in case she is in the waiting period”. 
(1186) 21 - It was reported to Malek that Marwan Ibn Al-Hakam judged the case of the man who made the solemn promise to forbid himself from his wife as follows: "If the four months of the waiting period have passed, she is already repudiated, and that is to him again belongs the fact of having it, as long as it is in the period of waiting”. - Malek said: "And Ibn Chehab shared the same opinion". - Malek on the man who makes a promise solemn to forbid himself from his wife and is judged, then divorces her after the four months (waiting period) is up, and he makes her come back again said: “If this man has not had carnal intercourse with his wife until her waiting period has elapsed, it will never be possible for him to have her, nor to be with her again, unless he presents an excuse of sickness or prison or a similar excuse. In this case having it again is final. On the other hand, if the woman's waiting period elapsed, after which he married her, and he had no intercourse with her until the period waiting either elapsed, the man is to be judged. If he has not taken her again, he is already divorced from her, for his solemn promise to forbid himself from his wife has already been made, since the four months have passed, without he has the right to bring her back. Because, in this case, he married her, then divorced without having had carnal relations with her, consequently, the waiting period is no longer considered, and he does not have to do it come back again”. Malek said about the man who promises solemn ban from his wife, then is judged after the lapse of four months, he divorces her then brings her back without him had carnal intercourse with her, and that the four months had elapsed before the waiting period had already ended (for the case of a pregnancy for example), that this man is not subject to a judgment, and is not required to divorce. On the other hand, if he had sex with her before the waiting period has not been completed, he is entitled to have it again. But if the waiting period has already ended before her husband has had intercourse with her, he cannot, in this case, take her back”. "And that's the best I've heard about it." - Malek also said: “Regarding the man who makes solemn promise to forbid his wife, then divorce her, and that the four months (known as the waiting period) have elapsed before this period has even ended, this is a divorce done for twice, if the man is called to be judged and he has not had relations with his wife. If the waiting period ends before the elapse of the four months, this man's engagement is not taken for a divorce, because the four months after which the woman was to be forbidden to her husband, have passed, without her still being married to him ". Malek added: “He who makes a solemn promise to forbid his wife for a day or a month, then stay there until the four months have passed, this is not taken for a commitment, because it will be considered such, for the one who made a promise, for more than four months. On the other hand, the one who makes a solemn promise to abstain from his wife for four months, or less than that, I do not see that he is subject to a commitment, because of the As soon as this duration has already passed, his commitment is no longer considered, and consequently he will not be subject to a judgment”. - Malek finally said: “He who makes a solemn promise to his wife, to forbid himself from her, until the weaning of his child, this case is not considered as a commitment. And I was informed that Ali Ibn Abi Taleb, asked about this, he did not consider it a commitment”. Chapter VII Of the commitment of the slave (.....) 22 - Malek asked Ibn Chehab about the commitment of the slave" He replied: "It is almost similar to the commitment of the free man, and he will even be an obligation . However, it is only valid for two months”. ChapterVIII About the free man who compares his wife to his own mother's back 
(1187) 23 - Sa'id Ibn Amr Ban Solaim Al-Zouraqi a asked Al-Kassem Ibn Muhammad about a man who divorced his wife, if he marries her”. Al-Kassem Ibn Muhammad replied: "He is like one who compares a woman to the back of her own mother and marry her”. However, Omar Ibn Al-Khattab gives him the order, that if he ever marries her, that he does not touch her, before making expiation. 
(1188) 24 - It was reported to Malek that a man asked al-Kassem Ibn Muhammad and Solaiman Ibn Yassar about a man who, before marrying his wife, compares her to my mother's back”. They replied, "If he has married her, he will not have to touch her until he make atonement”. 
(1189) 25 - Hisham Ibn Ourwa reported from his father that he said about the man who compares his four wives, at the same time: on the back of his own mother that this man will only have to make one atonement”. (.....) 26 - Malek narrated from Rabi'a Ibn Abi Abdul-Rahman, the same hadith». Malek said, “This is what is followed in Medina. Allah, Blessed and Most High, according to His words, said - about the expiation of the oath of the man who compares his wife to his mother's back: "The freeing of a slave before he touches his wife", “If he does not find it, a fast for two months in a row before he touches his wife, and if he is unable, he is responsible for feeding sixty poor people”. - Concerning the man, who, in different circumstances compares his wife: "On my mother's back", Malek said: "He has only one expiation to make". Now if he says this then atones then repeats it after his first atonement, he must again make atonement”. - Malek added: “Whoever compares his wife to the back of his own mother, then touches her before making atonement, he will have only one atonement to make. Then he forbids his wife until he makes atonement and asks Allah's forgiveness. And that's the best I've heard about it. - Malek also said: - For women who are told: "Be for me like my mother's back” and whether they are forbidden to men, or others who are foster sisters, or relatives, they are all considered under the same conditions”. - This way of divorce is only allowed to men”. - For the words of Allah Blessed and Most High (meaning) "Those who repudiate their wives with the formula: "Be for me like my mother's back", and who go back on what they said" Coran LVIII, v.3. Malek said: “I have heard in the interpretation of this verse, that it is the act of the man who formulates this repudiation and then decides to keep his wife and have intercourse with her. If so, he owes an atonement, but if he divorces her without that he has had relations with her, and without his having decided to keep her, he will not have to expiate. If he marries after that, he will not touch her with her until he makes the atonement of one who compares his wife: “to the back of his own mother”. - Malek said, "The man who formulates such repudiation of his wife (slave), if he wants to have intercourse with her, he must make atonement before he touches her”. - Malek finally said, "This way to divorce is only considered an oath of repudiation if the man wants to cause harm without going back on his oath”. 
(1190) 27 - Hisham Ibn Ourwa reported that he heard a man ask Ourwa Ibn Al-Zoubair about a man who said to his wife: “Any woman I marry after you, will be for me like my mother's back". Ourwa answered him: "It is enough for him for the expiation, to free a slave". Chapter IX About the slave who compares his wife to his mother's back 
(1191) 28 - Malek reported that he asked Ibn Chehab on the repudiation of slaves according to the formula: "Be for me like my mother's back". He said to him, "They are subject to the same conditions as a free man." * Malek said: * “The slave is considered under the same conditions as a free man”. * “This kind of repudiation is an obligation for the slave, and must on the other hand expiate it by fasting for two months in a row”. * “When the slave compares his wife to the back of his own mother", this is not considered as an oath of repudiation, because if he was going to make the fast which is that of the expiation of two months, just like a free man, he would have to divorce him before he finished his fast". Chapter X About Options 
(1192) 29 - Al-Kassem Ibn Muhammad reported that Aisha, the mother of the believers, said, “About Barira there were three judgments, one of which demanded his release. Giving him the choice, she opted to keep her husband. So, the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said: “Patronage is the right of the person who freed”. Then the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) On him the grace and peace of Allah entered while a pot full of meat was boiling. He was served bread and food which was at (Aicha's) house. The Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Be upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said: "Did I not see a pot where was the meat? He was answered: "Yes, certainly, O Messenger of Allah, but this meat is an alms given to Barira, and you, you do not do not eat what is alms”. Then, the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Be upon him the mercy and peace of Allah) replied: “She is an alms for Barira, and for us a gift”. 
(1193) 30 - Nafe' reported that Abdallah Ibn Omar said about the slave married to a slave and she is freed, the slave will have the choice to keep her husband, or to divorce him, as long as he has not touched her” (after being freed). Malek said, "If her husband touched her, and she claims to be ignorant, of having had a choice, she is in this case accused, and we do not believe what she claimed of ignorance. And it is no longer up to her to divorce her husband after he touched her. 
(1194) 31 - Ourwa Ibn Al-Zoubair reported that a slave belonging to Bani Adii, known by Zabra' told him that she was a slave herself. Freed, she continues, Hafsa, the wife of the Prophet (upon him the grace and peace of Allah) summoned me and said: "I am going to tell you something, and I do not like you to make a decision of your fate. It's up to you to decide, except if your husband touched you. Because, if that's the case, you won't have anything left to decide”. I answered him: "I am for the divorce, the divorce and the divorce". So-, she divorced him, for three times». 
(1195) 32 - It was reported to Malek that Sa'id Ibn Al-Mussaiab said: "Any man afflicted either with madness or an illness, and marrying, it is up to his wife to choose whether to stay at home. him, or to be divorced". 
(1196) 33 - Concerning the female slave who is married to a slave, and then finds herself freed before there is consummation of the marriage or her husband has not yet touched her, Malek said, "If she opts for her own person, she will have no dowry , and she will be divorced for once. Such is the tradition that we follow in Medina”. 
(1197) 34 - Malek reported that he heard Ibn Shehab say: "If the man gives his wife the right to choose, (between staying with him or being separated) and she chooses to stay with her husband, this case is not taken for a divorce case. - Malek said, "That's the best I've heard." - About the one given the choice, Malek said, "If her husband gives her the right to choose, and she will choose her own person, that's a thrice-done divorce. And if her husband says to her: "I only gave you, for once, the right to to choose, he said, is not to be considered”. And that's the best advice." - Malek finally said, "If her husband gives her a choice, and she's like, "So I accepted only once", and that her husband refuses him saying, "Rather, I give you the choice for three times", and that she shows herself refusing except for one, she stays with him as a bride, and therefore, it is no longer a separation" if Allah wills”. Chapter XI About “khol”(1) (1) Khol is the fact that a woman asks her husband, to free herself from the marital bond, and in exchange, she will give up all her rights to him. 
(1198) 35 - Yahia Ibn Sa'id reported that Amra Bint Abdul Rahman told him that Habiba Bint Sahl Al Ansari had married to Thabet Ibn Qais Ibn Chammas. When going out for the dawn prayer, the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) lives at his door, Habiba Bint Sahl, while it was still dark. The Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him be Allah's grace and peace) said to him, "Who is it?" She replied: "It is I, Habiba Bint Sahl, O Messenger of Allah". He replied: "What have you"? She said to him: “Neither I nor Thabet Ibn Qais, we get along as husbands”. When her husband Thabet Ibn Qais came, the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said to him: "Here is Habiba Bint Sahl, who has just told me, what Allah willed it to be", Habiba said: "O Messenger of Allah, all what he gave me, I have at home”. Addressing Thabet Ibn Oais, the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) said to him: "Take back everything you gave him", Thabet took it back and Habiba stayed with her parents (separated from her husband). 
(1199) 36 - Nafe' reported that a slave of Safia Bint Abi Oubaid divorced her husband, giving him all her rights. Abdallah Ibn Omar did not show himself against”. Malek said, about the woman who, to have the divorce from her husband, gives him all his rights, that, if it turns out that he causes her harm, that he oppresses her, and that he is known for his severity, divorce is a right , and he has to give her back what she Gave back". Malek said, "And that's what I heard, and who was following in Medina." Malek added: "There is nothing wrong with the wife, who wants a divorce from her husband, that she give him back more than he gave her”. Chapter XII Of the divorce of the one who is for the Kohl 
(1200) 37 Nafe' reported that Roubaié Ibn Mu'awaz Ibn Afra, had come with her wave to Abdallah Ibn Omar, telling him that she had asked for a divorce from her husband in the time of Osman Ibn Affan, and giving him back all his rights. Osman Ibn Affan, learning this, did not show himself against it. Abdallah Ibn Omar said: "His Waiting period is that of a divorced woman'. (.....) 38 - It was reported to Malek that Sa'id Ibn Al-Mussaiab, Soulaiman Ibn Yassar and Ibn Chehab said: "The waiting period of a woman who asks for Kohl' is the same as that of a divorcee, namely, that of three periods". - Malek said, “About the woman asking for the divorce, and in exchange she will hand over all her rights, which she cannot return to her husband, until she has married again. If she is married, then separated from her husband, without his touching her, she will not have to undergo a second waiting period, and she will take the first period into account”. Malek added, "That's the best I've heard about it." - Malek finally said, "If the woman asks her her husband divorces her by giving her part of his property, on condition that he repudiates her, and that her husband divorces her for three successive times, the divorce is to be considered. But if the divorce was made intermittently, it is not to be considered”. Chapter XIII Of the subject of the anathema (curse or reprobation following adultery) 
(1201) 39 Ibn Chehab reported that Sahl Ibn Sa'd Al-Saidi told him that Ouwaimer Al-AjIani came to Assem Ibn Adi Al-Ansari and said to him: “O Assem, what do you decide about a man who finds his wife with another? Will he kill this man and face the executive sentence? Or else, tell me, what should he do? Assem ask for me this question to the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam)”? Reporting this matter to the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) he was repelled and disgusted with such that Assem felt pain from what he had heard from the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah), Assem returned to his home, Ouwaimer came to his house and said to him: “O Assem, what was the response of the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah)”? Assem replied: "Your question did not bring me any good, because the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) hated the question I asked him”. Ouwaimer replied, "By Allah, I will not be silent only after asking him the question, personally". Ouwaimer went in search of the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him be Allah's Grace and Peace) until he found him in the midst of a crowd so he said, "O Messenger of Allah, what do you say about of a man who finds his wife with another man? Will he kill him and then he will have to be executed himself, what should he do”? The Messenger of Allah (sallallahu alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) replied: "A verse has been revealed to me about you and your wife, so go and bring her"! Sahl continued: "The two spouses presented themselves before the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the mercy and peace of Allah) and took an oath of anathema, while I was present with people. Once they finished their anathemas of reciprocity, Ouwaimer said: "O Messenger of Allah I would have lied, if I had restrained him", so he divorced her by three times, before the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the mercy and peace of Allah) orders him to do so". Ibn Chehab added: "And such was the sunnah of anathemas." 
(1202) 40 - Nafe' reported that Abdallah Ibn Umar narrated that a man has, at the time of the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah), accused his wife of anathema, in refusing to recognize the child as his own. The Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) separated them by attributing the child to the wife”. - Malek said: “Allah Blessed and Most High has said (meaning): “As to those who accuse their wives without having other witnesses than themselves: the testimony of each of them will consist in testifying four times before Allah that they are truthful and a fifth time to call the curse of Allah that they have uttered a lie; the chastisement of the woman will be averted, if she testifies four times before Allah that her accuser lies and a fifth time to call upon herself the wrath of Allah, if he is the one who is truthful” Koran XXIV 6-8. - Malek said, "The sunna followed in Medina is that those who are accused of anathema, they are forbidden to have intercourse with each other. If he contradicts himself, he will be flogged and the child will be attributed to him. He won't be able to have his wife again. And it is the tradition, followed in Medina, which is neither to be doubted nor disputed». - Malek also said: - “If the man separates definitively from his wife, in such a way that he can no longer bring her back, then he refuses her pregnancy, he can accuse her of anathema if she is pregnant and if she claims that it comes from her cohabitation with him, unless it is attested that it comes back to a period which is doubtful, and that the man in being ignorant". Such is the tradition followed, and which I have heard from versed men. - “If the man accuses his wife of infidelity after that he divorced her three times, while she is pregnant, as for him, he admits that this pregnancy comes from him then claims that he saw her fornicate before he separated from her , he will be scourged, and will not have to accuse him of anathema. But if he disavows his wife's pregnancy after he has been divorced from her three times, he must accuse him of anathema". "And that's what I heard." - "And the slave is on an equal footing with the free man, as regards defamation and accusation of anathema. He acts just like a free man with regard to the accusation of anathema, which is not the case with defamation, namely that he is not subject to flogging (in case the 'accused female slave, is in fact innocent)'. - “And the woman let her be a Muslim slave, or a free woman, Jewish or Christian, she may accuse a free Muslim man of anathema if he marries one of them carnal relationships. For Allah Blessed and Most High has said in His Book: “As for those who accuse their wives”, as long as these women are wives”. “And such is the tradition followed”. - “If the slave marries a free woman Muslim or a Muslim slave, or a free Jewish or Christian woman, he must take the oath of anathema". - “About the man who takes an oath anathema to his wife and then goes back on his oath by contradicting himself after one or two oaths, without him calling on the curse of Allah on him for the fifth time, Malek said: "If he returns on his oath before he curses, he must be scourged, and no one separates between him and his wife”. - “About the man who divorces his wife, and who, after three months had passed she confessed to being pregnant, Malek said, "If her husband denies this pregnancy, he must take an oath of anathema." - “Concerning the war captive to whom her husband takes an oath of anathema, then buys her," Malek said, "He must not have intercourse with her, even if she is in his possession, for the sunna requires that two spouses who have sworn oaths of anathema, can never be with each other again”. - "Finally Malek said, 'If the man accuses his woman of anathema before having intercourse with her, she will only have half the dowry”. Chapter XIV The right of inheritance of the child falling to two subjects separated by anathema 
(1203) 41 - It was reported to Malek that Ourwa Ibn Al Zoubair said about the adulterine child or child accused of being of anathematized parents, if he dies, his mother inherits him according to the rights prescribed in the Book of Allah Most High, and it is the same for his uterine brothers who will have their right of inheritance, as for the rest of the family. he inheritance will go to the relatives of the mother if she is a freedwoman, but if she is an Arab woman, she will have with the uterine brothers of her child their right of inheritance, and for what remains, it goes to the Muslims”. Malek said: “And I was told that Suleiman Ibn Yassar was of the same opinion, and this is still what I saw followed by the versed men in Medina”. Chapter XV The Divorce of the Virgin 
(1204) 42 - Muhammad Ibn Abdul-Rahman Ibn Thawban reported that Muhammad Ibn lyas Ibn Al-Bukair said: "A man divorced his wife for three times before having carnal intercourse with her and then he had wanted to marry her again, so he came to ask about it, versed men and I kept him company. He asked for Abdallah Ibn Abbas and Abu Houraira at this subject, who replied, "We are considering not allowing you to marry her, until she is married to another and then divorced". He went on: "But I only divorced her for a one time". Ibn Abbas said: "You delivered from your hand the best you possessed". 
(1205) 43 - Ata' Ibn Yassar reported: "A man came to ask Abdallah Ibn Amr Ibn Al'As about a man who divorced his wife for three times, before he touched her". Ata' said: "It is only for once that a divorce is made from a Virgin". Abdallah Ibn Amr Ibn Al'As protested and said to Ata: “You are only a reporter of hadiths. A one-time divorce imposes a new marriage and a new dowry. But the divorce made for three times, the woman will be forbidden to the husband until she is married to another man than her husband (then divorced). 
(1206) 44 - Boukair Ibn Abdallah Ibn Al-Achaj a reported that Mu'awia Ibn Abi Ayash Al-Ansari was sitting in the company of Abdallah Ibn Al-Zoubair and Assem Ibn Omar Ibn Al-Khattab, when Muhammad Ibn lyas Ibn Al-Bukair came to them and said: "A man of the Bedouins divorced his wife for three times, before he had intercourse with her, so what do you think about him”? Abdallah Ibn Al-Zoubair said: "We cannot decide this matter, so go to Abdallah Ibn Abbas and Abu Houraira, whom I have just left at Aicha's, and ask them the question then come back to bring us the answer". He left and asked them the question. Ibn Abbas said to Abu Huraira: "O Abu Huraira, answer him, here is a difficult question that has been put to you". Abu Hurairah replied, "A divorce done once, imposes a new marriage and a new dowry, and one that is done three times, will make the woman forbidden to her husband, until she is married from another man than him (and divorced)". Malek said: “Such was the tradition followed in Medina. As for the woman who had already been married to a man without his having had relations with her, she will be treated like a virgin: divorced once, she must marry again and have a new dowry. , divorced three times, she will be prohibited for her husband until she is married to another man than him (and then divorced). Chapter XVI The sick man who divorces his wife 
(1207) 45 –Yahya reported from Malek who took it reported from Ibn Chehab that Talha Ibn Abdallah Ibn Awf who knew more about it than them and Abu Salama Ibn Abdul Rahman Ibn Awf related that Abdul Rahman Ibn Awf had divorced his wife definitively, because he was sick. On his death, Osman Ibn Affan gave the woman her share of the inheritance, when her waiting period had already ended”. 
(1208) 46 - Al-A'raj reported that Osman Ibn Affan gave the share of the inheritance to the wives of Ibn Moukmel, while the latter had divorced them, being ill. 
(1209) 47 - Malek reported that he heard Rabi'a Ibn Abi Abdul Rahman say, "I was told that Abdul Rahman Ibn Awf's wife asked him to divorce her", he replied, "Once you get your period and purify yourself, do -Me know". Now, she only had her period once Abdul Rahman fell ill, when she got cleansed, she let him know, so he divorced her permanently or even divorced her once which was the third, because he was sick. Osman Ibn Affan gave him his share of the inheritance when his waiting period was already over”. 
(1210) 48 - Yahia Ibn Sa'id reported that Muhammad Ibn Yahia Ibn Habban said: "My grandfather Habban had two wives: a Hashemite and an Ansarian, he divorced the Ansarian so that she was still feeding her baby. A year ended, and this woman did not have her period, and then the man died. She said: “I have the right to inheritance, as long as I haven't had my period”, the two women argued and then went to report the matter to Osman Ibn Affan. Having given the right of inheritance to the Ansarian, the Hashemite blamed Osman who said: "Such was the decision taken by your cousin, who imposed it on us", designating by the cousin, Ali Ibn Abi-Taleb" . (Of the same descent as the Hashemite). (1211) 49" Malek reported that he heard Ibn Chehab say: "If a sick man divorces his wife three times, she will have the right to inheritance". - Malek said: “And if he divorces her, being sick and that before he has relations with her, she will be entitled to half the dowry, to her share of the inheritance and she will have to consider his waiting period. But if he has had relations with her, then he divorces her, in this case, she will be entitled to the full dowry and her share of the inheritance”. "And the tradition followed is that the virgin and the one who was already married should be treated alike, concerning the above question". Chapter XVII The necessities enjoyed by divorced women 
(1212) 50 - It was reported to Malek that Abdul Rahman Ibn Awf divorced his wife, gave her a slave for enjoyment”. (.....) 51 - Nafe' reported that Abdallah Ibn Omar said: "To every divorced woman, we must grant what is necessary (living expenses) except for the one to whom we have resolved a dowry and that this woman was divorced without being touched, she will have half of what we gave her solved". 
(1213) 52 - Malek reported that Ibn Chehab said: "Every divorced woman should enjoy a certain amount to spend." - Malek also said, "I was reported that Al-Kassem good Muhammad was of the same opinion regarding this matter”. - Malek finally said, “From the tradition followed, it is that the enjoyment of what is necessary has not been quantitatively limited, neither a little nor too much”. Chapter XVIII The subject of the slave's divorce 
(1214) 53 - Solaiman Ibn Yassar reported that Noufai' was, it seems, a contracted slave or freedman of Oum Salama, the wife of the Prophet (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) - married to a free woman. He divorced her twice and then wanted to take her back, the wives of the Prophet (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) ordered him to go to Osman Ibn Affan to tell him about this matter. He the crossed at “Al-Daraj” (a place in Medina), holding hands with Zaid Ibn Thabet. He addressed the question to them where both answered him: “She is forbidden to you, she is forbidden to you”. 
(1215) 54 - Sa'id Ibn al-Musaiab reported that Noufai', an indentured freedman belonging to Oum Salama, the wife of the Prophet (Upon him be Allah's grace and peace), divorced a free woman for twice. Consulting on this subject Osman Ibn Affan, he answered him: “It has become forbidden to you”. 
(1216) 55 - Muhammad Ibn Ibrahim Ibn Al-Hareth Al-Timi reported that a contractual freedman at Oum Salama, the wife of the Prophet (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him be Allah's Grace and Peace), said Noufai', consulted Zaid Ibn Thabet saying to him: “I have divorced twice from a free woman. Zaid replied, "She has become forbidden to you." 
(1217) 56 - Nafe' reported that Abdallah Ibn Omar said: “If a slave divorces his wife twice, she will be forbidden to him until she is married to another than him, whether this woman is free or a slave. Then, the waiting period of the free woman is three periods, and that of the slave is two”. 
(1218) 57 - Nafe' reported that Abdallah Ibn Omar said: "If the owner of a slave allows him to marry, the latter will have his own right of divorce, and no other man will wrest this right. There is nothing wrong with the owner of the slave marrying the daughter of his male slave or of his female slave. Chapter XIX Necessary expenses of which a pregnant and divorced slave can receive - Malek said: "It is not obligatory for a free man, or for a slave, divorced from a slave or a captive, nor to a slave who has definitively divorced a free woman, to give a portion of food to the woman even if she is pregnant, as long as he cannot not have it again". - Malek also said: "It does not belong to a man free to take care of a nurse for his child while he is a slave with other people. It is not permissible for a slave to spend his property on what belongs to his master, unless the latter authorizes him to do so”. Chapter XX The waiting period of the one whose fate of the husband is unknown 
(1219) 58 - Sa'id Ibn Al-Musaiab reported that Omar Ibn Al-Khattab said:, "Any woman who has lost her husband without knowing what is his fate, must put herself on hold for four years, then must observe her waiting period for four months and ten days, and after that she may marry”. - Malek said, “If the woman, after her period wait is over, gets married and whether or not her husband had sex with her, her previous husband will not be able to take her back". - Malek added: “Such is the tradition followed, but if her first husband joins her, before she marries, he will have the best right to have her again”. - Malek also said, "I realized the people who protested against what others reported, about what Omar said: "The first husband being present, (his wife being still unmarried) he will have the choice of being or for the dowry to be paid , or to have his wife again”. - Malek finally said, "I have been told that Omar Ibn Al-Khattab said: "For the woman whose husband divorced her, while away, then, may he want her again without her learning of his decision, although she had previously received her divorce him, and whether she was subsequently married again, whether or not the other husband had intercourse with her, the first husband who had already divorced her, can no longer have her again. - "That's the best I've heard about the missing husband," Malek said. Chapter XXI Menses, period of widowhood of a divorced woman, and divorce with a woman who is menstruating 
(1220) 59 - Nafe' reported that Abdallah Ibn Omar at the time of the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) divorced his wife, while she was menstruating. Omar Ibn Al-Khattab questioned the Envoy of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) about this, he said to him: “Command him to have it again, to hold her until she is cleansed, then she has her period, then is cleansed, and finally, if he wills, he can keep her. Otherwise, he can divorce her, but before he touches her. Such is the waiting period which Allah has required to be a norm for those who divorce wives”. 
(1221) 60 - Urwa Ibn al-Zoubair reported that Aicha, the mother of the believers received Hafsa Bint Abdul Rahman Ibn Abu Bakr al-Siddiq at her home (following her divorce) when she had her period for the third time”. Ibn Chehab said: "This was reported to Amra Bint Abdul Rahman who replied: “Ourwa spoke the truth”. Discussing this subject with Aisha, people said to her: "Blessed Allah and Most High has said in His Book: "The divorced women will wait three periods" Koran II, 228. Aisha replied to them: "It is true what you say, however do you know what is of these periods? It is in fact about three periods and their cessation”. 
(1222) 61 - Malek reported that Ibn Chehab said: "I heard Abu Bakr Ibn Abdul Rahman say, 'I have never known any of our versed men to fail to acquiesce in the words of Aisha.' 
(1223) 62 - Soulaiman Ibn Yassar reported that Al-Ahwass died in Syria, when his wife was menstruating for the third time, and she had been divorced from him. Mu'awia Ibn Abi Sufian wrote to Zaid Ibn Thabet asking him about this. Zaid replied, "If she had already had her period for the third time, they are both independent of each other, and are not reciprocal heirs." 
(1224) 63 - It was reported to Malek that Al-Kassem Ibn Mouhammad, Salem Ibn Abdallah, Abou Bakr Ibn Abddul-Rahman, Soulaiman Ibn Yassar and Ibn Chehab said: "If the divorced woman has her menses for the third time, she will be permanently separated from her husband, neither of them will inherit the other, and he cannot have her again”. 
(1225) 64 - Nafe' reported that Abdallah Ibn Omar said: "If the man divorces his wife, and she begins her menses for the third time, they are both independent of each other. the other". Malek said: “This is the tradition followed among us”. 
(1226) 65 - Al-Kassem Ibn Muhammad and Salem Ibn Abdallah said: "If the woman, once divorced, has her period for the third time, she will be freed from her husband and can marry." 
(1227) 66 - It was reported to Malek that Sa'id Ibn Al Moussaiab, Ibn Chehab, and Soulaiman Ibn Yassar said: "The waiting period for a woman divorced from 'Khôl', is three periods". 
(1228) 67 - Malek reported that he heard Ibn Chehab say: "The waiting period of a divorced woman is three periods, even if they are not successive". 
(1229) 68 - Yahia Ibn Sa'id reported that the woman of an Ansarian had asked her for a divorce. He said to her, "Once you had your period, let me know». When her period came, she let him know. He said to him, "Once you purify yourself, Let me know". When she was purified and he learned of it, he divorced her». Malek said, "That's the best I've heard." Chapter XXI About the woman who can spend her waiting period in the marital home from which she was divorced 
(1230) 69 - Al-Kassem Ibn Muhammad and Soulaiman Ibn Yassar reported that Yahia Ibn Sa'id Ibn Al-As', definitely divorced the daughter of Abdul Rahman Ibn Al-Hakam. Her father Abdul Rahman Ibn Al-Hakam, made her live in another house. Aisha, the mother of the believers sent word to Marwan Ibn Al-Hakam, when at that time he was the governor in Medina: "Fear Allah and make this woman be at home”. Following the door speaks Soulaiman, Marwan said: “Abdul-Rahman got the better of me,” and according to spokesman al-Kassem, Marwan responded by addressing Aisha: "Don't you know about Fatima Bint Qais”? Aicha replied, "It will do you no harm to allude to the subject of Fatima." Marwan to answer: “If you find that it is inappropriate (that one changes habitat), you must acknowledge that it is still inappropriate, what occurred between the two spouses. 
(1231) 70 - Nafe' reported that Sa'id's daughter Ibn Zaid Ibn Amr Ibn Noufail was the wife of Abdallah Ibn Amr Ibn Osman Ibn Affan, who had finally divorced her. The woman moved to another habitat, Abdallah Ibn Omar disapproved of it”. 
(1232) 71 - Nafe' reported that Abdallah Ibn Omar had divorced his wife while they were at the house of Hafsa, the wife of the Prophet (Upon him be Allah's grace and peace). This house, being situated on the road which leads to the mosque, Abdallah followed another path concealed by the houses, reluctant to ask permission to enter the house (where his wife was). He acted like this, until he took it again”. 
(1233) 72 - Yahia Ibn Sa'id reported that Sa'id Ibn Al-Mussaiab was asked about a woman whose husband divorced her while she was living in a rented house: Whose responsibility is it? the rental price? Sa'id Ibn Al-Musaiab replied, “It is up to the husband to pay the rent (as long as his wife is in her waiting period). The man says, "If the man does not have the means to pay"? Sa'id replied, "The woman will take care of it." The man finally said, "If the woman is unable to pay"? Sa'id replied, "It's up to the governor." Chapter XXIII Alimony for a divorced woman 
(1234) 73 - Abu Salama Ibn Abdul Rahman Ibn Awf reported from Fatima Bint Qais that Abu Amr Ibn Hafs had definitely divorced her, while he was in Syria. He sent his agent to her with a quantity of barley, she was repelled and said to the agent "By Allah I do not expect anything from you", he replied: "By Allah, you owe us nothing." She came to the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) telling her what had happened, he replied: "You owe him no expense", and ordered him to spend his waiting period at the house of Oum Charik, then said to him: “No, this woman sees a lot of people, it is better that you spend this period with Abdallah Ibn Oum Mak-toum, because he is a blind man. With him, you can reveal yourself (change your clothes). A when you finish your waiting period, let me know". Fatima continued: "Once I was at the end of my waiting period I came tell him that Mu'awia Ibn Abi Soufian and Abou Jahm Ibn Hisham asked me in marriage". Then the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the mercy and peace of Allah) replied: “As for Abou Jahm, he always has his cane on his shoulder (1) and for Mou'awia, he is only a man devoid of any good. Marry, Osama Ibn Zaid”. She says, "But I don't agree with him." But he resumed: "Marry Osama Ibn Zaid", and I would marry him: Thus Allah granted me so many goods and I lead a happy life with him. (1) He there are two different opinions about the meaning of the cane on his shoulder (one is that he is strict with his women and the other is that he is always traveling) 
(1235) 74 - Malek reported that he heard Ibn Chehab say: “The woman who is definitively divorced does not leave her home until she has finished her waiting period. She will have no child support unless she is pregnant. If she is pregnant, her husband will spend on her until she gives birth”. Malek said, "And such is the tradition in Medina." Chapter XXIV The Waiting Period of a Divorced Slave (1236)75 -Malek said: "It is the tradition followed among us, concerning the divorce of a slave from a slave wife, if he divorce her being a slave, then let her be freed, her waiting period will be that of a slave (i.e. two months). His postage does not change the length of his waiting period, whether she returns or does not return to him, this period is invariable”. * Malek said: *The same is true for the penalty to which the slave is subjected, then that he is freed after he has been subjected to the penalty. For his pain remains that of a slave. - * And the free man definitely divorces slave woman by three pronouncements of divorce, and her waiting period is two menses. As for the slave, he definitively divorces the free woman by two pronouncements of divorce, and his waiting period is three periods”. * For the man who marries a female slave, then who buys it and frees it Her waiting period is two periods, if he has not touched her. But if he has carnal intercourse with her, after he buys her and before he sets her free, she will have only one period for a waiting period, after which she can marry". Chapter XXV Of all waiting periods 
(1237) 76 - Sa'id Ibn Al-Musaiab reported that Omar Ibn Al-Khattab said: “Any woman, who was divorced, then had one or two periods, after which her periods stop, she will have to wait for the flow of nine months. if, during this time, a pregnancy appears, she is in fact pregnant, if not, she will spend a waiting period after the nine months have elapsed, and this for three months, so that afterwards she can marry". (.....) 77 - Sa'id Ibn Al-Mussaiab said: "The Divorce is the right of men, as for women, they conform to menstruation. 
(1238) 78 - Ibn Chehab reported that Sa'id Ibn Al-Musaiab said: "A woman's waiting period experiencing a discharge of blood (which is not menstruation) is one year”. - Malek said: "It is the tradition followed for the divorced woman whose menstruation ceases when her husband divorces her, to wait until nine months have elapsed. If, during this period, she does not have her period, her waiting period will be for three months. If, before these three months are over, she has her period, she will have to wait for it again. If nine months have passed before she gets her period, she will have a three-month waiting period. If she gets her period for the second time before the three months are up, she will wait for the following. In case the nine months have already been completed before she gets her period, she will have a three month waiting period. If she has her period for the third time, it means that she will have completely completed the three periods. If she doesn't get her period, she should wait three months until she gets married. And in this case, her husband will be able to take her back, before she not marry, unless he had definitively divorced her". - Malek said: “The tradition followed among us, when the man divorces his wife while having the right to take her back, and she has partially passed her waiting period, then he takes her back, and as a result he will separate from her before he does not touch her - it is that the wife will not have to consider what has already passed from the waiting period, and she will start a new waiting period from the day of her divorce, because her husband, having brought back without his needing her, will have committed an unlawful act. * What's tracking among us, when the woman divorced girl becomes a follower of Islam while her husband remains impious then converts to Islam, that he has full right to keep her as long as she is in her waiting period. But if the waiting period has already passed, he will not be able to bring it back. And if he marries from her after the waiting period has elapsed, the divorce will no longer be considered as such, because the conversion to Islam separated them without him having divorced her”. Chapter XXI The subject of the two referees 
(1239) 79 - It was reported to Malek that Ali Ibn Abi Taleb said about the two arbiters, which was mentioned by Allah in this verse (meaning): "If you fear separation between the two spouses, raise up an arbiter from the family of the husband and an arbiter from the wife's family. Allah will restore harmony between them of them, if they want to be reconciled. Allah is the one who knows and who is well informed” Koran IV, 35. This is explained either by the separation or the reunion of the two spouses. - Malek finally said, "And that's what I have to better understood to say of versed men, namely that the two arbiters have the right to judge between the man and his wife, separating between them or reuniting them”. Chapter XXVII The oath of divorce that the man has before there is a marriage 
(1240) 80 - It was reported to Malek that Omar Ibn Al-Khattab, Abdallah Ibn Omar, Abdallah Ibn Mass'oud, Salem Ibn Abdallah, Al-Kassem Ibn Mouhammad, Ibn Chehab, and Soulaiman Ibn Yassar said: "If a man has sworn to divorce a woman before there is marriage and then contradicts his oath, he must divorce her if he has already married her”. (.....) 81 - It was reported to Malek that Abdallah Ibn Mass'oud said: “For the one who says: “Any woman I marry is divorced, if he has not designated the name of the tribe, nor that of the woman, his oath is not to be considered”. - Malek said, "That's the best I've heard." - Malek finally said, "Regarding the man who said to his wife: "You are divorced, as well as those with whom I will marry", and who said again: "All my goods will be alms if I do not do such and such a thing", then that he returns to his oath, his case will be as follows: “As for his wives, they are certainly divorced, as for the other wives whose name, tribe, or country have not been specified, his oath to them is invalid. And for his goods, he will have to give alms from the third party". Chapter XXVIII The delay granted to the man who has not touched his wife 
(1241) 82 - Ibn Chehab reported that Sa'id Ibn Al-Musaiab said: “He who marries a woman, and he has not been able to touch, he will be granted a period of one year during which he will have to touch it, otherwise they must be separated”. 
(1242) 83 • Malek reported that he asked Ibn Chehab about fixing the date for the one who was granted a year's delay so that he could touch his wife? Would it be from from the day of the marriage, or from the day when the wife brought an accusation of her subject to the governor”? He answered her: "Rather, from the day when she impeached the governor. - Malek said: “But for the one who touched his wife then forbade himself for one reason or another, I did not learn that he was granted the setting of a deadline, or a separation between the two". Chapter XXIX The different cases of divorce 
(1243) 84 - Ibn Chehab narrated: “I was told that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him be Allah's grace and peace) said to a man from Thaqif, who had followed Islam when he had ten wives, and just when this man from Thaqif was a partisan of Islam: “To keep four of them, and to divorce the others”. 
(1244) 85 - Ibn Chehab reported that he heard, Sa'id Ibn Al Moussaiab, Houmaid Ibn Abdul Rahman Ibn Awf, Oubaidallah Ibn Abdallah Ibn Utba Ibn Mass'oud, and Soulaiman Ibn Yassar, say, reporting what Abu Houraira said: "I heard Omar Ibn Al-Khattab say, "Any woman whose husband has divorced her for once or twice, then he misses the period of idda making her divorced woman After which the woman marries another, who dies or divorces her, so that her first husband marries her again, in which case she is left with only a mention of divorce for that his divorce from her be final and that she be interdicted thereafter”. - Malek said: “It is good, the sunna followed, which is not to be disputed”. 
(1245) 86 - Thabet Ibn Al-Ahnaf reported that he had married a slave who was the mother of a son of Abdul-Rahman Ibn Zaid Ibn Al-Khattab, Abdul-Rahman Ibn Zaid Ibn Al-Khattab, invited me to his home, and I was present there. Having entered, I saw whips and iron chains, and two of his slaves seated near him. He tells me: “Divorce her, otherwise, in the name of the one by whom one swears, I will do such and such a thing to you”. I replied, "She is divorced for the thousandth time." Leaving his house, I met Abdallah Ibn Omar on the way to Mecca. I told him what happened to me, he got angry and said to me: "It's not a divorce, and it's not forbidden to you, go back to your family". Being still concerned, I went to Abdallah Ibn Al-Zoubair, who at that time was in Mecca, the governor, telling him what is my business, and what the response of Abdallah Ibn Omar, Abdallah Ibn Al-Zoubair answered me: "Your wife is not forbidden to you, and therefore return to your family". Then he wrote to Jaber Ibn Al-Aswad Al-Zouhari, who was the governor in Medina, ordering him to punish Abdallah Ibn Abdul Rahman and to leave my wife and me alone". I returned to Medina, Safia, the wife of Abdallah Ibn Omar prepared my wife for the wedding night and Abdallah Ibn Omar knew about it, then I invited him, the day of wedding, at the meal, and he came. 
(1246) 87 - Abdallah Ibn Dinar reported that he heard Abdallah Ibn Umar recite: “O Prophet! When you want to divorce your wives, do so at the end of their waiting period”. Koran LXV, 1. Malek, interpreting this, said: "He meant by that: for each period, once (remember that the waiting period of three periods, each corresponding to a divorce of once). 
(1247) 88 - Hisham Ibn Ourwa reported that his father said, “Before the man would divorce his wife and then bring her back before her waiting period was even over, that is permissible for him, even though he had divorced her a thousand times. The man would go to his wife and then he would divorce his wife, in such a way that he would wait until her waiting period was over, then divorce her and say, “No! By Allah! I would not keep you in my house and you are not lawful to another”, about him. Allah revealed this verse: "Repudiation can be pronounced twice. So take back your wife in a proper way or else send her back decently” Koran II, 229. From that day people, considered divorce in a new way if well those who had divorced than those who had not yet divorced". 
(1248) 89 - Thawr Ibn Zaid AI-Dili reported that the man would divorce his wife, then bring her back without needing her, refusing to keep her, so that her waiting period would be longer, thereby wanting to cause her harm. Allah Blessed and Most High revealed the following verse on this subject: "Do not don't keep them under duress, you would be breaking the law. Anyone would do so would harm himself” Koran II, 231. Allah, by this, wanted to exhort people”. 
(1249) 90 - It was reported to Malek, that Sa'id Ibn Al Moussaiab and Soulaiman Ibn Yassar were questioned about a drunkard who divorces his wife. They answered: "If a drunkard divorces his wife, his divorce is to be considered, if he kills he will be killed". Malek said, "And such is the rule that is followed among us." (.....) 91 - It was reported to Malek that Sa'id Ibn Al Moussaiab said: “If the man does not find enough to spend on his wife, we will separate them”. Malek said, "And that is what I have seen followed by the religiously versed in our area." Chapter XXX Of the waiting period of a widow if she is pregnant 
(1250) 92 - Abu Salama Ibn Abdul Rahman a reported: "Abdallah Ibn Abbas and Abu Huraira were asked about the pregnant woman whose husband dies"? Ibn Abbas replied: "She must spend the longest period of waiting" (Here we mean, the period of mourning which is four months and ten days, or wait for delivery). And Abou Houraira said in turn: “If she gives birth, she can marry again”. Abu Salama Ibn Abdul-Rahman went to Umm Salamah, the wife of the Prophet (Upon him be Allah's Grace and Peace) and asked her about it. Oum Salama, then replied: "Soubai'a Al-Aslamia had given birth to about fifteen days after her husband's death, two men proposed to her: One young, the other old, as she preferred the young, the old exclaimed, "You can't get married yet", the woman's parents being away, he hoped that once they were present, they will prefer the young. Soubai'a came to find the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) who said to him: "You are free and you can marry the one you prefer".
