(1251) 93 - Nafe' reported that Abdallah was asked Ibn Omar about the woman whose husband dies while she is pregnant? Abdallah Ibn Omar answered: "If she gives birth, she will be able to get married". A man from the Ansars, being at his house, told him that Omar Ibn Al-Khattab had said: "The woman who gives birth while her husband is dead is still on her bed, and is not yet buried, she can marry again". 
(1252) 94 - Al-Miswar Ibn Makkrama reported that Soubai'a Al-Aslamia had given birth a few days after the death of her husband. The Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Be upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said to him: "You are free, and you will be able to marry again". 
(1253) 95 - Soulaiman Ibn Yassar reported that Abdallah Ibn Abbas and Abu Salama Ibn Abdul Rahman argued over the case of the woman who gave birth a few days after her husband's death. Thus, Abu Salama says: "If she gives birth, she can remarry", and Ibn Abbas says: “She has to fix the longest period of waiting (cf 1250-92). Arriving, Abu Houraira said: "I approve, my brother's son designating Abu Salama. This done, they sent Kouraib, the slave of Abdallah Ibn Abbas to Oum Salama, the wife of the Prophet r (Upon him be Allah's Grace and Peace) and asked him about it. Kouraib returned and reported to them that she had said, “Soubai'a had given birth a few days after her husband's death. She asked the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) on this subject, he replied: “You can marry whomever you want. Chapter XXXI The residence of the widow in the house until the day when she can marry 
(1254) 96 - Zainab Bint Ka'b Ibn Ujra reported that Al Furai'a Bint Malek Ibn Sinan, the Sister of Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri told her that she went to the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) to ask him if she could to return to her family the Bani Khoudra, because her husband had gone in pursuit of his maroon slaves, and on arriving very close to "Al-Kadoum" (a place located six miles from Medina), they killed him. She continued: "I asked the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) if I could return to my family, the Bani Khudra since my husband's name had not not left in a dwelling which belonged to him, nor of which to live". The Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) answered me: "Yes certainly", she continued: "I left and when I reached the courtyard, the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) called me, or rather ordered that we calls me, and asks me: "What are you telling me"? I was telling him the story where I had alluded to my husband's affair, so he said: "Stay at home until what is prescribed has expired". Then she said, "I stayed at home for four months and ten days" and when Osman Ibn Affan sent for me, to ask me about it, I told him. He complied with the instructions of the Envoy of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him be Allah's grace and peace) and followed them. 
(1255) 97 - Sa'id Ibn Al-Musaiab reported that Omar Ibn Al-Khattab sent back women whose husbands had died in the "Al-Baida" desert, and forbade them to perform the pilgrimage". (. . ) 98 - Yahia Ibn Sa'id reported that he was made to learn that Al-Saib Ibn Khabbab died, and his wife came to Abdallah Ibn Omar to tell him that her husband had died, leaving him a cultivated land at "Qanate", and asked him if it was suitable to stay there? As Abdallah forbade her, she left Medina on before dawn, to be early in the morning at this site, and stayed until evening, when she returned to Medina, to spend the night in her house”. 
(1256) 99 - Malek reported that Hisham Ibn Ourwa said: "Concerning the woman who is a Bedouin, in case her husband dies, she will remain where her parents live". Malek said: "It is good What is followed with us (in Medina)". 
(1257) 100 - Nafe' reported that Abdallah Ibn Omar said: "The woman whose husband is either dead or has not definitively divorced her, remains only at home". Chapter XXXII The waiting period of slave mothers in case their masters died 
(1258) 101 - Yahia Ibn Sa'id reported that he has heard Al-Kassem Ibn Muhammad say: "Yazid Ibn Abdul-Malek had separated between men and their wives, while these were the mothers of children whose fathers died, these men were married to them after one or two periods have ended. Now, he separated between them so that these women pass their waiting periods which is four months and ten days. Al-Kassem Ibn Muhammad said, “Glory be to Allah! Allah has said in His Book: (meaning) “Some of you die leaving wives” Quran II, 234. And these women are no longer considered wives (i.e. they are slaves)”. 
(1259) 102 - Nafe' reported that Abdallah Ibn Omar said: "The waiting period of a mother whose master is no longer, is a single period". (.....) 103 - Yahia Ibn Sa'id reported that Al-Kassem Ibn Muhammad said: “The waiting period of a mother whose master dies, is a single period”. Malek said: “And such is the rule followed among us”. Malek added, "And if that woman is no longer having her period, her waiting period is three months." Chapter XXXIII Of the Waiting Period of a Slave in Case Her Husband or Master Dies 
(1260) 104 - It was reported to Malek that Sa'id Ibn Al Moussaiab and Soulaiman Ibn Yassar said: "The waiting period of a slave whose husband is no longer, is two months and five days". 
(1261) 105 - Ibn Chehab narrated the same hadith, above”. Malek said, "About the divorcing slave with his slave wife in a way that is not definitive, that he can bring her back, then if he dies while she is in the waiting period for her divorce, she will have to spend the same waiting period as the one whose husband has just died, namely two months and five days". But if this slave is freed, and her husband still has the right to bring her back, then that she did not choose to separate from him after his freedom and that he dies while she is in the waiting period for her divorce, she will have to pass the waiting period of a free woman whose husband is dead, a period which is four months and ten days. This is due to the fact that this woman's waiting period took place immediately after her freedom, so her waiting period must be that of a free woman. Malek said, "And such is the rule followed among us." Chapter XXXIV Ejaculation outside the womb 
(1262) 106 - Ibn Muhairiz reported: "I entered the mosque and at the sight of Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri, I sat down near him and asked him about ejaculation outside the womb? He answered me: "We left with the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) in an expedition against Bani Al-Mustaleq. We took as captives the best women of the Arabs. As we desired women, and as on the one hand we felt the pain of our state of celibacy, on the other, we wanted ransoms in exchange for the captives, we decided to live with them by ejaculating outside the uterus. So we tithes: "Can we do this, without asking the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the mercy and peace of Allah) since he is among us". We asked him, and he replied, "There is no harm in doing that, but be sure that from here on the day of resurrection, everyone whose life has been decreed will not fail to existence”. 
(1263) 107 - Amer Ibn Sa'd Ibn Abi Waqas reported that his father ejaculated outside the womb”. 
(1264) 108 - Ibn Aflah, the slave of Abu Ayoub Al-Ansari reported that a wife of the latter said that Abu Ayoub was ejaculating outside the uterus”. 
(1265) 109 - Nafe' reported that Abdallah Ibn Omar did not ejaculate outside the uterus, and he refused to do so”. 
(1266) 110 - Al-Hajjaj Ibn Amr Ibn Ghazia reported that he was sitting with Zaid Ibn Thabet, when a man from Yemen called Kahd came and said: "O Abu Sa'id! I have several female slaves and wives who don't please me more than they, I, don't like my slaves to carry me, can I ejaculate, outside the womb”? Zaid addressing A-Hajjaj said to him, “O Hajjaj, what do you say”? I replied, “May Allah forgive you! I only see you for learn", I replied to the man: "Your wives are like a field for you to plow, you can either irrigate it (make it fertile) or alter it (keep sterile). That's what I heard about Zaid. So he said, "He said the truth." 
(1267) 111 - A man known by the name of Zafif reported that Ibn Abbas was asked about ejaculation outside the womb. He called one of his slaves and said, "Teach them." She was ashamed, he said: "He is such, as for me, I do it", meaning by that, that he was ejaculating outside the uterus". Malek said: "The man will not be able to coitus interrupted with his free wife, unless she allows him to, however he can freely do it with a slave girl. On the other hand, if his wife is the slave of an owner, he can only perform coitus interruptus after having had their permission”. Chapter XXXV rules of mourning 
(1268) 112 - Houmaid Ibn Nafe' reported that Zainab Ibn Abi Salama told him three hadiths, saying: "I was at Oum Habiba, the wife of the Prophet r (On him the grace and peace of Allah) just at the death of his father Abu Soufian Ibn Harb. Oum Habiba brought a perfume containing "Soufra -Khoulouq” or something like that. Then she rubbed this perfume on one of her servants and passed her hand over her cheeks saying: "By Allah, I do not need to wear perfume, however I heard the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam ) (Upon him be Allah's Grace and Peace) say: "It is not lawful for a woman who believes in Allah and the Day of Resurrection to be in mourning for more than three days, except in the case of her husband, where his mourning should be four months and ten days”. (Such was the first hadith). 
(1269) 113 - Zainab (recounting the second hadith) said: “Then I was at Zainab Ibn Jahch, the wife of the Prophet r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah), at the death of her brother, she asked that perfume be brought to her by which she perfumes herself. Then she said, "By Allah, I don't need this perfume, nevertheless, I heard the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) say: “It is not the right of a woman who believes in Allah and on the day of the resurrection, to mourn for more than three days, except if the deceased is her husband, where the mourning may cover four months and ten days”. 
(1270) 114 - (During the third hadith) Zainab has said: "I heard Umm Salamah, the wife of the Prophet (Upon him be Allah's grace and peace) say: “A woman came to the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Be upon him the grace and peace of Allah) and said to him: “O Messenger of Allah, my daughter just lost her husband, and her eyes are sore can she coat them with Kohol”? The Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Be upon him the grace and peace of Allah) answered him: "No", taking up the “no” for two or three times, meaning by that “A definite no”, then he said: “The mourning is for four months and ten days. And during the pre-Islamic period, one of the women threw a dung after the passage of one year”. Houmaid Ibn Nafe' continued: "I asked Zainab: "Why did the woman throw a dung after the passage of a year"? She replied, "When the wife lost her husband, she lived in a place with poor furniture, and put on ragged clothes, without touching any perfume or anything like that, until a year was up. . Then she asked for an animal, be it a donkey or a sheep or a bird, against the skin of which she rubbed her body. And it was rare that the beast could survive, and then the woman would come out, and they give her a dung, she threw it in front of her, at the as a result of which she could touch perfume or the like”. 
(1271) 115 - Aisha and Hafsa, the wives of the Prophet r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said: "It is not lawful for a woman believing in Allah and in the day of the last judgment, to mourn for a dead person, for more than three nights except, that the dead person is her husband”. 
(1272) 16 - It was reported to Malek that Oum Salama, the wife of the Prophet (Upon him be Allah's Grace and Peace) said to a woman, grieving for her husband, and suffering from pain in her eyes: "Coat your eyes with Kohol at night and remove -the, the day». 
(1273) 117 - It was reported to Malek that Salem Ibn Abdallah and Soulaiman Ibn Yassar said about the woman whose husband dies: "If she risks ophthalmia affecting her eyes, or she is sore from any ailment, she can, if necessary, smear the eyes with Kohol, or even with a remedy, even if a perfume is contained therein”. Malek said, "If he is of a necessity, Kohol or other remedy are allowed there, because religion is easy to practice”. 
(1274) 118 - Nafe' reported that Safia Bint Abi Oubaid suffered from sore eyes, mourning the death of her husband Abdallah Ibn Omar. She didn't use the Kohol although her eyes were going to be closed with dirt. Malek said, "The woman whose husband is lost, can use sesame oil and fat, or other similar products, unless they contain perfume”. Malek also said, "The woman whose husband dies must never put on adornment jewellery, namely a ring, anklet or other jewellery. She will also not put on clothes with colored fabrics or embroidery, unless these clothes are of coarse fabric or black in color. She won't comb her hair only with lotus or something like that, namely with what will not leave traces on his head”. 
(1275) 119 - It was reported to Malek that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the mercy and peace of Allah) entered Um Salama then that she was in mourning at the death of her husband Abou Salama. Having put the traces of the tamarind on his eyes, he said to him: “What are you doing, O Oum Salama”? "It's only tamarind, O Messenger of Allah,” she replied. He shot back, "Put it on at night and wipe it off by day." Malek said: "Bereaving, for a woman who has not yet reached the age of puberty, on the death of her husband, is the same as that of an adult woman, and will even have to forbid herself from all that an adult woman is forbidden from”. Malek said again: “A slave woman, will be in mourning, at the death of her husband, for two months and five nights, the duration of her waiting period”. Malek finally said, "A mother slave, don't will not be in mourning at the death of her master, and this is also the case of a captive of war at the death of her possessor, because mourning is only an obligation for free women”. 
(1276) 120 - It was reported to Malek that Umm Salamah, the wife of the Prophet (Upon him be Allah's grace and peace) said: "The bereaved woman, comb her hair with oil and lotus, free of any perfume". MOUATTAA In the Name of Allah The Clement the Merciful Book 30 The topic of breastfeeding. First chapter Infant breastfeeding 
(1277) 1 - Amra Bint Abdul Rahman has reported that Aisha, the mother of believers taught her that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) was at home when she heard a man asking for permission to enter Hafsa's house. Aisha said, “O Messenger of Allah! He there is a man asking to be allowed to come into your house”. The Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said: "I see that he is so-and-so, a paternal uncle to Hafsa by nursing relationship". Aisha replied, “O Messenger of Allah! If such a man, my paternal foster-uncle, were alive, could he come into my house? The Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Be upon him the grace and peace of Allah) replied: "Yes certainly, because the lactation relationship imposes the same prohibitions as childbirth”. 
(1278) 2 - Hisham Ibn Ourwa reported that Aicha, the mother of believers said, “My paternal uncle by milk came to ask permission to enter my house. But I refused to allow him to enter, before asking the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) on this matter. The Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) having come, I asked him and he replied: "It's your uncle, you could allow him to enter". I said to him: “O Messenger of Allah! But it was a woman who breastfed me and not a man! He replied, "He is your uncle, let him come into your house." Aicha said, “It took place after the revelation of the verse concerning the veil" finally she said: "Breastfeeding is for the same prohibitions as childbirth". 
(1279) 3 - Ourwa Ban Al-Zoubair reported that Aicha, the mother of the believers taught her that Aflah, brother of Aboul-Kou'ais came to ask her permission to enter her home, he who was her brother by breastfeeding, and that after the verse of the veil had been revealed”. She said again, “But I refused to let him in. But when the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) entered, I told him told me what I had done, and he ordered me to let him in. 
(1280) 4 - Thawr Ibn Zaid Al-Daili reported that Abdallah Ibn Abbas said: “even if it is a single suction, in two years it will make breastfeeding relatives prohibited for marriage”. 
(1281) 5 - Amr Ibn Al-Sharid reported that Abdullah Ibn Abbas, when asked about a man who had two wives, one of whom had suckled a boy and the other a girl, if this boy can marry this girl"? He answered; “No, because the husband is the same”. 
(1282) 6 - Nafe' reported that Abdallah Ibn Omar said: "Breastfeeding is only allowed to those who have had it, as infants, and is forbidden to adults". 
(1283) 7 - Nafe' reported that Salem Ibn Abdallah Ibn Omar told him that Aicha, the mother of the believers, sent him when he was small, to his Sister Oum Kulthoum Bint Abi Bakr Al-Siddiq, telling her: "Breastfeed him with ten complete meals so that, once he is great, he can enter my house, without permission». Salem added: “Oum Kalthoum breastfed me for three meals and then fell ill without her being able to complete the ten planned meals. Thus, I could not enter Aicha's without her permission, because Oum Koulthoum had not breastfed me for ten meals”. 
(1284) 8 - Nafe' reported that Safia Bint Abi Oubaid told him that Hafsa, the mother of believers had sent Assem Ibn Abdallah Ibn Sa'd to her sister Fatima Bint Omar Ibn Al-Khattab to breastfeed him for ten meals, while he was still an infant. so that he could later, grown up, enter her home without his permission. Fatima having done so, Assem entered Hafsa's house, without having permission”. 
(1285) 9 - Abdul Rahman Ibn Al-Kassem reported that his father told him that Aisha, the wife of the Prophet (Be upon him peace of Allah) brought into her home, without permission, those whom her sisters and her brother's daughters had breastfed, which was forbidden for those who have been nursed by the wives of his brothers”. 
(1286) 10 - Ibrahim Ibn Ouqba reported that he asked Sa'id Ibn Al Moussaiab, about breastfeeding”? Sa'id replied, "All lactation does, even if it is from a drop of milk, in the first two years, imposes a ban. However, what is given beyond two years is considered only food to eat”. Ibrahim Ibn Ouqba added: “Then asking Ourwa Ibn Al-Zoubair on the same subject, he gave me the same answer as that of Sa'id Ibn Al-Mussaiab. 
(1287) 11 - Yahia Ibn Sa'id reported that he has heard Sa'id Ibn Al-Mussaiab say: "Breastfeeding is only necessary for an infant in the cradle, because beyond this period, food is more valuable for the development of the flesh and the bone". (.....) 12 - Malek reported that Ibn Chehab said: "Breastfeeding, whether for a short period or a long period, imposes prohibitions". - Yahia reported and I heard Malek say: “Any breastfeeding whether quantitatively little or too much, in the first two years, imposes prohibitions. But, after this period, the breastfeeding of a large quantity either it or a small one, will not prohibit anything, because it is taken for food”. Chapter II Breastfeeding the big 
(1288) 13 - Malek reported that Ibn was asked Chehab about breastfeeding the big one. He replied: "Ourwa Ibn Al Zoubair told me that Abu Houzaifa Ibn Utba Ibn Rabi'a, who moreover was one of the companions of the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) with whom he had attended the battle of Badr, had adopted Salem known as Salem, the freedman of Abu Houzaifa just as the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) had done for Zaid Ibn Haritha. Abou Houzaifa, taking Salem as his son, marries him from the daughter of his sister Fatima Bint al-Walid Ibn Utba Ibn Rabi'a, who at that time was one of the first women who had made the hijrah, and was one of the most beautiful single women in Quraish. Immediately Allah Most High revealed in His Book the following verse: "Call these adopted children by the name of their fathers, it will be more just with Allah, but if you do not know their fathers, they are your brothers in religion, they are yours» Koran XXXIII, 5. Each of these adopted children were called in the name of his real father, and in case the latter was unknown, the child would be known by the name of his father who had adopted him. Thus, Sahia Bint Souhail, the wife of Abou Houzaifa who was from Bani Amer Ibn Louay, came to the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him be Allah's grace and peace) and said to him: “O Messenger of Allah! We had considered Salem as a child and being such, he entered my home when I was without a veil having only a one-room house, what do you think about him”? The Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) replied: “Breastfeed him for five meals from your breast and you will be prohibited”. “And she took him from then on for a suckling son. Aisha, the mother of the believers, being aware of this fact, she followed him with all those whom she wanted to bring into her home without their permission. So she asked that this be followed by his sister Oum Kalthoum Bint Abou Bakr Al-Siddiq and by his brother's daughters, for those whom they liked to bring into their home without let them take their permission. As for the other wives of the Prophet (upon him the grace and peace of Allah) they refused to let at home, those who have been breastfed in this way, without giving them permission and said, “No, by Allah! What the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) ordered Sahia Bint Souhail to to do, was only such a particular authorization, so that she breastfeeds Salem alone. No, by Allah! We will not allow any man to enter our house, having been nursed in this way”. This was the way of acting, wives of the Prophet (upon him be Allah's grace and peace) concerning the breastfeeding of the grown-up". 
(1289) 14 Abdallah Ibn Dinar reported: “A man came to find Abdallah Ibn Omar, whom I accompanied in the court of justice, asking him about the breastfeeding of the big child? Abdallah Ibn Omar answered him: “A man came to Omar Ibn Al-Khattab saying to him: “I had a slave with whom I lived, my wife had breastfed her, wanting to have intercourse with the slave, my wife exclaimed: Take care, for, by Allah, I have breastfed her”. Omar, thus, says: “Tease your wife, and have intercourse with your slave because breastfeeding imposes prohibitions only if it is proper to infants. 
(1290) 15 - Yahia Ibn Sa'id reported that a man said to Abu Moussa Al-Ach'ari: "I sucked my wife's breast and I swallowed the milk". Abou Moussa answered him: "I think that your wife is forbidden to you". Abdallah Ibn Mass'oud said: “Pay attention to what you have just said to the man” Abou Moussa replied: “what are you saying to yourself”? Abdallah Ibn Massou'd replied: "Breastfeeding does not impose prohibitions only if given during the first two years of the infant'. Abou Moussa then said: "don't ask me any more questions, as long as this scholar is present". Chapter II Everything about breastfeeding 
(1291) 16 - Aisha, the mother of the believers reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him be Allah's grace and peace) said: "Breastfeeding calls for the same prohibitions as those of childbirth. (1292) 17- Aicha, the mother of believers reported that Joudama Bint Wahb Al-Assadia taught her that she heard the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Be upon him and the peace of Allah) say: "I intended to forbid men cohabitation with their wives and ejaculation, as long as their wives were still breastfeeding their infants, when, I remembered that this was done by the Romans and Persians, without harm to their children". - Malek said: "This is, interpreting the hadith above, for the man to have intercourse with his wife while she is breastfeeding". 
(1293) 18 - Amra Bint Abdul Rahman reported that Aisha, the wife of the Prophet r (Upon him be Allah's grace and peace) said: "Among the verses revealed in the Quran, one of them was about the prohibition caused by the ten breastfeedings, then it was reduced to five full meals. The Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the mercy and peace of Allah) died, and had recited this verse so much as part of the Qur'an". Malek said, "And we don't follow that among us." MOUATTAA In the name of Allah the Merciful the Merciful Book 31 The sales book First chapter Sale by pawn 
(1294) 1 Amr Ibn Cho'aib reported from his father, according to his grandfather that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) forbade the sale by pawn". - Malek, interpreting the hadith above says: "What I think, and Allah is most informed, that for the pledge, it is a question of the fact that the man buys himself a slave, or even that he rents himself a mount, then that he tells the one from whom he bought himself or s is rented: "I will pay you a dinar or a dirham or more, or less than this price, provided that if I keep the goods or use the mount, what I would have paid you as sum will be part of the price of the merchandise, or of the frame; and if I no longer want to buy myself the goods, nor rent the frame, what you would have had as a sum paid, will not be your right”. a - What is tracked among us (in Medina), it is that it is accepted that man buys the eloquent and gifted slave for commercial business in exchange for other Ethiopian slaves or even of other origins who have not not the eloquence of this slave, nor even his commercial skill, nor either his conviction, nor finally his knowledge. Thus, it is permitted to buy this slave, to exchange it for two or more others, for a well-determined time. However, if, later on, it turns out to be different, the slightest comparison that will be underlined is enough for his exchange for two to be canceled even for a limited time. And it is the same for the difference of origins. b - It is tolerated that one can resell what one has bought before taking it, if this price has been collected from another man who is not the one from whom one made the purchase”. c - It is not allowed, in the event of the sale of a woman, to make her exempt from the child she has in her lap, because this is an abused market, by ignoring whether it is a male or a female, whether he is beautiful or ugly, whether he is a complete or incomplete creature, whether he is alive or dead, therefore it will devalue the price of this woman”. d - For the case where a man who buys a slave for a hundred dinars forward, then the seller regrets this sale and asks the buyer to declare the contract void, paying him ten dinars cash or forward, and considering the hundred dinars as canceled, Malek said: “It is valid. But if the seller regrets and asks the buyer to cancel the purchase of the male or female slave, paying him ten dinars cash or term, in surplus, in a date that exceeds the term provided, this is not permitted. In other words, it is as if the seller sold the slave at one hundred dinars for a period of less than a year, and ten dinars in cash or at a term for a period of more than one year. This means that it is the sale of gold against gold that comes into play, at term. e - Concerning man who sells a slave to another, for one hundred dinars, to be paid in time, then he buys her at a price exceeding that of the sale price, for a period beyond that of the term, this is not tolerated . And this is explained by the fact that either the man sells the female slave for a well-determined period, then that he buys it for a period exceeding the first, so that he sells it at thirty dinars at a term of one month and that he buys it at sixty to one. one-year term, or six months. Thus, it is as if his merchandise came back to him as it was, and the other man gave him thirty dinars for a month, sixty for a year or even for six. However, this is not tolerated”. Chapter II The Subject of the Slave's Property 
(1295) 2 - Abdullah Ibn Omar reported that Omar Ibn Al-Khattab said, "Whoever sells a slave possessing a sum saved, this is the seller's right, unless the buyer stipulates it." Malek said, “What is of follow among us (in Medina), is that if the buyer stipulates what slave possesses, it must be returned to him, whether it be cash or in the form of debt or a commodity, determined or indeterminate. And if the slave has a sum of money exceeding that of the price by which he has just been bought, the purchase price of the slave is made either by cash or by a debt or even merchandise. Because, what the slave owns, his master will not have to pay Zakat on his behalf, just like the case where the slave owning a slave can cohabit her by his right of possession. If the slave is freed in a definitive way or in the long term according to a clause, his possession belongs to him, and in the event that he goes bankrupt, his creditors can monopolize his possession, without his master taking responsibility for paying him. his debts, if he has any. Chapter III Warranty 
(1296) 3 - Abdullah Ibn Abi Bakr Ibn Muhammad Ibn Amr Ibn Hazm reported that Aban Ibn Osman and Hisham Ibn Ismail alluded in their preaching to the guarantee of slavery, within three days of the purchase of the slave (male or female) and the one-year warranty". - Malek said: “What can reach a slave, in the first three days they were purchased, it is the seller who holds the responsibility. Corn if during a year given as guarantee, there would be an attack of madness, or leprosy or the loss of a limb due to an illness, after this year has passed, the seller is exempt from all liability”. - Malek added: “A heir or another who sells a slave without there being a guarantee clause, this seller is no longer responsible for any defect, and he no longer has to keep a guarantee, unless he was well aware of a vice and that he does not admit it. So if he had done so, his indemnity is of no interest to him, and what he had sold must return to him. And this guarantee is only required here (in Medina) when it comes to selling slaves. Chapter IV The disadvantages of slaves 
(1297) 4 - Salem Ibn Abdallah reported that Abdallah Ibn Umar sold a slave he owned for eight hundred dirhams, and Abdallah ibn Umar stipulated that he was not responsible for any fault in the slave. The buyer said to Abdallah Ibn Omar: "This slave is touched by a disease which you did not make known to me". They argued and went to Osman Ibn Affan to decide, the man said: "He sold me a slave with a vice without him admitting it to me", and Abdallah on his part said: "I sold with the stipulation that I was not responsible for any defect in the slave". So Osman Ibn Affan demanded that Abdallah Ibn Umar swear to him that he had sold him the slave free from any vice he knew; Abdallah refusing to take an oath, he took back the slave who, at home, was cured. Then Abdallah sold it again for one thousand five hundred dirhams”. - Malek said: “What is followed up with us (in Medina), in case someone buys a slave, cohabits her and makes her pregnant, or buys a slave and later frees her, or any other case where what is bought does not East more subject to being returned, and that the evidence be put in evidence, namely that what was purchased had been affected by a defect while it was with the seller, or even that the seller admits that there is had such, or that another has witnessed it, it is necessary that the slave, male or female, be valued while taking into account the defect they had, the same day they were sold, the seller will deliver to the buyer a concluded price be split between the true price (the male or female slave considered in a safe and sound condition) and the current price (i.e. that this or that slave have some defect). - Malek also said: “This which is practiced with us (in Medina) in the case where the man buys the slave for himself, then finds him some defect which gives him the right to return him to the seller, but even that this slave while being at the buyer has been affected by another defect, namely, for example, that this defect either or the amputation of one of the members of this slave, or that this last became blind or any other form close to this defect, it is necessary, this case being, that the purchaser has to choose: or that he decreases the price of the slave in view of his vice by a value equivalent to this vice, from the very day on which he had bought him, or if he wants to, that he pay the seller the value of the defect suffered by the slave when he had been in his possession, then return it to the seller. If the slave dies while being with the buyer, its price is estimated at the value it had on the day of purchase, taking into account its default. Thus, if the value of the slave, on the very day of his purchase, and being free from any defect, was one hundred dinars, and that this value, on the day of his purchase with the default, was eighty dinars, the buyer would be given the value of twenty dinars, who would thus have paid four and twenty dinars, the suitable value of the slave, taking into account his default”. Malek said, “He who will return a slave for having found any vice whatsoever in her, but whom he had already cohabited, when she was a virgin, he must, in this case, take into account the reduction in his price for having cohabited her. But if it was previously cohabited, he would not have to take this cohabitation into account and will owe nothing to the seller who had given him the guarantee. - Anyone who sells one or a slave, or even an animal by indemnity, to those who inherit or to others, the seller shall be exempt from all liability concerning any defect found for what he sold, unless he was aware of this defect and that he had not declared it. If this is so, his indemnity will be of no interest to him, and what he had sold must be returned to him”. - In case a slave is sold in exchange for two others, then that there is in one of her, any defect for which, she will be returned, Malek said: "We will make the evaluation of the slave against that he there was an exchange with two others, and we will estimate its price, then we will the evaluation of the two slaves, exempt from the vice which was in one of them, namely that the evaluation will be made by considering the two slaves in a safe and sound state. Then we will distribute the price of the slave, for whom two other slaves had been exchanged, by esteem of their own prices, so that each of them has its true value, taking into account the one that is much safer and safer compared to to another, therefore, we will consider the one with whom we has found the defect, in order to deprive it of its value, however great it or small, to return it to the buyer by compensation, so that each of the two slaves is valued according to its true price, the day of its sale”. - About the man who buys a slave and employs him on a long-term or short-term basis for wages and food, then finds any fault in him and thereby returns him, his buyer will have his wages and his food. And such was the rule followed in Medina. Else hand, if a man buys himself a slave who builds him a house whose value is worth several times that of the slave, then he finds in the latter any defect allowing him to return it and to have its price again; the slave in this case, will have no wages for the construction which he had made, and such will be its situation if one had made it work with another person, since the salesman had guaranteed it against all vice. And such is the rule followed with us (in Medina). - For the man who buys several slaves in a single batch of a single transaction, and among which, it turns out that a slave has been stolen (before he takes possession of it) or that he is even affected by some defect , this man will have to fix the price of what has been stolen, or of what is affected by a vice, and if this slave is the most expensive or the best among the others, or even that it is because of him, that the transaction has been made, or that people have had no esteem for him, this transaction will be completely canceled. But if it happens that a slave has been stolen or reached with a defect other than the first slave, without having his qualities, this slave alone will be returned by handing over its price once it has been estimated". Chapter V The female slave sold while being subject to a condition 
(1298) 5 - Oubaidallah Ibn Abdallah Ibn Utba Ibn Mass'ud related that Abdallah Ibn Mass'ud bought himself a slave from his wife Zainab Al-Thaqafia, who gave it on condition of reselling it to him at the same price which will be offered on the day of the sale, Abdallah Ibn Mass'oud asked on this subject, Omar Ibn Al-Khattab who said to him: "you will not be able to touch this slave, as long as its sale is subject to one condition”. 
(1299) 6 - Nafe' a reported that Abdallah Ibn Omar said: "Man should not cohabit with a slave, except that he can sell her, that he can make a donation of her, that he can even retain her, or even that he can do with her whatever he wants. - Malek said: "Concerning one who buys a slave on condition that he has neither the right to sell her, nor to make a gift of her, nor to do anything else likewise, its buyer is not allowed to cohabit it, consequently, he will not even have the right either to sell it, or to offer it as a gift, as long as it is not absolutely his. own possession because there is a condition which deprives him of disposing of this slave in full, thus, such a sale is to be detested”. Chapter VI The prohibition that a man live with a slave who already has a husband 
(1300) 7 - Ibn Chehab a reported that Abdallah Ibn Amer had offered as a present, a slave to Osman Ibn Affan, having a husband, and that he had bought her in Basra. Osman told her, "I won't touch her until she separates from her husband." So Ibn Amer got along with the husband of this slave compensated him, and he parted from her”. 
(1301) 8 - Abu Salamah Ibn Abdul-Rahman Ibn Awf reported that Abdul Rahman Ibn Awf bought himself a slave, finding that she was married, he returned her”. Chapter VII Of the sale of fruit trees and their fruits 
(1302) 9 - Abdallah Ibn Umar reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Be upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said: "Whoever sells pollinated date palms, the fruits go to the seller, unless the buyer stipulates so, in the conditions of purchase”. Chapter VIII Of the ban on selling fruit before it begins to ripen 
(1303) 10 - Ibn Omar reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him be the grace and peace of Allah) forbade the sale of the fruits before they start to ripen. And this prohibition was to be followed by the seller and the buyer”. 
(1304) 11 - Anas Ibn Malek reported that the Apostle of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) forbade the sale of the fruits before they are coloured'. The Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) was asked r (Be upon him the grace and peace of Allah) about what he means by colorful? he answered: "let them blush" and he added: "What do you think, it is possible that Allah does not allow the fruits to ripen, one of you will he have the right to take his brother's money for free? 
(1305) 12 - Amra Bint Abdul Rahman reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) forbade the sale of the fruits as long as one doubts their ripening”, (eu escaping the plagues). Malek said: “The sale fruits before they are completely healthy from diseases that could destroy them is considered a random sale”. 
(1306) 13 - Kharija Ibn Zaid Bint Thabet reported that Zaid Ibn Thabet, his father, sold the fruits only just at the appearance of the pleiad (namely, only at this time, we can distinguish the color of the fruits, especially if they are dates". - Malek said: “what is practiced with us (in Medina), concerning fruits such as watermelons, cucumbers, Khirbiz and carrots, is that their sale is permitted in case they are ripe and good to eat then, the buyer will have , all rights over what grows on the trees until they lose all their fruit or are no longer edible, and this for a period which is not to be fixed, because it is a period which has been agreed upon by the people. But if ever these fruits are damaged, and that they are no longer in a state to be consumed, even before the period previously provided for in this way, if this is the case, and that at least a third of these fruits have deteriorated, we must give the buyer a discount equal to or greater than one third, depending on the case. Chapter IX From the sale of “Al-Aryya”^ 
(1307) 14 - Zaid Ibn Thabet reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him be Allah's grace and peace) allowed the recipient of a date tree tells Arya to sell its fruit, while being on the tree, after estimation, against already picked fruit”. 
(1308) 15 - Abu Hurairah narrated that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him be Allah's grace and peace) tolerated the owner of the "Al-Arya" (a kind of dry date) that their fruits are sold while they are still on the tree, exchanging them for fruits picked, in case the weight is less than five “awsouqs”. Daoud doubts whether it is five awsouqs or less. - Malek said: “the Al-Arya” date palms are sold by estimating their dates, namely that we will consider approximately and we will estimate the dates both they are on the trees. And this tolerance is due to the fact that dates are held in the same way as a charge, or a resolution of a contract or even an association. If the dates were considered like any other merchandise, no one, in this case, will have accepted that another does not share them with him, before he takes possession of them, or before he rescinds a contract, or even even if he charges someone else with it, before he has fully received the price”. Chapter X Of the scourge that ravages fruits and crops 
(1309) 16 - Muhammad Ibn Abdul Rahman heard his mother, Amra Bint Abdul Rahman say: "a man, in the time of the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the mercy and peace of Allah), had bought himself the fruits of a garden, which he maintained well, until a plague ravaged the fruits of this garden. This man asked the owner of the garden either to forgive him of his debt or to cancel the contract, the owner of the garden, taking an oath not to make either such or such, the mother of the buyer went to the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) to inform him of this subject. The Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him be Allah's favor and peace) said: "Has he taken an oath to no longer do good”? The owner of the garden, hearing this, came to the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him be Allah's grace and peace) and said to him: “O Messenger of Allah! The choice is his”. 
(1310) 17 - It was reported in Malek that Omar Ibn Abdul Aziz demanded that we subsidize the value of the fruits, or of the harvest, damaged by a plague”. - Malek said, "And such is the rule followed at home (in Medina)." - Malek has added: “This subsidy will only be made if the deteriorated part or quantity is one-third of the harvest”. Chapter XI Permission to hold a bumper crop party 
(1311) 18 - Rabi'a Ibn Abdul Rahman reported that Al-Kassem Ibn Muhammad, was selling fruits from his garden, excepting a part”. 
(1312) 19 - Abdullah Ibn Abi Bakr reported that his grandfather Muhammad Ibn Amr Ibn Hazm sold the fruits of a garden he owned called "Al-Afraq", to four thousand dirhams, and kept a quantity of dates aside, worth eight hundred dirhams". 
(1313) 20 • Muhammad Ibn Abdul Rahman Ibn Al-Harith reported that his mother, Amra Bint Abdul Rahman sold her fruits, keeping aside a certain quantity”. - Makk says, “What is followed by us (in Medina), is that, by selling the fruits of his garden, the man has the right to keep aside a quantity of these fruits, which is not beyond the third , but that this quantity is more than the third, this is not allowed”. - Malek added: “He is not forbidden for a man to sell the fruits of his garden, putting aside a certain quantity of these fruits, namely the fruits of one or more date palms that he chooses, citing their number. Because, the owner, by setting aside some trees, he wants to keep their fruits for him, and not sell them, preferring to sell other fruits from his garden. Chapter XII The sale of dates which is not permitted 
(1314) 21 - Ata'Ibn Yassar reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said: "Dates in exchange with other dates, equal for each other”. He was told: "Your prefect at Khaibar": exchanges one Sa' of dates for two". The Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Be upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said to him: "Do you exchange a Sa'de dates against two (namely dates)”? The prefect answered: “O Messenger of Allah, those who sell me, do not give me a sa' of dates of a good quality for a sa' of an inferior quality”? The Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) ordered him: "To sell the dates of various qualities exchanged against money, then to buy with this money dates of good quality". 
(1315) 22 - Abu Sa'id Al Khudri and Abu Huraira reported that the Messenger of Allah (sallallahu alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) had designated in Khaibar a man who had brought him dates called "janib" (which are of good quality). The Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said to him: “Are all the dates of Khaibar, are they of the same quality”?. The man replied, "No, by Allah, O Messenger of Allah, the sa' of such dates is exchanged for two, and two Sa's against three”. The Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Be upon him the mercy and peace of Allah) said to him: "Do not do this any more, sell dates of different qualities and take money in exchange, then buy from this money, janib”. 
(1316) 23 - Zaid Abu Ayach reported that he asked Sa'd Ibn Abi Waqas about exchanging barley for rye”? Sa'd said to him, "which is more valid"? Zaid replied, "That's barley." Sa'd forbade him and said: "I heard the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him be the mercy and peace of Allah) say about the exchange of fresh dates for the dry ones: "Fresh dates, once dried, will they lose weight"? He was told yes, the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) forbids this kind of exchange”. Chapter XIII From the "mouzabana" and "al-mouhaqala" 
(1317) 24 - Abdallah Ibn Umar reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) was against “al-muzabana”. Al “Mouzabana” is the act of selling dates on the date palms for dry dates, and selling grapes on the vines for raisins”. 
(1318) 25 - Abu Sa'id Al Khudri reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him be Allah's grace and peace) refuted "the muzabana" and "the muhaqala”. And “la mouzabana” is the sale of dates on the date palms for dry dates, and “la mouhaqala” is the fact of renting the land in exchange for a quantity of wheat”. 
(1319) 26 - Sa'id Ibn Al-Musaiab reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the mercy and peace of Allah) forbade "the muzabana and the muhaqala” (see hadith above), emphasizing that “muhaqala” is either the sale of the harvest in exchange for wheat, or the fact of renting the land in exchange for wheat”. Ibn Chehab, asked Sa'id Ibn Al-Musaiab about the leased land for gold and silver, Sa'id replied, "It is permitted." Malek said: "The Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the mercy and peace of Allah) forbade "the muzabana" and "the mouzabana” which is explained as follows: “Any form of sale is said to be random as long as during the sale the weight, measure and number are unknown. By way of example, a man possessing food whose weight cannot be specified, such as wheat or dates or anything similar to them, or even possessing wheat, or fresh dates, or vegetables, or safflower, or of linen, or of cotton, or of silk or that which is similar to them, in short, that he possesses them everything of which neither the weight nor the number can be specified, and that a man comes to say to the possessor of all this merchandise: "Weigh this merchandise, or ask someone to do it, or weigh what may be weighed, or even counted what can be counted; thus if what is measured from such and such lacks a sa', or even if what is weighed from such and such lacks a certain weight, or even what is counted from such and such is lacking, in short all that is missing, I will take it at my expense, whatever the goods designated; and if there is a surplus of this merchandise, I will take it without paying the price. Thus, I guarantee that what is lacking of this commodity is my possession, and is even equivalent to what is surplus. However, this is not a sale but it is a sale of risk, chance and wear and tear, because during this sale, he does not pay the price of a well known and specified commodity, which he bought, but he at least guaranteed himself to have what is said of measure, weight and number, of this merchandise by taking possession of what was in surplus. But if this merchandise lacks what is of these units (measure, weight, number), the one who bought it, should have taken from the owner of this merchandise, what is priceless, or even what is a gift, of which , in fact, he does not have the right to have it because that is usury, or something similar to it". - Malek said, “He is cause the man to say to the other possessing the fabric: I guarantee you that with such fabric, you will have to make such a number of caps, in such a way that each one will be of such and such unit of measurement, that it cited. If it is less than the designated piece of cloth, I will give you what is missing so that you have the full number, and if there is more, it will come back to me”. - Or again, always about the fabric, let the man say to the other: I guarantee you to make of such fabric, such number of shirts, each of which will be of such and such length; but if this fabric is missing, I will give it to you so that you have the number, and if there is more, you will give it to me». - Or again, that the man say to another, concerning leather, whether of cows or camels: "I assure you to cut this leather, in order to make it according to this pattern a hundred pairs of sandals, if the number is less than a hundred, I will complete it for you, and if it is more, this superfluity I will have it free because I guaranteed it”. - Or again, that the man say to the other who has seeds of "ban" (Egyptian willow): "By pressing this ban, you can extract such and such a weight of perfumed oil, or if the weight is less, I will give you what lack, and if there is more, I will have it for myself”. “Thus, all these forms of sale are “la mouzabana”, in other words, sales that are neither permitted nor tolerated”. It will be the same in case the man says to the other, possessing leaves of trees, or stones, or flax, or cotton, or safflower, I will buy such and such a kind of your merchandise. , by Sa', proceeding just as it was mentioned in the previous hadiths, everything comes down to what is quoted from the muzabana”. Chapter XIV The sale of fruit 
(1320) 27 - Malek said: "Let a man buy dates from palm trees, or from a designated garden, or let him buy milk from certain definite sheep, so that that the buyer takes what he has bought, as soon as he has paid the price, this presents no prohibition. This is similar to the case where a man buys oil from a wineskin, at the price of one or two dinars, thus giving his money and signaling to the seller to weigh him some oil from this same skin, there is no prohibition. But in the event that the skin splits and its oil leaks, the buyer will take back his money, and consequently there will be no obligation to sell between him and the seller”. "But what is for any merchandise that is bought at the same time such as milk that is milked, or dates that are picked, namely that the buyer can have them on a day-to-day basis, it is a purchase that is tolerated, since the quantity purchased is well known; but in case it is ravaged before the buyer takes possession of it, or the seller keeps the price of the goods already sold, or the buyer gets the difference of the sum of money already paid, at the price of another commodity after having agreed with the seller on this subject, and that this takes place at the same time, before the buyer and the seller are separated because in this case this is not tolerated. Because, if the separation took place before they both agree, this is refused because the goods in question are subject to the payment of a term sum, but it is forbidden for goods to be delivered after a certain time. Therefore, a transaction is tolerated if the goods are submitted for a certain time already fixed, thus, the seller will guarantee to the buyer the delivery of the goods without it being necessary to specify whether, for example, they are dates from a well-designated garden, or well-defined sheep's milk". Malek was asked about a man who buys dates from a garden of different kinds of palms namely "from Ajwa, from Kabiss, and from Azq", and other kinds of dates, that the seller makes the With the exception of a few date palms, Malek replied, "That is not tolerated, for by doing so he would have taken a measure of fifteen sa's from the 'ajwa' against a measure of ten sa's from the Kabiss, preferring such kind to such another, namely that "the ajwa" is less valid than "the Kabiss". His case is similar to one who, having a quantity of dates, neither measured nor weighed, will make three batches of them: the first consisting of fifteen sa's of "ajwa", the second of ten sa's of "Kabiss", and the third of twelve sa's of "azq", that the buyer subscribes the seller for one dinar, provided that he himself chooses the batch of dates» , this is not allowed, added Malek». - Malek, was questioned, about the man, who having paid a dinar in advance, to the owner of the palm trees, so that he could buy fresh dates, then for any cause whatever, that the palm trees are devastated, he answered: “Let the buyer make his account with the owner of the palm trees, then that he has what is his right of the dinar already paid; and that depends on three cases: if he had bought fresh dates at the price of two-thirds of the dinar, he is entitled to the remaining third; if the dates bought fresh were at the price of three-quarters of the dinar, he will have the remaining quarter, or else that they have agreed, buyers and owners among themselves, namely that he can, if he wants to, buy at the price that remains to him, fresh dates, or other merchandise than dates. This, on the condition that they cannot be separated from each other, before the buyer has received from the owner either the dates or another commodity. - Malek added: “This case above is similar to the same situation where a man lends to another either his horse by renting it to him, or his servant to make work at a dressmaker's or a carpenter's or to do any other work for him, or even though he rents his house to her, so that the first has in advance the payment of the labor of the servant, or the hiring of the house, or the mount, after which an accident of death, or of that which is unforeseen, arises. Thus, it is necessary that the owner of the mount, or of the slave, or of the house return to the other man the price paid in advance for the mount, the slave, and the house, for a sum relatively suitable to what has already been used up of what is rented, which for example is an amount of the half a little less or a little more”. - Malek said about of this advance: "It is tolerated only if the object which is subjected to it, is well known and determined to know a mount, a slave, or a house that is delivered just on payment of the advance, without there being neither delay nor delivery at a certain time. The interpretation of the refusal of this payment in advance is clearer in the following case: "Let a man say to another: I will pay you this amount in advance for your mount, which I will use to perform the pilgrimage, whereas a good time still separates him from the intended pilgrimage, or the same for his slave or his house. This done, it is as if the one who pays in advance was going pay money, because if it happens that the mount is still in good condition in order to use it for the pilgrimage, this mount is rented to him, and if it is no longer due to death or other reason, the owner of the mount must return to the man the sum paid, from which he had in any case benefited". And Malek added: “Now, there is a distinction to be made between this fact above (advance payment returned) and the fact of receiving a sum definitively. Whoever receives the price of what he has rented is no longer accused of a random sale, because it is payment in advance, for a known thing. This case is similar to the man who buys a slave, so he appropriates them and pays their prices immediately, if any incident will affect them during one year of their possession, their owner can have again the amount paid, from the seller; so, for this case, there is no harm; moreover, such was the sunna followed for the slave trade. Malek finally said: “He who hires a known slave, or a well-appointed mount, which will be delivered to him at a fixed date, this is not permitted, because, by this act, he will have paid a sum for a thing which is not in his possession on the day of payment and which the owner can only guarantee on the day of delivery. Chapter XV The sale of fruit 
(1321) 28 - Malek said: “What is followed with us (in Medina) is what follows: The one who buys fruits, fresh or dried, can only sell them after having paid their (purchase) price. He can only sell them, exchange them from hand to hand. Fresh fruits that can be dried , and do even a provision and consume them dry, such fruits will not be sold from hand to hand or such fruits against such others if they are of the same species. If they are of different species, it is tolerated that two quantities are sold for one, from hand to hand, and without any delay. If there are fruits which cannot be dried or stored, but which are eaten fresh, such as watermelons cucumbers, carrots, oranges, bananas, and pomegranates and any other such fruit, so that, even if dried, they are no longer considered fruit, nor of what one can stock up and they are fruit, I think one can sell a quantity for two and from hand to hand on the market even without it being a term”. Chapter XVI The sale of minted and powdered gold for silver 
(1322) 29 - Yahia Ibn Sa'id reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him be Allah's grace and peace) allowed the two Sa'ds (namely Sa'd Ibn Abi Waqas and Sa'd Ibn Oubada) the sale of the vases of the booty, made of gold and silver selling three vases against four measures of pieces, or four vases against three measures of pieces, the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said to them: "You have committed the usury, this sale must be returned”. 
(1323) 30 - Abu Hurairah narrated that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him be Allah's grace and peace) said: “One dinar is worth another, and one dirham is worth another, without any preference from one to the other”. 
(1324) 31 - Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him be Allah's grace and peace) said: "Do not sell gold exchanged for gold, unless one is worth the other, and one of you don't give more than the other. Do not sell either, silver exchanged for silver unless one is of the same value as the other, and one of you does not give more than the other. Do not sell a commodity present against another absent (or non-existent). 
(1325) 32 - Mujahed a reported: “He was at Abdallah Ibn Omar, a jeweler came to tell him: “O Abu Abdul Rahman, I work gold, I sell it more than its weight, thereby earning the value of my work”. Abdallah forbidding him to do this, the jeweler kept repeating the same subject and Abdallah for his part forbade him, until he was at the door of the mosque, or even near a mount to be mounted, then Abdallah Ibn Omar said to him: “The dinar against another, the dirham against another, without preference from one to the other. Such was the commitment of our prophet (on him the grace and peace of Allah) towards us, and such will be ours for you”. 
(1326) 33 - Malek Ibn Abi Amer reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him be Allah's grace and peace) said to Osman Ibn Affan: “Do not sell the dinar for two, nor the dirham for two”. 
(1327) 34 - Ata Ibn Yassar reported that Mu'awia Ibn Abi Souffian sold a gold or silver vase, where water is cooled, at a price higher than his weight. Abu Al-Darda said to him: "I heard the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) prohibit such a sale unless it is made, by equivalence of weight”. Mou'awia replied: "I don't find anything wrong with that." Abu Al-Darda resumed: "Mu'awia answers me according to his opinion, whereas I have just reported to him a hadith according to the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Be upon him the grace and the peace of Allah); to whom do I owe my apologies? I refuse to find me in the same country where you are". Then, going to Omar Ibn Al-Khattab, Abu Al-Darda told him what had happened; so Omar Ibn Al-Khattab sent in writing to Mu'awia: "avoid such a sale, unless it is made at equivalence of weight". 
(1328) 35 - Abdullah Ibn Omar reported that Omar Ibn Al-Khattab said, “Do not sell gold against the other, except at equivalence, and without preferring one to the other. Do not sell silver for silver except in an equivalence, and without preference from one to the other. Do not sell silver for gold if one of these two metals is present while the other is not. If one of you asks the other for a certain time so that he can return home, he should not grant it to him, for I fear for you the practice of usury”. 
(1329) 36 - The hadith above, was narrated by Abdallah Ibn Dinar from Abdallah Ibn Umar”. 
(1330) 37 - Al-Kassem Ibn Muhammad reported that Omar Ibn Al-Khattab said: "a dinar against a dinar, a dirham against a dirham, a sa' against a sa' and not to sell a present object against another which is not ". 
(1331) 38 - Abu Al-Zinad reported that he heard Sa'id Ibn Al Mous-saiab say: “Usury is only in the sale of gold or silver, of what is measured or weighed, of what is to be consumed or drunk”. 
(1332) 39 - Yahia Ibn Sa'id reported that he heard Sa'id Ibn Al Mousaiab say, "The exchange of gold and silver is corruption in the world of the living." - Malek said: “There is no no harm in a man buying gold for silver, and vice versa, whether it is gold powder or wrought articles. On the other hand, concerning dirhams and accounting dinars, it is not suitable for a person to buy them, as long as he does not know the nature and the number of these coins. If we buy them at a fixed price, we will have practiced usury, from the moment that we have neglected to count them, for therefore it is not a sale practiced by Muslims. But there's no harm in selling what's weighed gold dust or jewels worked, which is not the case, if one wants to buy them with fixed price. For it is considered as wheat, dates, and like them other foods that can be eaten. sell on credit, as long as they are weighed or measured". Malek finally said: "Whoever buys with dinars or dirhams, a Koran or a sword or a ring, encrusted with gold or silver, the value of the item purchased will be estimated by fixing the value of the precious material as well if the article is valued by two thirds and the precious material is by one third, this is tolerated, provided that the purchase is made on the field, and without any delay; It is the same for the article bought with the money”. “And such is, from time immemorial, the rule followed among us (in Medina)”. Chapter XVII The subject of change 
(1333) 40 - Ibn Chehab reported that Malek Ibn Aous Ibn Al-Hadathan Al-Nasri was looking for a change with someone one hundred dinars. Malek continued: “Talha Ibn Oubaidallah summoned me, and made me the exchange, taking the dinars in hand, then said to me: “Wait until my cashier comes back from “Al-Ghaba” so that I can change them for you. Omar Ibn Al-Khattab listening to us, said: "By Allah, you will not leave him until you have cashed your money", then he continued: "The Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said: "exchange the gold for money is usury except from hand to hand!”, so wheat against wheat is usury except from hand to hand!”, even dates against dates, subject to usury except from hand by hand!" and barley against barley where there will be usury, except from hand to hand!”. - Malek said: “If the man changes dirhams for dinars, then finds that one of the dirhams is falsified, and intends to return it, all the change is at cancel, and everyone will take back their change". The interpretation of the refusal of this change is due to the fact that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Be upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said: "Exchanging gold for money, is usury, except hand to hand!”. And Umar Ibn Al-Khattab said: “And if he asks you to give him some time, so that he can enter his house, do not allow him. If he gives you back a dirham change, after he leaves you, this is taken as a debt or for a sum to be paid at term. Such is the cause, for which this exchange is refused. And Omar Ibn Al-Khattab had refused to sell gold for money, or for food as a whole against a sum to be paid in time, because it is not suitable to sell the same commodity for a same species or of different species if payment is not made on time". Chapter XVIII Of the sale made after a weighing 
(1334) 41 - Yazid Ibn Abdallah Ibn Qusay reported that he saw Sa'id Ibn Al-Musaiab weighed his gold, pouring it into one of the pans of a balance, and his companion did so in the other pan. As soon as the equivalence between the two trays was made, each of them took the gold from the other”. - Malek said, "What is followed with us (in Medina) for the sale of gold for gold, and silver for silver, is to be made by weighing, namely that one will have ten dinars against eleven others, from hand to hand, if the weight is of an equivalence in the two trays, and even if there is a difference in the number of parts; The case will be the same for silver coins which are dirhams”. ; - Malek also said: “Whoever, exchanging gold for silver, finds that there is a difference in weight as regards the gold exchanged, and in compensation he will give to his companion the difference in silver or with another commodity, the latter must not accept it, because this is refused, to be usury, Thus, if it were tolerated to the first to have the surplus by paying the price, as if he had bought his share, he would be tolerated to buy it for his express price, making the sale lawful. What if the seller was going to give him this exceeding separately, the buyer would not have taken it, not even for the tenth of its real price that he had paid, by tolerating this kind of sale which will only be a certain way of making licit what is illicit, which justifies that it should be prohibited”. - Malek added: "Concerning the man who exchanges pure gold coins by adding them with gold powder of poor quality, against broken gold coins called "Koufia", and who is moreover repelled by people. That the two men make a transaction by this exchange, Malek does not allow it, interpreting this prohibition as follows: "The owner of the pure gold coins added with the gold dust does not seek to profit from these coins provided that he can make the gold powder flow, otherwise the other would not have accepted such a transaction, where he exchanged "his Koufia". This case is similar to a man who wanted to buy three sa's of “ajwa” dates in exchange for two sa's and a moudd of “Kabiss” dates. Telling him that this exchange is not allowed, he offered to give two sa's of “Kabiss” dates, and one Sa' of “hachf” dates, believing thus to make the exchange legal. However, even there, the exchange is not allowed because the owner of the "ajwa" would not have accepted to give him a sa' of such dates for a sa' of hachf, if he did not want to have other dates say "Kabiss" which are more valid To underline another example where a man says to another: "Sell me three sa's of white wheat in exchange for two sa's and a half of brown wheat". The other, answering him, that this is suitable only by exchanging his' by his', the first will have two sa's of brown wheat and one sa' of barley exchanged, thus seeking to return, between: them, the lawful transaction”. Now, even this transaction is repugnant, because the first would not have given a sa' of barley against a sa' of white wheat, if this sa' were exposed alone, however he had agreed to make this exchange, because the brown wheat is superior to white wheat. It is an example similar to what was previously said about gold dust. - Malek has definitely said, "Thus, whatever is gold, silver, or food, in short, , which is not permitted to be exchanged except on equal terms, it is not unsuitable about them, which is added to the goods of good quality, and which, moreover, is well appreciated by everyone, of the goods of mediocre quality, so that the sale is considered lawful; therefore, in doing so, or making lawful what does not is not. As long as what is mediocre has been mixed with what is well appreciated; the seller thereby seeks to convince of the good quality of what he sells”. Chapter XIX Sale at interest and the like 
(1335) 42 - Abdallah Ibn Umar narrated that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Be upon him the mercy and peace of Allah) said: "Whoever buys food, will not be able to resell it, until he has taken possession of it". 
(1336) 43 - Abdallah Ibn Umar reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Be upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said: "Whoever buys food, must not resell it, before it is in his possession”, thus, he cannot expose for sale a mediocre merchandise, which, if it had been designed to be sold by itself, it would not be bought only because it had been mixed with another commodity of good quality. Now, it is unseemly that gold, silver and food should be sold in this way, therefore, whoever wants to expose for sale a mediocre commodity, let him do it, but by keeping it separate from any other merchandise, with which he is forbidden to mix it. This being done, there is no harm”. 
(1337) 44 - Nafe' reported that Abdallah Ibn Umar said: "It is a fact, that in the time of the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him be Allah's grace and peace) we bought ourselves food (for merchandise); so the Prophet (salallahou alayhi wa salam) sent someone to us ordering us to move from the place where we had bought the food, to another so that we resold it”. 
(1338) 45 - Nafe a reported that Hakim Ibn Hizam bought food that Omar Ibn Al-Khattab offered to people. Hakim, having sold this food before he possessed it, and this was learned by Omar Ibn Al-Khattab, he gave it back to him, saying: "never resell a commodity that you have just bought, before it is in your possession". 
(1339) 46 - It was reported to Malek that titles had been given to people from the time when Marwan Ibn Al Hakam was governor, for food originating “Al-Jar”. People having exchanged between them, these titles before the food is in their possession, Zaid Ibn Thabet, and one of the companions of the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) went to Marwan Ibn Al-Hakam, and said to him: “O Marwan! How do you make usury lawful? He exclaimed, “I take refuge with Allah! What are you talking about"? They answered him, "About these titles, which the people exchanged with each other, before they possessed the food." So Marwan sent his guards, searching for these titles, snatching them from the hands of the people, and delivering them to their original owners”. 
(1340) 47 - It was reported in Malek that a man wanted to buy food from another, for a certain time. The seller, accompanied the one who wanted to buy food, to the market, showing him different kinds of food, and said, "What kind do you want to buy"? The buyer replied: “How do you sell me what you don't own? Then both went to Abdallah Ibn Omar, telling him what had happened. So Abdallah Ibn Umar addressed the buyer and said: “Do not buy from him, what he does not have? Then addressing the seller, said to him: “Do not sell what you do not own”. 
(1341) 48 - Yahia Ibn Sa'id reported that he heard Jamil Ibn Abdul Rahman the muezzin say to Sa'id Ibn Al Moussaiab: "I am a man who buys with the will of Allah the food vouchers from al-Jar, which are given to people, then I try to resell the food that I myself had guaranteed, at a certain time". So Sa'id said to him, "Are you looking for there, to pay you for this food before you have possessed it”? The other replied that yes, Sa'id forbade him”. - Malek said: “What is followed with us (in Medina) and which, moreover, is confirmed, is that the person who buys food such as wheat, barley, rye, corn, millet or other grasses oilseeds or what is similar to them, which in fact are subject to zakat, or even what is edible such as oil, fat, honey, vinegar, cheese, sesame, milk or other foodstuffs which are similar to them, the buyer, in the event that he wishes to resell such goods purchased, may only resell it after having possessed it and even paid the price ". Chapter XX Of refusing to sell food, at a certain time (1342)49 - Abu Al-Zinad reported that he heard Sa'id Ibn Al Moussaiab and Soulaiman Ibn Yassar prohibit the sale, with a certain delay, of wheat for gold, by which, following he s 'will buy dates, even before he has possessed the gold in question'. 
(1343) 50 - Malek a reported that Kathir Ibn Farqad asked Abu Bakr Ibn Muhammad Ibn Amr Ibn Hazem about a man who sells food for gold, with some delay in delivery, then he buys with this gold, dates, before he possessed the gold? Abu Bakr was against such a sale and banned it”. (.....) 51 - Ibn Chehab was of the same opinion». - Malek said: "However, Sa'id Ibn Al-Musaiab, Abu Bakr Ibn Muhammad Ibn Amr Ibn Hazm, Ibn Shehab, forbade the fact that a man sells the wheat exchanged for gold, with which he will buy dates, and that before he has possessed the gold which is due to him as the purchase price of the wheat. This is explained by the fact that he must buy with gold, the selling price of wheat, with a certain delivery time, dates from another seller than the one to whom he sold his wheat, and that before he owns the gold, then he makes a delegation of debt between the one from whom he bought the dates and the one to whom he sold the wheat, to recover the gold in question, this is tolerated” . Malek said: "I have asked many learned men on this subject, who have all approved of it." Chapter XXI The advance made for the purchase of food 
(1344) 52 Nafe'a reported that Abdallah Ibn Omar said: "It is tolerated that a man advances to another, well-qualified food, at a fixed price, and for a fixed period, except in the case of a harvest whose quality cannot be determined, or dates whose nature cannot be known". Malek said, “What is follow up with us (in Medina), about food advanced, at a fixed price, and made for a delay, and that the delay is over, if the buyer does not find the food requested from the seller, he will cancel this transaction by taking back his silver or his gold, which he had previously paid to the seller, or even the price at its full value. And he won't be able to buy with what he paid for, any goods, until he had the full amount paid. Because, if he takes back other than the sum paid, or if he leaves it with the seller from whom he buys a commodity other than food, he will have bought food even before he possessed it”. Malek continued: “And the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the mercy and peace of Allah) had forbidden the sale of the food before it is delivered (and the seller has taken possession of it). Malek added: “If the buyer regrets this purchase, saying to the seller: "Cancel this sale and I will give you a certain time so that you return to me the sum I paid you, that is not allowed, and men of science disapproved. For as long as the food may be in the possession of the buyer, at the order of the seller, and he has not yet taken it, for the purpose |of canceling it, such food shall be sold to a certain period of time before it is possessed by the buyer'. - Interpreting this, Malek says: “in case the buyer, the deadline ended, refuses the commodity having its price one dinar for a certain time, this is not considered a repeal of the sale-purchase contract, as long as neither the seller has asked for more nor the buyer has given more. And if this surplus is present and it is payable to a certain time, or that the seller and the buyer ask for and give something in addition from which one of them will benefit, this is also not an abrogation. However, it would be repealed if there has been a sale on either side. On the other hand, we tolerated the repeal, association and delegation, as long as they present neither surplus, nor reduction, nor adjournment; consequently if these last cases exist, that turns to a sale, subjected to the tolerances and the prohibitions”. - Finally Malek has said, “Whoever advances a quantity of brown wheat, it is good that he receive it after the time has expired. It will be the same for the advance of any other species, where it is allowed that it has a better or lower quality, once the deadline is ended. This is interpreted as follows: “Whether the man advances a quantity of wheat, it is good that he takes back in exchange for barley or brown wheat.
