Whether the advance made is “ajwa” dates, it is still to be exchanged for so-called “saihania” dates (mediocre and dry dates) or a heap of different qualities. Whether it's from red grape, it is to be exchanged for dry black grapes, provided that all such exchanges are accomplished after the period has expired, and that the measure thereof is equal to equal”. Chapter XXI The sale of food exchanged for another without distinguishing them 
(1345) 53 - It was reported to Malek that Soulaiman Ibn Yassar related: "The supply of the donkey of Sa'd Ibn Abi Waqas being exhausted, he said to his servant: "Take wheat from your parents, and exchange it for barley, and let it be in equal quantity. 
(1346) 54 - Nafe’a reported that Soulaimnan Ibn Yassar told him that, the supply of the donkey of Abdul Rahman Ibn Al-Aswad Ibn Abd Al-Yahouth, was exhausted, the latter said to his servant: "Take wheat from your parents, in as food, in exchange for which you will buy barley, and take only an equal quantity". 
(1347) 55 - It was reported to Malek that Al-Kassem Ibn Muhammad and Ibn Mu'aiqil Al-Dawsi acted similarly”. - Malek said: “What is followed with us (in Medina), it is that we do not sell wheat for wheat, nor dates for dates, nor wheat for dates, nor dates for raisins, nor wheat against raisins, nor any of that food, unless the sale is made from hand to hand. Because, as long as there is a delay in the transactions, the sale is no longer legal, but rather illegal. And let this be followed for any other food, if it is not exchanged from hand to hand”. - Malek also said: "You cannot sell food of the same kind in such a way that two quantities are exchanged for one, for example: that a moudd of wheat is exchanged for two moudds, nor a moudd of dates against two, nor a mudd of raisin against two, nor any other grasses or foods which are of one kind, even if it is made by hand. For this is considered to be analogous to the sale of silver for silver, and gold for gold, where what is lawful will be absent if there is a surplus, but present if the sale is made in equal proportion and hand to hand". - Malek continued: “If the food, intended to be eaten or drunk, presents a difference in measure or weight, and that therefore this difference is very clear, it is agreeable that the exchange of one measure be made for two, but from hand to hand. hand. Thus, it is correct to exchange one sa' of dates for two sa's of wheat, one sa' of dates for two sa's of raisins, one sa' of wheat for two sa's of fat. Thus, if the two species are different, it is agreeing to sell two measures in exchange for one, or even more, from hand to hand. But, if there is an expected delay (between delivery and payment), everything will be illicit". Malek finally said: - It is not legal that an indeterminate quantity of wheat is exchanged for another of the same kind, but on the contrary, if the exchange is made from hand to hand for a quantity of wheat against another of dates, and it is even tolerated that the we randomly sell wheat for dates”. * Subsequently, all difference highlighted for two kinds of food, will allow them to be bought, as a whole, in a random way and from hand to hand. But if the deadline is at its end, it is better not to do so, because buying randomly is the same as buying again random money by gold. However, whether wheat is randomly purchased for silver, or dates for gold, this is lawful and good”. * On the other hand, the one who piles up food, knowing its weight well, sells it to a buyer, without his admitting it to him, this is not permitted. Now, the case being, the buyer can deliver the food to the seller, lest he has been deceived, ignoring the weight. This is still the case, for all what the seller knows about it and the weight and measure of food and other merchandise, and yet the random sale, without the buyer knowing it. Thus, if the buyer is willing, he can return to the seller what he bought. Well-versed men constantly prohibit such a way of selling”. * It is not good, to sell bread one loaf for two, nor one large for one small, if some are larger than others. However, it is sought that the loaves be of the same size, so that the exchange is made on an equal basis, this is permitted, even without weighing them”. * It is not admitted that we sell a moudd of butter and a moudd of milk against two moudds of butter. This is similar to what was quoted about the dates sold, two sa's of 'kabiss' dates and one sa' of 'hachaf' dates in exchange for three sa's of 'ajwa' dates, when a man said to another: “I will give you two sa's of "Kabiss" dates against three others of "ajwa", searching there to sell his goods. The same goes for the owner of the butter and milk moulds, who wants to benefit from the other person, from a mould of butter, which is superior to mould of milk'. * It is permitted to sell wheat exchanged for flour, on an equal basis, because the flour has already been cleared of sound. Even in the case where half a moudd of flour, mixed with half a moudd of wheat, to be exchanged for a moudd of wheat, this is the same as the cases mentioned above (i.e. milk and butter, loaves of bread), therefore it is not permitted because this exchange of half a flour grind aims to have on the other hand a half wheat grind which is superior to it”. Chapter XXIII Selling all the food 
(1348) 56 • Malek a reported that Muhammad Ibn Abdallah Ibn Abi Mariam said to Sa'id Ibn Al Moussaiab: "I buy myself food by titles of 'Al-Jar', or it happens that I buy myself against a dinar and a half dirham (by these titles) where they give me half of the food”. Sa'id him answered: "No, it is better that you give yourself a dirham, and for the rest, take food". 
(1349) 57 - It was reported to Malek that Muhammad Ibn Sirin said: "Do not sell the grains while they are in their ears before they have become thick". - Malek said: A - When a man buy food for a specific price, and at a specific time, then that time ends, and the seller says to the buyer: "I do not have the food that I promised you, so sell- me for a fixed time", the buyer replies: "This is not tolerated because the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) has prohibited the sale of the food before it is possessed". The seller's reply: "So sell me this food for a fixed time so that I can fulfill it", this is still forbidden because it is as if gave him food to take back, and the gold he had given, shall be the price of what he owed, and the food which he had given him shall become lawful. Such a transaction, if carried out, will consist of selling food before having possessed it”. B - Concerning the man who owes a food from another, and that the latter owes it likewise from a third; that the second says to the first: "you will have to negotiate, about your food, with another, who owes me the same food which is moreover of the same value as that which you owe me". Malek said: “act thus, is forbidden, as it is a way of selling the food before it is possessed. However if the food is already possessed , it will be allowed that there is negotiation between the first and the third, because this case does not present any more an action to sell, for the good reason, that it is well known, the prohibition to sell a food before she is not possessed. This is, therefore, in accordance with the refusal of the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) concerning the above subject, while religiously versed men have held association, delegation, and avoidance of contract admissible when it comes to food. They also equated this case to a deed of good without them taking it for a sale. They have, at this title, gave the example of a man who lends to another dirhams whose weight is lower than the legal standard to have them later dirhams whose weight is legal; this is tolerated even if there is a difference in weight. But that he buys dirhams of an inferior quality to have after others which are legal, this is not tolerated. It is also forbidden for him to lend dirhams lower than what is legal and intends to take them back after the determined time, other dirhams of legal weight”. 
(1350) 58 - What is similar to the cases, cited above, is what the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) forbade about the sale called "Al-Muzabana", and allowed for Al'araya, namely to sell the fresh dates against the dry dates by distinguishing between them: Al-muzabana implies a damage, on the other hand the sale of al-araya is said to be an act of good”. - Malek said: A - II is not tolerated let a man buy food at the price of a quarter or a third or even a fraction of a dirham, provided he has this food after a while. But it is benevolent that he buys himself food by a fraction of a dirham so that he has this food after a determined time, then that he gives a dirham so that he has a commodity among many. others, for what remains to him of the value of his dirham, because he had given the fraction he owes, in money". B - It is tolerated that a man keeps in reserve at another, a dirham, then he buys a specific commodity for the value, or a quarter or a third or a fraction of this dirham”. But, if in this case, the price is not fixed and the man will say, "I buy myself goods according to the everyday price", this is not allowed, because it is random, where the seller can either increase or decrease the price at its own way. All the more so since they did not separate by agreeing both on the quantity of the goods and on its price”. C - When a man sells merchandise randomly, without discarding any part of it and then going to buy a part of it, this is not tolerated except if that part purchased is subject to a fixed exception of less than one-third. In case this part exceeds one third, it will be the mouzabana that is repelled. Thus, what is tolerated is at the limit of a third, and this is what is an undisputed norm with us (in Medina)”. Chapter XXIV Of grabbing and waiting 
(1351) 59 - It was reported in Malek that Omar Ibn Al-Khattab said: “Grabbing is prohibited in our markets. Men having within their reach the goods that Allah has granted us, and that they are in our markets, will not have to monopolize them. On the other hand, any man having brought a commodity, carrying it, winter and summer, on his back, this one is the guest of Omar: that he sell it as he wishes or even retain it". 
(1352) 60 - Sa'id Ibn Al Moussaiab reported that Omar Ibn Al-Khattab passed by Hateb Ibn Abi Balta'a, while he was selling his raisin in the market”. Omar Ibn Al-Khattab told him, "Either you sell according to the current market price, or you leave our market." 
(1353) 61 - It was reported to Malek that Osman Ibn Affan, forbade hoarding”. Chapter XXV Of the Permissible Sale of Animals of the Same Species, and of the Advance Paid on Them. 
(1354) 62 - Hassan Ibn Muhammad Ibn Ali Ibn Abi Taleb reported that Ali Ibn Abi Taleb sold a camel he owned, called 'Us-saifir', for twenty camelets, at a specified time. 
(1355) 63 - Nafe’a reported that Abdallah Ibn Omar bought himself a camel against four camelets guaranteed to him, while having to pay “Al Rabza”. 
(1356) 64 - Malek a reported that he asked Ibn Chehab about selling one animal for two, eventually? Ibn Chehab replied, "That is tolerated." - Malek said: * What is tracked at us (in Medina), it is that we tolerate the sale of a camel for the same camel, by paying dirhams more, from hand to hand. It is also tolerated the sale of a camel against another camel, and that the dirhams paid in addition, are paid in time. On the contrary, it is not it is not good that one camel is sold for another, in the long term, and that the dirhams paid in addition are paid as a cash sum. It is not good either, that the camel and the dirhams are delivered in time”. * It is good that we buys himself a camel of good breed, exchanged for two or more others of an ordinary breed from a herd of camels even if they are of the same species. It is even tolerated that one buys a camel against two in the future, provided that they do not show themselves clearly different, or on the contrary completely similar, with the variation or not of their kind, because in this case, it is not appropriate to sell forward, one, against two". * The interpretation of this refusal, is explained by the fact, that this exchange during the sale, of a camel against two, showed that there is neither superiority of race, nor power of load. Thus, if these two distinctions were not found, it is not necessary that one buys oneself in the long term, two for one. But it is tolerated that we sell what we bought, before it was possessed, to someone other than the one from whom we bought, if the price was paid to the latter”. * The one who pays in advance, for an animal, eventually, and that he has made the description of this animal, this is tolerated. Consequently, this becomes an obligation for both the seller and the buyer for having made the description of this animal. Besides, such a way of haggling, is always followed by people, and even accepted, by men versed among us (in Medina)”. Chapter XXI Animals that are prohibited from sale 
(1357) 65 - Nafe' reported that Abdallah Ibn Umar said that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) has forbidden the sale of what a female wears, and that she will give birth. It was a sale followed at the pre-Islamic era, when a man bought a carrying camel so that she gave birth and that the latter in turn would give birth to another camel”. 
(1358) 66 - Ibn Chehab a reported that Sa'id Ibn Al-Musaiab said: “Never practice usury in the animal trade. And we had forbidden this under three conditions: the sale of what the females carry, the mating stallions, and the female for what she carries and what she will give birth to". - Malek said: “He does not someone must not buy an animal which is described, and which is not present, even if he had previously seen and accepted it, by paying its price, and that its possession is made of it sooner or later”. This is refused, for the good reason that the seller has already taken advantage of the price, without knowing whether or not the goods in question are still in the initial state, as fixed by the buyer. This explains the refusal; on the other hand, this refusal is an admission, if the price is paid on condition that the animal to be sold, is such as it was described”. Chapter XXVII Selling animals for meat 
(1359) 67 - Zaid Ibn Aslam reported that Sa'id Ibn Al Musaiab said that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) has forbidden the sale of animals for meat”. 
(1360) 68 - Daoud Ibn Al-Hussain reported that he heard Sa'id Ibn Al Moussaiab say: “Among the games of chance, practiced in the pre-Islamic period, there was the sale of the animal against meat, and the sheep against two”. 
(1361) 69 - Abu Al-Zanad reported that Sa'id Ibn Al-Musaiab said; “We had forbidden the sale of the animal (live) against meat”. - Abu Al-Zanad also said: "Then I addressed myself to Sa'id Ibn Al-Musaiab, saying: that you say, about a man who bought an old camel for ten sheep”? Sa'id to reply: "If he bought it to sacrifice it, he is not good". And, added Abou Al-Zanad: "People I have known, have prohibited the sale of the animal against meat", and Abou-Zanad concludes: "And this had been prescribed to the prefects, of the time of Aban Ibn Osman and Hisham Ibn Ismaïl, to prohibit the sale of an animal against meat". Chapter XXVIII Meat sold for meat 
(1362) 70 - Malek said: “What is the unquestionably followed norm among us (in Medina), concerning the meat of camels, cows, sheep, and all animals like them, is to barter only on an equal basis, or equivalent weights, taking delivery immediately. He It is also tolerated that we barter meat, without having weighed it, provided that we have fixed the exchange of hand to hand. - Malek added: “He is tolerated to barter the flesh of fish, against that of camels, cows, sheep, and other animals, in the equivalence of two measures against one and in an immediate way. But if this is done in time, there will be no good”. Malek finally said: “As for the flesh of poultry, I see it as different, meat from herds and fish. Thus, it is tolerated that we buy it in order of preference. However, this flesh should never be sold in the long term”. Chapter XXIX Of what is the price of the dog 
(1363) 71 - Abu Mass'ud Al-Ansari reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him be Allah's grace and peace) forbade profit from the prize of the dog, of the reward of the prostitute, and of the wages of the soothsayer". And he means by the recompense in question, the price paid for fornication, and for the fortune of the seer, the bribe he receives so that he predicts. - Malek said: "I disapprove of the price of the dog, whether hunting, or otherwise, because the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) was against ". Chapter XXX Advances and sale of goods commingled with each other 
(1364) 72 - It was reported to Malek that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the mercy and peace of Allah) has forbidden any sale conditional on an advance”. Malek, performer this, says: “That a man says to another: I will buy at such price, your goods, provided that you advance me such sum, the contract of sale concluded according to the example above, is unacceptable. But if he who had laid down the condition of an advance, abandons it, this contract would be accepted”. Malek added: “There is no harm if the man buys himself a garment of "linen" (or "du Chatur" or "du Qassabi" in exchange for one or two or even three garments of the genre or "Itribi" or "Qassi" or “Ziqa” or “Harawi” or "Marwi" or even Yemeni clothes or izar, but whether it's skillfully done or eventually. If these garments are of the same fabric, the forward sale is wear and tear. Also, it is inappropriate to sell one piece of clothing for two, in the long run, unless they are clearly different, because if they are more or less the same and they are by the name of the different fabrics, this is always unsuitable, for example, that two garments from the “Harawi” are sold for one garment from the “Qouhi” or from the “Fourkoubi” for one garment from the “chatwi”. And if it is made that these genres are of the same quality, it is forbidden that we buy two clothes against one, in the long term". - Malek has finally says: "It is tolerated that one sells what one bought oneself by paying the price and before making possession of it, of the third person". Chapter XXXI The advance made for the purchase of goods 
(1365) 73 - Al-Kassem Ibn Muhammad reported that he heard Abdallah Ibn Abbas say - when a man asked him about another man, who paid in advance, the price of articles made of linen, expecting to sell them before not to have possessed them”? That this sale of money for money, is, answered Ibn Abbas, prohibited”. - Malek on this, answered: "There, I think, and Allah is most informed, that this man was seeking to sell the articles of the merchant from whom he had them. purchased from the same merchant at a much higher price than their purchase price. Now, if he was going to sell them to another person, that is permit”. - Malek said: "the norm unquestionably followed in Medina, is the following: "concerning, the one who pays in advance and on time, the slaves, the herds or other merchandise, so that the whole is qualified, if the date is due, the one who bought what is quoted above, cannot sell anything to the one from whom he bought, and especially of a higher price in comparison with what he had paid in advance for sum, before having the possession of this sum in question. And if he acts contrary, it will be usury, as long as the buyer having given the seller dinars or dirhams in advance, from which the latter had benefited, on the appropriate date, the buyer reselling the same goods to the seller before having ownership of the latter, the buyer would in this case have collected the sum paid in advance and an additional sum, and this is usury”. ' - Malek added: “The one who pays in advance and in the future, gold or silver to buy a herd or another qualified commodity and that the date is due, it is tolerated that the buyer sells part of his goods to the seller, against others (not of the same nature as the goods already purchased), but that it be done immediately, whatever the price. However, this is no longer tolerated, if it is about food, because it is not lawful for him to sell it, once he has owned it. Consequently, the buyer will be able to sell this commodity to someone who is not necessarily the seller from whom he bought this food, against gold or silver or any other commodity, of which he must immediately take possession without any delay. Because if he takes delayed possession will not be good, and it constitutes a sale of debt for term debt to a third person (i.e., who is no longer the buyer or the seller)". - Malek finally said: A - The one who pays advance, the price of a commodity which is neither food nor drink, and that this is done in time, this buyer, can sell it to whom he wishes for money or d other commodity, even before he possessed it from the seller; but, he must not sell what he has bought, to the seller, unless it is exchanged for a commodity to be possessed without any delay”. Before the date of delivery, the buyer is allowed to barter it to the seller, against a commodity of a different kind, and that this difference is quite clear, and also, that he immediately takes possession of this new commodity". B - The one who pays in advance, and eventually, dinars or money, to buy four pieces of quality fabric, on the due date, these pieces cannot be found at the seller's, and the buyer finds other pieces of fabric there of lesser quality, then if the salesman says to him: "I sell you, in exchange against the four pieces, eight others of another fabric", this is tolerated. Thus, if the buyer immediately takes these eight coins before he separates from the merchant, this is tolerated. However, it is not appropriate to make this transaction either before or even on the due date, unless the parts exchanged are different from those for which the price has been paid in advance”. Chapter XXXU The sale of copper, iron, and similar metals by weight (1366)74-Malek said: - The rule followed at us (in Medina), concerning that which is sold by weight, with the exception of gold and silver, namely red or yellow copper, lead, and tin, iron, vegetables, figs, cotton, or other products similar to them and sold by weight, it is good, to skilfully sell of the same species, two weights against one, for example two weights of iron, against a weight of the same metal”. - However, it is not not good, that one sells, in the long term, two weights against a weight, of the same species, of any product quoted above. But if they are different, and that this difference is clear, it is tolerated that the sale is made for two masses against one mass, and in the long term. On the other hand, if they are close, by their category, and even if they are of different names such as lead and tin, red copper and yellow copper, I disapprove, says Malek, that we sell two weights against one in the long term”. - On the other hand, when we buys all the products, previously mentioned, it is tolerated even before owning them to sell them to a third party, as long as you collect the price, and provided that you have bought them by weight or measure ". “But if the purchase was made without taking no measurement of the goods, whether these products are sold to a third party in cash or on credit, because the guarantee is imposed there. However, this guarantee will no longer be compulsory if the sale is made after having either weighed or measured the products and after they have been received'. "And that's the best I've heard about it, and people keep following it back home (in Medina)." - What is tracked for that which is measured or weighed, and which is neither to be eaten nor to be drunk, such as safflower, pits, tree leaves, myrtle and other species similar to them, is that it is tolerated that two quantities of the same species are sold for one, provided that this is not done in time. But if the two species differ and that their difference is clearly perceived, it is tolerated to sell two quantities against one, but in the long term. And all that one will have bought of these products, it is tolerated that one sells them to a third person, on the condition of having taken possession of it and to have touched the price of it. - And all that people sell to profit from it as products even if it is about small pebbles or plaster, if one sells them, two quantities against one, in the long term, it is usury; or even that it is a quantity against a similar and something else in addition, done in the long term, it is also wear and tear”. Chapter XXXIII The ban on making two kinds of sales in one 
(1367) 75 - It was reported to Malek that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him be Allah's grace and peace) forbade making two kinds of sales in one”. 
(1368) 76 - It was reported to Malek that a man had said to another: “Buy for me this camel in cash, so that I may buy it from you in the future". Abdallah Ibn Omar, questioned on this subject, refused such a sale and prohibited it”. 
(1369) 77 - It was reported in Malek that Al-Kassem Ibn Mouhammad had been questioned about a man who had bought goods at ten dinars in cash or at fifteen dinars in advance". al-Kassem, had rejected such a purchase, and forbade it”. - About a man who had bought from another, a commodity, either at ten dinars cash, or at fifteen forward, and that the buyer will have to opt for one of these two prices, Malek said: "This is not tolerated, because if he fact that the ten dinars will be paid later, they must be paid at the value of fifteen; and if he pays the ten dinars in cash, it is as if he had bought what is worth fifteen dinars forward”. - Malek was questioned, about a man who bought from another, a commodity, either at ten dinars in cash, or for a specific good quality sheep, at term, and that the buyer, therefore, must opt for one of the two prizes", he replied: "This is not tolerated, and is refused, because the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Be upon him be grace and peace of Allah) forbade the two sales made in one". And the sale in question is an example of this. - For the man who said to another: "I will buy from you, for one dinar, fifteen sa's of dates "ajwa" or ten sa's of dates "Saihania", or fifteen sa's of wheat deliverable, or ten sa's of brown wheat, and I owe one of these goods," Malek said, "Such a sale is forbidden, for, by the price he fixes, the buyer gives himself the choice of taking what he wants, preferring for example the fifteen sa's of "ajwa" to the other ten of "Saihania", or fifteen sa's of ordinary wheat to another ten of brown wheat. This is similar to what is prohibited for two sales made in one, and again what is inadmissible regarding the sale of the same kind of food, two quantities against one, and to have at the same price”. Chapter XXXIV The random sale 
(1370) 78 - Sa'id Ibn Al Musaiab reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him be Allah's grace and peace) forbade the random sale”. - Malek said: - What is random and yet another form of bet is that a man, having lost his mount or his maroon slave, the price of which is fifty dinars, that a another says to him: "I will buy it from you at the price of twenty dinars", at the case, where the buyer finds it, the seller will have lost thirty dinars; Where in case he does not find it, the seller will have received the sum of twenty dinars from the buyer”. “On the other hand, it is vicious for another reason, in the event that what was lost is found, but while being changed a little or too much, or even having suffered some defect, this constitutes a great risk”. - However, what is followed with us (in Medina), and which is considered as random, the purchase of what women and females wear; for one cannot know whether what is worn will be brought into the world, and one cannot know whether it will be beautiful or ugly, of a complete or incomplete creation, male or female; and in all this there are preferences, from such to such, and its value will be such and such according to the state”. - Still it is not tolerated to sell the females by setting aside, what they carry; that a man for example says to another: "the price of my dairy sheep is three dinars, but I will give it to you at two, at provided that I have what she wears; but this is refused, because it is a random and risky sale”. - It is unlawful that olives are sold for olive oil, nor sesame for oil, nor fat for butter, because the mouzabana comes into play here. game in this case. Although a man buys grain or the like for himself, against what he can extract from these grains, not even knowing, if what is extracted is less or more, this is also random and risky”. - It is the same for whoever buys willow seeds for their crude oil, this is random, because what is extracted from willow seeds is none other than its raw material. However, it is tolerated that willow seeds be exchanged for scented seeds, as the latter have been subjected to a transformation where they have been perfumed, dried, so that they are no longer in the state of a raw material”. - About a man instructing another to sell him a commodity by fixing him a minimum price, Malek said: "Such a sale is illicit and is even random". And this is interpreted as follows: “it is as if he hired him, for a profit, in case this commodity will be sold at a price exceeding that which had been fixed. But if it is sold either at the same price, or less, and the effort of the buyer is in vain, this is not permitted. Because he is entitled to a salary evaluating the effort he had made for the sale. As for the seller, he will, on his part, be entitled to profit or loss, if the merchandise has been sold at a higher or lower price. On the other hand, he must assume the loss if this merchandise remains unsold, to be sold later at a lower price. But if the goods are still in demand, the sales contract will be cancelled”. - Malek has finally said: "But if a man definitely sells to another, a commodity, as a result of which the buyer will regret this transaction, saying to the seller: give me a discount" and that the latter answers him: “Sell it instead, and you won't lose", this sale is tolerated, because it has nothing random, because the difference in price will be borne by the seller even if it is not a term of the contract, and this is what, moreover, we follow in Medina". Chapter XXXV The moulamassa” and “the mounabaza” 
(1371) 79 - Abu Huraira reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him be Allah's grace and peace) forbade "mulamassah and mounabaza". - Malek said: “the moulamassa is to allow the man to touch the fabric, without spreading it, thus ignoring, if there is a defect, or that he buys it at night, without having examined it properly". “And the mounabaza, is that a man spreads his cloth and another spreads his without one examining the cloth of the other, then that one says to the other: such cloth against Phone; but this is what is forbidden from the moulamassa and the mounabaza”. - About the sale of Persian fabric in their wrapper or the so-called "Qoubti" fabric all folded, Malek said: "It is only tolerated to sell them after having spread them out, examining them, otherwise their sale is random and precisely she is almoulamassa”. - On the other hand, the sale of the pieces of fabric according to the catalog is quite different from that of Persian and Qubti fabrics. This practiced sale that people have been following for a long time, imitating in this way, those who preceded them, is always allowed, because it is not designed to be random like the moulamassa, even if there has not been to spread the fabrics”. Chapter XXXVI Selling for a profit 
(1372) 80 - Malek reported: "What is followed with us (in Medina), about a haberdasher who buys clothes from one country, to sell them in another, aiming to make a profit", is that it will have to exclude from the price: the sum to be paid for the brokers, the costs of bending and pulling, and the rental of the house. As for the cost of transporting these garments, they will be part of the initial price, without considers a profit, unless the seller makes it known to the buyers; this being the case, if they can make him benefit from a certain sum, willingly, this will be tolerated”. - Malek said: “For this which is laundering, sewing and dyeing, they are to be considered, just like the case of clothing. The profit one earns on them is to be calculated just as it is done for clothes. In the event that the haberdasher sells the clothes without informing the buyer of the costs mentioned above, he is not owed any additional profit. Thus, if the clothes are not sold, the transport costs will be part of the price, without counting any additional profit, if the opposite occurs, any sale is to be eliminated, between seller and buyer, except if the latter s 'agree with each other on other items that may be purchased'. - About the man who buys goods for gold or silver, and that on the day of the purchase, the dinar was equivalent to ten dirhams, then that this man is in another country in order to sell them for a profit, or that he sells them in the same country, for the one from whom he buys them. is purchased, according to the exchange that took place on the very day of this sale", Malek said: "If he had bought them and paid for them with dirhams, and sold them for dinars, or vice versa, and that the goods were still at the sale the buyer will have to choose: either to buy these goods or to leave them. But if the goods are not sold, the buyer has the right to buy them according to the paid purchase price which will be the right of both. - If a man sells a goods that he had bought for a hundred dinars, in such a way, to receive eleven dinars against the ten, as selling price, then he realizes that the purchase price was not more than ninety dinars and that his merchandise is no longer sold, the seller will have the choice of receiving the value of his merchandise according to the price at which he sold it, unless this sum is greater than that which he had as right on the day of the sale; in this case, he does not receive more than the price, namely, against a hundred dinars, he will have ten more, or else a profit will be calculated for him taking into account the real price which was four and twenty and ten except if the value of the goods is lower than the actual value; in this case, he can receive a sum worth the real price of the goods, namely 90 dinars and a gain of ten for ceni which is nine, and thus, he will have an overall sum of four and twenty and ten and nine dinars”. - Malek finally said: "if a man sells a commodity for a gain, saying that he bought it for a hundred dinars, then someone comes and tells him after a while, that the buyer who had already bought this commodity, in made at one hundred and twenty dinars, the buyer will have to choose: either that he gives the seller the sum which is the price of the goods, on the day of the sale, namely one hundred dinars, or that he gives an amount equivalent to the price sale taking into account the gain he has obtained whatever it is, and which does not must not, in any case, be less in value than the purchase price, because it has no right to cause the seller any loss, since the sale was concluded pursuant to a transaction made between the two parties . Because, in such a case, the seller may claim the difference in price and the buyer on his part cannot refuse it and make a discount of the purchase price according to the catalog”. Chapter XXXVII Selling according to a catalog 
(1373) 81 - Concerning the men who have bought a commodity such as clothes or slaves, and that a man was aware of this purchase, that he comes to say, to one of them: "The clothes you bought at such and such a merchant, I already know their quality and their nature. Do you want, therefore, that I make you benefit from a certain sum concerning your share, for what is purchased? The other having accepted it, then the new buyer will make him benefit from a sum, and consequently, becomes, a partner in his place among men, in case, where the buyer examines the goods, and finds them ugly and unsuitable; Malek said on this subject, "He must obligatorily discharge it, and will not be able to refuse any more, as long as he bought the goods according to a well described and known catalog". - Malek also added: “A haberdasher, having received a quantity of fabrics, and that the merchants are present at his home, he reads his catalog to them, saying: “With such a measurement one can make a Basrarian coat, with such another a "Sabria", and so on, so, buy these fabrics, according to this which I have just informed you". Then the merchants buy these fabrics as they have been described, realize later, on examining them, that they have been paid for at a high price, and regret that this purchase has been concluded". On this subject, Malek said: “This sale is assigned to them, as long as it has been shown to be suitable for the catalog”. Moreover, it is the rule followed by people here (in Medina), that they never stop judging lawful between them, if what is bought is in conformity with the catalog, without it being different from it” . Chapter XXXVIII The optional sale 
(1374) 82 - Abdallah Ibn Umar reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said: “A seller and a buyer, who have agreed among themselves on an optional sale, have the right to withdraw from the sale as long as they have not separated, unless the sale is not made at option". Malek said: “The question of the option has, for us (in Medina), no limit, nor a precise thing”. 
(1375) 83 - It was reported to Malek that Abdallah Ibn Mass'ud taught that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) had said: "A seller and a buyer, who between them, have concluded a sale and quarrel, one takes into account what the seller stipulates, otherwise, the contract of sale is to be cancelled”. Malek said, “A man, buys goods, and the seller stipulates, before the sale is concluded, that he must consult a third person in such a way that: "If the latter agrees, the sale is permitted, otherwise there will be no more sales". The contract is concluded between them, then immediately after the buyer regrets it even before the seller has consulted, the third party", Malek says: "This sale is an obligation, according to what was agreed between them, by Consequently, the buyer does not have to choose, if the third person consulted agrees. - Malek finally said: “Let a man buy himself a commodity from another, then let them both dispute the price, and the seller says: "I sold it to you for ten dinars" and the buyer replies: "No, I bought it for five", we will say, in this case to the seller: "If you want, you can sell it to him, at the price he has fixed, or else, swear to sell it to him only at the price you have just told him". Now, if the seller swears, the buyer will be told: "Either you buy the goods at the price the seller has fixed, or you swear to buy them only at the price you have even fixed. If the buyer takes an oath, it is considered, in this case, that each of these two, the buyer and the seller, accuses each other”. Chapter XXXIX usurious debts 
(1376) 84 - Abu Saieh, the servant of “Al-Saffah” (the first of the Abbasite caliphs) reported: “I had sold for a certain period of time a garment which belonged to me to people from “Nakhla” (place in Medina). Then wanting to leave at Al-Koufa, they offered to pay me the cash price by making a discount? I was going to ask about this Zaid Ibn Thabet who said to me: "I order you not to do this, nor to let others the right to do so”. 
(1377) 85 - Salem Ibn Abdallah reported that Abdallah Ibn Umar was asked about a man who eventually owes a debt to another, and asks the creditor to postpone to pay it before the due date”? He disapproved of this and even prohibited it. 
(1378) 86 - Malek a reported that Zaid Ibn Aslam said: "Usury, in pre-Islamic times, consisted in the fact that a man owed a debt to another, and if so, he said: 'Do you want to pay it to me, or you will pay it later with interest”? Thus, if he pays the other will have what is in his right; otherwise, he will grant him a delay, after the debt increases, of a certain interest”. - Malek said: “what unquestionably repugnant to us, (in Medina), is that a man having a debt to pay to another the first makes a remission to the second in order to recover his money before its term, which consequently is to be compared, in the case where a creditor will grant a delay to his debtor by increasing the debt by a surplus (taken as interest); but that is, no doubt, wear and tear». - Malek also said: “Concerning a man, who owes another a debt of one hundred dinars, and eventually; on the due date, that the debtor says to the creditor: "Sell me, a commodity at the cash price of one hundred dinars, and one hundred and fifty dinars in the future"; Malek replied, "It's a sale that is not admitted, and such is always what is repugnant, by well-versed men". - Malek finally said, interpreting the cause of this repugnance: "It is that the creditor would have, in this case, sold to the debtor, the goods at its real price, by delaying the payment of one hundred dinars, in the long term, to which, he will add fifty dinars because of delay. But this is repugnant, and inadmissible. Moreover, this is to be compared, to what Zaid Ibn Aslam reported, concerning the sale in the pre-Islamic era, where once the debts were due on the date, they said: "Where you pay, or your debt is increased; If he paid, the creditor took his due; otherwise, the debt was increased, by a certain amount of interest, to be paid on time”. Chapter XLL Debt and transfer of debt (to a third party) 
(1379) 87 - Abu Huraira narrated that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam)r (Upon him be the grace and peace of Allah) said: “Let a rich man, delays, what he has to pay, is an injustice. If one of you receives a delegation, of debt on a solvent man, that he accepts this delegation. 
(1380) 88 - Malek a reported that Moussa Ibn Maissara heard a man ask Sa'id Ibn Al-Musaiab: "I am a man who sells on credit". So Sa'id answered him, "Sell only with what you need to get home." - Malek said: "Concerning a man who buys a commodity from another, on condition that he deliver it to him on a definite date, and that be for a fair where he wishes to sell it, or for a necessity at the designated time and then the seller does not deliver it to him on the scheduled date, which will lead the buyer to return the goods". In this regard, Malek said: "The buyer will not have the right to do so, and he must pay the price of the goods purchased, because if the seller had delivered them to him before that date, the buyer would have accepted them”. - Malek also said: "For he who buys food, and measures it or weighs it, and then someone comes to his house, wanting to buy it for him, and the owner of the food informs him that he had bought it for himself- even, and having even weighed it, the buyer believes it and wants it take according to the measurement already made, paying the cash price”. Malek in this regard says: “What is sold according to such criteria, is permitted; but if it is sold, according to this term criterion, it is repugnant, unless the buyer does not weigh or measure the goods himself. either not of the same measure or of the same weight. And if this sale is made in time, it is repugnant, And there is no disagreement on this subject with us (in Medina)”. -Malek added: “He does not should not buy a debt from a man, whether or not he is present, if there is not a declaration made on the part of the debtor, nor from a dead person even if one knows what this dead man left, because the fact of buying in this way is uncertain, especially since we do not know whether or not it is possible to complete this transaction”. As for the interpretation of this reluctance, it is explained as follows: "If one buys a debt from an absentee or from a dead person, one does not know what unknown creditor is attached to this debt, this . Thus, if the deceased owed a debt, the sum which had been paid will remain vain and useless”. - Malek finally said: “Let us underline, too, the presence of another vice: It's that he bought this which is not guaranteed for him. And if what is bought is not delivered to the buyer, the price he should have paid would be vain and invalid. And it's still random, and it's not allowed. - However, added Malek, there is a difference between the fact that the man only sells what he owns, and on the other hand, that the man advances for something that he does not in fact own. Whoever wants to buy a commodity takes his money, what he intends to buy and says: “What do you want me to buy you with these ten dinars? Now, acting as such, it is as if he sells them cash for fifteen forwards. It is for this reason that the sale is considered prohibited and is usury, even an imposture”. Chapter XLI Association, delegation (of debts) and termination 
(1381) 89 - Concerning the man who sells several kinds of clothes, making an exception of some that are embroidered, Malek said: “If he wants, keep away a few of these clothes, there is no harm in that; but if he does not make a choice, with the exception of a few clothes, I believe that he becomes a partner in the clothes that we bought from him, because it is possible that the two clothes are embroidered in the same way, and yet their prices are different”. - Malek said: “what is followed at (in Medina), it is that there is no harm in association, delegation and termination being particulated in respect of food and other goods, be- whether they are deliverable or not, and whether the sale is made in cash, without there being neither profit, nor lack, nor delay in payment. However, if one of these three aspects is present, the sale will be lawful like any other sale, and prohibited for any prohibition found in the sale. Therefore, there will be no association, delegation or termination”. - Malek also said: “Whoever buys for merchandise, either clothes or slaves, and that there is a man proposing to the buyer, that he is associated in this sale thus paying, both, the price of the merchandise. Subsequently, if the goods, for any reason, are no longer deliverable, in such a way that the partner asks for his money from the other, and the first in turn claims the full price of the goods of the seller, except that the first buyer asks his associate just at the sale and session done, telling him: "The deposit that is yours, belongs to the seller". But after separation and the first buyer has neglected this condition, he will bear all responsibility”. - Malek finally said, "Let one man say to another: buy this merchandise for both of us, equally, paying my share as regards the price, as for me, I will take care of selling it to you", that is not allowed, for the following good reason: "When the man says, let the price be paid by the other, as for him, he will take care of the sale, it is as if the half of the price will be considered as an advance made to the second person, due to being responsible for the sale. On the other hand, if this merchandise is no longer valid, or it is no longer salable, the buyer may have from his partner, half the price that he had paid, and this value will be like an advance which will imply a profit (which is usury). But if a man buys a commodity, which is already his property, and another says to him: "Make me associated with this merchandise by paying me the price I owe, as for me, I will resell it to you" , this is licit, and is even tolerated. The interpretation of this means that it is a new sale which is accomplished by selling him half of the merchandise, and the other will later be the seller”. Chapter XLII Debtor's bankruptcy 
(1382) 90 - Abu Bakr Ibn Abdul Rahman Ibn Al-Hareth Ibn Hisham reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said: "When a man sells a commodity to another, and the one who has just bought it goes bankrupt, while the seller has not received anything from the price of the merchandise which is intact, the seller has more rights than the buyer, and can take back his merchandise. However, in the event that the buyer dies, the seller will be held to be a creditor”. 
(1383) 91 - Abu Hurairah reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him be Allah's grace and peace) said: "The man who finds as is his goods which he had sold to another who has gone bankrupt, the former has more right than anyone else to take back his goods”. - Malek said: A - When a man sells goods, and the buyer goes bankrupt, if the seller finds his goods as they are, he can take them back. Yes the buyer had already partially sold this merchandise, or even that he had distributed it, the seller will have the full right to take back the rest, without that, what has been partially sold of this merchandise, does not prevent him from taking it back. Even, if he wishes, he can return to the buyers what he received from the price. And as for the part that cannot be found, the seller will be a creditor in relation to the buyer who has made a deficit”. B - The one who buys himself any commodity, either weaving yarn, or a piece of land or something else, then that what is bought has been or worked - such as building a house on the land - or making thread a fabric, then the buyer made a deficit, bearing the owner of the piece of land to say to the buyer: "I am buying this piece of land, including what is built", this is not tolerated. Then we will evaluate the land, and what is built on it by the buyer, and we will fix both the price of the land and that of what is built on it, following which, the buyers will both be partners, emphasizing that the owner of the land will have what is his share, as for the creditors, they will have a share, what is built”. Interpreting this, Malek said, “Assuming that the assessed price is one thousand five hundred dirhams, then the value of the land will be five hundred, and that of what is built, one thousand dirhams. Therefore, the owner of the land will have one-third, and the other creditors, two-thirds. It will be the same with regard to weaving thread and the like, if they are worked and the buyer is indebted for them by a sum of which he cannot manage to get rid of them. acquit”. C - But as far as sold goods that the buyer had not worked on, except that their price has become higher, and that their owner is willing to keep them, as well as the creditors are willing on their part to retain them, these creditors will have to choose : or they pay at owner the price of the goods which he had sold, without reducing it, or that they return his goods to him. In the event that the price of the goods is reduced, the person who had optionally sold them may, if he wishes, take back his goods, without owing the creditors a share of his goods; or he is to be considered as one of the creditors, so he will be entitled to a share of the property, without have the goods”. D - The one who buys himself a slave or a mount who engenders at his place, then that he made a deficit, the slave or the mount with his child must return to the seller, except if the creditors do not want to pay him the price of the slave or the mount with her little one, so that they may retain them". Chapter XLIII Of what is advance allowed 
(1384) 92 - Abu Rafe, the freedman of the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) reported: “The Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) owed a young camel, to a man, who came to ask him for it; camels of alms, having reached the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (On him the grace and peace of Allah) he ordered me to give the man his camel. Telling him, that among the camels, there was not a camel of the same age, but another six years old, the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said to me: "Give it to him, because the best of you is the one who fulfills the payment of the debt he owes with the most of liberality”. 
(1385) 93 - Mujahed a reported that Abdallah Ibn Umar owed a man a certain amount of money, he gave him an amount exceeding that of the debt. Thereby the man said, “O Abu Abdul Rahman, what you have just given me for the debt is much more than what you owe me”; then Abdallah Ibn Omar answered him: "I know, but I had done it with all my soul". - Malek said: “He is tolerated to the one who advanced all that relates to either gold, or silver or food or an animal, to receive from the one who owes him, what is better compared to what he advanced, if ever there was between the two, no proposed condition, or custom. But if any condition or custom or anything is present, it is repugnant, and therefore does not bring any good." Interpreting this, Malek said, "The Messenger of Allah (Be upon him be grace and the peace of Allah) had acquitted himself against a young camel that he owed, another older camel and Abdallah Ibn Omar of a surplus debt. What is tolerated as long as there has been neither condition nor custom, therefore this is tolerated and licit”. Chapter XLV Prohibited Advances 
(1386) 94 - It was reported to Malek, that Omar Ibn Al-Khattab had made to another, a debt of food, on the condition that the second will return it to him in another country. And Omar said: "And the transport costs, who will take care of that?" 
(1387) 95 - It was reported to Malek that a man, on his way to see Abdallah Ibn Omar, said to him: "O Abu Abdul Rahman, I advanced a debt to a man, asking him to return it to me with a surplus" . So Abdallah Ibn Omar: “Such is the attrition”. The man resumed: “What are you ordering me to do”? Abdallah to answer: “The advance is of three aspects: one that you will advance desiring thereby, the Face of Allah, and you will have it; another of fact, where you will seek to please your companion, and you will receive his satisfaction; a third of accomplished, where you aim to get a lot more, and such is the wear”. The man again said, “What do you order me to do, O Abu Abdul Rahman”? He replied, "I conceive that you have to cancel the contract of the advance made; so if he gives it back for the same value you will have to accept it; if he gives it to you less than its value, and you accept it, you will have the reward; and if he gives you back wve advance of much more worth than the yours, he will thus show his gratitude, which is moreover a form of thanks, as for you, you will still have a reward». 
(1388) 96 • Nafe' reported that he heard Abdallah Ibn Umar say: “Whoever makes a loan should only ask to be reimbursed”. 
(1389) 97 - It was reported to Malek that Abdallah Ibn Mass'oud said: “He who makes a loan, should not ask that the collection be much better, even if it is a handful of food, it will be wear and tear». - Malek said: “What is unquestionably followed among us (in Medina), about the one who borrows a well-defined animal for any enjoyment, that it is tolerated, on condition of returning an animal similar, except for the case of female slaves, where there would be the risk of doing what is not lawful, which in fact will be unlawful, but this is not allowed. The interpretation of this repugnance is explained as follows: "Supposing that a man borrows a slave, that he cohabits as he pleases, then that he returns her to her possessor, which is neither tolerated, or lawful. And well-versed men keep forbidding it without ever giving anyone permission to do so." Chapter XLV What is prohibited about haggling and overbidding 
(1390) 98 - Abdallah Ibn Umar reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Be upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said: "Let none of you outbid another ". 
(1391) 99 - Abu Huraira narrated that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him be Allah's grace and peace) said: "Do not go in front of caravans, that one of you does not sell to another, a commodity that he had already sold, do not indulge in one-upmanship, that a city dweller does not sell for a Bedouin, do not let the milk accumulate in the breasts of female camels and ewes, because the one who has bought one of them, will have the right when milking them either to keep it if he is satisfied with it, or to return it if he does not like it with a sa' of dates (in exchange for his milk ). By interpreting this hadith, Malek said: "What is meant by this, and Allah is most aware of it, that one should not overbid in sales, that it is intolerable for a man to outbid a commodity, when his co-religionist brother has already negotiated it, and that the seller on his part has agreed with the buyer on the weight of the gold, and has guaranteed against any defect that may exist in the goods , noting that the seller does not want to give his goods to the second buyer. This is what the Apostle of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him be the grace and peace of Allah) has forbidden, and Allah is most aware of it. - Malek added: “He There is nothing wrong with haggling the price, where all final sales will be suspended, as long as everyone has the right to participate in the haggling. If people left the haggling and stopped at the price that the first buyer had already offered, the goods would have been sold at a low price and the sellers would be damaged. And this is what is always practiced in Medina”. 
(1392) 100 - Abdallah Ibn Umar reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the mercy and peace of Allah) had forbidden that we supplant others”. - Malek performing it says: "The action of overbidding is that a man gives a commodity a price exceeding what is effectively its value at the moment when one no longer intends to buy it but only to push another to buy it at this high price". Chapter XLVI On the sale in general 
(1393) 101 - Abdallah Ibn Umar reported that a man had taught the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) that he was deceived during the sale”. The Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said to him: "When you go to buy, tell the seller: "no deception". And this man, making the purchase, was saying to the seller: “no deception”. , 
(1394) 102 - Yahia Ibn Sa'id reported that he heard Sa'id Ibn Al Moussaiab say: "If you arrive in a country and you find, that it is taken into account and the measure and the weight, make there, a long stay . On the other hand, if you find yourself in a country where weight and measure are neglected, hurry to leave this place”. 
(1395) 103 - Yahia Ibn Sa'id reported that he heard Muhammad Ibn Al-Munkader say: “Allah loves the servant who shows magnanimity when selling, or buying, or paying or claiming his right”. Malek said A - Concerning the man who buys camels, or sheep, or clothes, or slaves, or any other commodity that can be counted, there is nothing random about this. B-About the man who gives another a commodity to sell it, when its owner had already made his assessment by saying to the other: "If you sell it for me at the price I have fixed, you will have a dinar" or something else what they agreed on and on which the two agree, and say if you don't sell it you won't get anything". This is tolerated, if the sale price of the goods, and what the seller will receive, is a fixed salary. So if he sells, he will benefit, if not, he will have nothing”. C-This is similar to a man who says to another, "If you can find me my runaway slave, or my stray camel, you will have such sum", this is considered as a fee paid, and not a salary, because the salary in this case does not is more suitable”. D As for the man to whom one gives a commodity, saying to it "Sell it, and you will have such an amount as a percentage of each dinar", this is not allowed because each dinar, reduced by the price of the goods, will imply a reduction in the duty of the other, and this is random". 104 Malek reported that he had asked Ibn Chehab about a man who rented a mount, then he in turn rented it at a higher price than the first rental? He replied, "There is nothing wrong with that." MOUATTAA In the name of Allah the Merciful the Merciful Book 32 The Limited Partnership Book “AI-Qirad” First chapter Of what is said about the limited partnership 1396) 1 - Zaid Ibn Aslam reported that his father said: “Abdallah and Oubaidallah, the two sons of Omar Ibn Al-Khattab, left with a troop towards Iraq. Once back, they passed by Abu Musa Al-Ach'ari, who was the governor in Basrah, who welcomed them cordially. Then he said to them: “If I could be of any use to you, I would have made". Then he continued: “I keep on me a certain amount of money forming part of the public treasury, which I intend to send to the prince of the believers. I deliver it to you, with which, you can buy goods from Iraq, which you will sell in Medina. Thus you will give to the prince of the believers the capital of the money, and you will have the benefit of it”. They replied, "We want to do that." He gave them the money, and sent in writing to Umar Ibn Al-Khattab, to receive the money from them. Once they arrived (in Medina) they sold the merchandise, and made a profit. They gave Umar the sum of money, he said to them: "Did he act similarly, with all the troop of the army, as he did with you"? They replied, “No”. Omar Ibn Al-Khattab resumed: “As you two are the sons of the prince of the believers, he acted in this way with you. Give me the capital of money and its profit”. While Abdallah was silent, Oubaidallah, said, “Why do you act this way, O prince of believers? If the money had diminished or was lost, we would be obliged to insure it.” Omar resumed: “Give it then”. Abdallah always kept silent Oubaidallah proposed to his father to reflect; immediately one of Omar's companions said, "O prince of the believers, and if you made this money, a capital of a limited partnership "Al-Qirad", to which Omar replied, "Yes I will do so". So Omar took the capital and half of the profit, and the other half was the share of his two sons Oubaidallah and Abdallah". 
(1397) 2 - Al-'Ala Ibn Abdul Rahman reported according to his grandfather that Osman Ibn Affan had given him a limited sum of money, to be used in trade, on condition that the profit be shared between them”. Chapter II What is allowed in the limited partnership 
(1398) 3 Malek said, “Sponsorship is permitted when a limited partner gives a capital to a general partner in order to use it in trade, without the latter wishing to insure it. Subsequently what the general partner will spend during his trip, and for his food and for his clothes and in case the capital is portable and of sufficient value, will be taken from the capital. Thus, if the general partner is resident in his country, he will not be entitled to any capital expenditure, not even for his clothes”. - Malek said, “It is tolerated that sponsor and general partner suitably agree if there are no stipulations on either side. The sponsor can buy whatever he wants from the general partner, for merchandise, if the sale is made normally, without being subject to a condition. - Malek added: “He who advances to a man and to a slave, a capital, in order to use it in trade, there is no harm in that, and it is permissible because the profit accrues to the servant and not to his master, as long as he is taken for a general partner who is entitled to profit". Chapter III What is prohibited in the limited partnership 
(1399) 4 - Malek said, "If a man owes a another, a debt, about which, he asks him to keep it in the form of a capital of a "quirad" limited partnership, this is not allowed, except in the case where he will have received his money after which he may either consider it limited capital or the keep. This must be done lest the debtor find himself in difficulty and delay payment for a certain period, wishing later to pay it off with a profit (and this will be usury). About a man who paid another a sum of money for a "quirad" limited partnership, of which part of the money is lost before it bears fruit and by using the remaining part, he has made a profit and the general partner asks the limited partner to consider the part which remained, as new capital before using it in trade- Malek said: “what is said is not accepted, and the general partner must pay the lost amount of his profit, then he shares with the limited partner the rest of the benefit, according to the condition which they have advanced". Malek further said, "The capital of a limited partnership should be only silver or gold, and never any commodity or commercial transaction which causes dispute between them. As for usury, it is absolutely forbidden, and it is never permissible to take it whatever its amount, because Allah the Blessed and the Most High has said (meaning): "If you repent , your capital will be preserved. Harm no one and you will not be harmed” Koran II, 279. Chapter IV Stipulations permitted in a limited partnership 
(1400) 5 - Concerning the man who shed to another a sum of money in the form of a limited partnership, subjecting him to the condition of buying himself with the sum which is specific to him only such and such a commodity or even that he prohibits him from buying a specific commodity Malek said: “Whoever submits the general partner, on the condition, of not to buy with this sum of money, neither an animal, nor a well determined commodity, that is tolerated; on the other hand, it is not tolerated that the sponsor prevents the general partner from buying such or such merchandise, except if the latter is abundant, and that it is not not hard to find in winter and summer, so it will be tolerated. - "About a man, who pays another a limited sum, subjecting it to the condition, to share in a partial profit, regardless of the total profit,” Malek said: "this is not allowed, even if it is a profit of a single dirham, because the profit is to be shared equally, half of which must legally go to the sponsor unless the profit is set to him by a third or of a quarter, or less or more than this proportion. Any benefit whose proportion is fixed, is therefore lawful, therefore such is what which is basically followed in a limited partnership between Muslims. And Malek added: “But if the sponsor advances as a condition, that the profit therefrom is one dirham or more, going to him alone independently of the part of the general partner, and that the rest of the profit is shared equally between them, this is not tolerated, and it is not an established foundation in the partnership between Muslims”. Chapter V What is prohibited as a condition in a limited partnership 
(1401) 6 - Malek said: "It is not the right of the owner of the capital to appropriate a partial gain, by not making not a part to the general partner, nor that the latter cannot do this. In a limited partnership, neither the limited partner nor the general partner has the right to submit to each other any condition of sale or lease or of any work or advance or even a business without a mutual agreement. But this is permitted when both agree on this subject, without being subject to any condition, therefore it must be done for good, and that this is agreed for both partners. On the other hand, neither the principal, nor the general partner, has the right to subject the other to the condition, to have more than his partner, as far as gold is concerned, or to money, or food, or any other such thing, in the sense that one will have more than his partner. And Malek explains: if the sum in sponsorship is affected by this or that aspect (cited above), it will turn out to be a wage earner that demands what is stable, what is determined. It is not no no longer allowed to the one who receives the capital, to have it, by having a reward, neither to entrust his merchandise to someone, nor to entrust it to himself. If the money has increased in such a way that the capital is already reserved, sponsor and general partner must share between them, according to the condition on which both have agreed the profit. But if the money has yielded no profit, or even the price of the goods sold has not recovered the capital, the general partner is entitled to nothing, namely neither of what he has done as expenses personal, nor of the loss suffered, and it is up to the sponsor alone to bear this loss. The limited partnership is permitted as long as the owner of the capital (limited partner) and general partner, have agreed on the sharing of the profit, namely or that it is equal, or fixed at one-third or one-fourth, or more or less than that”. - Malek said: "It is not permitted for the general partner to put forward the condition of profiting from the capital for several years without being required to pay it. It's not allowed either the limited partner to ask the general partner to reimburse him the capital within a time limit that they both set; because the limited sum must never be given for a term. However, the owner of the capital can give his money to the general partner in order to grow it for him; but in case one of them wants the contract terminated and the capital is still liquid the owner of the capital can have his money again. On the other hand, that the owner of the capital wants to recover his money after a commodity has been bought with it, this is only permitted if the sale price and the capital are in cash. Else share if the general partner wants to return the capital in the form of a commodity, before selling it, this is not allowed to him, because he must return the capital in the form of cash”. Malek also said: it is not tolerated that the sponsor conditions the general partner to pay zakat in respect of his own share of the gain, because if the sponsor had acted thus, he should have seized a fixed sum of his own gain, making himself exempt from the zakat which he actually had to pay on his own. It is also not tolerated that the limited partner requires that the general partner only buys from such or such merchant, that he will designate. This is therefore not tolerated because the general partner becomes an employee who does not know his salary”. - Malek said again: “It is not tolerated yet that the limited partner subject the general partner to the condition of giving him a guarantee of the capital that he has paid to him, because he will have thus requested this which is not agreed in the limited partnership and what is the practice of Muslims. However, if the capital has suffered a increase, his winning percentage would have increased further because of this guarantee. However, they must share the gain without any guarantee of either one or the other. And if this money is for any reason lost, the general partner will not assume any responsibility, because any condition in a limited partnership is considered null and void”. - Malek, finally, said: "If the sponsor pays the general partner a certain sum, requiring him to buy only palm trees or animals, with the aim that this sponsor wants the date palms and the evolution of the beasts, withholding them for some time, Malek said, “This is intolerable, and also is not what is practiced by Muslims in a limited partnership except, s 'he buys this commodity and then resells it like any other commodity'. However, it is tolerated that the general partner asks the owner of the capital, a servant to help him in the operations of the company and not to other purpose. Chapter VI The limited partnership when capital is commodity 
(1402) 7 - Malek said: “It is not tolerated, in a limited partnership, that the capital be other than money, thus excluding all merchandise, because if the capital is merchandise, it will have two aspects: either that he says to the general partner: “Take this commodity and sell it, and from the sale price you will buy another commodity, as agreed in the limited partnership”. Now, in this way, the sponsor would have earned a surplus by selling his merchandise, by having possessed enough, what he needs”; or even that he says to the general partner: "Sell this merchandise at a price, buy another then resell it, once the purchase and sale are perfectly accomplished, buy merchandise similar to that which I had, consequently this who is of a certain surplus will be shared equally between the two of us. And it is likely that the sponsor has given the general partner such a flowing and expensive commodity, as a result of which the general partner will buy himself a similar commodity, the price of which is less, so that this commodity will be purchased at a third of the previous price, or even less, Thus, the general partner will have enjoyed a profit coming from half of the difference of the two prices, or that he will have bought the goods at a reduced price which, put on the market, will bring to the general partner a valuable profit, then he will wait for the price of this commodity to rise so that he can pay it, and will spend what he has received as a gain, thus making all his work vain. Such a sale is held for random; however if this affair is unknown to the sponsor and the general partner, and that it has been accomplished until the end, the salary which is due to the general partner for having carried out, purchase and sale, and for his maintenance of the goods, will be considered, and we owe it to him pay. As for the commodity, which has become cash, this is taken for new capital”. Chapter VII Transport costs in a limited partnership 
(1403) 8 - “For a sponsor who had paid a sum to his partner to buy a commodity, and that the latter transported it to a market, there was a risk that the commodity would be lost, or even sold at a price less than that of the purchase , so he went and carried her to another country, paying the transportation costs. There, by selling the merchandise, at a price less than that of the purchase, the transport costs will have eaten up all the capital. In this regard, Malek said, “If the sale price is worth the sum of the transport costs, so it will be. But if the costs exceed by their value, that of the capital, the general partner will have to pay without the limited partner paying an additional sum, because he had already advanced a certain capital to the general partner in order to use it in trade. The general partner may not, whatever the condition, ask the limited partner for more than the capital he had paid, and if it is the case that the latter must anything else, it will be held as a debt that he will have to pay, which is unseemly. Chapter VIII The transgressed terms of the limited partnership 
(1404) 9 - "About a sponsor who had paid his partner a sum, which used in trade brings him a profit, from which he bought a slave whom he had cohabited and thereby became pregnant, therefore the capital was diminished”; Malek said: “If the general partner has money, the value of this slave is to be removed from the money in question, so that the sum of the capital which is missing, is rectified. If there is anything left over, it will be shared between them as agreed. If the general partner does not have the money to pay it, the slave is sold so that the capital is recovered from its price”. - About a man who gives capital to a general partner, and the latter buys a commodity whose price exceeds by its value that of the capital, and therefore pays this price difference itself”. Malek on this subject says: “The owner of the capital will have to choose: if the commodity is sold at a profit or at a loss or even that it is not sold, he will be able to have it by paying its price or on the other hand, if he refuses it, the general partner will be his associate for this merchandise in question according to his share of the price which he has already paid, whether that portion be increased or diminished, taking into account the sum which was paid out of his own money. - About a general partner who, receiving a capital on the other, the book to a third party, without having had the sponsor's permit, Malek said: “The general partner must guarantee the capital, such that, if it decreases, it must cover this decrease, and in the event that he benefits, the limited partner will be partially entitled to this benefit, according to the condition advanced, and the rest will go to the general partner”. - About a general partner who had received capital of a limited partner, from which he had bought himself a commodity of his own, Malek said, "If he has a profit, it will be shared according to the terms of the limited partnership, and if he loses, the general partner will assume responsibility for such loss”. - In the event that a general partner asks the limited partner to advance him a sum other than the capital to buy a commodity for himself, the limited partner will have two choices: either that he is a partner of this commodity with the general partner according to what is agreed in the limited partnership, or let him leave it to her, returning to her all the sum he had paid her. Besides, this is how we should deal with those who transgress the terms of a limited partnership”. Chapter IX Expenses allowed in a limited partnership (14
(15) 10 Malek said: “When the sponsor pays a capital of a large sum and that the general partner travels the travel expenses are taken there, the general partner can obtain his food and his clothes according to what suits him, just as he can have a certain sum for the expenses miscellaneous corresponding to certain work which is due to him such as: claiming debts, transporting goods and other similar work. Thus he can use this money as long as it is necessary. However, the general partner does not have the right to deduct any sum from the capital as long as he is still at home, without being a traveller. If so thus, he will not be entitled to any additional expense for his clothes, because he will use the money of the trade, in the place where he is resident”. On the other hand, Malek said: “If the general partner travels with the capital on him of the limited partnership and also his own money, his expenses are to be considered as two sums and this in a manner proportional to their amount”. ChapterX What Expenses Are Not Allowed in a Limited Partnership 
(1406) 11 - “Malek said: “In case the general partner travels while having on him the capital of a limited partnership, he will be able to spend what he needs as a sum and buy clothes. However, he is prohibited from making a donation of this capital. or an alms or a reward to someone.
