But if he is with people, who will bring food just as he himself will bring it for them to eat together, I believe, said Malek, that the general partner has the right to do so provided he does not seek to obtain food that is much more valued than that others, and this without having had the permit of its sponsor. Because if he refuses, the general partner will have to pay him compensation, if this thing deserves to be done”. Chapter XI The practice of debt on the capital of a limited partnership 
(1407) 12 - Malek said: “What is unquestionably followed with us (in Medina), in the event that the general partner receives capital from the sponsor, thus buys goods and resells it in the long term to a third person, thus benefiting from a profit, then that this general partner dies before recovering the debt”, Malek said, “If his heirs are willing to take on this matter, but on the condition of still having the benefit which is their father's right, they may do so, if they show fidelity; but if they refuse to take responsibility for the recovery of the debt, thus leaving the task to the sponsor, they may still do so, without their having any right to it. If they intend to undertake debt collection themselves, they will be substituted for their father and will thereby enjoy the same rights of the contract and the expense. Just as they can instruct someone else they trust to claim the debt and perceive; consequently, the office being accomplished, they will be able to enjoy the same rights as their father”. Malek further said: “When a general partner sells the commodity forward, he will have to guarantee this debt”. Chapter Xn Merchandise in a limited partnership 
(1408) 13 - "About a limited partner who pays a general partner a capital, and that both borrow money (sum independent of the capital) or that the limited partner asks his partner to sell for him a commodity that he owns, or also that he gives him dinars with which the general partner will buy goods for the sponsor, Malek said: "The sponsor would not have charged his partner with a purchase and a sale if he had not not delivered a capital, friendly asking him to do so and finding it easy to do, but if the general partner refuses to undertake it, the limited partner will not have the right to take back his capital from this partner, and the latter will not have to borrow from the other nor will agree to sell him a commodity, knowing full well that he has no capital; on the other hand, if the general partner refuses to take charge of both the purchase and the sale, he is not obliged to return the capital of the limited partnership. However, if it is done, that both have agreed on what is suitable and for one and the other, without this being a condition, this is therefore permitted and tolerated. But if any condition appears in such a way that the general partner risks reimbursing the limited partner the capital in the event that he refuses what the limited partner instructs him to do, or that the limited partner fears that the general partner will not return his capital to him, this does not is more permissible in a limited partnership and it is what men versed in religion have forbidden to do”. Chapter XIII The advance made in a limited partnership 
(1409) 14 - Concerning a man who pays to another a sum of money on loan, and the latter requests that this sum be made a capital of a limited partnership, Malek said: "I disapprove of this, and the debtor must first discharge this that he borrowed, since the sponsor has the choice, either to return it to him as capital or to retain it". - Malek also said: “If a sponsor gives a capital to the general partner, and that the latter then tell him that the money is on him, to leave it to him in the form of a loan, Malek, says this, is disapproved, as long as the limited partner has not yet taken back all his capital, following which, if he wishes, he can either return it to the general partner or keep it for himself. This must be done, to avoid any risk that the money will be diminished and that the general partner only asks for this in order to delay the payment in order to be able to cover the deficit. Now, this is repugnant, not permitted and forbidden”. Chapter XIV Accounting in a limited partnership 
(1410) 15 - "About a sponsor who, paid a capital to a general partner, in such a way that the latter, using it in trade, wanted to have his share of the gain, in the absence of the general partner, Malek said: "It is not permitted for the general partner to having a share of the money while the limited partner is away; in case he will, this must be guaranteed so that this sum will be part of the money, once it is divided”. - Also, Malek said, "You don't have to have both partners count and share, while the money is not available to them. Once the money is there, the limited partner will take part of his capital, then afterwards he will share with the general partner the gain according to the condition accepted by one and the other”. - Malek further said, “Once a general partner has received a capital, with which he bought a commodity, and has a debt to pay, which his creditors claim from him, and which they cross the general partner in a country where the general partner does not reside, this done, the debtor general partner having in his possession good and beneficial merchandise to sell, the creditors will not have the right to impose on the general partner the sale of this merchandise for the purpose to have their debt recovered from the profit of this sale, as long as the limited partner is not present to have his capital, after which the profit will be shared according to the condition admitted by him and the general partner. - Malek added: “Whether a sponsor pays to a general partner a sum which, put on the market, brings to the latter a profit, thus bringing the general partner to set aside the capital, then to share the profit, so as to have one's share, and to add that of the limited partner to its capital in the presence of witnesses. On this subject Malek said: “The profit should not be shared without the owner of the capital being present; if the general partner had already had any share, he must return it until the limited partner has recovered his capital, then the two will share, what remains, according to the condition accepted by them”. - Malek finally said: “In case a sponsor after having given a capital to the general partner which he has used in trade, that the latter comes to say to the first: "Such is your share of the profit, and I have had a similar share, and also your capital is well reserved," Malek said, "I do not approve of this, until all the capital is fully available, so he will account to him until the capital is within reach of the hand of the sponsor, knowing thus, that he has it in full and that he even received it, after which they will share the profit between them. the sponsor can return the capital to the general partner or he can keep it, but what is necessary is to have all the capital for fear that the general partner has reduced it, especially since he wants us to do not take it away from him, and let him keep it within his reach”. Chapter XV About the limited partnership 
(1411) 16 - About a general partner who has bought with a capital received from a sponsor, a commodity, which the latter requires him to sell against what the general partner opposes, and which consequently causes them to enter into dispute, Malek said: "It is not necessary that 'we listen to one without the other, it is better to ask experts for their points of view; thus if they judge that the goods should be sold, let it be so for both; if they think it is better to wait, let them wait”. - Malek said: “In the event that a general partner has put in trade a capital, which is delivered to him by a sponsor, and that the latter claims it from him, to which the other replies: "I have it in whole"; the limited partner insisting on having his capital, the general partner says to him: “I lost of this capital such sum, which he quotes, and I told you that I have it so that you still leave it with me", Malek finds that it is necessary to take into account the first answer of the general partner, namely where it is said that he owns all the capital, because it is useless for him to disown it afterwards, unless he does not advance compelling arguments justifying the cause of the loss; otherwise he must pay all the capital”. It is the same, continues Malek, if the general partner had made a profit of such sum; and once the sponsor claims his capital and his gain, the other responds: "In fact, I have not benefited anything, and I do not had said that so that you let me keep this capital; here again, it is not good for him to contradict himself if he does not put forward valid arguments justifying the cause of the loss”. - Malek also said: “In the event that a general partner, benefiting from a sum coming to him from a capital which is delivered to him by a sponsor, will go and say to the latter: "I have requested this sum to trade, on condition that I receive two-thirds of the profit", and the sponsor replies: "No, I paid you this money to trade on the condition that you only have a third of it", it is necessary, says Malek, to be for what is proposed by the general partner, and he will have to take an oath proving his presumption, namely that he wants to hear that such is the custom followed between both partners and which, moreover, is practiced by people. Otherwise, neither his words nor his oath will be given importance, and he is responsible for returning the capital to the limited partner with the profit, according to what is usually practiced for a similar general partnership business”. - On the other hand, about a sponsor who has given to a general partner one hundred dinars, with which he will buy goods. When paying the seller for the merchandise, he realizes that the hundred dinars have been stolen, the sponsor offers the general partner to sell this merchandise, and to take the price of what is sold plus the profit that would come out of it, and s there is a loss will be the general partner to cover the money lost. However, to this the general partner replied: "Rather, it is up to the roof to pay the price of this merchandise that I bought with your money. Malek on this subject says: "In fact it is up to the general partner to pay the price to the seller, and the sponsor is asked: "or that you give the general partner the hundred dinars and that the goods are for both of you, therefore these new hundred dinars will be new capital according to the terms of the first contract, or that you give up the goods. So if he pays the hundred dinars to the general partner, this sum will be considered a new capital according to the conditions of the first contract, and if he refuses, the goods are the property of the general partner and it is up to him to pay his price”. - Malek finally said: “If he stays, after payment of capital and sharing of profit, junk, it is up to the general partner. And I haven't heard otherwise. But if what remains is of the value of an animal, or a camel, or garments of coarse material, or the like, the general partner shall have to return them to the limited partner, unless the latter gives them to him. leave alone". MOUATTAA In the name of Allah the Merciful the Merciful Book 33 The Watering Contract Book First chapter About watering 
(1412) 1 - Sa'id Ibn Al Musaiab reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him be Allah's grace and peace) said, on the day of the conquest of Khaibar, to the jews: “I keep you in this territory as long as Allah Him the power and the glory grant it to you, provided that the dates are divided between us”. The rapporteur adds: "And the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him be grace and peace of Allah) sent Abdallah Ibn Rawaha, instructing him to be in Khaibar to estimate the quantity of dates, and he said to the Jews: "If you want to keep the dates, you can buy our share, if not, we will have them and we will give you half”; but the Jews preferred to have them”. 
(1413) 2 - Sulaiman Ibn Yassar reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) sent to Khaibar Abdallah Ibn Rawaha, instructing him to estimate the picking of dates and its sharing with the Jews. One day, continues the reporter, the Jews brought him their wives' jewels, saying: "This is for you, if you give us a discount and give us more than half". So Abdallah said to them, “O Jews! By Allah, you are the most hideous creatures towards me. However, that will not cause me to be unfair to you, because it is only an illegal bribe that we will hardly eat”. They answered him: "In fact, it is according to this justice that the earth and heavens have been established”. - Malek said: “In case the man waters palm groves where a part is fallow, what he plants and harvests there will be for him". Also, if the owner of the land wants any new plantation to belong to him, this is not accepted, because the man who has been entrusted with the watering will be charged with an additional work, not belonging to the advanced condition”. ^ On the other hand, there is nothing wrong with the harvest is shared if the expenses of the seed, watering and maintenance costs are borne by the partner. In case the partner stipulates to the owner of the land, the condition that the price of the semen is borne by the latter, this is not accepted, because in this way the partner would have charged the owner of an expense considered surplus on capital. The watering and sowing contract obliges the partner to assume all the expenses without the owner of the land taking charge of anything. Besides, such is what is decent in a contract”. - If a water source is the possession of two men, and that its water dries up, and that one of the two men wants to get its water, by accomplishing some work there to recover this water, while the other refuses it, one will say to the first: “You have to dig so that you have all the water you need to water your land. If your partner comes to claim his share of water, you you will ask him for half of the payment that the work cost if he ever accepts, he will have his share of water, otherwise you will have the whole quantity. - If all fees and expenses are borne by the owner of the garden and that the partner will only have his manual work in this garden in respect of which he will have a share of the harvest, this is not tolerated because the salary of the partner is not specified and he will not know whether or not he will have his full mail-order pay at harvest”. - Neither the sponsor nor the person who makes a contract for watering and sowing to make an exception for a sum of money, nor for certain palm trees, without either of them approving it because in this case, one would be considered an employee with respect to the other, namely that the owner of the capital will say to the other: “I conclude a contract with you on the condition that you take care of the palm trees, water them and pollenize them; and I will pay you another ten dinars if you work and this money will not be part of the capital”, Malek said: “It is not allowed and this is what is done here”. - What is a rule put into practice in the watering contract is to allow the owner of the garden to stipulate to his partner the insurance of works such as: firmly maintaining the walls, cleaning the water source, getting rid of stagnant water around the palm trees , to pollinate palm trees, to cut dry branches, to pick dates, and to do other such work. However the partner will have in this case, half of the harvest or less according to what is dictated in this contract, or even more, if they agree on this point. On the other hand, the owner of the garden may not impose other additional work on his partner such as digging a well, or raising water from a spring, or planting trees by paying their price, or building a rampart around it. 'a basin of water, in short, expensive work. This case is equivalent to that of an owner of a garden asking a person to build him a house in a specific place, or to drill him a well, or to dig him a source of water or other work, in exchange for which he will have half the quantity of the fruits of his garden, even before they are matured and consumable. It will be like a sale of the fruits before they are in question, but this is what has been forbidden by the Messenger of Allah r (sallallahu alayhi wa salam). - However, if the fruits are already ripe and they are for sale or consumption, it is tolerated for a man to say to another: "Do some work for me (cited above), specifying them, and you will have half the quantity of the fruits of my garden" , for thus, he would have charged him with work for wages determined, which he has known and accepted. As for the watering contract, in case the garden has no more fruit trees or even the fruits have diminished or are ravaged, under the effect of a plague, the partner will only have what is his right to harvest. A man can only be recruited for a well-defined job, because recruitment is considered the same as a sale, where one buys his work from the worker, and this is not tolerated, if done randomly, because the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) has forbidden the random sale”, i - The rule followed in the watering contract is that it depends on fruit trees such as palms, vines, olives, pomegranates, plums and other such trees. This is tolerated on condition that the owner has half the quantity of the fruit, or a third or a quarter, or more or less”. - It is also allowed in the watering contract, as soon as a plantation grows and becomes robust that the owner is incapable of watering it, working it, and caring for it". - However, the watering contract is inadmissible, once the fruits or other kinds of crops become ripe, edible and satisfactory for sale, but it may, if necessary, be concluded for a following year. Thus in the previous case, as soon as the fruits become ripe, the owner can pay the other person a salary, in gold or silver, so that he cuts the date palms for him. Therefore the watering contract is permitted during the period of the cut, and the time when the fruits will be ripe and ready to be sold”. - Also the watering contract is tolerated, when it it is the watering of trees whose fruits are not yet ripe and edible and good for sale”. - On the other hand, it is not tolerated to conclude a watering contract for unsown or planted land; however, it is tolerated for its owner to return the soil, for a price paid in gold or silver or at another known price”. - Likewise, let a man deliver his unsown land or planted to another to sow it against the third or quarter of the crop that might be produced, this is considered random, because it may be that the plantation pays or it may yield nothing at all. Thus, the owner of the land will have neglected the rental who could make his land fertile, preferring what is random, while not knowing whether this will happen or not; but this is repugnant, because the case of this proprietor is like that of a man who engages another for a certain journey, saying to him: "do you want me to give you the tenth of the profit of my trade, as wages"? This is neither lawful nor tolerated”. - It is not tolerated for a man to engage in any work, or to hire his land or his ship, except for a specified sum". - And, says Malek, it is to be distinguished between the watering contract concluded for a land planted with palm trees, and that which is for an unplanted land; thus the owner of the first will not be able to sell the fruits until they appear ripe; as for the other, he will be able to cultivate his land as long as it is not not yet planted. - The rule followed in Medina makes it possible to conclude a watering contract for three or four years, or even more or less for palm trees, for that matter, said Malek, that's what I heard at the subject to such a contract concerning palm trees and any other fruit tree where the owner is permitted to conclude, for years, a watering contract". - Regarding the owner of a garden, Malek has said, that he is not permitted to take from his partner who gave him water, nor gold, nor silver, nor food, nor something else, because it is not tolerated. Likewise, it is not permissible for the partner giving the water, to take from his partner neither gold, nor silver, nor food, nor anything like that. As for what is surplus, for one and for the other, it is not allowed either”. - Similarly, says Malek, the sponsor is treated just like the one who gives water, if ever there is a surplus in the watering, or even that the sponsored sum turns out to be a salary, moreover, everything that will bring into play, a salary, n 'East not tolerated, especially since this salary is considered random. And, we will not know if we will have the whole harvest, or more or less”. - Concerning the man, who concludes a contract irrigation, for a man's land, where the palms and vines or other similar trees are, and there is a part of the uncultivated land, Malek said, "If the part not planted is auxiliary to that which is planted and which moreover constitutes the major part of the land, there is nothing wrong with that, provided that the part planted with palm trees is two-thirds or more, and that which is not, either by a third or at least. Thereby if the uncultivated part forms the two-thirds where the palms, vines or other similar trees are, it is tolerated that one pays a salary for watering without there being a contract which is prohibited. Because it is customary for people to conclude a watering contract when it comes to land where the planted part is major, while it contains an uncultivated part. He is allowed to rent uncultivated land, against payment, even if it contains a planted part, just as one sells the Koran or the sword while each having a silver ornament, or even the medallion or the ring encrusted with precious stones, sold for gold. And such sales are practiced by people, as well as purchases, without any specific criteria (inspired by the Koran or the sunna) being advanced on this subject, stipulating that, when the main material constitutes half or less, this is prohibited; and if she is otherwise, this rental is permitted. The rule followed in Medina, which people from elsewhere do not stop practicing and indulging among themselves, is as follows: if the precious stone in question constitutes only the lower part of the object made of gold or silver , there is no harm in that, such as the case of the sword or the Koran or the ring, valued for more than two thirds, and the adornment for the remaining third or even less”, Chapter II The condition provided about slaves in the watering contract (1414) 3-Malek said: "The best I've heard about the slaves hired by the one who holds the responsibility for watering according to the contract he concludes with the owner of the land, it is that they are taken in the same way as a capital, from which their master will not draw any profit. If he does not make them work, it is up to him to provide them with food, sometimes requiring expenses. excessive. They are considered just like watering from a flowing spring or from the water carried on the backs of camels. And you won't find a man doing a watering contract for two lots bringing the same benefit, so that the first is watered with water from an inexhaustible source, and the other by of water that one draws and where for the first, one pays insignificant expenses to maintain the source, as for the other, that requires excessive expenses. Such is the rule followed in Medina. And by insistence, Malek says: "the inexhaustible source, is that which is not to be perforated, and whose water is always abundant". - It is not permitted for the owner of the land to instruct employees to carry out other work (other than watering) or to ask their partner to do so. Nor is it permissible for the person responsible for the watering to ask the owner of the land to make slaves work there while they were not working according to the contract". - It is not permitted for the owner of the land to ask whoever is responsible for the watering to remove one of the paid slaves during the contract. Thus, if he wants to dismiss it, he must do so before entering into the contract. Consequently, he is not allowed to enlist a new employee, only before concluding the "contract". - In case one of the slaves dies, or is absent or becomes ill, it is up to the owner to find another to replace him". MOUATTAA In the name of Allah the Merciful the Merciful Book 34 The Land Rental Book First chapter About land rental 
(1415) 1 - Rafe' Ibn Khadij reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the mercy and peace of Allah) had prohibited the renting of lands which are for cultivation”. Hanzala, reporting this hadith, said: “I had asked Rafé Ibn Khadij about the rent, if it is paid in gold or silver, he answered me: “Either one or the other, there is no harm”. 
(1416) 2 - Ibn Chehab reported that he asked Sa'id Ibn Al-Mussaiab about paying for land rental; gold or silver? He replied, “There is nothing wrong with that”. 
(1417) 3 - Ibn Chehab reported that he asked Salem Ibn Abdallah Ibn Omar about renting the land”? He replied, "There is no harm in it being done for gold or silver”. Ibn Chehab added: "I said to him: what are you saying concerning the hadith narrated by Rafé Ibn Khadij”? He replied, “Rafe' explained this hadith incorrectly. If I had land to cultivate, I would have rented it”. 
(1418) 4 - It was reported to Malek that Abdul Rahman Ibn Awf had rented land; he kept it that way until his death. His son has said, “I thought we owned her because of long time she was with us, until my father mentioned it to us just when he died; thus, he ordered us to pay the rent he owed, in gold or silver”. 
(1419) 5 - Hisham Ibn Ourwa reported that his father rented his land for gold or silver”. Malek was asked about a man who rented his farm, percent sa's of dates, or even for what it will produce of wheat, or other crop". Malek pushed that back. MOUATTAA In the name of Allah the Merciful the Merciful Book 35 The Book of Preemption First chapter What is subject to preemption 
(1420) 1 - Abu Salama Ibn Abdul Rahman Ibn Awf reported that the Messenger of Allah (sallallahu alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) commanded that preemption be applied in all that was not divided between the partners, but if the delimitation of the shares has already taken place, there is no longer any question of pre-emption”. Malek said, "Such is the sunna unquestionably followed." 
(1421) 2 - Malek reported that Sa'id Ibn al Musaiab was asked about pre-emption, if there is a followed Sunnah He replied: "Yes, certainly, pre-emption is to be applied in dwellings and lands, and is only proper to partners". 
(1422) 3 - It was reported to Malek that Sa'id Ibn Al Musaiab narrated the same hadith». Malek said: "If a man, in a country, buys a part of a property in association by paying with an animal, or a slave or other goods, and that a partner comes to claim this share, according to the right of pre-emption, and finds that the slave is dead, without the two parties can specify its value, and that therefore the buyer says: "The value of this slave is one hundred dinars", against which the entitled partner says: "Rather it is fifty", Malek said: " The buyer will make an oath that the price of what he has bought is one hundred dinars, then will ask, if he wants, the one who has the right to pre-emption, to leave what is bought or to take, until the latter can provide clear proof that the price of the slave is lower than what is said by the buyer". - “Whoever donates part of a house or of land belonging to several partners, to a third person who in exchange gives him money or other goods, the partners can if they want to take back this part under pre-emption, and consequently pay this third person the value of the donation, either in dinars or in dirhams”. - One who donates his share in a house, or land belonging to several partners, without him changing it or claiming it, and his partner telling him that he wants to have it according to his own value, that is not permitted, as long as he has not changed it, but this done, this part will be given to him who has the right to pre-emption, at his same value”. - About a man who bought a share in a land belonging to several partners, for a term price, and one of the partners asks to take it back by right of preemption", Malek said: "If he is solvent, he has the right to preemption, but if he runs the risk of not being able to pay the price within the fixed period, that he presents a solvent guarantor, that is permitted to him”. - Malek said, "A man's right of first refusal absent cannot be limited to a fixed date, although his absence is long-lasting, and this is what we follow at all times in Medina”. - For a man, who gives to some of his son, his land as an inheritance, and that one of them will have other children then the father dies. If one of these last children wants to sell his share of this land, his brothers will have more than the paternal uncles, partners of this land with the father, the right to pre-emption. And such is the rule followed in Medina”. - Malek further said: - The right of pre-emption between the partners, is proportional to the value of their shares: each of them will be entitled to his share whether it is little or a lot, even if they seek to have some reduced compared to others. So if one of the partners buys the share of the other, and another partner says: I buy a share equivalent to mine, by right of first refusal, then the buying partner says: "If you want, I let you have, by right of first refusal, all the shares, or you can leave them to me. This being advanced by the buyer, the partner must either have all the shares, or else leave them. If he buys, it is his right, otherwise he has no right to anything”. - Concerning the man who buys land, makes it plant or even dig a well there, and then there comes a man who claims by the right of first refusal, this land, and wants to have it, but he will not have it until he has paid the other, the value of the work expenses; if this value is paid, he will have the land by right of pre-emption, otherwise he will have no right”. - He who sells his share in land or house owned by partners, and once the partner with the right of first refusal has been made aware, and the buyer wants to resolve the purchase agreement and the first accepts, Malek said: “He has no right to do so, and whoever has the right of first refusal can take it back at the same price that was paid”. - One who buys a share in land, or a remains or animals or other goods, of a single transaction, and that the partner having the right of pre-emption claims his share in everything, the buyer to respond to him: “You have to buy everything at once because I already bought everything,” Malek said: “Rather the partner must buy his share of the abode or land, estimating thereby that share independently of other things sold, thus taking account of the price which has been paid. Then the partner will have his share of what has been estimated, once the price has been paid, without having any rights with regard to the others. goods or animals, unless he so wishes". - When a man sells his share in land which belongs to several partners, also delivering some shares of partners to the seller, as for others, refusing this, insist on having, according to the right of pre-emption, their own shares; thus, these partners who have refused, can, and always according to the right of preemption, have all the shares, without them being satisfied with the proportion of their share, and consequently abandoning what remains”. About the plurality of partners having a only remains, if one of them sells his share while his partners were all absent, with the exception of only one, who, so to speak, or offered him to have, by right of first refusal, this share or to leave it, and that he answers: "I will have my share, and I leave the others to my partners waiting for them to be present. Thus, if they take their shares, it will be so, if not, I will take, by right of pre-emption, all the shares. Malek said: “He can only either have the whole thing, or the to leave; thus, if his partners present themselves, they can claim it from him, or leave it to him. However, if ever this is offered to him, and he refuses it, I, continues Malek, think that he no longer has the right to withdraw. Chapter II What is not subject to the right of preemption 
(1423) 4 - Abu Bakr Ibn Hazm reported that Osman Ibn Affan said: "If the delimitation of the land has already been made, it is no longer subject to the right of first refusal; no right of first refusal with regard to a well or a male palm tree”. Malek, on this subject, said: “Such is the rule followed in Medina”. * Malek said: * Preemption is not invoked for a road suitable for dividing or not; the same applies to a common forecourt between several dwellings, divisible or not”. * About a man who buys a share of a land belonging to several partners, in such a way that he is given the choice. If the seller's partners want to have what he has sold, and refer to the right of pre-emption before the buyer has to choose, they cannot allow themselves this right as long as the purchase and sale have not been definitely completed; thus, if the sale is made, they will act according to the right of pre-emption”. * Concerning the man who buys land now for some time in his possession; then came another telling him that he has the right to inherit this land; Malek said: “He will have the right to pre-emption, if he proves to have the right. As for the harvesting of the land, it must revert to the first buyer, until the other has proved his right, because the first buyer had already guaranteed the planting, if ever it had been ravaged. or uprooted by a torrent". But if a long time had passed, or the witnesses were dead, or that the seller or the buyer was dead, or that they were alive, but the sale and purchase price had been completely forgotten for lack of time, the right of pre-emption is broken and everyone will have their right. If the case were to be considered otherwise, depending on whether the time is sooner or later, and it is realized that the seller had secretly kept the real price with the aim of depriving the other of the right to pre-emption, we will make the valuation of the land, for a new price in relation to the first, then one will consider what has been added to this land, of construction or planting or other works, thus the man having the right of preemption , will buy the land, paying the price for the total”. Malek added: “The right of first refusal is at consider in the property of the dead as well as in that of the living. Thus, if the relatives of the deceased fear the loss of his property, they can share them and sell them, therefore, the right of first refusal is no longer to be considered”. - However, continues Malek, we never consider the right of pre-emption in respect of a slave, female or male, nor a camel, a cow, a sheep or any other animal, or a garment or a well in a uncultivated land; on the other hand, the right of preemption is considered in what is to be shared, and what is delimited in a land; and if it is the contrary, this does not call no right of first refusal". Eventually Malek said, "Whoever buys land where people have a right of pre-emption, and they are present, they have to bring this matter to the sultan; so, or they deserve it by their right of pre-emption, or that the sultan deliver their share to the buyer. If he leaves them without referring to the sultan when they are aware of this purchase, if they leave for a long time after which, they claim their right, I think they will have no more right to do it) MOUATTAA In the name of Allah the Merciful the Merciful Book 36 The Book of Sentences First chapter The exhortation to judge fairly 
(1424) 1 - Um Salama, the wife of the Prophet (upon him the grace and peace of Allah) reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him be Allah's Grace and Peace) said, “I am a human being. When you report your accusations to me, one of you may skillfully present his case to me, to such an extent that I agree with him on something of his brother's good. So let him not take it, because indeed, I only give him a piece of Hell”. 
(1425) 2 - Sa'id Ibn Al-Musaiab reported that a Muslim and a Jew, disputed between them, brought their accusation to Omar Ibn Al-Khattab. Finding that the Jew was right, Omar judged in his favour. So the Jew exclaimed, "By Allah, you have judged in all justice", Omar gave him a whipping, saying: "How do you know that"? The Jew replied, "We find that no judge gives his judgment in justice, except that he has an angel at his right hand and one at his left, which put him on the right path, granting him success for justice as long as he is for justice. But, if he leaves justice, they abandon him and return to heaven». Chapter II About testimonials 
(1426) 3 - Zaid Ibn Khaled Al-Jouhani reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him be Allah's grace and peace) said: "Did I not tell you , who is the best martyr? He is the one who presents his testimony before being asked, or the one who declares his testimony before being asked to do so”. 
(1427) 4 - Rabi'a Ibn Abi Abdul-Rahman reported that a man from Iraq came to Omar Ibn Al-Khattab and said to him: “I come to see you for a question that has no beginning or end”; Umar answered him, “What is this question”? The man replied: "The false testimonies that are present in our country”. Omar asked him: "Is this really so"? - Yes, answered the man. So Umar exclaimed, “By Allah! No man is detained in a country of Islam without the testimony of righteous men”. I (...) 5 - It was reported to Malek that Omar Ibn Al-Khattab said: “The testimony of an adversary and an accused is not admitted”. Chapter III The testimony of one who has undergone a prescribed sentence - It was reported to Malek that Sulaiman Ibn was asked Yassar and others, about a man, who having suffered a punishment of flogging, can his testimony be accepted? They replied, "Yes if he showed repentance." (...) 6 - Malek reported that by asking the same question to Ibn Chehab, he responded similarly to Soulaiman Ibn Yassar”. Malek said, "And such is the rule followed in Medina, and it is from the words of Allah Blessed and Most High (meaning): "Knock eighty lashes for those who accuse honest women without being able to designate four witnesses; and never accept their testimony again; these are the ones who are perverse except those who, as a result of this, repent and reform. Allah is verily the One who forgives, He is merciful” (Koran XXIV, 4,5). Malek further said, “So what is indisputable, in Medina, is that he who suffered a punishment of flogging, and after he repented and reformed, his testimony will be admitted. And that's the best I've heard about it." Chapter IV The subject of the judgment based on the oath of a witness 
(1428) 7 Ja'far Ibn Muhammad reported from his father that the Messenger of Allah (sallallahu alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) judged according to the oath of the plaintiff and of a witness”. 
(1429) 8 Abu Zinad reported that Omar Ibn Abdul Aziz gives the order in writing to Abdul Hamid Ibn Abdul Rahman Ibn Zaid Ibn Al-Khattab, while the latter was the governor of Kufa: “Judge according to the oath of the plaintiff and of a witness”. 
(1430) 9 It was reported to Malek that Abu Salama Ibn Abdul Rahman and Sulaiman Ibn Yassar were questioned if one could judge according to the oath of the plaintiff and, a witness”? They replied: "Yes". * Malek said: The precedent in the sunna prescribed that one judges according to the oath of the plaintiff and the testimony of only one man, thus if the plaintiff makes an oath with his witness, he is confirmed in his rights. Thus, if the plaintiff renounces the oath and refuses it, the accused is asked to do so, if the latter takes the oath, he is judged innocent, and if he refuses to do so, that proves the plaintiff completely right,'. * However this sunnah is followed for all that is private property; which is not the case for everything concerning delimitation (of land), nor marriage, nor divorce, nor postage, nor theft, nor defamation. Thus, if one wants to say: "The postage is part of the goods, one will be wrong, because if it is thus, the slave and his witness this one being present would have made an oath, that his master the freed. On the other hand if the slave had had a witness presented, who attests that he is the owner of the money, and that they both make an oath, he will have his full right, just like the case of a man free". ' * Thus, it is from the sunna followed in Medina, in case where a slave presents a witness, who testifies that he has been freed, to bring the master of that slave to swear that he has not freed him if this is done, which the slave claimed to be n' is no longer considered". * It is the same for the sunna followed concerning divorce, thus if the woman presents a witness, attesting thanks to him, that her husband divorced her, her husband will be brought to swear that he has not divorced her; if he does, she will not be divorced”. * Malek continued and said, "There is only one Sunna, , concerning divorce and deliverance, supported by the testimony of one man; the oath shall be made by the husband of the wife, and by the master of the slave, as long as emancipation is one of the prescribed laws and the testimony of the wife on this subject is not tolerated, for if the 'slave is freed, his person will be honest, and will therefore be subject to the same prescribed penalties, just like a free man; if he commits adultery while he is married, he will be stoned; if he kills, he will be killed; he finally has the right to inherit his successors. If one protests by saying: "If ever a man freed his slave, and another came to claim from the master of this slave a debt which the latter owes him, in such a way that he has as witnesses, that he owes him a debt, a man and two women. If the slave has no property, and the man insists on having his debt, the master will be inclined to hold this debt in charge in order to pay it, and therefore postage will no longer be considered. This man who came to claim his debt, sought to bear the testimony of the women, a tolerated testimony about the emancipation; yet their testimony takes into account only the question of the debt. The case of this man is like that which, freeing his slave, a man comes, supported by a witness, swearing to claim a debt which this slave owes him. If this debt is found to be due, postage will no longer be considered. Or even that a man who, having a financial dispute with the master of a slave, comes to claim that he has a debt that the master of the slave must pay him, one will say to this master: "Swear that you don't owe him, what he claims to have in you”; if he renounces and refuses to swear, the plaintiff will be asked to take this oath, which, consequently, by doing so, proves that he is entitled to this debt from the master of the slave. This means that the freeing of the slave is no longer considered, if it is proven that the master owes a debt to the man in question”. - It is the same for the case of a man who marries a slave; having become his wife, her master comes to say to the man: “You bought my slave for so many dinars”; husband denying this slave master appeals to a man and two women testifying and justifying his words. Thus the sale is maintained, the master will have his right, the female slave will be illicit for her husband, and will separate from him. The testimony of women, in the case of a divorce, is not admitted”. - Another example: That a man accuses a free man of slander, so that he ends up being subjected to the prescribed penalty. He calls a man and two women testifying and certifying his words that the accused man is a slave. Thus, the man who has woven the slander, flees the prescribed punishment. The testimony of women is no longer admitted concerning slander”. - Which is still similar to this case, where we emphasizes the discrepancy between the judges and who is from the Sunnah followed, it is when two women testify that a child was born alive, and therefore, he is entitled to inheritance, and will subsequently bequeath his property to his successors. If the boy dies, and the women who have been witnesses, are found unaccompanied by a man, and having not sworn an oath, and let the inheritance be a great fortune consisting of gold, silver, residences, gardens, slaves or other property, therefore the two women who had already testified, of one dirham or more or even less their testimony is not to be considered, if they are not supported, by a man witness and an oath to be made”. - There are some among the people who say that one oath made by a single man witness, is not considered, justifying their protest, relying on what is said by Allah Blessed and Most High (the meaning): "Ask for the testimony of two witnesses among your men. If you cannot find two men, choose a man and two women, among those whom you accept as witnesses” (Koran II, 282). Malek said, "if we don't call in a man and two women to testify the complaining man will not be entitled to anything and therefore, he should not be asked to take an oath with his witness, the complaining man will not be entitled to anything and therefore, he should not be asked to ask to take an oath with his witness". It is from the argument of whoever said this hadith, to say to him: "What do you think of a man who claims to have a debt from another, will not the latter be asked to swear that he owes nothing, so the claim of the other will be Refused; If he renounces swearing, the plaintiff will be asked to take this oath, and then his right will be affirmed. Besides, this is not disputed by anyone, nor in any country. However, which verse of the Book of Allah did he refer to? If he wants to say this, let him do it by appointing his witness who will take the oath, even if it was not mentioned in the Book of Allah. And he is enough to follow the tradition that has been adopted by our ancestors. But the man wants to know what is right and what is argued. And, this is an explanation of what may trouble the mind, if Allah wills it”. Chapter V The judgment concerning the man who dies and leaves a debt to be repaid and another debt which is due to him and having on this subject only one witness (1431) - Malek said: "When a man dies, and that we owe him a debt, and that he has only one witness on this subject, and on the other hand that he owes people a debt, having still only one witness there, then that his heirs refuse to do, with their witness, an oath, not to owe such a debt, creditors are asked to swear to recover what they owe. In this case, if any part of the estate remains, the heirs will have no right to it because they have been called upon to take an oath and have refused it, except that they say: "In our opinion, our deceased n 'left nothing as an inheritance', and we realize that they refused to take an oath because of this. So, in my opinion, they must take such an oath and take the rest after the debt is paid”. Chapter VI Judgment on a lawsuit 
(1432) 10 - Malek reported that Jamil Ibn Abdul Rahman Al-Muezzin shared with Omar Ibn Abdul Aziz the sessions, where he decided controversies between people. In case a man came to claim to have a right from another, Omar took the matter into consideration; thus, if he found that between them, there was a common affair or conjecture, he asked the accused to take an oath, and if he found that there was nothing like it, he did not take not an oath”. Malek said: "That's what we follow at us (in Madinah) namely that, in the event that a man brings an accusation against another, it should be considered in this way, if he finds himself between them a common affair or conjecture, the accused is asked to make an oath; if he does, the charge is no longer considered, on the other hand, if he refuses to do so, deferring the oath to the plaintiff, and the latter takes the oath, he will thus have his full right”. Chapter VII The judgment made on the testimony of the children 
(1433) 11 - Hisham Ibn Ourwa reported that Abdallah Ibn Al-Zouhair took into consideration the testimony of the children, for the common wounds between them”. Malek said, “What is followed (with us) in Medina, it is that the testimony of the children is tolerated between them, for wounds which are common to them, without this being tolerated for others. Thus, their testimony is tolerated, for having had only between them, wounds, and that before they separate, or before they are deceived or even taught. Thus, if they separated, their testimony is no longer considered, except in the case where they declared, before separating, what they had witnessed, to righteous people”. Chapter VIII The violation of the oath before the pulpit of the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) 
(1434) 12 - Jaber Ibn Abdallah Al-Ansari reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him be Allah's grace and peace) said: "Whoever, before my pulpit will make a false oath will have its place in the fire”. 
(1435) 13 - Abu Ummah reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him be Allah's grace and peace) said: "Whoever, making a false oath, succeeds in seizing the property of a Muslim, Allah will prohibit him from entering Paradise, and will integrate him into Hell”. He was asked, “Even if it is something insignificant, O Messenger of Allah”? He replied: "Even if it is a simple branch of arak", repeating this for three times". Note: the arak, a kind of shrub, of which we uses branches, in order to make the siwaks, which are used to brush the teeth”. Chapter IX The oath taken before the minbar (the pulpit) 
(1436) 14 - Abu Ghatafan Ibn Tarif Al-Mouri a reported: 'Zaid Ibn Thabet Al-Ansari and Ibn Muti' had argued over a house, they brought their accusation to Marwan Ibn Al-Hakam, who was, at that time, the governor of Medina. Marwan asked Zaid Ibn Tabet to take an oath before the pulpit, so Zaid replied, "I will take an oath, from my place." Marwan replied: “No, by Allah! You will only do it before the bench of the judges”. Zaid, never ceased to make oaths, thereby affirming that his right is just, and refusing to do so in front of the pulpit, which astonished Marwan Ibn Al-Hakam”. Malek said, "I don't envision anyone doing an oath before the pulpit, if the subject is less than a quarter of a dinar equivalent to three dirhams”. Chapter X What is not tolerated in the withdrawal of the deposit 
(1437) 15 - Sa'id Ibn Al Musaiab reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r Upon him the grace and peace of Allah said: "It is not permissible to prevent withdrawal. pledge". - Interpreting this, Malek said: “I think, and Allah knows best of this, that a man who has pledged to another something of greater value than what he has borrowed, and the pawnbroker says to the lessor: "I will return your right on such a date, otherwise you will have what I have already pledged". Now, continues Malek: “This is neither permitted nor lawful; by the way, that's what which has been prohibited even if the borrower pays what he owed after the due date, because he will always have the right to withdraw his pledge and what has been stipulated is to be cancelled”. Chapter XI The judgment made in the pledge of fruits and animals (1438) Yahia reported that he heard Malek say about someone who pledges a garden for a specific period, that he will not have to do, fruits picked from this garden, before the date of the period, an integral part of the pledge, unless the lessor the request. Likewise, if a man pawns a slave who is pregnant or will be pregnant after the date of the pledge, her newborn remains with her”. - Malek said: “We made the distinction between the fruits, and the newborn of a slave. On this subject, the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said: “Whoever sells palm trees already fertilized, the fruits belong to the seller, unless the buyer asks to have them”. The rule, says Malek, unquestionably followed in we (in Medina), about the one who sells a slave, or a female of the animals being pregnant, the newborn comes back to the buyer whether or not he asks to have it, however the palms are not considered like animals, nor fruits like the fetus in its mother's lap". Malek interprets this as follows: "People usually pawn the fruits of the palm trees and not the palm trees themselves, but no one pawns a fetus while being in the bosom of its mother, whether it be that of a slave or a female of animals. Chapter XII The judgment concerning the deposit with animals (1439) - Yahia reported that he heard Malek say, "What is unquestionably followed with us (in Medina), regarding the pledge is the following: "If what is taken in pledge, is a land or a dwelling or an animal, which may be ravaged or destroyed or die, while being in the hands of a lessor, this responsibility rests with the pledge borrower without however the right of the lessor being diminished in any way. Thus, any pledge disappearing while being in the possession of the lessor and which can only be assessed according to the latter's statements, its compensation is the responsibility of the lessor who must pay it and who will be told : “Describe it, and make an oath”. Considering what is said, expert people will estimate the value; thus if the value of the pledge is higher than that which was fixed previously, the borrower will be able to keep the difference, but if the value is lower, one will ask the borrower to make an oath agreeing to the assertion of the statements of the lessor without him being responsible for the compensation, held for the difference between the pledge and the object given in substitution. If the borrower refuses to take the oath, the lessor will be given the difference. If the lessor, in turn, is unaware of the value of the pledge, the borrower will be asked to take an oath in which he will give the description of the pledge, recovering the difference himself if he provides obvious proof”. Malek said, "This is done, as long as the lessor keeps the pledge in his possession, without having given it to another". Chapter XII The judgment made for a pledge existing between two men (1440) Yahia reported that he heard Malek say about a pledge, which, is between two men, one of them then wants to sell it, as for the other, he had granted him for the question of this pledge, the period of one year?. Malek said: “If the pledge can be divided, without the share of the one who granted the delay being diminished, half of the pledge will be sold to secure his right. And if one risks his share being diminished, one will sell the entire pledge and give the damaged party its due. If the one who had granted the delay wants to give his half to the borrower for good, let it be done, otherwise the lessor will be asked to make an oath proving that the other had granted him a delay, only for to be able to keep the pledge as it is, and in this case we will immediately give him his right”. About the slave whose master pawns him, while the slave owns property, Malek said, "These property does not form part of the pledge unless the lessor requires it." Chapter XIV The judgment concerning pledges in general (1441) - Yahia reported that he heard Malek say: "As regards the person who advances in pledge personal things, which were destroyed at the lessor, but that the debtor admits this that he owes by giving the description of these things and without denying the other his right. They are in agreement except for the value of the pledge so the dispute will hold on the value, where the borrower says that it is twenty dinars, and the lessor says it is ten dinars, while the loan is twenty dinars?. Malek said, “Whoever is in possession will be told pledge; “Make his description”; if he does, he will be asked to take an oath, and therefore experts will be called in to assess the pledge in question. If the value proves to be higher than that of the real value of the pledge, the lessor will be asked to pay the borrower the difference of what he is entitled to. If the value is lower, the lessor will recover the difference from the borrower. If, in the end, the value is the same, the pledge will be compensated”. - On the other hand, in case two men quarrel the question of a pledge, so that the borrower says to the lessor: "I advanced this in pledge, for ten dinars" and that the lessor answers him: "It's more like twenty dinars", emphasizing that the pledge is in the possession of the lessor, Malek said: "We will ask the lessor to make an oath where he will specify the value of the pledge so if he shows himself that it is such without anything more or less, the lessor will take back the pledge against this value. And there, or will ask him first to make an oath because the pledge is always his property, unless the borrower does not pay the value, in order to want to take back his pledge. - If in the above situation, the value of the pledge turns out to be less than twenty dinars, the lessor will be asked to make an oath thus ensuring the sum he has fixed, and the borrower will be asked: "You will pay the sum fixed by the lessor, by making an oath and you will take back your pledge, or, you will take an oath, where you seek to ensure the fixing of the sum that you have declared, and consequently you will dispense with the difference that the lessor has designated. If the borrower makes such an oath, nothing is due to him, otherwise he will pay the sum that the lessor had already fixed". - If the pledge has disappeared, and the pledgee and the borrower both deny the right; if the one who has the right says: “I accepted this pledge by paying twenty dinars”, and the debtor answers him: “you only had ten dinars”; then the lessor, who has the right, replies: "The value of the pledge is only ten dinars", to which the borrower replies: “It was worth twenty dinars”, one will ask to that which has the right, to describe the pledge; so if he does, he will be made to take an oath, and then relying on this description, expert people will in turn estimate the value. If it turns out to be higher than that estimated by the pledger, he will be asked to make an oath, and therefore the borrower will be given the excess of the value of the pledge. If the value is lower, the pledgee will be asked to take an oath, thereby ensuring his right (of twenty dinars), and he will seek to compensate the value, the debtor will then be asked to make an oath thereby ensuring that the remainder must go to the defendant, once the value of the pledge is taken into consideration. For he who has the pledge in its possession, will become in relation to the borrower, an applicant, who taking an oath, he will owe nothing that the lessor had makes an oath about the excess value of the pledge. But, in case he refuses, he will have to pay the right of the lessor which is related to this excess”. Chapter XV Judgment on the rental of animals if they cause damage (1442) - Yahia reported that he heard Malek say: "When a man hires a mount to go to a well-determined place, then crosses this place to another, the owner of the mount will have to choose: "either that he claims the rental of his mount for the distance that has been covered in addition and will therefore have to collect with it the first rental by taking back his mount, or that he claims the price of his mount (in proportion to the distance covered in addition) and the first rental if this rental was made for the outward journey. If the rental includes the round trip, then the renter exceeds the middle he had previously designated, the owner of the mount would be entitled to half (of the excess) of the first rental, since this rental covers two journeys: the outward and the return . The tenant having passed the place designated, will only have to pay half of this rental. If it turns out that his mount is dead when he arrives in the designated country, the tenant will have no guarantee with regard to the owner and will only pay him the rental provided for in his half”. This is the rule followed when it is a dispute between the owner of a mount and its tenant, about the mount rented by the latter”. On the other hand, it is the same for the one who takes from the owner of a capital, a limited sum, in such a way that the latter said to him: "Do not buy yourself with this sum either an animal or a commodity", which he quotes to him, and that he forbids it to him, repugnant that his sponsorship sum be paid for such purchase. Now, if this man who had taken the money, was going to buy himself, which the owner of the capital forbids him to do so; wishing thereby to guarantee the money, and deprive the owner, of the profit, if so, this is done, the owner will have to choose: "or to share with the other the profit of the goods according to the condition advanced by them on this subject, by entrusting him with the money or even to have his capital back being guaranteed by the other, and of what moreover he had abused it". It is the same for the case of a man who asks another to buy from him a commodity which will be added to his own by paying him a sum, so that he can buy from him a commodity that he designates for him. In the event that the other buys a commodity which is not that which has been designated for him, by abusing this trust, the owner of the sum will have to choose: "either that he takes the commodity which the other bought it for him, or that he takes back his money once the second guarantees it to him". Chapter XVI The judgment relating to the woman raped by force 
(1443) 16 - Ibn Chehab reported that Abdul Malek Ibn Marwan ruled that the man who raped a woman by force, must pay her the dowry”. - Malek said: “Regarding the man who violates a woman by force, whether she be a virgin or married, he will have to pay her her dowry if she is free, and a sum equivalent to her price, which has become devaluative, if she is a slave. As for the prescribed penalty, it is to be applied to the violator alone, independently of the one who was violated who is not responsible for it. On the other hand, if the violator is a slave, it is his master who will be responsible for it, unless he agrees to hand him over”. Chapter XVII Of the Judgment concerning the use of an animal and the consumption of food and other (...) - I heard, reported Yahia, Malek say: "What is followed with us (in Medina), concerning the one who has consumed an animal without having had the permission of its owner, is that he will have to pay to the latter, the estimated price of this animal on day, even when he consumed it, without his giving in compensation for this animal, another which is similar to it. The sum, in this regard, is considered the fairest compensation, whether it is an animal or of a commodity. - Malek also said: “About the one who has consumed a food without having had the permission of its owner, it must in compensation give back to this owner the same food and of the same weight or measure, for the good reason that food is considered as gold and silver, where silver is compensated by silver and gold by gold . On the other hand the animal is not taken in the same way as gold; and in this respect it is by the sunnah that the distinction has been made”. - Malek finally said, “If a man deposits at another a sum of money, with which the second will go to trade and acquired a profit, this profit belongs to him alone, from the moment he has guaranteed money until he return to its owner. Chapter XVIII Of the judgment made about the apostate 
(1444) 17 - Zaid Ibn Aslam reported that the Apostle of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said: "Whoever changes his religion, strike his neck" . Interpreting this hadith, Malek said, "What we think, and Allah is the most informed, about the one who changes his religion, he must be killed who denies Islam and converts to a another religion such as atheists and their ilk, and who declare, they are killed, because it is not known whether they have repented, but if they keep their atheism in disbelief, and declare to be Muslims, they must neither be allowed to repent nor accept their words. On the other hand, the one who leaves Islam, to adopt another religion, while declaring it, we will accept for this one his repentance, if he puts it in proof, otherwise we kill him. Because, for people who find themselves in such a situation, I think that we must convert them to Islam and that they repent. So if they show repentance, we will accept it, if not, we will kill them. And said Malek, I do not believe, that the Prophet (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) designated by this, the Jews who became Christians or the Christians who became Jews, nor those who left their religion for another, except that it is about Islam, because the one who leaves it to adopt another religion while declaring, this is the man whom the Prophet (Upon him be the grace and peace of Allah) wanted to designate and Allah is most informed about this. 
(1445) 18 - Abdul Kari reported that a man came from Abu Moussa Al-Ach'ari, find Omar Ibn Al-Khattab, who questioned him about people, to which the man replied. Then Omar said to him, "Have you heard from those who are in the distant regions"? The man replied: “Certainly a man apostatized after being a Muslim". Omar resumed: "What have you done with him"? The man to answer: “We brought him in and we cut his head off” ; Omar exclaimed: "Did you not put him in prison for three days, giving him a piece of bread to eat every day, in order to give him the possibility of returning to Allah, repenting and converting again to Islam”? Then Umar added: “Great Allah! I was not present at this murder, and I would not have ordered it, nor accepted it, if I had been informed of this event”. Chapter XIX The judgment made about one who finds his wife with a man 
(1446) 19 - Abu Huraira reported that Sa'd Ibn Oubada, finding the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said to him: "What do you think, if I find a man with my wife; should i leave it so i can call four witnesses”? The Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) answered him: “yes”. 
(1447) 20 - Sa'id Ibn Al Musaiab reported that a a man from Syria, named Ibn Khaibari, having found a man with his wife, killed him, or killed them together. Reporting this case to Mouawia Ibn Abi Soufian, so that he can judge on it; Mouawia falling into the embarrassment, wrote to Abou Moussa al-Ach'ari, asking him to have the opinion of Ali Ibn Abi taleb, on this subject. Ali -replied, “This event did not take place in my country; I ask you to tell it to me; Abou Moussa wrote to Mouawia Ibn Abi Soufian, following which Ali gave his proposal saying: “I, the undersigned; me Abou Al Hassan if he does not call four witnesses, that he must pay the price of the blood of the victim”. Chapter XX The foundling judgment 
(1448) 21 - Ibn Chehab reported that Sunain Ibn Jamila, a man from Bani Soulaim, found, in the time of Omar Ibn Al-Khattab, an abandoned child. Sounain continues: “So I took him to Omar Ibn Al-Khattab who asked me: “What made you take charge of this little soul”? Sounain answered: "I found it, neglected, so I took care of it". One of Omar's advisers said: “O prince of the believers, he is a virtuous man”, Umar on his part replied: “Do you find him as such”? Yes, replied the adviser; thus Omar Ibn Al Khattab declared: “Leave therefore, he is free, and you have the right to patronize him, as for us, we will take care of his expenses". Malek said, “What is followed in Medina is to consider the abandoned child, free, and to the Muslims to patronize him, while inheriting him and paying for him, the price of blood”. Chapter XXI The judgment concerning the adoption of the child to his father 
(1449) 22 - Aisha, the wife of the Prophet (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) reported: "Utba Ibn Abi Waqas had entrusted to his brother Sa'd Ibn Abi Waqas, a child, saying to him: "The son of the slave of Zam'a is mine, take charge of him”. Aisha continues: "When it was the year of the conquest, Sa'd took the child saying: 'He is the son of my brother (nephew) and it was his father who entrusted him to me.' Abd Ibn Zam'a protested and said, "He is rather my brother, and the son of my father's slave, born on his bed." Bringing their accusation to the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him be Allah's grace and peace) Sa'd said: "O Messenger of Allah, he is the son of my brother, who entrusted him to me", and Abd Ibn Zam'a, on his part , says: “He is my brother, and is the son of my father's slave, born on his bed”; the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him be Allah's favor and peace) said, "He is your brother, Abd Ibn Zam'a”, then added: “The child returns to the master of the bed, on the other hand adultery, must be stoned”. Finally addressing Sawda Bint Zam'a, the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said: "You have to veil yourself, in his presence", seeing the resemblance of the child in question to Utba Ibn Abi Waqas. And this child never saw Sawda, until his death”. ; 
(1450) 23 - Abdallah Ibn Abi Oumaya reported that a woman, having lost her husband, passed a widowhood of four months and ten days, then this period having elapsed, she married a man with whom she remained for four and a half months, and gave birth , a child after a nine-month pregnancy. Her husband went to Omar Ibn Al-Khattab to whom he told this; Omar then summoned elderly women, who had witnessed such a situation in pre-Islamic times, and asked them to inform him about it. Moon of them said: “I can tell you about this woman; her husband died while she was pregnant, then she had a discharge of blood, but her child remained stable in her bosom. As soon as her second husband has had intercourse with her, the child, having tasted the sperm, is revived and grows bigger”. Omar considering what was advanced by this woman, separated between the woman subject discussed and her husband, saying: "I have been told about you (addressing the group of women) nothing but good, and then attached the child to the first husband". 
(1451) 24 - Soulaiman Ibn Yassar reported that Omar Ibn Al-Khattab linked children born in pre-Islamic times to those who claimed to be their fathers in early Islamic times. Two men came, each claiming in turn to be the father of a a son born to a woman. So Omar Ibn Al-Khattab summoned a physiognomist who was going to examine them both and then said: "This child is both at the same time” Omar, gave him a whiplash and then summoned the woman saying to him: “Tell me the truth”. So the woman said: "One of these two men - and she pointed to one - was going to my house, when I was at that time tending the camels to pasture, he did not part with me unless he was sure and me too, that I had become pregnant. The leaving, she had a discharge of blood, after which the second man had cohabited her, thus, she does not know of this fact which of the two is the father”, the physiognomist, listening, exalted Allah, as for Omar, addressing the child, said to him: "It's up to you to choose, which of the two will be your boss ". 
(1452) 25 - It was reported to Malek, that Omar Ibn Al-Khattab or Osman Ibn Affan, had judged the case of a slave, who invited a man to adultery, telling him that she was free, he married her and bore her several children: "Let a man ransom his children with what is equivalent". Malek on this, said: "And to ransom them at the value of their price is more just, in this case, Allah willing." Chapter XXII The judgment relating to the subject of the child's inheritance recognized (1453) -Malek said: - What we follow at home (in Medina), is this which follows: “when a man dies, and one of his many sons says: “My father has recognized such, to be his son”; this kinship is not never taken into consideration, based on the testimony of a single person. On the other hand, whoever makes such a recognition, will have to give from his share received from the paternal inheritance, a share similar to that which he recognized to be son of his father”. • Interpreting this, Malek said, "Consider that a man dies leaving two sons, and a sum of six hundred dinars, where each will have three hundred dinars for his share. One of them, testifying that his father had declared to him, before his death, that so and so is his son, he will have to give on his part, one hundred dinars to the son in question. Such a sum constitutes half of the recognized child's share; on the other hand if the other brother had made the same testimony, the child should still have a hundred dinars, thus receiving his full share of the inheritance, and consequently his relationship would be evident (let us emphasize that, the inheritance being thus divided, each will have had his fair share, namely two hundred dinars). Her case is similar to that of a woman who confesses that her father or husband owes a debt, and the other heirs deny it; thus, she will have to pay this debt to the creditor, in proportion to what she will receive as part of the inheritance, if it is done that the debt will revert to all the heirs: for example, if she inherits one-eighth of the inheritance as a wife, she must pay one-eighth of the debt to the creditor; and if she inherits half as an only child, she will pay half the debt. This is the standard that should be applied to women acknowledging debt”. If again, a man admits in the same way, to the woman, that his father owed any debt, the creditor is inclined to make an oath with his witness, and will thereby have all the debt. However, this case is not taken in the same way as that of the woman, as long as the testimony of the man is tolerated; thus the latter having recognized the debt, the creditor is asked to make an oath with his witness, and will therefore have all his rights. If the creditor reuses to take this oath, he will have of the inheritance of the one who recognized the debt to him, a part which is proportional, to the part returning to the successor of the inheritance; as for the others, they would have denied this debt”. Chapter XXIII The Judgment Made About Child-Slave Mothers 
(1454) 26 - Abdallah Ibn Omar reported from his father that Umar Ibn Al-Khattab said: “What happens to men, who after having cohabited with their slaves, they leave them? Every slave who came to tell me that her master had cohabited her, I would only attribute the child to her master, whether or not he practiced coitus interruptus with her. 
(1455) 27 - Safia Bint Abi Oubaid reported that Omar Ibn Al-Khattab said: “For what reason, men cohabit their slaves, then leave them. Any slave who came to confide in me, that her master had sex with a slave, I would adopt the child. So either you have to give them up or keep them”. - Malek said: “About the slave-mother of a child, in case she commits a crime, it is the rule followed here (in Medina), that her master pays the price within the limits of its value without him delivering it. And, consequently, he will not have to burden himself with any value other than that which his price merits. Chapter XXIV The judgment made about wasteland belonging to no one 
(1456) 28 - Urwa reported from his father that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him be Allah's grace and peace) said: "Whoever does the reviving a dead earth, it will be his property. On the other hand, whoever appropriates land unjustly, by planting it, this land will never be his possession”. - Interpreting this hadith, Malek said: “we mean by unequal appropriation, any land which has been either cultivated or planted, without any right”. 
(1457) 29 - Abdullah reported that his father Umar Ibn Al-Khattab said: “He who revives a dead land, it will be his possession”. Malek said, "This is what was followed at home (in Medina)." Chapter XXV The judgment made about the water 
(1458) 30 - It was reported to Abdullah Ibn Abi Bakr Ibn Muhammad Ibn Amr Ibn Hazm that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said: “About the irrigation canals of “Mahzouz and Mouzaineb” two valleys in Medina: “Whoever owns the part upper part of these two valleys, retains the water at the level of its land (thus watering its land) then when it reaches the level of the ankles it sends it back to water the lower part". 1459). which abounds with water, because in this way we will prevent the grasses, serving as pasture, from growing". 
(1460) 32 - Amra Bint Abdul Rahman reported that the Apostle of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him be Allah's grace and peace) said: "One should not forbid the abundance of water from a well. Chapter XXI Judgment made for a service of common interest 
(1461) 33 - Amr Ibn Yahia Al-Mazini reported from his father that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said: "One must neither harm anyone nor respond to a damage by another". 
(1462) 34 - Abu Hurairah narrated that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him be Allah's grace and peace) said: "Let none of you don't forbid his neighbor to plant a beam in the wall of his dwelling”, then Abu Houraira added: “Why, I see, that you are turning away from accepting it; by Allah, I will throw this beam to you between your shoulders”. 
(1463) 35 - Al-Mazini reported from his father that Al-Dahaq Ibn Khalifa had dug from “Al-Ouraid” - valley in Medina - an irrigation canal, which he wanted to cross in a piece of land which belonged to Muhammad Ibn Maslama. The latter refusing it, Al-Dahaq said to him: “Why do you refuse it to me, and yet you are going to take advantage of it? you will be able to have water to drink forever, and it will not harm you”. Muhammad still refusing it, al-Dahaq informs Omar Ibn Al-Khattab, who summoned Muhammad Ibn Maslama, and ordered him to allow Al-Dahaq. But Muhammad still not accepting, Omar exclaimed: "Why do you prevent your brother from doing what is useful, and which is still so for you: you will water your land forever with this water, and that will in no way harm you". Muhammad's answer being: "No, by Allah", Umar exclaimed: "By Allah, he will make this channel pass, even on your belly", and then ordered, to Al-Dahaq to dig it, the latter did it”. 
(1464) 36 - Yahia Al-Mazini reported that his father said: “There was in the garden of his grandfather, a rivulet which belonged to Abdul-Rahman Ibn Awf. As Abdul Rahman wanted to divert the course of this rivulet towards a place close to his land, the owner (who is the grandfather) forbade him; so Abdul Rahman having made Omar Ibn Al-Khattab learn this, he gave him the right to do it”. Chapter XXVII The judgment made on the distribution of property
