(1465) 37 Thawr Ibn Zaid Al-Dili said: “I have been told that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said: “Any abode or land that was divided in pre-Islamic times, it will be maintained as it was divided. And any abode or land that is to be shared in Islamic times, will be shared according to Islamic law”. 
(1466) 38 - Malek said: "He who dies, leaving property, being in "Al-Alia" and "Al-Safila" (places in Medina), the non-irrigated territory will not be shared with that which is irrigated, with water that is brought to it; unless the heirs of the deceased accept it. A non-irrigated land is to be shared with another watered by water from a spring, if both are the same. At where the property is in one place, or close to each other, each party will be valued alone, then the division will be made between the successors. It is the same with houses and dwellings. Chapter XXVIII Judgment Regarding Carnivorous Beasts and Kept Herds 
(1467) 39 - Haram Ibn Sa'd Ibn Muhaiissa reported that a camel possessed by al-Bara Ibn Azeb had entered a garden and caused damage. The Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the mercy and peace of Allah) requires that the owners of the garden keeps it during the day; as for the damage caused by the camel during the night, it is up to its owner to compensate for it”. 
(1468) 40 • Yahia Ibn Abdul-Rahman Ibn Hateb a reported that some of his slaves stole a camel from a man of Mouzaina and cut her throat. The case was presented to Omar, who ordered Kathir Ibn Al-Salt to cut off their hands. But immediately Omar grabbed hold of him and said to Hateb: “Don't you give them enough to eat? By Allah, continued Omar, I will make you pay an unbearable fine”, then addressing the man: “What is the price of your camel”? Al-Muzani replied, "By Allah, I will not sell it for less than four hundred dirhams." So Umar said to Hateb, "Give him eight hundred dirhams." - Malek said: "You must not believe that you sought in Medina, to double the value; but that's what people usually followed; now, however, the value of the fine is equal to that of the price of the camel or the animal on the day it was taken”. Chapter XXIX Judgment Made About One Who Causes Harm to Beasts (1469) - Malek said: "What is followed in us (in Medina), in case someone has caused harm to a beast, it is that he will pay a price, compensate for the one who was going to be subtracted from the real price of the animal which has thus lost its value". - In case a camel throws itself on a man of frightened, kills or mutilates him, Malek said: "If this man were fully sure of the danger, nothing comes back to him. pay as compensation; on the other hand, if your only argument is what is said by him, he must indemnify the owner of this camel". Chapter XXX The ruling on workers' wages (1470) - Malek said: “He who gives his garment to the launderer to change his color, after which he comes to say to the latter: I did not order you to do it, and that the other answers him: in fact, it is you who ordered me to do it do", one must in this case, admit what is the words of the laundress, and it is the same, when it is a question of a dressmaker and a jeweler where they are brought to make an oath to this topic, unless they were going to do something else what they were asked to do; thus, they will no longer be able to be believed and the one who possesses the garment will be asked to make an oath. If he refuses to do so, the dyer is asked to do so. - Malek also said: "If the dyer, to whom one has given the garment, is mistaken in knowing that he gives it to another man who is not its possessor and that he puts it on, nothing is demanded of this man but it is up to the dyer to pay an indemnity to the teacher of the garment, since the person who put on the garment was unaware that it was not his; on the other hand, if he knew that this garment was not his, he must guarantee it”. ChapterXXXI The judgment made about the guarantor and the person who assumes a claim (1471) - Malek said, "In case a man having a debt, causes it to be borne by another who is a creditor to him; if the latter goes bankrupt or dies without having paid the debt, we demands nothing from the debtor and the creditor has no right to go back on him to recover his debt. Such is the indisputable rule followed with us in Medina. – Malek also said, “When a man takes charge a debt which he will pay for another and whether he dies or goes bankrupt, the creditor has the right to come back to the debtor to settle his debt”. Chapter X XXII The judgment made about someone who buys a garment with a defect (1472) - Malek said: “Whoever buys a garment having a defect such as a burn or other, that the seller knows and has confirmed, and that the one who bought it, tore it, in such a way that this tear reduced the price of the garment, after which the buyer has noticed the original defect, the garment can be returned to the seller, without the buyer having to pay anything for having torn this garment”. – Malek also said: “If a man buys a garment having a defect such as a burn or a hole, which he seeks to cut out or dye, and the seller says he was unaware that the garment was so, the buyer can choose between having or keeping the garment after the seller has agreed to reduce his price because of the defect, or to return the garment to the seller by paying him the indemnity for cutting or dyeing. However, if the buyer has had the garment dyed in such a way that it has become more expensive, he will still have to choose: or ask the seller for a price compensating the defect of the garment, or to be a partner of the seller for the question of the garment. Then, we estimate the garment included the burn or hole; so if the price is ten dirhams, and the dyeing of the garment is five, the seller and the buyer are both partners in the garment, where each will have a share which will be proportional either to the initial price of the garment or to the costs paid for the dyeing”. Chapter XXXIII What is not permitted when giving gifts 
(1473) 41 - Al-Nou'man Ibn Bashir reported that his father brought him to the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) to whom he said: "I have done to my son, the gift of a slave I owned. The Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Be upon him the mercy and peace of Allah) replied: "Did you give the same gift for all your sons”? No, replied the other, so the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him be Allah's grace and peace) said, "So take back this slave." 
(1474) 42 - Aisha, the wife of the Prophet (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) reported that his father Abu Bakr Al-Siddiq had given him a gift of twenty wasqs of dates, being his property in "Al-Ghaba". When he died he said: “By Allah, my daughter, I would not like to see after me, someone richer than you, and it is unbearable to me that you are poorer than the others, so I gave you a gift of twenty wasqs of dates, which if you had picked them personally, they would would be a donation; but now, being considered an inheritance, you will have to share them with your two brothers and sisters, according to what is prescribed in the Book of Allah”. Aisha asked him, “Father, if it were so, by Allah, I would have abandoned him. However, I don't have only Asma for sister, who is the other”? He replied: "It is the daughter that Bint Kharija (the wife of the brother of Abu Bakr of the Ansars) carries in his lap, and I consider her as such (he implies that this girl will be Aicha's sister). 
(1475) 43 - Abdul Rahman Ibn abdul Qari reported that Omar Ibn Al-Khattab said, “What happens to men giving gifts to their sons and then retaining those gifts with them. So if one of them has a son who dies, he says: "My goods are always within my reach, I have not given them to anyone". But as soon as he feels death approaching he says: "This is a gift I gave to my son". "Now, whoever decides to make a donation, and does not advance it to the person to whom he intended it, preferring to keep it as an inheritance to his successors, this donation becomes illicit". Chapter XXXIV Of what is forbidden as a gift (1476) - Malek said: "What one follows in we, (in Medina), about the one who gives a gift to someone, not aiming to have another in exchange, doing it also in the presence of witnesses, that this gift, is already assured to the person destined, except in case the one who made the gift dies, before he actually gave it to the other. On the other hand, if the donor wants to retain his gift, after he has made a testimony about it, this is forbidden to him; thus, if the one to whom belongs the gift, claims it, he must have it”. - Malek also said: "Whoever gives a certain gift, after which he denies it, then that whoever was to take advantage of this gift, bring a witness, assuring him that the other had indeed given him a gift, namely whether it be a commodity, gold, silver or an animal, one will bring the one who was to benefit and his witness to make an oath about it. If they refuse it, the donor will be asked to do so, if this one still refuses it, he will give to the other what he claims, by right, to have, especially if he has only one witness; if the latter is not present, the donor will have nothing to advance”. - Malek finally said, “Whoever donates, without wanting to have something in return, and that the beneficiary dies, the heirs of the latter, will benefit from this gift; and if the beneficiary dies before having had his gift, he will have nothing in this case, because the gift was not yet in his possession. Thus, if the donor wants to keep it, having had a witness about his donation, proving that he had made it, the beneficiary will be able to have it, if he asks for it”. Chapter XXXV Judgment Made About Donations 
(1477) 44 - Abu Ghatfan Ibn Tarif Al Mourri a reported that Umar Ibn Al-Khattab said, “Whoever gives a gift, or even alms, to a close relative, should no longer withhold it. And whoever makes a gift, wanting thereby to obtain another in exchange, can keep his gift, even go back on this gift, if he is not satisfied with what he should have in exchange”. - Malek said: “What is followed at home (at Medina) about the receipt of a gift, which undergoes a transformation of more or less, that the donee wishing to make an exchange, will have to consider the value of this gift just at its delivery”. Chapter XXXVI The taking back of alms (1478) - Malek said: "What is unquestionably followed with us (in Medina), when a person who has given his son an alms which he has already taken, or who has remained in the custody of his father, and who has testified about this alms, the father will no longer have the right to withhold this alms, either partially or totally. - Malek said again: "He who gives a gift who is not an alms to his son, , has the right to withhold this gift as long as the son has not used this gift to take on a debt from people so that he becomes a debtor; thus, in this case there the father will not be able to retain this gift to leave his son unable to discharge his debt. Therefore, the father has no right to withhold his gift in the following cases: Whether the father gives his son, or his daughter in marriage, so that the girl marries the man or the man marries the girl only to be rich and for the money that her father had given her. Or that the man marries the woman to whom his father had donated, thereby assuring him of a large dowry due to his wealth and possessions, and to what his father had given him". Chapter XXXVII The judgment made about the "Umrah" NB The "Oumra": it is about the fact that someone says to another: "I will give you this home where you can stay as long as you are alive". On the death of the person who disposes of this residence, the residence must return to its owner if he is still desire; otherwise the heirs of the one who lived in the house will be able to benefit from it”. 
(1479) 45 Jaber Ibn Abdallah Al-Ansari reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam)r (Upon him be Allah's grace and peace) said: "Everyone, receiving what is of the “Umrah”, as well as its heirs, it will be his possession, without ever returning to the donor”; also this property will be subject to the laws of inheritance”. 
(1480) 46 - Abdul Rahman Ibn Al-Kassem reported that he heard Makhoul Al-Dimashki ask Al-Kassem Ibn Muhammad about the "Umrah", and what people say about it"? Al-Kassem Ibn Muhammad replied, "People never cease to bind themselves to their time-honored promises, about their possessions and what they receive." - Malek said: "What we follow at home (in Medina) concerning the Umrah is that it must return to its owner on the death of the donee unless he said to the latter: "It belongs to you and to your heirs". 
(1481) 47 - Nafe' reported that Abdallah Ibn Umar had inherited Hafsa Bint Omar, his home. However, the latter, had lodged in this residence, the daughter of Zaid Ibn Al-Khattab, as long as she was alive; but when she died, the residence returned to Abdallah Ibn Omar, which he considered to be his”. Chapter XXXVffl Judgment about what is found 
(1482) 48 - Zaid Ibn Khaled Al-Jouhani reported that a man came to find the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) asking him about what is found”. He replied: "Study well, the shape of the object found, then make an announcement about him for a year; if its owner comes to claim it, it will be his right, if not, it will come back to you”. The man asked again, "O Messenger of Allah (Upon him be Allah's mercy and peace), what do you say about the lost sheep?" He answered: "It will be either yours or your brother's or the wolf"; the other added, "What about the stray camel?" The Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him be Allah's Grace and Peace) replied, “Do not worry about him; for the camel has its water to drink, and its hooves (to move about); it will therefore be able to drink, eat the leaves of the trees to eat, until its owner finds it”. 
(1483) 49 Mu'awia Ibn Abdallah Ibn Badr Al-Jouhani reported that his father told him, that on the way to Châm (the Syria), he stopped with people and found a purse containing eighty dinars. Telling it to Omar Ibn Al-Khattab, he said to him: "Announcement ; this find in mosques, and to anyone who arrives from Châm (Damascus), for a year; if this time has already elapsed, it will come back to you”. 
(1484) 50 - Nafe' reported that a man having found a lost object, went to Abdallah Ibn Omar and said to him: "What do you say about a lost object that I found"? Abdallah Ibn Omar said to him: "Announce this object". Answering him that he had already done it, Abdallah asked him to do it again; So, after having announced it several times, Abdallah said to him, “I will not order you to consume it; because if you wanted to, you would not have taken this object”. Chapter XXXIX The judgment made about the consumption of a slave for a found object (1485) Malek said: “What is followed with us (at Medina), about the slave, who, finds an object, consumes it, before a year has elapsed from the very day on which he had found this object, that he will assume the responsibility for it, namely: "Or that the master of this slave will pay to the owner of this object, a price thereby compensating for what his slave had consumed, or that he will deliver his slave to him”. But if the slave had kept the object found for the period provided for, namely, one year, after which he consumed it, this object will be for him a debt which the slave will have to discharge; Therefore if he happens to be freed, nothing will be demanded of him or his master regarding this object”. Chapter XL The judgment made about stray animals 
(1486) 51 - Soulaiman Ibn Yassar reported that Thabet Ibn Al-Dahhaq Al-Ansari told him that he found a stray camel in "Al-Harra", he restrained it and then reported it to Umar Ibn Al-Khattab who ordered him to announce about the camel, three times. Now Thabet said to him: "This camel made me neglect my properties", Omar said to him: "Leave it where you found it". 
(1487) 52 - Sa'id Ibn Al Musaisab reported that Umar Ibn Al-Khattab, while leaning his back against the wall of the Ka'ba, said: "He who guards a stray animal, has already committed a sin." 
(1488) 53 - Malek reported that he heard Ibn Shehab say: "The lost animals were, in the time of Omar Ibn Al-Khattab, considered as belonging to their owner, and of the In fact, they copulated without anyone thinking of holding them back. But, when it was time for Osman Ibn Affan, he ordered to advertise about them and then sell them; thus, if their owner presented himself, he was paid their selling price”. Chapter XLI Alms given from the living for the dead 
(1489) 54 - Sa'id Ibn Amr Ibn's grandfather Churhabil Ibn Sa'id Ibn Sa'd Ibn Ubada reported: "Sa'd Ibn Ubada, went with the Messenger of Allah r (On him the grace and peace of Allah) for an expedition, and his mother was about to die in Medina, he was told: "Make your will". She replied, “Why make this will; all the property I own goes to Sa'd”; then she died, before Sa'd was present in Medina, he was told what had happened, Sa'd said to the Messenger of Allah (sallallahu alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him be Allah's favor and peace): "O Messenger of Allah, will she be rewarded if I do alms in his name”? The Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Be upon him the mercy and peace of Allah) replied: “Yes, certainly”. Then Sa'd said: "Such a garden, (which he pointed to), is alms." 
(1490) 55 - Aisha, the wife of the Prophet (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) reported that a man came and said to the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah): “O Messenger of Allah my mother died suddenly, and I believe that she wanted to tell me to give alms for her; can I do it”? The Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Be upon him the grace and peace of Allah) answered him: “Yes, certainly”. 
(1491) 56 - It was reported to Malek that a man of the Ansars, from the tribe of Al-Hareth Ibn Al-Khazraj, made his parents, an alms. His parents having died, the son inherited all their property which was palm groves. So he asked about it the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) who replied: “You gave alms to your parents, and you have already had a reward; as for the inheritance, it is your acquisition”. MOUATTAA In the name of Allah the Merciful the Merciful Book 37 The Book of the Testament First chapter The order to make a will 
(1492) 1 - Abdallah Ibn Umar reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said: “It is required of all Muslim, who has property to bequeath, not even to spend two nights without having written down his will". - Malek said: “What is followed at home (at Medina), about the one who, is healthy or sick, and who has already made his will in which he freed a slave or ordered something else, that he can, if he wants, change what is will, until his death. He can even neglect this will and proceed to write another, except the posthumous freeing of a slave, because there, he will not be able to change anything. This is in accordance with what the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said: "It is the duty of every Muslim, who, having property to bequeath, not even to spend two nights, without having written down his will". - Malek continues: “So if it is done that the testator can no longer either have his will modified, nor change its contents concerning postage, he will have withheld his money which he tended to spend for postage and for other action. The testator must make his will when he is traveling and when he is healthy”. Eventually Malek said, "Thus, what is an indisputable rule is that the testator can therefore change his will as long as he wishes, without this change affecting the subject of posthumous emancipation". Chapter II Permission for the younger, the sick, the weak and the foolish to make their will 
(1493) 2 - Abu Bakr Ibn Hazm reported from his father that Amr Ibn Soulaim Al-Zouraqui told him that Omar Ibn was told Al-Khatiab, about a young man who has not yet reached puberty, of the Ghassan tribe, owner of a fortune whose only heiress in Medina is a paternal cousin, as for the other heirs, they are found in Cham (in Syria). Umar Ibn Al-Khattab replied, "Let him make a will to his cousin." The young man, thus, bequeathed him a piece of land called: "Bir Joucham" which was sold for thirty thousand dirhams. This cousin who received this bequest was Oum Amr Ibn Sulaim al-Zouraqi”. 
(1494) 3 - Abu Bakr Ibn Hazm reported that a young boy from the Ghassan tribe, was dying, while he was in Medina, and that his heir was in Cham. We informed Omar Ibn Al-Khattab of this, and we asked him if this young man could make his will, he replied in the affirmative. Abu Bakr added: "The young boy, in question was ten or twelve years old, and had bequeathed a piece of land called "Bir Joucham", later sold by the heir for thirty thousand dirhams". - Malek said: “What is followed at home (at Medina), about one who has a weak mind, and one who is foolish, and also, one who sometimes loses the consciousness, that their will is to be considered, if they prove to be, if necessary , reasonable. However, if they fail to be so, that is, they fail in reason, they cannot make their will”. Chapter III The bequest that does not exceed one third of the inheritance 
(1495) 4 - Sa'd Ibn Abi Waqqs narrated: "The Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) having come to visit me, during of the farewell pilgrimage, when I was seriously ill, I said to him: “O Messenger of Allah, the disease attacked me from all sides; but I have a good fortune and I have only one heiress daughter, can I donate two-thirds of my wealth”? The Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him be Allah's Grace and Peace) replied, "No"; So I asked him: "and half"? “No, replied the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah), but the third, and even the third is already too much; That you leave your heirs rich is better than leaving them poor, holding out their hands to people. For all your expenses on your family seeking by it the love of Allah, you are rewarded, even for the mouthful you put in your wife's mouth". I said to him: “O Messenger of Allah will I remain in Makkah, then that my companions are no longer there”? The Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Be upon him the grace and peace of Allah) replied: "You will not be vainly a latecomer, for every good work you do will raise you in rank and consideration. You may be retarded, but on the one hand you will be useful to some and a detriment to others. O Great Allah! Make my companions complete their emigration and do not turn them back. But the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) was saddened, a little later, that the unfortunate Sa'd Ibn Khawla died in Mecca”. - Yahia reported that he heard Malek say: "when a man bequeaths a third of his property to another, saying: "my slave will serve such a man as long as he is alive", after which he will be freed, and that following the death of the testator, the 'we note that the value of the slave constitutes a third of his goods, one must, in this case, make esteem for the service rendered by the slave, and thus, the two men will have their share, just as follows: one gives to the first what is proportional to the third of the goods, and to the other what belongs to him of the service of the slave after evaluation; therefore each of them will have his share of the value of the slave's service or wages if he has done the work of his employee, in proportion to what he is entitled to do. But if the man in whose service the slave had worked dies, he must be freed”. - Malek also said: “He who bequeaths a third of his inheritance, saying: "One part to such, another to such", quoting his goods, and that his heirs find that the legacy is more than a third”, these heirs will have to choose: or that they give to the designated characters their part of the goods which return to them, by having with them all the heritage of the deceased; or that they give to the designated persons a third of the property of the deceased, and will subsequently have their shares, of whatever value they may be”. Chapter IV The bequests given by a pregnant woman, a sick person and a man fighting in the way of Allah (1496) - Yahia reported that he heard Malek say: "The best I have heard about the will made by a pregnant woman, and concerning her property, what is allowed to her is that she is considered just as a sick person, who in case, where his illness is not serious, namely that it is not tragic, he can dispose of his property as he wishes; on the other hand, if the illness is tragic, the patient will only be able to bequeath a third of his inheritance”. And, continues Malek, such is the case of a woman pregnant: her pregnancy is a welcome and a joy, where she is neither sick nor risky, which is also said by Allah (Blessed and Very high): َ ق يَ ْع ُ ق وب { ْس َح َ و َ ر اء إ َ ق َ و ِ م ن ْس َح َش ْ ر ن َ ا ه ا ب ِ إ ْت َ ف ب َض ِح َ ك َ م ٌة َ ف َ ق آئ } َ و ام َ ر أ ُت ُ ه "We announced to him the good news (of Isaac, and Yacoub, after Isaac" (Koran XI, 71) and: َ ه ا { إ ِ ل ْ ي َ م ا َ ف ل ْت بِ ِ ه َ ف َ م َ ر َخ ِ ف يفا َح ْ م ا َح َ م ل ْت َ ش اها َ م ا ت َغ َ ف ل َ ص ال ِ ح ا ْ ن آت ْ ي َت َ ن ا َ م ا ل َ ئ َ ر ب ُ ه ّ َ ه َد َع َ و ا َ ق ل َ ت أ ْث ِ م َ ن الشاك ِ ر ين ُ ك و ن َ ن } ل َ ن “She carried a light burden with which she walked easily. When it grew heavy, both called on Allah, their Lord: If You give us a just man, we will surely be grateful” (Koran VII, 189). Thus, once the woman's pregnancy is at sixth month, the woman will be able to dispose of a third of her property; because it is the completion of the six months, where Allah Blessed and Most High said: { ِ ن َ ك امل ْ ي َح ْ و ل ْ ي ِ ن ُ ه َ ن َ ن أ ْ و ا َد ِض ْع ُ ي ْر َ د ات } َ و ال َ و ال “Mothers who want to give breastfeeding their children, will breastfeed them for two whole years” (Koran II, 33), and: ُش َد ُ ه { َ غ أ َح َ ت ى إِ َ ذ ا بَ ل َش ْ ه ً ر ا ُ ه ثَ َا ُ ث ون َ ص ال } َ و ف “From the moment she got it designed, up to the time of his sevarge, thirty months have passed" (Koran XLVI, 15). Thus, if, from the day the woman became pregnant, six months have passed, she will only be able to dispose of a third of her property”. - Malek finally said: “The man who participates in a fight, he will therefore be able to bequeath only a third of his property, thus he is considered, under the same conditions, as a pregnant woman, and a seriously ill man”. Chapter V A Reservee's Bequest, and the Right of Possession (1497) - Yahia reported that he heard Malek say about this verse: ِ ق ين { ُ م َت َ ع ل َ ى ال َح ً ق ا َ م ْع ُ ر وف َ و اأق َ ر ب ِ ي ن ب ِ ا ل َد ْ ي ِ ن ُة ل ْ ل َ و ال ِ ص ي َخ ْ ي ً ر ا ال َ و } إ ِ ن ت َ ر َ ك “If this (the deceased) leaves property, he must make a will in favor of his father and mother. (Qur'an, II, 180), that it has been abrogated by other verses relating to the distribution of inheritance according to what is prescribed in the Glorified Book of Allah. - Malek also said: “He is from the sunnah unquestionably followed in our country (in Medina), not to tolerate making a bequest to an heir, unless the heirs give this right to the deceased. In case some of the heirs allow it and others refuse it, the heir to whom it is decided to make a bequest will receive this exceptional share of the first part, while the others will have their full share. - About the patient who can only have the third of his property, his heirs are asked for a permit to make a bequest to an heir, exceeding one third, Malek said, "Once this permit is granted, the heirs will no longer have the right to return to it , because, if it were allowed to them, any heir at the death of the testator, would have acted similarly, namely, that he will have the inheritance without putting the legacy into execution, including the third party and what the testator had bequeathed according to the permit granted to him". As for the testator, who in good health, asks to his heirs the permission to make a bequest, and that the latter grant it to him, Malek said: "They are not bound to accept it, and these heirs even have the right to refuse it, because, the man in question , being in good health, he has more than anyone else the right to enjoy his goods, namely to make alms at all, or to give them to anyone. On the other hand, if the man falls ill, thus no longer being able to dispose of his property, the heirs' permit becomes payable as long as he can only dispose of a third of his property, as for them, they will only have two third of which they have more right than him. Consequently, if one of the heirs comes to ask the dying man, to give him the inheritance, and that this one accepts it without putting it into execution, this gift must return to the one who must benefit from it, except if the man leaving the inheritance does not say: "Such of the heirs is weak, and I like that you give him your share and that he accepted, this is tolerated if the sick man had precisely mentioned the thing». - Malek further said, "If he gives her the inheritance, and that the beneficiary has executed a part, while another remains, this part must revert to the donor after the death of the heir”. - Eventually Malek said, “About the one who, in his will, mentions having given to one of his heirs, something which he had not obtained, and as a result, these heirs refuse to tolerate him, this legacy must return to them, according to what is prescribed in the Book of Allah, because the deceased did not want this legacy to be part of his third party. And we never give to legatees what is a third of their inheritance”. Chapter VI The subject of effeminate men and the one who has the most right to a child (1498) 5" Hisham Ibn Ourwa reported from his father that an effeminate, present at Oum Salama, the wife of the Prophet (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah), said to Abdallah Ibn Abi Oumaya, and the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam), was at his listen: “O Abdallah! if Allah will grant you tomorrow, the conquest of Taif, I will guide you to the daughter of Ghailan, who has four folds in front, and moving away, she shows eight”. The Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) then said: “Do not let such a man into your house”. (....) 6 - Yahia Ibn Sa'id reported that he heard Al-Kassem Ibn Muhammad say: “A woman from the Ansar, was married to Omar Ibn Al-Khattab, she bore Assem to him, and after that he divorced her. Arriving in Qouba, he found his son Assem playing in the courtyard of the mosque; so he took him by his arm and placed him before him on his mount. Immediately the child's grandmother stopped him and took the child away from him. Then both went to Abu Bakr Al-Siddiq where Omar exclaimed, "he is my son", and the woman from him said, "he is mine". Then Abu Bakr, addressing Omar, said to him: “Do not come between the mother and her child”; and Omar did not repeat his request. - Malek on this subject says: “This is what I want to follow”. Chapter VII The defect of a product and its guarantee (1499) - About the man who buys a merchandise, an animal, or a garment or any other merchandise, and he finds that sale is not approved, so that he decides to return what he bought, Malek said: " The owner of the merchandise only receives from its price the sum which was paid to him on the day he sold it, because the seller had guaranteed the merchandise on the day the sale was decided; thus any defect or lack, found in the goods, after the date of the sale, returns to the purchaser, given that his usufruct or the increase in the price returns to him. Also, it is possible that the buyer buys a commodity at a time when it is demanded and consumed, then he decides to return it when it is no longer fit to be sold. For example, a man buys goods for ten dinars, keeps it, then wants to return it, when its price is only one dinar; this he is not allowed as long as he causes the seller the loss of nine dinars; so either he resells it at this price or keeps it. On the other hand, if the buyer was going to return the goods, the very day of his purchase, he should have taken back the ten dinars he had paid, and no longer the price he must have had on the day he decided to return it, which had become, moreover, one dinar, causing the seller to lose nine dinars”. What justifies this, says Malek, is the following: “When a thief steals an object; the price of this object is estimated on the day the theft was committed, so that it is decided to cut off his hand, even if the decision is delayed, and the thief is in prison. If the thief had fled, and then was, after a certain time, arrested, and if, on the other hand, the value of the object had been reduced in such a way that the prescribed penalty can no longer be applied, this fall in price, is not to be considered. Nor is it considered that the offense is not subject to the penalty prescribed on the day of the theft, and that the price has increased when the thief was imprisoned and therefore the prescribed penalty to which he is subject will no longer be applicable to him". Chapter VII General Chapter on Passing Judgments and Despising Him 
(1500) 7 Yahia Ibn Sa'id reported that Abu-Al-Darda had written to Salman al-Farisi, "Come to the Holy Land, to which Salman replied: “The land sanctifies no one; it's rather his works that make man holy. I have been told that you have been appointed judge, in charge of people's affairs; so if you succeed in judging fairly, that happiness be granted to you, and if you do not succeed, take your precautions not to have a man killed, and that you find yourself in Hell”. Thus, each time Abu Al-Darda insisted on to judge two litigants, as they left, he stared at them and said to them: “Come back to me, and tell me again, your accusations; by Allah, I give only proper judgments. - Yahia reported that he heard Malek say: “Whoever seeks the help of a slave, without having had the permit of his master, in order to perform any work for him where he will pay him a salary, he must ensure the safety of this slave. In case where he accomplishes this work without being subjected to an accident or any harm whatsoever, if the master of this slave claims his salary, the man must pay it to him. And this is what is followed with us (in Medina)”. - Also Malek said: “in case a slave is half-freed half-slave, he retains for himself, his salary, however, he will not be able to fully dispose of this salary, except for his food and his clothing as far as possible; but if he dies, all his money goes to the man who didn't have it. not freed". - Finally, Malek said, “The standard followed at Medina, allows the father to claim from his son the expenses he had incurred, if the latter already possesses property; whether it be flowing funds or goods, according to what the father envisages”. 
(1501) 8 - Omar Ibn Abdul-Rahman Ibn Dalaf Al-Mouzani reported from his father that a man from Jouhaina, anticipated the period of the pilgrimage, bought mounts to make them more expensive, then hurried to arrive earlier than the pilgrims. He went bankrupt, Omar Ibn Al-Khattab was informed about him, who said: “This done, O men! This man Oussaïfé of the Jouhaina tribe was satisfied, that people say of him, about his faith and his sincerity, that he arrived before the pilgrims. Now, he has become indebted, and is in a difficult situation, those to whom this man, owes money, that they come to us tomorrow morning, so that we share with them what he left. So, avoid debt, because its beginning is a pain, and its end is an embarrassment”. Chapter IX The subject of losses and injuries caused by slaves. (1502) - Yahia reported that he heard Malek say: "The sunna followed in Medina, concerning an offense caused by the slave, requires the following: "Anything that a slave may cause, injury to a person, or an object that he steals , or a sheep which he seizes at night outside an enclosure, or a branch of a tree, which bearing fruit, he cuts or destroys, or again any kind of theft, which is not subject to the prescribed penalty requiring that the hand be cut off, and which, generally, does not exceed the price of this slave. indemnity for this offence, and he keeps his slave, or he hands him over to the damaged person, as he chooses, without owing anything else". Chapter X What is allowed as a gift 
(1503) 9 - Sa'id Ibn Al-Musaiab reported that Osman Ibn Affan said: "Whoever makes a gift to his minor child without the latter being able to take care of it, he must declare his gift publicly, being confirmed by witnesses, this is allowed to the father and he has the right to recover it, in case his son dies”. - Malek said: “The rule followed at home (at Medina), about the one who gives his minor son a gift, gold or silver, and he dies, so that his son inherits it, nothing will return to the latter, except in the case where his father had completely set aside this gift, or that he had given it in deposit to a third person; if he does so, this gift will be of the right of the son”. MOUATTAA In the name of Allah the Merciful the Merciful Book 38 The Book of Postage and Patronage Chapter I Of him who frees his share in a slave 
(1504) 1 - Abdallah Ibn Umar reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Be upon him the mercy and peace of Allah) said: "He who frees his share in a slave, while having enough money, for the price of the slave, one will make estimate of the value of this slave, so that the one who took the initiative of the postage, pays to the partners, their shares, making that his postage is total; otherwise, the slave will not be completely freed”. - Malek said: “What is followed at home (at Medina), concerning the slave whom his master has partially freed, and whom the associates have freed either by a quarter, or by a third or by a half, that this slave is only partially freed, according to what has been quoted from by his master. Therefore this postage partial is obligatory, as long as the man (owner of the slave) is dead, although if the latter were still alive, he should have had a complete choice in this matter. Thus, after the death of the master (the testator), the slave finds himself only partially freed, namely, in proportion to the value of the bequest made by the deceased; as for the legacy of the latter, it is due rights of heirs. This done, how can one demand of others that they free the slave, without them having themselves had, the initiative of the postage, nor even, that they highlighted it; therefore, they no longer even have the right of patronage. So, in fact, it is the man who died, who was for the emancipation of the slave and to whom belongs the right of patronage, without however entrusting others with the emancipation of their shares. However, if the deceased had, in his will, made a legacy where one must pay to the others their shares for the total emancipation of the succession, the slave will be absolutely freed and the partners will not have to refuse this, from the moment that the dead had disposed of the third of his property, without this causing damage to his heirs". - And Malek to say: "In case a sick man frees the third of slave and that definitively, this one will be absolutely freed thanks to this third of the estate; this case is not similar to that where a man makes a legacy to free the third of his slave, after his death, for the good reason, that if this man is still alive, he will have the right to return on this legacy, and no longer free his slave. Also, the slave, whose master freed him from the third, when he was sick, should have, if he had always been alive, totally free his slave. But if the man dies, the slave will be freed from the third party, since the dead has the right to bequeath a third of his property, just like a healthy man who can enjoy all his property”. Chapter II The postage condition 
(1505) 2 - Malek said: “The slave who was absolutely freed so that one can attribute to him all the rights of a free man, namely the testimony, and the inheritance, his master can no longer subject him to the conditions to which another slave submits, such as the payment of the price of freedom, or work to be done, or subject him to a charge of slavery, because the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said: "Whoever frees a slave for his share, that slave will be esteemed at his just value, and he will give his associates their part, while assuming alone the complete emancipation of this slave". - Malek said: "So this slave being of the belonging of this man alone, instead of freeing him partially, it is his right to enfranchise him completely and set him free completely”. Chapter III He who frees his slaves without having any other property 
(1506) 3 - Muhammad Ibn Sirin reported that a man, at the time of the Messenger of Allah (sallallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) had freed, at his death, his six slaves without being possessor of other goods. So, the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) drew lots to set free a third of these slaves”. - Malek said: “I was told that the man in question did not have any other property”. (1507)4- Rabi'a Ibn Abi Abdul-Rahman reported that a man had, when Aban Ibn Osman was governor in Medina, freed all his slaves, without possessing any other property apart from them. Then Aban ordered, to distribute these slaves in three categories, then made on their subject, a draw, so that one can indicate the third of these slaves who, later, was freed”. Chapter IV Of the judgment made respecting the property of a slave, if he finds himself freed 
(1508) 5 Malek reported that he heard Ibn Chehab say: "The sunna requires that, as soon as the slave is freed, this one must have all his goods". - Malek also said: "What justifies, that the slave freedman, must have his goods, is that the contractual freedman says: "Al-Mukatab", has his postage which belongs to him in person, and also to his property, even if he did not ask for it; this is explained by the fact that the contract of emancipation is also a contract of patronage, if this has already been decided, without it being considered that the goods of the slave and of the contractual freedman are taken from it. same title as their children. In fact their children are like them slaves, and are not taken as property, because it is the sunna, incontestably followed, that the freed slave must have his property, but without this freeing his children; it is the same for the contractual freedman, who is freed, this will be for his property, but not for his children. - Malek further added: “what justifies this, it is that, from the moment that the slave and the contractual freedman, know deficit, one must remove their goods and their wives, independently of their children because these are not their goods. Also, this is justified by the fact that, if the slave is sold, and his buyer demands that he still have his property, his children will not be part of his property. Eventually, Malek says, "if the slave is injured, he himself is taken as well as his property, regardless of his children." Chapter V The Liberation of Enslaved Mothers and the Judgment Made About Emancipation 
(1509) 6 - Umar Ibn Al-Khattab said: “All a slave who gives birth to a child of her master, the latter may neither sell her, nor make a gift of her, nor consider her an heiress; however he can enjoy his person, and at his death, he will be liberated”. 
(1510) 7 - It was reported to Malek, that Omar Ibn Al-Khattab, had received in his home a slave whom his master had tortured with fire, or with what, he had harmed her, Omar freed her”. - Malek said: “What is unquestionably followed with us (in Medina), it is that we do not tolerate the liberation of a man whose debt is beyond his value, nor even the emancipation of a young slave until he has not reached the age of puberty, nor the release of a slave, who is pubescent and who does not however have the right to dispose of his property before he actually has the right to dispose of it ". Chapter VI Slaves permitted to be freed when freeing is compulsory 
(1511) 8 - Omar Ibn Al-Hakam reported: “I came to find the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him be Allah's grace and peace) and said to him: “O Messenger of Allah I have a female slave who leads the herd to pasture; in the meeting, I realized that she had lost a sheep, I asked her to explain this to me, and she answered me that the wolf devoured her, I got angry, and being a human being, I slapped. I had a slave to free, can I free her in her place? The Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him be Allah's grace and peace) asked the slave: “Where is Allah”? In heaven, she replied”; he asked him: "Who am I"? Responding to him: "You are the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) , he then said, "Free her." 
(1512) 9 - Oubaidallah Ibn Abdallah Ibn Utba Ibn Mass'oud reported: "A man from the Ansar, brought a black slave, with him, came to find the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him be Allah's favor and peace) and said to him: "O Messenger of Allah I have to free a slave, but if you find that this slave is a believer, I will free her». The Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Be upon him the grace and peace of Allah) addressing the slave said to him: “do you bear witness that there is no god but Allah”? "Answering yes", he asked him again: "Do you bear witness that I am the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam)"? "Responding, again, with a yes", he finally asks her: "Do you believe in the resurrection after death"?; his answer being, a yes, the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him be Allah's Grace and Peace) then said to the man: “Free her”. 
(1513) 10 • Al-Maqbouri reported that they asked Abou Houraira, about the man who has a slave to free, will he be able to free an adulterine slave? Abu Huraira replied: “yes, certainly, and that will be considered a release for him”. 
(1514) 11 - Fadala Ibn Oubaid Al-Ansari, who, moreover, was one of the companions of the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah), was asked about a man, who has a slave to free, will he be allowed to free an adulterous slave? “Yes, certainly, he replied, and that will be considered a release for him”. Chapter VII What is not tolerated as mandatory release 
(1515) 12 - It was reported to Malek that Abdallah Ibn Omar, was asked to determine if one could buy a slave for the specific purpose of the obligatory emancipation of a slave”? He replied, “No”. - Interpreting this, Malek said, "This is what I have better understood on the subject of the obligatory franking of one or a slave, where that which intends to free it, must not buy it later, nor either to advance such a condition. For if he were to do so, his emancipation would not be complete, from moment that he would pay for this slave, a price lower than his real price". And Malek added: “There is no harm in a man freely buying a slave and then freeing him”. - On the other hand, Malek said, “What I heard from better about the compulsory freeing of a slave, it is that one cannot free neither a Christian, nor a Jew, nor a contractual slave, nor a posthumous freedman, nor a slave who has become mother, nor a slave for a few years, nor a blind man. But, there is no harm in arbitrarily releasing a Christian, a Jew or a Magus, for Allah Blessed and Most High, has said in His Book َ د اء { َ م ا ف َ و إ َ م ً ن ا بَ ْع ُد َ م ا } َ ف إ (meaning): “ Then you will choose between their release and their ransom ” (Koran XLVII, v.4). This liberation is nothing other than emancipation”. - Malek finally said, “So the slaves, mentioned in the Book of Allah, which are to be franked, must only be believers”. Similarly, when it comes to giving food to the poor, under the title of an expiation, it can only be done for Muslims, emphasizing that this is not allowed for those who are of a other religion”. Chapter VIII The liberation made by a living person for a dead person 
(1516) 13 - Abdul Rahman Ibn Abi Amra Al-Ansari reported that his mother wanted to make a will, and delayed it until the morning she died, when she intended to free a slave". Thus, Abdul Rahman, questioned Al-Kassem Ibn Muhammad on this subject, and asked her, if she will be rewarded if he frees the slave in her place, Al-Kassem replied: "Sa'd Ibn Oubada had asked the same question to the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) and he replied: "Yes". 
(1517) 14 - Yahia Ibn Sa'id reported that Abdul-Rahman Ibn Abu Bakr died accidentally, Aisha, the Prophet's wife (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) frees several slaves in his title. Malek said, "That's the best I've heard." Chapter IX The excellence of freeing a slave, a profligate, and an adulterer 
(1518) 15 - Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, the wife of the Prophet (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) was asked to (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) which of the slaves, is it better to free”? He replied, "The one that is the most expensive, and that his master most wants to retain." (...) 16 - Nafe' reported that Abdallah Ibn Omar freed an adulterer and his slave mother». Chapter X The right to grant patronage to the person making the postage 
(1519) 17 - Aisha, the wife of the Prophet (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) reported: "Barira comes to tell me: "I had concluded with my masters, to pay them, concerning my postage, nine ounces of silver, in such a way that one ounce is paid every year, and I ask you to support me". Aicha replied: “If your people accept that I pay them this sum in your place so that you are freed, I will do it, on condition that I patronize you”. Going to his masters to teach them Aicha's proposal, and that they refused it, Barira returned to Aisha, while the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the mercy and peace of Allah) was at her house, and said to her: "I had reported your proposal to them, but they refused it, wanting have to them the right of my patronage". Listening to this, the Messenger of Allah r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) asked Aisha, to explain it to him; once, informed, he addressed Aicha, saying to her: «bring her, and ask them, the right to patronize her, because this right belongs to him who freed», Aicha, accomplishes what he says to him; the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) arose, among the people, then gave praise and glorification to Allah, and said: “Then! What happens to men to put forward conditions, which are not in The Book of Allah? thus, any condition that was not mentioned in The Book of Allah, is invalid, even if these conditions are one hundred in number; therefore the right of Allah is the most meritorious and the strongest, moreover, the right of patronage belongs to the one who frees. 
(1520) 18 - Abdallah Ibn Omar reported that Aisha, the mother of believers intended to buy herself a slave to free her, her masters said to her: "We will sell her to you, only at provided that we hold the right to his patronage”. Aicha, teaching this to the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) he said to him: “Let nothing prevent you from buying it and freeing it; for patronage is the right of the person who made the postage”. 
(1521) 19 - Amra Bint Abdul Rahman reported that Barira, came to ask Aicha, the mother of the believers, to support her, this one said to him: "If your masters wish that I pay them all the sum, so that I free you, I will do it". Barira, let it be known this to his masters, they refused, saying: “No, except, in case we had the right to patronize you”. Amra, learned this from Aisha, she in turn reported it to the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) , (Be upon him the grace and peace of Allah) who said to him: "Buy it, and free her, because the right of patronage belongs to the one who freed”. 
(1522) 20 Abdallah Ibn Umar reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam),r (Upon him be Allah's grace and peace) forbade the sale of the right of patronage, and to make it a donation". - About a slave who is bought from his masters, provided he himself chooses who will patronize him, Malek said, “This is not permitted, for patronage is the right of the one who freed. Although, if a man gives to him whom he frees, the right to belong to him whom he chooses himself, this is also not permitted, for the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him be the grace and peace of Allah) said: "Patronage is the right of him who freed", prohibiting, however, that this right be sold, or made as a gift. Thereby. if the man tolerates to his freedman the right to choose himself, his boss, or even that he allows it, this is considered as a gift, is moreover prohibited”. Chapter XI Of liberation, which implies the right of patronage 
(1523) 21 • Rabi'a Ibn Abdul Rahman reported that Al-Zoubair Ibn Al-Awam had bought a slave and freed him. This slave, had children of a free woman, and Al-Zoubair having freed him, says to him: “These children are my freedmen”, and on their behalf, the close relations of the mother claim them as being of theirs. Bringing their accusations to Osman Ibn Affan, he gave Al-Zoubair the right to patronize them”. (...) 22 - It was reported to Malek, that Sa'id Ibn Al-Mussaiab, asked about a slave who has children from a free woman, who should be given the right to patronize them? Sa'id replied, "If their father dies, before he is freed, the right of their patronage reverts to their mother's relatives." - Malek said: "This case is similar to the one of an adulterine child, who, attached to his mother's relatives, patronize him, inherit him even if he dies, and still pay him legal compensation or blood money in case he commits a crime or misdemeanour. However if his father recognizes him (as a son), this child will be attached to him and his relatives, and as a result will be able to inherit him, just as they will pay him legal compensation or blood money, if he had committed a crime or an offense, on the other hand, his father will be subjected to the prescribed penalty (namely, that he will be flogged". - Malek to continue: “So is the case of a free Arab woman, practicing adultery; if her husband accuses her about it and calls a curse on her, and does not not recognize the son brought into the world. However, the inheritance of this child at his death will return to the Muslims, after the part of the mother and his uterine brothers has been set aside, unless the father does not attach the child in question, to him. Because this child, before he was recognized by his father, he had been subordinated to the patronage of his mother's relatives, since he had neither membership nor "assaba". Thus, thanks to the recognition of the father, his belonging returned to his “assaba”. - Malek to add: "what is followed, with us (at Medina), about a child whose father is a slave, and mother is free, and the slave's father happens to be free, is that the grandfather, namely, the father of the slave, can take away the right to patronize free children, born of a free woman; therefore, this grandfather can inherit them, as long as their father is still a slave. However, if the slave father is freed, the right to the patronage of the children reverts to the relatives of the father, and if he dies while being a slave, their patronage and inheritance revert to the grandfather. If the slave has two free children, and one of them dies while the father is a slave, the grandfather takes the right of both patronage and inheritance”. - On the other hand, about a slave, who found freed while she is pregnant, while her husband is a slave, and then freed after she gives birth to her child, Malek said, “The patronage of the newborn is the right of him who had freed his mother, because this infant would have been subject to slavery, if his mother had not previously been freed, especially since he is not considered on the same footing as that, who was still in her mother's lap, after her emancipation; for if it were so, and his father is no longer a slave, he takes away the right to patronize him”. - Eventually, Malek said, "For the slave who asks his master to allow him the freeing of another slave who belongs to him, and that his master grants it to him: the right patronage belongs to the master of the slave and no longer to the slave who had been freed". Chapter XII The subject of the "Walaa" legacy 
(1524) 23 - Hicham reported from his father that Al-Assi Ibn Hisham died leaving three sons, two of whom are siblings, and the other is consanguineous. One of the two siblings having died, leaving property and freedmen, it was his full brother who inherited the property and the Walaa of the freedmen. Then the latter, dying in his turn, he leaves a son, and a consanguineous brother. So his son said, “I have the right to inherit everything that my father had acquired in property and also the Walaa of the freedmen. However, the consanguineous brother, protesting, said to him: “No, you only have the right to inherit the goods, as for the Walaa, you do not have the right. Besides, if my brother died today, wouldn't I have the right to inherit him? Both wearing their accusations to Omar Ibn Affan, the latter granted the Walaa to the brother". 
(1525) 24 - Abdallah Ibn Abi Bakr Ibn Hazm a reported from his father, that while sitting with Aban Ibn Osman, a group from Bani Jouhaina, and another from Bani Khazraj, submitted their differences to him, on the occasion of which, he was told that a woman from Jouhaina who was the wife of Al-Hareth Ibn Al-Khazraj called Ibrahim Ibn Kulaib, died, leaving property and freedmen. Thereby, her son and her husband inherit it; then his son died, his heirs said: "it is up to us to have the Walaa (1) of the freedmen as long as it is the son who enjoyed this right". The men of the Jouhaina replied: “No, it is not so, because the heirs do not are only freedmen of the mother, who was of us; but her son being dead, the Walaa is our right, and we must inherit them”. Thus Aban granted the men of Jouhaina the Walaa». (1) The Walaa is said of any right of patronage, to the holding of the one who makes a postage, by proceeding to multiple means such as the contract, or posthumous, or other. 
(1526) 25 - It was reported to Malek that Sa'id Ibn Al Moussaiab said about a man who dies leaving three sons, and freedmen, after which two of his sons die, leaving children”. Sa'id says, “the third son will inherit the Walaa; and if he dies in his turn, the Walla of the freedmen will be granted both to the children of the one who has just died, and to the children of his brother, in an equitable and legitimate manner”. Chapter XIII Of the legacy of the so-called “Saiba” slave and of the Walaa of those who emancipate Jews and Christians 
(1527) 26 - Malek asked Ibn Chehab, about the “Saiba”? He replied, “He can give the right of his patronage to whomever he wishes; so if he dies, he will not grant it to anyone, his inheritance will therefore go to the Muslims, who are responsible for paying him the legal compensation”. - Malek said, "The best I've heard at about the 'Saiba' is that it is not owned by anyone; as for his inheritance, it is the right of the Muslims, on condition that they pay him the legal compensation, if he had to do so”. - And Malek added: "In case the slave of a Jew or of a Christian, becomes a follower of Islam, and his master frees him before he is sold, the Walaa of this freed slave, returns to the Muslims; and if the Jew or the Christian, in turn, become partisans of Islam, the Walaa of the liberated will not be his. But if a Jew or a Christian releases a slave, while he is of their religion, after which he will have converted to Islam, even before those who released him, namely the Jew or the Christian , have themselves converted to Islam, the Walaa returns to the freer, because this was justified to him from the very day he freed”. “Saiba” (2) These are the slave, freed by his master, without him granting him the right of patronage, but rather giving it to the freedman. - Malek finally said: "If a Jew or a Christian had a Muslim child, the latter inherits the freedmen from his Jewish or Christian father if the freedman showed himself to be a follower of Islam before this was followed by the freedman; on the other hand the Muslim child of a Jew or a Christian does not inherit the Walaa of the Muslim freedman, as long as this Walaa belongs neither to the Jew nor to the Christian, but to the Muslim community”. MOUATTAA In the name of Allah the Merciful the Merciful Book 39 The Book of the contractual freedman and said "AI-Moukatab" Chapter 1 The judgment made about the contractual freedman. (1528)1 - Nafe' reported that Abdallah Ibn Umar said: "The so-called moukatab still freed by contract, will always remain held as a slave, as long as he has a certain sum, which has not yet been paid, of the price of his release". 
(1529) 2 - It was reported to Malek, that Urwa Ibn Al-Zoubair and Soulaiman Ibn Yassar said: "As long as the mukatab has not yet paid the full sum, constituting the price of his emancipation, he is still a slave". And Malek adds: “And such is my opinion”. - Malek said, “If the moukatab dies, leaving a sum of money, exceeding that which is to him of the price of his postage which he had already concluded, or that on their subject, he had concluded a similar contract, his children will have the right to inherit what remains of his property, if the price of his postage had already been fully paid. 
(1530) 3 - Houmaid Ibn Qais al-Makki reported that Ibn al-Moutawakel had a mukatab, who died in Mecca, leaving some terms of the cost of his postage as well as the debts he owed to people, and leaving another daughter. The prefect of Mecca, falling into embarrassment, wanting to judge this affair, he sent to ask in writing on this subject, to Abdul Malek Ibn Marwan, who in turn answered him in writing: "First discharge the debts of the creditors, then complete what remains of the price of his emancipation, and finally, divide equally what remains of his goods, between his daughter and his master". (1) “The moukatab" is said of the slave, who must obtain from his master, a postage, having concluded a contract with him by virtue of which he will pay him a fixed sum which extends according to the terms of this contract. This type of contract has been given the name of “kitaba”. - Malek said: “what is followed (with us) at Medina is that the master of the slave is under no circumstances obliged to conclude a contract with his slave, if the latter asks him to. And I have not even heard any imam compel a master to conclude such contract with his slave. Still, I happened to know that, asked about it, a man versed in religion replied, “Allah Blessed and Most High has said (meaning): “…..Draw up a contract of freedom for those of your slaves who desire it, if you recognize in them qualities…..” (Koran XXIV, verse 33), again this man recited the following two verses (meaning): “….hunt when you have returned to the profane state….” (Koran V,2) and: “….when the prayer is finished, scatter yourselves in the land, and seek the grace of Allah” (Koran LXII,10). Interpreting this, Malek said, “This, is a tolerance from Allah, granted to people although it is not obligatory. - Malek said: “I heard some men versed in religion, say about the following verse: “…and give them goods which Allah has bestowed upon you…” (Koran XXIV.33), that one implies, that the man can conclude a contract of emancipation with his slave, then can make him a handing-over of a given sum at the end of the acquittal. This is, moreover, what I have heard, men versed in religion, say and which was followed by the people in Medina. I was even told that Abdallah Ibn Omar had concluded a freeing contract with his slave for a sum which is thirty and five thousand dirhams, and as a result, he gave her a discount of five thousand”. - On the other hand Malek added: “What is followed at Medina, about the slave with whom his master had concluded a contract of emancipation, it is that the latter will free the goods of the freedman, which will not be for his children, unless the master had them , again them, included in the contract”. - Yahia reported that he heard Malek say to the subject of the "moukatab", who had concluded a contract of emancipation with his master, while having to him a pregnant slave, of whom he was unaware of the affair, as well as his master, during the contract, as well as the child once born, will not be part of the contract, and will therefore be a slave of the master; as for the female slave, she is already freed because she was an integral part of the property of the mukatab”. -About a man who, inheriting from his wife dead, as well as her son, a mukatab, Malek said: “If the mukatab dies before he has fulfilled his Kitaba, the man and the son will divide his inheritance according to what is prescribed in the Book of Allah; but if the moukatab had paid in full the price of his postage, all his inheritance will revert to the son without anything being given to the husband”. - About the moukatab who concludes with his slave a Kitaba, Malek said: “We are checking this contract, so if it has been done on the part of the Moukattab to show himself kind to his slave, and to want to lighten his work for him, this is not tolerated. But if this contract was made by desire, or by need of money, or even still to have the advantage and the assistance, that is tolerated. -About the man, who concluded with his slave (female) a contract, Malek said: "If, because of having had sex with her, she has become pregnant, she will have to choose: or whether she is the mother of the child, or that she be freed, once her Kitaba was accomplished. If it turns out that she is not pregnant, she is at her kitaba”. - Malek said: “what is followed at home (at Medina) in the case where a slave belongs to two men, it is not tolerated that one of them concludes a Kitaba, while his partner wants or does not allow him, from the moment that the two must agree on the Kitaba, because this constitutes for the slave a complete emancipation. If this Kitaba is made by one of the two partners, the slave will be half freed, and the other partner cannot be made to free the other half; therefore, it will be a contradiction with the words of the Messenger of Allah r (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) who said: "Whoever frees the part he owns about a slave, must free him completely if it is possible for him, after having made the evaluation of the slave”. - Malek to continue: "if the partner ignores the Kitaba on the other, until the slave has completed the payment of his Kitaba or even before, we must give him back what he already had to pay. paid, and the two partners will share the sum already paid between them in proportion to their share; consequently the Kitaba will be annulled, and the slave will remain common to both partners”. - For the contractual freedman who is belonging to two men, and it is a fact that one of them granted the slave a period of time to pay, as for the other, he granted it to him. refused, the latter is inclined, says Malek, to fix what is of his right, especially if the slave dies, leaving a sum that does not allow him to pay in full". Still on this subject, Malek said: “both partners will receive what is due to them, in a proportional way, each his share; as for what is of the remainder of the price of the franking which is as a surplus left by the slave, it will be divided between the two partners with equality. If the slave had not fully paid the whole sum, and the one who had refused to grant him a delay had received more than his partner of the sum in question, the price of the slave would be shared equally. between the two partners, and the sum already received by one of the partners is not to be reimbursed, because he only received it after consultation with his partner. On the other hand, if one of the two partners had remitted what he owes, and the other had received an additional sum, the latter owes nothing with regard to the former who, moreover, had only received what was due to him; as for the price of the slave, it is to be divided equally between the two. This case is to be compared to that where one has a debt which a single debtor must discharge to two men where one of them had granted him a delay, while the other had already partially recovered what is in his right, and the debtor is made bankrupt; so the creditor who had already received part of the debt, must not repay any sum to the other”. Chapter II Postage Price Guarantee 
(1531) 4 - Malek said: "what is unquestionably followed in Medina, when a group of slaves concludes a contract of collective emancipation, it is that each one can be guarantor of the others, and nothing of the price of their emancipation is to be given to the death of one of them, as long as their contract is collective. Thus, if one of them declares that he is unable to pay, his companions can assign him a job that he can accomplish according to his abilities, while maintaining their solidarity with him, so that he will be released once they are all released, or it will remain enslaved as long as they are". - Malek to continue: “what is followed with us (at Medina), concerning a slave concluding with his master, a contract of emancipation, it is that this master does not have the right to accept that another takes charge in his place, the guarantee concerning of his slave, whether he dies or becomes incapable of acquittal. Also, this is not the sunnah of Muslims, because if a third person guarantees the slave, and the latter is still unable to pay, even though the master has already recovered the amount of the contract of the guarantor, he would thus have had illicit money, namely that, on the one hand he did not buy the slave and what he will have paid as price will return to him, and on the other hand the slave will not have been set free from the illicit price of his postage. If the slave finds himself unable to pay his own price, it remains his master's propriety that the contract of freedom is not taken as a debt guaranteed by a third person, but rather considered an obligation which, once the slave fulfills it, will be set free. Else hand, if the contractual freedman dies, while having a debt to pay, the creditors will not have to claim what remains of the Kitaba of this slave, of his master, although they have on this subject, their primacy in relation to the master, Finally, if the contractual freedman finds himself unable to pay the debt he owes to people, he will remain a slave belonging to his master, and his debt will remain at its debit, without it being the right of the creditors to announce its price, which is, in fact, property due to its master". - Finally Malek said: “If a group of slaves concludes a collective franking contract, without having a family relationship between them which allows them to inherit one from the other, they will be considered in full defense of each other, and still guaranteeing each other mutually, they will all be freed only after having paid the amount of the contract. In the event that one of them dies, leaving to himself property, the value of which exceeds the sum which they all together owe, the sum which they owe is subtracted, and for what remains, it returns to the master. of the slave without the other slaves have nothing to do. Also, the master will claim from the slaves, the payment of what they owed, namely the sum which was subtracted from them of the goods left by the dead slave, for the good reason, that this one, had given them the price they had to pay, to be freed, and which was his own property. On the other hand, if the dead slave had a child who will have to be born after the freeing contract has been concluded, this child will inherit nothing from his father because the latter had not been freed before his death. dead". Chapter III Flat-rate contractual postage 
(1532) 5 - It was reported to Malek that Umm Salamah, the wife of the Prophet r (Upon him the mercy and peace of Allah) concluded with her slaves, franking contracts, by collecting their price in advance, both in silver and in gold”. - Malek said: “What is unquestionably followed about a contractual freedman, common to two masters, it is that it is not allowed for one of them, to free this slave, by asking a fixed price, without having had the consultation of his partner, as long as the slave in question as well as what he owns belong to both partners; therefore it is not tolerated that one of them seizes anything without having had the permit of the other. If one of them was going to act without having had the permitted by the other, and that it is done that the slave dies leaving his property, or that he is unable to pay his own price, the partner who had already freed the slave will have nothing of his property, therefore he will not have to return anything of what he already had. himself had, to his partner, and therefore he will have no right over this slave. But he who frees his slave for a fixed price, having had his partner's permit, then the slave finds himself unable to complete his freeing contract, the one who had him freed can, if he wants, return what he had already taken and will continue to enjoy his right on this slave, moreover, that is allowed to him. If the slave dies leaving property, the partner who had not yet freed him will have what is his right to what remains of the price of the postage, as for the rest of the goods, it will be divided between the two partners, according to the part which each has in this slave. In the event that one of the two partners has already received the fixed price of the slave, and that, on the other hand, the other maintains the contract, then that the slave is found incapable, one will say to the first: " If you want, you can give your partner half the price you already had received, and the slave is common to both of you, otherwise the slave is the possession of the one who still holds the contract on him". - About the slave owned by two partners, where one of them seeks to free him, for a lump sum while having had the permit of the other, who in turn asks for the same sum taken by the other or more, and that the slave se found incapable, Malek said, “The slave remains common to both, for the second has received what is his right; if he receives less than the sum received by the first and the slave finds himself incapable, so that the first accounts to render to the second half of the difference of the sum which he had already had provided that the slave is possessed of it equally between the two, this is permitted to him; in case he refuses it, the slave will remain in the possession of the second. In case the mukatab dies leaving property, and the partner who had already freed him, wants to return to the other half of this that he had obtained from more than him, in such a way that the inheritance of the goods of the slave, is shared with equality between the two, he can do it. If, the one who maintained the contract had, on his part, had the same sum as the first or even more, the inheritance will be proportionally distributed, suitably to the shares of possession as long as the second had only received what was due to him. - Concerning the moukatab, which belongs to two partners, and where one of them frees him by receiving half of what is his right, while having had his partner's permit, as for the other who still maintains the contract he receives less than the sum the first had already had, and the mukatab found himself unable to complete his freeing contract, Malek said, "If the partner, who had already freed the slave, is willing to return to the other half the difference, the slave belongs to them equally, and if he refuses to return to him, the one who maintains the contract, will have half of the share of his partner. Interpreting this, Malek says, "The slave being owned equally between them, and both of them had entered into a contract of emancipation with him for a certain sum, and then let one set the slave free while having permission on the other, thus receiving half of his share, which is a quarter of the real price of the slave, and that the latter is incapable of the acquittal, one The first partner will then say: "You can give back to your partner half of what you had received and the slave is owned equally by you both. If you refuse, whoever maintains the contract will be entitled at a quarter of the price and still his own half of the slave, which means that he will have in all three quarters of the slave, while the other will have had only a quarter, that he will have refused to return". - For the moukatab, who for wanting to be released, will go and conclude with his master a contract of emancipation, by prescribing a debt of what remains of the price of his release, and that he dies without having been discharged of this debt and owed debts to others, Malek said, “The master has no right to claim what is his right until the creditors have already received what is due to them and they will even have the primacy of enjoying it. On the other hand, the mukatab does not have the right to carry out such a contract, if he has a debt to pay to the people, thus becoming free while he owns nothing, because the creditors have more than the master of this slave, the right to claim their debt". So this is not tolerated for him. - Malek, finally said: "What we follow at home (in Medina), about a man, who makes with his slave, a contract of emancipation, thus stipulating a sum of gold by giving him a discount of the amount of the contract, if he pays him in advance, there is nothing wrong with that. However some have refused this kind of contract, because it is taken in the same way as a debt that a man owes to another, handing it over to him on condition that he pays it before the due date. Now, this fact is not actually a debt, but rather a lump sum, which the master asks in advance for emancipation, consequently the slave will have to enjoy the rights of inheritance, testimony and will even be subject to the prescribed penalties just like a free man. So it's not about buying cash for cash or gold against gold, but his case is like that where a man says to his slave: "Bring me such and such dinars, and you will be freed", and he discounts her that way.
