Or even that the man says: “If you bring me less than such, you will be released”, and there again, it is not a question of a well determined debt; for if the debt were such, and the slave died or made a deficit, the master would have the right to claim what is his ghost, the property of the slave, just as the creditors will do”. Chapter IV Injuries caused by a mukattab 
(1533) 6 - Malek said: “What I heard from better about a mukattab that hurts a person, is the following: “If the mukattab causes injury to a third person, in such a way that he is subject to the payment of compensation, if he is able to do so with his kitaba, let him do so while maintaining his kitaba; but if he is unable to do so, we do not consider his kitaba until he paid the price for his crime. If he still proves unable to do so, it is up to his master to choose: either he pays the compensation and keeps the mukattab still a slave, or he hands him over to the injured man, and he will not have not to act otherwise, that is, apart from these two cases”. In the event that a good number of mukattabs have concluded a collective contract, and that it happens that one of them causes an injury to a man where he has to pay compensation, Malek said: “all mukatabs are asked to pay this compensation; so, if they do, they will maintain their Kitaba, otherwise their master is granted the choice of either paying compensation for the injury and keeps, therefore, the mukatabs as slaves, or that he delivers the slave responsible for the injury, alone, independently of the other slaves he keeps and this, because they fail to pay the price of their companion's crime". - Malek said, "What is unquestionably followed with us (in Medina), in case a mukattab receives an injury deserving compensation, or even if one of the sons of the mukattab has suffered an injury and is included in the kittaba, the compensation which will be payable must be relative to the value of the slaves; thus, the compensation paid, is to be given to the master who keeps it until the end of the kitaba to be reduced by the last term of the kitaba”. - Interpreting this, Malek said: "It is assumed that the value of the kitaba is three thousand dirhams, and that the compensation corresponding to the wound of the mukattab is one thousand dirhams, if the mukattab gave his master two thousand dirhams, he would be released, even if he still had his kitaba, a thousand dirhams to pay. Thus, it will be released once this sum is given to the master. If the remaining value of the kitaba is less than one thousand dirhams, the master will receive what is his right and give the surplus to the mukattab. In any case, it is better not to give the mukattab the compensation for his injury which he can either spend or consume, especially since, once he finds himself unable to discharge his kitaba, he will remain a one-eyed slave, or amputated or deformed, as long as his master does not had entered into the kitaba with him only to have a share of what he earns and also his goods, and not to enslave his son, nor even to have the compensation for his injury which he will have either consumed or spent. So, just as we have shown, that compensation which is to be paid as a result of an injury caused to a mukattab or his children; born during the kitaba period and who are part of it, is to be given to the master who in turn will make a decrease in it, at the mukattab, just at the end of the last term of the kitaba”. Chapter V From the sale of the mukattab 
(1534) 7 - Malek said: “What was heard better, said about a man buying a mukatab from another, is that the latter did not sell it to him, if his kitaba was made against silver or gold, namely dirhams or dinars, unless the price was that of a commodity to be delivered as soon as possible, on the other hand if the price is to be delayed, it will be considered as a debt against a debt, but such a transaction had been prohibited". If, on the other hand, the subject of the kitaba was a commodity which is either camels or cows or sheep or slaves, it is tolerated for the buyer to buy the moukatab against gold, money or even of a different commodity in its nature from that of the kitaba made by the master, on condition of delivering it as soon as possible and without delaying it”. - Malek to continue: "The best I've heard about a moukatab subject to sale, it is to have to himself much more the right to his kitaba than another buyer, especially if the moukatab has all the power to be able to pay his master the price than the latter fixed him, that he might be set free; consequently, that the slave proceeds to his own purchase, it is already a certain way of freeing himself. Also, postage takes precedence over any other bequest. If this mukatab belongs to several partners, and it is made that one of them will sell his share of the mukatab, whether it is half or a third or a quarter or even one share among many others , the moukatab in this case does not enjoy the right of withdrawal, because this sale is considered to be a fixed price and he can only conclude it after having had the permit to his partners. Therefore, the share sold does not constitute something sacred to him, although the mukatab will not be able to enjoy his goods. Also, whether it is partially sold, this is a risk for the mukatab, because he may find himself incapable as he gradually loses his property, especially since this is not considered to be the purchase of a mukatab on his own unless his master who still having his right on him, does not authorize him, and thus, this moukatab will have more, the right, than any other to buy himself his sold share. - Malek again said: "The sale of one of the terms of a mukatab is illicit, because it is considered a sale random, especially if the mukatab finds himself unable to pay nothing is imposed on him; and if he dies or has a deficit and debts to pay to people, he who had bought himself the term in question will have no share like the other creditors, because having thus reacted by buying this term, he is considered just like the master of the moukatab who will not have to claim his kitaba like the creditors, and it is the same applies to the gain acquired by the moukatab who will go to the creditors without his master having the right to touch a penny”. “There is no harm, continues Malek, in a mukatab buying his own kitaba either from a flowing fund, or from a commodity quite different in nature to what has been the subject of the kitaba, or even that it is of the same nature if it is cash without any delay”. - Malek also said: "the moukatab who dies in leaving a wife, and small children, whether of that wife or another, in such a way that they cannot work, and about whom, they are likely to become incapable of s acquit of their kitaba, Malek underlines: "We will sell the woman-slave, mother of the children, if by her price we pay the kitaba of all the children whether she is their own mother or not, after which they will be freed, as long as their father would not have prevented the sale of the woman-slave, if he had the risk of not being able to pay her kitaba . So therefore, for such children where one fears not being able to discharge their kitaba, one will sell the mother, and one will use her price for the acquittal, but if there is one that her price does not is not enough for the payment of the value of the kitaba, and that it is with the children unable to work, they will all remain enslaved to their master”. - Malek finally said: "what is practiced in us (in Medina) about a man who buys the kitaba from a mukatab, and that the latter dies before his kitaba is completed, the man who bought the kitaba, has the right to 'inherit the mukatab; but if the moukatab finds himself incapable of acquittal with regard to the buyer, he will be his slave; on the other hand, if he pays of his kitaba, he will be freed by the buyer, without the latter even having any right to the patronage which belongs to the former master with whom he had concluded the kitaba”. Chapter VI The work of the mukatab 
(1535) 8 - It was reported to Malek that Urwa Ibn Al-Zoubair and Soulaiman Ibn Yassar were questioned about a man who concluded for himself and his sons, a contract of postage, then he dies, if his sons can work, so that they discharge of the value of this kitaba, or should they remain slaves? They replied, "Rather, they will have to work, so that they discharge it, and nothing will be returned to them (from the kitaba) at the death of their father”. - “And if they are so young, continues Malek, not even being able to bear the work, they will not be expected to be older, and they will remain slaves with their father's master, unless the moukatab - who is their father, by the way - has not left any what to fulfill the terms of the kitaba on them, expecting them to be able to work. So, if what is left is suitable for the discharge of their kitaba, one will use this, and they will remain such, until they are able to work if they discharge, they will be freed , otherwise they will remain enslaved”. - Malek further said, "The mukatab who dies, leaving not enough money for him to fulfill his kitaba, and that he still has children with their mother, who are subject of the kitaba, and where the mother intends to work to ensure their life, Malek must be told that she will be given the money if she proves herself able to keep it, and still able to work. But if she is neither, nothing will be given to her, and she remains with her sons, slaves of the master of the mukatab. - Malek finally said, "If several moukatabs conclude a single franking contract together, without their having a place of kinship between them which unites them, and that some are incapable of working, while the others are, until they discharge of the kitaba and are all freed, those who had worked claim from those who had not worked, what they had paid them, because some are the guarantors of the others". Chapter VII From postage of the moukatab in case he has paid what he owed before the fixed term. 
(1536) 9 - Malek reported that he heard Rabi'a Ibn Abi Abdul Rahman and others, tell about a moukatab which belonged to Al-Fourafissa Ibn Oumair al-Hanafi, propose to the latter who is his master, to pay him all he owes him from his kitaba, but Al-Fourafissa refused. Thus, the mukatab went to Marwan Ibn Al-Hakam, who was at that time, governor of Medina and told him his business; Marwan summoned al-Fourafissa and asked him to accept, but when the latter refused, Marwan ordered that the mukatab's money be taken and deposited in the public treasury, then told the mukatab: “Go ahead! you are freed, Al-Fourafissa seeing this, agreed to have the money». - Malek said: “What is followed at home (at Medina), about the moukatab is that he is tolerated to pay what he owes of his kitaba before the due date, and his master has no right to refuse him; also he will have to release the moukatab from any condition by allowing him to work and travel, as long as the emancipation of a slave is not complete if he is even partially enslaved by it, and therefore his social condition will not be not sacred, his testimony will not be considered nor will he have to inherit; also he will not enjoy other rights if he still has still paying part of his kitaba. As for his master, he will not have the right to impose work on him, after his emancipation”. - Malek finally said: “About the falling moukatab seriously ill, and therefore intends to pay all that he owes his terms to his master, with the aim that his free children inherit from him without them being subjects of the kitaba, Malek underlines, that this is permitted, for thus his social condition will be sacred, his testimony admitted, his declaration of debts to others accepted, and his will tolerated. Therefore, his master will not have to deny him, claiming to say, "he escaped me by paying the terms of his kitaba." Chapter VIII The succession of the moukatab in case he is freed 
(1537) 10 - It was reported to Malek that Sa'id Ibn Al-Musaiab, was questioned about a mukatab common to two masters where one of them had freed his share, following which the mukatab died leaving a good sum of money, which Sa'id said: “We will give the one who maintained the kitaba his share, and for the rest it will be shared equally between the two bosses”. - Malek said: “The moukatab, who completed his kitaba, then who is freed, will be inherited by the men who are closest to him and with whom he had concluded the contract of franking, the day the mukatab dies, whether the heirs are his children or close relatives. It is also, continues Malek, the case of any freed man, where his inheritance goes to those he is those closest to those who freed him, namely children or close relatives, on the day of the death of the mukatab, after he is freed, and therefore he is inherited by patronage”. - Malek finally said, “The brothers in the kitaba are taken in the same way as the children, in case they have all concluded a single contract of postage, and that it is made that neither of them has a child, subject included in the contract, or even born during the kitaba, or that he is subject of the kitaba then one of them dies by leaving money, one uses this money to pay the discharge of what is still due from the terms of the kitaba, and one sets them free. As for the rest of the money, it will go to his children independently of his brothers”. Chapter IX The conditions imposed on the mukatab 
(1538) 11 - About a man who concluded with his slave a kitaba, to be exchanged for gold or silver, by advancing him as a condition in the kitaba, to make a trip, or to perform a service or even to offer him an animal for sacrifice, seeking thereby, to cite everything clearly in the contract, since it is the fact that the moukatab was able to pay everything, to his terms even before the due date, Malek said, “If he has paid all of his terms, and submitted to the condition in question, he will be released and his social condition will be created. Then, we will discuss the condition who submits him to a service to be rendered or to a trip to be made, or other action similar to them, which he can, if need be, accomplish himself, and he is relieved of this charge, without his master has the right to compel him to pay it. As for the sacrifice or clothing or something similar, it will be taken in the same way as the dinars or the dirhams, where one seeks to evaluate it, so that the moukatab pays him with the terms of the contract; therefore, he will not be freed until he has paid everything». - Malek said: “what is followed at home (at Medina), and what is indisputable is that the mukatab is considered as a slave whom the master frees after having enslaved him for ten years. Gold; if the master who freed the slave is dead, before the latter has completed at home ten years of enslavement, what remains of this period, the slave will spend it in the service of the heirs of his master; as for his patronage, it belongs to him who freed him, as well as to his sons and his close relatives”. - Concerning the man who submits his mukatab to the condition of not traveling, nor marrying, nor leaving the country without having had his permission, and consequently if the mukatab does one or another before he had permission, and his kitaba was within reach of the man threatening to cancel it, Malek said, "This man has no right to cancel the kitaba, even if the moukatab had done what is against the condition in question; rather, this man will bring his accusation to the Sultan; thus, the mukatab will not have to marry, nor to travel, nor to leave the country without the permission of his master, whether this is an imposed condition or not, as long as the latter has to conclude a contract of franking with his slave for the value of one hundred dinars, while the moukatab has a nest egg of one thousand dinars or more; therefore, the slave will go and marry a woman, giving her a dowry whose value exceeds the whole sum in question, which will cause the incapacity of the mukatab; consequently, he will return to his master a penniless slave, or that he will travel, neglecting the terms of his kitaba, by his absence, which, in fact, he is not tolerated. For this reason, and according to the kitaba, the master has the full right either to authorize it or to refuse it”. Chapter X The patronage of the mukattab in case he is freed 
(1539) 12 - Malek said: “If the moukatab frees his slave, without having had the permission of his master, that is not permitted to him. But if the master of the mukatab allows it, the right of patronage of the freedman reverts to the mukatab (if he had paid his kitaba). On the other hand, if the mukatab dies, before he is freed, the right of patronage of the slave reverts to the master of the mukatab, and if the freed slave dies before the mukatab is freed, his master must inherit it”. - Malek to continue: “It is the same, if the moukatab concludes a kitaba with his slave who will be freed before the moukatab is freed by his master; thus patronage is the right of the master of the moukatab as long as he is not completely freed. But if he is freed, the patronage belongs to him, namely, that it is the right of the moukatab. If the first mukatab dies before he has paid what is due to him, or even if he is unable to do so, and he has free children, these will not inherit the right to the patronage of their father's mukatab, for the good reason that their father does not yet have the patronage in a sure and certain way, and then he will only have it if he is completely freed". - Malek also said: “The moukatab which is of belonging to two masters and where one of them neglects his share, as for the other he maintains it, then that the moukatab dies leaving money, Malek underlines: "We will give to the one who maintained the postage contract, which again is his right to the kitaba, then the two masters will share the money, as if the mukatab died as a slave, because the first by neglecting his share which he has in the slave, had not yet completely freed him, but he had simply left, what he owes her". - And Malek to say again: "What justifies what precedes, is that it is supposed that a man dies leaving a mukatab, and male and female children, then that one of them has freed his part which he has of the mukatab, this does not give him not allowed of patronage. But if it were a freeing, the patronage will be the right of those who have been freed, of his male and female children”. - Consider again, continues Malek, the case where one partners frees his share of the slave, then the slave becomes unable to pay the kitaba, one does not ask this partner what is left of the kitaba; however, if it was a postage, he should have been asked for it in order to assess the remaining part, and thus recover it from the property of this man, and this is in accordance with the words of the Apostle of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah): "Whoever frees a slave for his share, if he does not have the means to free him completely, thus estimating the price of the slave at his fair value, he will be partially freed". - A third case, presented by Malek, where he is says that: "The incontestably followed Sunnah is that he who frees his share of the slave, this freeing will not take into account his goods, because if he were such, he would have to enjoy, alone, the right of patronage, independently of the other partners. Also it is the sunnah of Muslims, that the right of patronage belongs to the one who concluded the kitaba, and not to those who inherit the master, from the women who had freed their shares from slavery, but rather it is the male heirs and close relatives among men who are entitled to patronage". Chapter XI Cases where postage of mukatabs is not permitted. 
(1540) 13 - Malek said: "If several mukatabs conclude together a single franking contract, their master does not have the right to free one of them, without having had the agreement and the approval of the others, even if they are young, although this agreement and this approval are not obligatory”. Interpreting this, Malek said, "It may be that one of them works in order to free his companions by paying them what they owe from the kitaba, the master will have to free him, which will cause for the others the inability to be able to act just like their companion. He releases the moukata for his own benefit, in their causing others harm. And the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said: "Not to respond to evil with evil,” and this is the hardest of evils.” - Finally Malek said: “In case the slaves conclude together a single kitaba, their master has to free among them the old and the young who can neither discharge nor that one of them has the help and the power to do so. The master then has the permission to do so”. Chapter XII Emancipation from the mukatab of the female slave known as “oum walad”. 
(1541) 14 - Concerning the man who with his slave, concludes a kitaba, then that this slave dies leaving the slave woman, mother of his child, while he still owes part of his kitaba, and the money which is sufficient to discharge it, Malek said, "This woman, mother of her child, still remains a slave when the mukatab is not completely freed until just upon his death, without even leaving children who would be freed once the kitaba had been discharged, thus the mother of their father's child would be freed, thanks to their freedom". - About the moukatab who frees his slave or gives alms of his money, without saying this to his master until he has been freed, and Malek emphasizes on this subject: “the mukatab must accomplish his deed without returning to it. However, if the master of the mukatab learns what is the actions of the latter, he can prevent the mukatab from doing so, because the master, enjoying the power of emancipation, may not free his slave as he can. prevent him from giving alms, unless he allows him to give it voluntarily". Chapter XIII The testament of the mukatab 
(1542) 15 - Malek said, "The best I have heard about the mukatab from which the master frees him, on his death, is as follows: the mukatab is valued, on that day, as if one wanted to sell it, and such would indeed be its real price. Thereby, if it is found that the value is less than what is left of his kitaba, this is subtracted from the third of his inheritance, without considering the amount of money he owes. This is explained, by the fact, that if he were killed, one would impose on his assassin only the payment of the price, valuing him, the day of his murder. On the other hand, if he had been injured, the one who had caused the injury to him will not pay for indemnity than the compensation as assessed on the day of the injury; and we will not consider anything of the value of the kitaba, whether in dinars or dirhams, because as long as he remains to pay of his kitaba, he is taken as a slave, even if the remaining sum is of a value which is less than its own value, and this is not to be subtracted from the third of the deceased's inheritance. Thus, he only has for sum what remains to him of his kitaba, as long as the dead man has made this remainder a simple legacy. - Interpreting this, Malek said, “if the value of the moukatab was one thousand dirhams, and that he only had to pay his kitaba one hundred dirhams, about which the master was going to make a bequest, this sum would be subtracted from him from the third of the inheritance and consequently he would be freed " . - Concerning a man who at his death, concludes with his slave, a kitaba, Malek said: "one will assess his price as a slave, and in case the third of the inheritance is suitable to cover a slave, this is tolerated". - Explaining this, Malek said: “Supposing the value of a slave is one thousand dinars, and that his master concludes, at his death, a kitaba of two hundred dinars, thus, the third of the money possessed by the master is one thousand dinars, this therefore is tolerated for him, because in fact it was a legacy he had made to her. If a master had made for other people a bequest, where it is shown that the third is only suitable for the value of the kitaba, one takes the initiative to the postage of the moukatab, who has the privilege of the legacies, which in turn will be part of the kitaba of the moukatab, so that the moukatab depends on the people to whom the bequest has been given, then we give to the heirs of the testator to choose: if they are willing to give these people their entire inheritance according to the bequest, and that they have the kitaba of the moukatab, they can do so, and if they refuse by delivering, by the very fact, the moukatab and what it owes, to people having right to inheritance, they can also act as such, as long as the moukatab constitutes one third of the inheritance. And because everyone has the right to make a bequest, and where the heirs say: "our testator made a bequest which is beyond one third, so he got what does not belong to him", the heirs will have to choose, and they will be told: “your testator has made the legacy that you already know; so if you want to put into execution, what is of the testator, do it, otherwise give to the legatees a third of the inheritance of the deceased”. - Malek to continue: “so, if the successors deliver the mukatab to the legatees, the latter will have from the moukatab what is due from his kitaba, and if this moukatab executes his kitaba for good, the legatees will have, according to their shares, the value of this kitaba, but if the moukatab is unable to pay, it will be slave of the legatees and not of the heirs, because they delivered him to others by asking them to opt in. Given that the legatees have shown themselves to be guarantors with regard to the mukatab as soon as it has been delivered to them, thus, if he dies, they will have nothing to claim from the heirs. By then, if the moukatab dies, before he pays his kitaba, thus leaving a sum of money which is worth more than that which he owed from his kitaba, this sum will revert to the legatees; and if the mukatab had acquitted himself perfectly, he would be freed, and his patronage would belong to the close relatives of the man with whom the kitaba was concluded”. - Concerning the moukatab, in front of his master the sum of ten thousand dirhams, and that on his death, he gives him a discount of a thousand dirhams, Malek said: “We evaluate the moukatab, in order to fix its price; thus if it is one thousand dirhams, what is already given is only the tenth of the kitaba which is one hundred dirhams, namely a value which is one tenth of the price; therefore he will be given a rebate of the tenth of the kitaba which will effectively be the tenth of the value, as if he had been given a rebate of all that he owes. If this will be accomplished by this way, the third of the money of the deceased will only be considered as suitable to the value of the moukatab which is one thousand dirhams. On the other hand, if he had been given a discount equivalent to half the kitaba, this is to be calculated in one third of the money of the deceased taken for half of the value; and if the discount made was less or more than half, the same method mentioned above is applied. - But, and Malek continues, if a man, upon his death gives his moukatab a discount of one thousand dirhams out of a total of ten thousand, without him quoting if it is done just at the beginning or at the end of his kitaba, we will make a discount of one tenth for each term". Malek said, "When a man at his death makes a delivery of one thousand dirhams to his moukatab without specifying whether it is to be made at the beginning or at the end of the kitaba which is three thousand dirhams, the evaluation of the moukatab will be made by correspondence to that of the money, then the 'we will distribute this discount over all the terms of the kitaba as follows: or calculate for each term its percentage of the discount, taking into account the period between your date of death of the man and that of the due date ; Where subtract this percentage from each term until total payment, namely that one must take into consideration the price of the moukatab as basis of the kitaba, spread over several terms. Once this operation is completed, we calculate the third of the estate of the deceased, if this remittance is equal to or less, the case is settled, if it turns out that it is higher, then we calculate the difference to recover it according to the above-mentioned method”. - About a man who bequeathed to another of a quarter of a mukatab, or even who freed a quarter of this mukatab; then the man dies, and after him the mukatab, but the latter left much more money than he should, Malek says: “One gives to the heirs of the possessor of the mukatab and to the legatee what is still due to them from the mukatab. As for the remaining sum, it will be shared, namely that the legatee will have a third of the sum once the kitaba has been completed; as for the heirs of the possessor, they will have two-thirds, because the moukatab remained slave of its owner as long as he owed the latter the acquittal of his kitaba and as a result, his owner inherits it, being considered a slave", Concerning the moukatab whose master freed him just at his death, Malek said: “If one-third of the property of the deceased is not sufficient for the kitaba to be paid in full, he will be partially freed from corresponding to one-third of the property, thus making a remission of the kitaba. For example, if the mukatab had to be paid for five thousand dirhams, and its value was two thousand, as for the third of the property of the deceased, it was only one thousand, half of the mukatab would be freed, and we would give back half of the kitaba". - About a man who in his will quotes: “Such a slave of my possession is free, and to conclude a kitaba with such another, Malek said: “one begins with the postage, by preference with the kitaba”. MOUATTAA In the name of Allah the Merciful the Merciful Book 40 The Book of "Mudabbar" Chapter 1 Sentences applied to the subject of the mudabbar (1) (1) The moudabbar is the slave who will be freed after the death of his owner”. 
(1543) 1 - Malek said: "What is followed in us (in Medina) concerning the one who frees a slave after her death, who, pregnant, gives birth to children from him after she has been freed, but who dies before her master, Malek emphasizes, that her children are taken in the same way as her, namely that they are subject to the same condition, without their mother's death causing them harm. So if he who freed the mother was death, they will in turn be freed if a third of the inheritance suffices as a price”. - Malek said: “So any female who gives birth children, these will be treated similarly to her, namely, if she is free and gives birth after being freed, her children will be free. In the event that she is subsequently freed, or is a moukataba, or is released after a few years, or is in the service of a man for a specified time, or is partially released, or is subject to 'a pawn, or mother of children, the child of any female will be in the same situation as her mother, namely, freed or enslaved, just as she is'. - Concerning a female slave, who pregnant, will be freed posthumously her child will experience the same situation; besides, she is just like the woman slave whose master will free her, unaware that she was pregnant”. Thus, it is from the sunna that the child in be of the same condition as his mother, namely, to be freed if she is". - It is the same, continues Malek, for the man who buys a pregnant slave woman, of whom he will be the possessor, whether he has asked the seller for it or not" "Besides, continues Malek, it is not tolerated for the seller to sell the slave woman, in excluding what is in his lap, as this is a sale which will devalue the price of the slave, without knowing whether the fetus is alive or dead. This case is similar to that of a man who sells what is in the bosom of his mother (a slave), and there again, this is not tolerated for him, because it is a random sale. -Concerning a moukatab or a moudabbar that can be bought a slave, and having had relations with her, becomes pregnant and then gives birth, Malek said: “the child of each of them, will be in the same condition as his father, namely whether he is freed or a slave. Thus, if the slave is freed, the mother of his child will be part of property he owns (mudabbar or moukattab), and therefore, it will be delivered to him, in case he is freed”. Chapter II Posthumous emancipation set chapter. 
(1544) 2 - About a mudabbar who said to his master: "Hurry up and free me, and I will give you fifty dinars, paid on time, to which the master replied: "Yes, you are freed, on condition that you give me fifty dinars where you will pay me every year , ten dinars”, and that the mudabbar accepts, after which the master dies, two or three days after this agreement”, Malek said: “His postage is proven, the fifty dinars are a debt, his testimony is accepted, his person sacred, his inheritance is a right, he is subject to the prescribed penalties (just like a free man), however the death of his master will not cause him a remission of the debt". - Concerning a man who frees by title posthumously a slave, after which this man dies, while having left some money which is available to him, and some which is not, without that what is available may suffice for the freeing of the mudabbar slave, Malek said, "The mudabbar is made to keep his money within reach, and what it can bring him pending determination of the amount of the master's money which was not available to him. So if one-third of the total money is enough for the emancipation of the slave, this one will be freed and will even have his money, in case the third was not enough, and from this fact, he will be partially freed suitably to the third, by making him keep his own money- Chapter III From the will made during a posthumous emancipation. 
(1545) 3 - Malek said: “What is followed with us (at Medina) in any emancipation effected by a man, which he cites in a will which he himself has made in the state of health or sickness, it is that this man can retain you, or even change it, as long as this does not consist of a posthumous emancipation, because if it is such, he does not have the right to retain it. - Malek to add: "And all the children born of a slave, fit to be freed by a will, without having been a posthumous freedwoman, these children will not be freed, once she is freed, as long as her master can if he wishes or change her will, or that he retains her, without the emancipation of this slave being certain, moreover her situation is similar to that of a man saying to his (female) slave: if such a person stays with me, until my death, she will be free”. Thus, if this slave lives in the expected condition, she will be freed, although her master, if he wishes, he can sell her with his children, because these have not had the same favor that was granted to their mother." - Malek to continue: "And postage in a testament is quite different from posthumous emancipation, which the sunna has clearly distinguished. Moreover, if the two were the same, any testator will no longer have the right to vary his will and what is quoted therein from the emancipation, thus retaining the property of the slave without the latter being able to benefit from it. . - About a man, who, in full health, had freed all his slaves posthumously, without his owning any other property, Malek said: "If he had freed some of them, one before the other, we start with the postage of the first, then so on until one reaches the third of these slaves. And if he had them, while being ill, all set free, saying: “Such will be free, then such, then such another, at the same time, in case where my illness hastens my death" or that he had freed them all posthumously, once and for all, they will enjoy a third of his inheritance, without one having priority over the other, for the good reason that it is about a will, and that they have the third of the inheritance to distribute between them equitably, the third of these slaves will be freed some is the number; and none of them will have the priority, if the man had freed them, while being ill". - Concerning a man who had released a mudabbar, after which the man dies, without having any property other than the slave-mudabbar, who has money for him, Malek said: "one third of the slave will be freed, by making him keep his money within his reach". - About a mudabbar whose master had entered into a kitaba for him, after which the latter dies, leaving only the mudabbar in question as his property, Malek said: "the mudabbar will be freed one-third, one-third of his kitaba will be returned to him, and will have to pay the last two-thirds of the sum foreseen". - Eventually Malek said, "For a man, who everything while being ill, had freed his slave, half or even had completely freed him, and had done the same, posthumously for another slave, before falling ill, Malek emphasizes: one takes charge first of the moudabbar before the one who was freed in the state of his illness, because the man can neither go back on his postage, nor retain his slave for any reason. Thus, if the mudabbar is freed, one calculates the remainder of the third of the goods left by the death, for the benefit of the other slave, who has already been half freed, until he is completely freed. But if the remainder of the third is not sufficient for such emancipation, the slave will be proportionally emancipated according to this remainder, after having emancipated the first mudabbar”. Chapter IV Of the cohabitation of a man with his slave whom he had freed posthumously. 
(1546) 4 - Nafe' reported that Abdallah Ibn Omar had made two of his female slaves mudabara (released posthumously) and he lived with them”. 
(1547) 5 - Yahia Ibn Sa'id reported that Sa'id Ibn Al-Musaiab said: “If the man posthumously frees his female slave, he can cohabit with her, without his having the right either to sell her or to give her away; her child also enjoys the same situation as her mother”. Chapter V On the subject of the sale of the mudabbar 
(1548) 6 - Malek said: “What is followed with us (in Medina), about the mudabbar is that its owner can neither sell it nor change its condition. In the event that the owner must a debt which he cannot manage to discharge, his creditors cannot sell him his mudabbar, as long as its possessor is still alive. But if the owner dies, without having a debt to pay, his mudabbar will profit from the third of the inheritance, being made that his possessor had enslaved him, as long as he was alive, and that the mudabbar did not had only to serve his master during his lifetime. Thus, this slave would be freed, without it being on behalf of the heirs, but rather of the whole inheritance, namely that he alone will have the third, and the heirs two-thirds. Now, if the possessor of the moudabbar dies, while leaving other property than the moudabbar, his third is to be freed, and his two-thirds will revert to the heirs. If the owner dies, having for debt what is worth the price of the mudabbar, one sells it to pay the debt, and the third of the mudabbar will be freed. On the other hand, if the debt is only suitable for half the price of the mudabbar, or sells this half to discharge the debt, then one frees the remaining third of the mudabbar, of the remaining value of the debt, namely, of the sixth”. - Malek also said, "It is not permitted, neither to sell the mudabbar nor anyone buy it, before this mudabbar has bought itself from its possessor, and this is permissible for him. He is the same with its possessor, and this is permitted to him. It is also tolerated that one gives money to the owner of the mudabbar, so that he is freed from it. And the right of patronage will always be granted to the master of the mudabbar”. - Malek to continue: "It is not allowed to sell the service of the mudabbar, because this is random, as long as he does not even know, until when his master will remain alive”. - As for the question of the slave, who, common to two men and where one of them freed his rightful share, posthumously, Malek said, “they must esteem the slave; thus if the one who had freed him bought him, the slave will be completely freed, otherwise, his liberation is invalid, except if the one who maintains his share of slavery, delivers him to his partner against a price, and then the one who had taken the initiative to free the slave, will totally free him posthumously. - Finally, about a Christian man, who had freed his slave, posthumously, after which the latter adopted Islam, Malek emphasizes: “The Christian is forbidden to enslave the slave, and he will be given a certain income in exchange; therefore the slave will not be sold until the decision is made by him in person. If the Christian dies, having a debt to pay, this will be subtracted from him from the price of the mudabbar, except if he had left property, which can cover the debt; thus, the mudabbar will be freed”. Chapter XI Injuries that the mudabbar causes to others. 
(1549) 7 - It was reported to Malek that Omar Ibn Abdul Aziz judging about a mudabbar which caused an injury, said: "It is up to its possessor to deliver it to the injured person who will put it to work, or put him at his service, imposing on him compensation for his wounds. Thus, if the mudabbar manages to pay, before its possessor dies, he returns home”. - Malek said: “What is followed at home (at Medina) about the mudabbar which caused an injury, after which his master dies without his having any other property, than the mudabbar in question is that he will be freed from a third, then the compensation will be divided into three parts, and will be paid as follows: the first third will be calculated from the freed third of the slave, as for the other two thirds, they will revert to the heirs who, if they wish, will give the injured their share against what is due to them from the slave, namely two-thirds, or else, they will give him two-thirds of the compensation, thus retaining their share of the slave, because the compensation for this injury belonged to the slave, and is not a debt due to the master. Thus, what had been committed by the slave will not invalidate what the master had already done, such as liberation and posthumous emancipation. If the master of the slave had a debt owed to people, and the slave had committed a crime, we will sell from the mudabbar a share corresponding to the compensation for the injury, and the value of the debt; then we will debit by the payment of the compensation subtracting it from the price of the mudabbar, which will follow the payment of the debt of the master; finally we will calculate what remains of the price in order to free the third of the slave, leaving the other two-thirds, a share to the heirs. Moreover, we will act in this way, because the offense committed by the slave has priority over the debt of the master, given that if the latter had died, in leaving a moudabbar slave whose value is one hundred and fifty dinars, and that the latter had caused a serious injury to a man, worth compensation valued at fifty dinars, Malek explains thus: "We will pay, first of all the fifty dinars, by way of compensation, which are to be subtracted from the price of the slave, then the debt of the master will be paid, and we will finally calculate what rest of the price of the slave so that his third is freed, as for the other two thirds, they will be the share of the successors. Thus, the slave's compensation is much more indebted than the debt of his master, and the debt in turn is in relation to the posthumous emancipation which in fact, is only a will related to the third of the goods left by the deceased. Therefore, we do not tolerate anything from pothumous postage, as long as the master who intends to execute it, has a debt which he has not discharged, especially since the postage is a legacy, about which Allah bless and Most High said (meaning): "...After his legacies or debts have been paid..." (Koran IV, 11). - And Malek to continue: "If it is only the third of the property left by the dead is sufficient for complete freedom from the mudabbar, he will be freed, and the compensation he owes will be a debt to him which he will discharge after he has been freed, even if it is the blood money of a victim and his master will owe no debt”. About the mudabbar which hurts a man which leads his master to hand him over to the wounded, after which the master dies with a debt to pay, and he leaves only the moudabbar as his property; and the heirs say, "We deliver it to the injured," and he to whom the debt is owed protests, saying, "What is owed to me is higher," Malek said, "If the creditor is owed a sum which is more than the value of the slave, he will have the precedence to enslave the slave, and there will then be a remission of the debt which is suitable to what has been added to the sum. But if the creditor has advanced no addition, he will not possess the slave”. - Finally concerning the moudabbar which has property and causes injury to a man, and the master refuses to pay compensation, the injured person, Malek said, will take money from as compensation for his injury, if the amount is adequate to cover it; once he has had his right to compensation for his injury, he must return the slave to his master. If the amount is not suitable, the injured will recover it from the money possessed by the slave, and he will make him work until he has a full payment of his compensation. Chapter VII The oumm walad (mother (slave) of the child) who hurts another. 
(1550) 8 - Malek said: "In case an oumm walad injures someone it is his master who has the duty to pay compensation, unless what he will have to pay exceeds the price of his slave; in this case, he will only pay his price, as long as the master of the male or female slave, delivering one of them so that he pays the compensation, nothing more is imposed on him, if the compensation has a value greater than the price of the slave. If the master of the umm walad cannot deliver it, in accordance with the sunnah, if he pays a compensation corresponding to its value, it is as if he delivered it, and nothing more is imposed on it". And, said Malek, that's what I have heard better, and the master will not have to take responsibility for the crime of his slave, if his value exceeds his price”. MOUATTAA In the name of Allah the Merciful the Merciful Book 41 The Book of Prescribed Punishments Chapter 1 Stoning 
(1551) 1 - Abdallah Ibn Omar reported: “Jews went to the Messenger of Allah r (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the mercy and peace of Allah) and told him that a Jew and a Jewess had committed adultery. The Envoy of Allah r (sallallahu alayhi wa salam) (Upon him be Allah's Grace and Peace) asked them, "What do you find about stoning in your Torah?" And they answer: "To stigmatize them and flagellate them". Abdallah Ibn Salam answered them: “You are lying; for your Torah mentions stoning”. They brought the Torah, and opening it, one of them hid with his hand the verse where the stoning is mentioned, then he read what precedes it and what follows it. Abdallah then said to him, "Push your hand", and the other doing so, the verse of stoning was found. So the Jews said: “It is true, O Muhammad, this verse exists there”. So the Messenger of Allah r (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) ordered the stoning of the accused”. - And Abdallah Ibn Omar continues: "I have saw the man bend over the woman to protect her from the stones". - And Malek explains: "The man leaned over the woman so that he alone received the stones." 
(1552) 2 - Sa'id Ibn Al Moussaiab reported: "A man from the Aslam tribe went to Abu Bakr al-Siddiq and said to him: “The evil man (implying his own person) has committed adultery; Abu Bakr asked him: “did you teach it to someone else”? “No, replied the other”, then Abu Bakr said to him: “Make your repentance to Allah, and do not reveal what Allah has hidden from you, for Allah accepts repentance from his servants”. But as the soul of this man was not appeased, he came to Omar Ibn Al-Khattab and took back from him what he had previously said to Abu Bakr; Omar speaking everything like Abu Bakr, and because the man has not yet been appeased, he went to the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (On Allah's grace and peace to him) and said to him: "The evil man has committed adultery"; and he did this three times Sa'id continued: "the Messenger of Allah r (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) inquired from the parents of this man, inquiring about him and asked, "Is he ill or a alienated”? They replied, “O Messenger of Allah! By Allah, he is safe and sound." The Messenger of Allah r (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him be Allah's Grace and Peace) again asked, "Is he single or married"? - "Married, they answered him". So the Messenger of Allah r (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) ordered that he be stoned”. 
(1553) 3 - Sa'id Ibn Al Musaiab reported that he was told that the Messenger of Allah r (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Be upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said to a man from the Aslam tribe, known as Hazzai: “O Hazzai, if you had covered him with your garment, it would be better for you” (i.e., it was better if the man had not told the Apostle of Allah r (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah), what he had committed as an offence). Yahia Ibn Sa'id who reported this hadith, also said: "This hadith was told in an assembly where Yazid Ibn Nu'aim Ibn Hazzai Al-Aslami was, he said: "Hazai is my grandfather, and this hadith is true". 
(1554) 4 - Ibn Chehab reported that a man confessed to having committed adultery, at the time of the Messenger of Allah r (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Be upon him the grace and peace of Allah) by making his own testimony four times. The Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) ordered that this man be stoned”. Ibn Chehab said: "Such is the cause for which the prescribed penalty is applied to a man who has confessed to his crime”. 
(1555) 5 - Abdallah Ibn Abi Moulaika reported that a woman came to the Messenger of Allah r (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) telling him that she had committed adultery while she was pregnant. So, the Messenger of Allah r (sallallahu alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said to him: "Go away, until you give birth"; once she gave birth she returned to the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him be grace and peace of Allah) who said to him: "Go home and nurse your little one"; the breastfeeding period being over, the woman returned to the Apostle of Allah r (sallallahu alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) who said to him: "return home, and entrust your child to a third person", the reporter says that the woman having done so, returned again to the Messenger of Allah r (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) who ordered her to be stoned”. 
(1556) 6 - Abu Houraira and Zaid Ibn Khaled Al-Jouhani reported that two men took their disputes to the Messenger of Allah r (sallallahu alayhi wa salam) (Upon him be Allah's Grace and Peace) and one of them said: "O Messenger of Allah, judge between us according to the Book of Allah", and the other, who did not lack eloquence, said in turn: "Certainly yes, O Messenger of Allah, judge between us, according to the Book of Allah, but first allow me to speak". He says to him: “speak”. And the man resumed: "my son was employed by this man, and committed adultery with his wife. So he told me that my son is to be stoned; I bought it against a hundred sheep and a slave girl that I owned, then I asked, about it, the men versed in religion, who taught me that my son must be whipped for a hundred times and exiled for a year, and it is the woman alone who was to be stoned”. The Messenger of Allah (sallallahu alayhi wa salam) (Upon him be Allah's Grace and Peace) said, “By him who holds my soul in His hand, I will judge your case according to the Book of Allah; as for your sheep and your slave, you will take them back”, then he ordered that the son be flogged for a hundred times, and exiled for one year, the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the mercy and peace of Allah) ordered Ounais Al-Aslami, to go to the wife of the other, who confessed that she had committed adultery, and she was stoned. 
(1557) 7 - Abu Huraira reported that Sa'id Ibn Ubada said to the Messenger of Allah r (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him be Allah's grace and peace): "What shall I do if I find a man with my wife; should I leave it, so that I can find four witnesses”? “Yes, replied the Messenger of Allah r (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah). 
(1558) 8 - Abdallah Ibn Abbas reported that he heard Omar Ibn Al-Khattab say: "Stoning is, in The Book of Allah, a penalty to which are subject, men and women who have committed adultery, if they are married, especially if, on this subject there is evidence, or a pregnancy or even a confession made". 
(1559) 9 - Abu Waquid Al-Laithi reported that a man came to find Omar Ibn Al-Khattab, who was in Cham (Syria), and told him that he had found a man with his wife. Omar Ibn Al-Khattab on his behalf sent Abu Waqid Al-Laithi to the woman to ask her about it. He was at her house, while certain women were there, and he told her what her husband had told Omar. Afterwards he informed her that she would not judge on the only her husband's words and suggested denying her husband's statements, so that she would not confess her offence. As the woman refused, and confessed her offence, Omar ordered her to be stoned”. 
(1560) 10 - Yahia Ibn Sa'id reported that he has heard Sa'id Ibn Al Moussaiab say: "Returning from Mina, Omar Ibn Al-Khattab stopped at Al-Abtah, piled up stones, which he covered with his garment and lay down, then lifted up his hands to heaven and said: “Great Allah! I have already grown old, my strength has weakened, my subjects have spread everywhere. Collect my soul without my being subject to disobedience or neglect of divine orders. Returning to Medina, he preached to the people saying: “Men! You have been given a Sunnah, and prescribed obligations, and everything is clarified to you, so don't mislead people”. Then clapping one hand over the other, he said: "Take heed that you do not lose yourselves by neglecting the verse concerning stoning, and let one say: “We do not find in The Book of Allah a crime which is subject to two penalties. And the Messenger of Allah r (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) ordered the stoning and we did the same. By him who holds my soul in his hand, if I was not afraid that people would say: "Umar added a verse to the Book of Allah", I would have dictated it, namely: "Stone the man to death. and the middle-aged woman", because this verse, we had recited it". - Sa'id Ibn Al-Musaiab reported: and Zul-Hijja did not end until Omar was killed, may Allah be merciful to him”. - Yahia reported that he heard Malek say, "We implied by the woman and the mature man, those who are married. Having committed adultery, they are to be stoned”. - Note: to emphasize that the above verse is not quoted in The Book of Allah; but according to men versed in religion, he has been revealed and then repealed”. 
(1561) 11 - It was reported to Malek that a woman had gave birth after six months and was brought to Osman Ibn Affan, he ordered that she be stoned. But Ali Ibn Abi Taleb said to him: "We must not submit to the prescribed penalties, for Allah Blessed and Most High has said (meaning): "Since the time she conceived it until the time of its weaning, thirty months have elapsed" (Koran XLVI verse 15), and (the meaning) "Mothers who want to give their children full breastfeeding, will breastfeed them for two full years" (Qur'an II verse 233). Thus the pregnancy, being six months, is not to be stoned. Osman went in search of the woman, and found that she had been stoned”. (...) 12 - Malek asked Ibn Chehab about the one who did the sodomy? He replied, "He must be stoned, whether he is married or single." Chapter II One who confesses to having committed adultery. 
(1562) 13 - Zaid Ibn Aslam reported, that in the time of the Messenger of Allah r (sallallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) a man confessed to having committed adultery.The Apostle of Allah r (sallallahu alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) asked that a whip be brought to him. A broken whip was brought to him, he said, "Let the whip be longer." Thus, or brought him a new whip which had the ends still hard». “Another less hard than this, said the Messenger of Allah r (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah). A suitable whip was brought to him, he ordered the man to be whipped, then he said, “Men! It is already time for you to observe the punishments prescribed by Allah. Let him who commits such a despicable crime, let him hide himself by the veil of Allah. And whoever so whoever lets us know he has it committed, we will punish him according to the Book of Allah”. 
(1563) 14 - Nafe' reported that Safia Bint Abi Oubaid told him that a man who had committed adultery with a woman, and she became pregnant, was brought to Abu Bakr Al-Siddiq. She confessed to having committed adultery, and not being married, Abu Bakr ordered that the man be subjected to the prescribed punishment, then exiled him to Fadak”. - Concerning one who confesses to having committed adultery, then reconsiders his statements, saying: "I did not committed, but I thought I had done such a thing, which he quotes", Malek said: "We accept his reaction, and we do not subject him to the prescribed penalty, because the penalty is not to be applied that in two cases or that a proof is obvious, and condemns by the same fact its author, or that a confession is made, and one then subjects it to the prescribed sorrow”. - Malek said, "What has come down from men versed in religion, it is that slaves are no longer to be exiled, in case they have committed adultery". Chapter III The Appropriate Punishment for Adultery in General 
(1564) 15 - Abu Houraira and Zaid Ibn Khaled Al-Jouhani reported that: Asked about a slave who committed adultery, without being married, the Messenger of Allah r (sallallahu alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) replied: "She has committed adultery, flog her, flog her, flog her, then sell her even for a rope. And on this subject, Ibn Chehab underlines: "I do not know if she should be sold after being flogged for three or four times". 
(1565) 16 - Nafe reported that a slave, who was had been charged with watching over the captives forming one-fifth of the booty, had cohabited, in spite of herself, with one of these captives. Omar Ibn Al-Khattab flogged him and exiled him, without doing so with regard to the slave, who was coerced”. 
(1566) 17 - Soulaiman Ibn Yassar reported that Abdallah Ibn Ayyach Ibn Abi Rabi'a Al Makhzoumi said: "Omar Ibn Al-Khattab ordered us, young Quraishites and me, to whip slaves of the province of Islqm, for hundred lashes, having committed adultery”. Chapter IV About the raped woman - Malek said: “What is followed at home (at Medina) about the woman who is pregnant; without her being married, and saying. "I was forced" or even: "I was married", that this is not taken into consideration, and that she is to submit to the prescribed sentence unless she has evidence evidence justifying that she was married or that she was forced, or that she arrives bleeding if she is a virgin, or even that she asks for help until she receives help during this rape". Thus, adds Malek: "If she has no proof, she is to submit to the prescribed sentence and we do not accept to take into account her statements". Malek said: "And the raped woman cannot marry only after having had three periods (thereby ensuring that she is not pregnant). And if during her period, she suspects that she is pregnant, she cannot marry until she has freed herself from this doubt”. Chapter V Libel, accusation of bastardy, and insinuations thereon. 
(1567) 18 - Abu al-Zinad reported: “Omar Ibn Al-Khattab, whipped a slave for eighty lashes, for defamation”. Abu Al-Zinad added: “I asked Abdallah Ibn Amer on this subject who answered me: “I lived in the time of Omar Ibn Al-Khattab, Osman Ibn Affan, and other caliphs, and I do not I saw none of them, whipping a slave, for a defamation, beyond forty blows”. 
(1568) 19 - Zuraiq Ibn Hakim Al-Aili a reported that a man known as Misbah asked to be rescued by one of his sons. Since the latter arrived late, his father said to him: "O fornicator!" Zouraiq continued: "The son asked that I support him, and wanted to whip the father, then the son cried out, “By Allah! If you are going to whip him, I will confess to having committed adultery”; Now, when I said this to myself, I was embarrassed, and I wrote to Omar Ibn Abdul Aziz, who at that time was governor, telling him about this subject. Omar replied: “To forgive the father”. “I wrote, continue Zouraiq, again to Omar Ibn Abdul Aziz, saying to him: "What do you say about a man who has been defamed or whose father and mother have been defamed when both are dead or the one of them is alive” Omar answered me in writing: “If the one who is defamed forgives the other for his defamation, may his forgiveness be accepted; but for his relatives, dead, or one of them living, and who have been defamed, apply the penalty prescribed by the Book of Allah (namely eighty lashes), unless the defamed does not want to conceal himself”. - Malek said: “It is due to the fact that the defamed runs the risk of being as he has been accused, and that evident proofs are put forward on his subject. But if his case is such, he is forgiven, and even his forgiveness is acceptable”. 
(1569) 20 - Hisham Ibn Ourwa reported that his father said: "If a man defames a crowd of people, only one sentence is applied to him". And Malek, on this subject, adds: “If they separate from each other, only one sentence is applied”. (...) 21 - Malek reported: “Abu Al-Rijal Muhammad Ibn Abdul Rahman Ibn Haritha Ibn Al Nou'man Al-Ansari, then of the Al-Najjar tribe, reported from his mother Amra Bint Abdul Rahman, whom two men cursed each other in the time of Omar Ibn Al-Khattab and where one of them said to the other: “By Allah, my father was not a fornicator, nor nor my mother”. Asking Omar, to advise her, on this subject, a man exclaimed: "He only gave praise to his father and mother". Others replied, "He could return them in another way, so we find that he must be scourged." So Omar applied to him the prescribed penalty of eighty lashes". - And Malek adds: “The penalty prescribed is not to apply only for an accusation of bastardy, or defamation or an insinuation the author of which intends by the latter only an accusation of bastardy or defamation; thus the prescribed penalty must certainly be applied to him”. - Eventually Malek said, “What is followed at us (in Medina), about a man accusing another of being a bastard, it is to have to apply the penalty to him even if the mother of the defamed was a slave”. Chapter VI Cases where the penalty is not applied (1570) - Malek said, "The best I've heard about a slave girl whom a man had cohabited, while he is partial owner of her, that he will not be subject to the prescribed penalty; however the child will be assigned to her, and the slave will be valued the day she became pregnant; thus, one will give his partners their share, and the slave will be his belonging. This is what is followed with us (in Medina)”. - Concerning the man who allows another to live with his slave, Malek said: "If he had intercourse with her, the price of this slave will be assessed, the very day he touched her, pregnant or not, and thus he escapes the prescribed penalty. However, if she is pregnant, the child will be attributed to the man”. - Malek finally said about the man who had cohabited with the slave of his son or daughter, that he will not have not to suffer the prescribed penalty; but the slave will be valued, pregnant or not, so that he pays his price”. 
(1571) 22 - Rabi'a Ibn Abdul Rahman reported that a man had traveled in the company of a slave (female) of his wife and that he had had sexual intercourse with her. His wife showed up jealous, and told Omar her case, who asked the man for an explanation. The latter replied: "My wife gave me a gift"; Omar resumed: “Provide obvious proof, otherwise I will stone you”; thus the woman confessed that indeed, she had given it to him". Chapter VII That which is subject to the cutting of the hand. 
(1572) 23 - Abdallah Ibn Umar reported that the Messenger of Allah r (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) ordered the amputation of the hand, for the theft of a shield, the price of which is three dirhams”. 
(1573) 24 - Abdallah Ibn Abdul Rahman Ibn Abi Hussein al-Makki reported that the Messenger of Allah r (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said: "One does not cut off the hand of a man who has stolen fruit still on the tree, or an animal lost in a mountain; but in case the animal is at the retable, or the fruits are there where they are dried, the cutting of the hand is required if the value of the stolen object is the price of a shield”. 
(1574) 25 - Amra Bint Abdul Rahman reported that a thief, in the time of Osman Ibn Affan, stole a citron. Osman demanded that we assess his price, and it was valued at three dirhams, and we exchanged one dinar for twelve dirhams, he ordered that the thief's hand be cut off". 
(1575) 26 - Amra Bint Abdul-Rahman reported that Aisha the wife of the Prophet r (Upon him be Allah's Grace and Peace) said: “Not so long ago of that that I forget, that one cuts off the hand of a thief, if the stolen object is of a price of a quarter of dirhams or more”. 
(1576) 27 - Amra Bint Abdul Rahman reported the following: "Aisha, the wife of the Prophet (Be upon him be peace and of Allah) left for Mecca in the company of two of his freedwomen and a servant belonging to the family of Abdallah Ibn Abi Bakr. She sent with the two freedwomen a cloak, on which was sewn a piece of green cloth. Amra continued and said, “Then the servant took the cloak, unstitched it and put in place of the green patch, wool and hair and then sewed it with new. Once the two freedwomen arrived in Medina, they returned the coat to its owner, who unstitching it, found wool and hair instead of green fabric. The two freedwomen were questioned about this, and they reported it in writing to Aisha, the wife of the Prophet (upon him be Allah's grace and peace) and accused the servant. The latter questioned, confessed his crime, Aicha, the wife of the Prophet (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) ordered to cut off his hand and said: "We cut the hand of the thief, in case the price of the stolen object is a quarter of a dinar or more. - Malek said: “My favorite thing is that the hand is cut, in case the stolen object is of the price of three dirhams, even if the exchange price undergoes an increase or a decrease, therefore, the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) had ordered that the hand be cut off in case the shield is of a price of three dirhams. As for Osman Ibn Affan, he also demanded it for a citron whose price is three dirhams”. That's the best I've heard about it." Chapter VIII The cutting of the hand of the maroon slave and the thief 
(1577) 28 - Nafe' reported that a maroon slave belonging to Abdul-lah Ibn Umar, had stolen. Abdallah sent him to Sa'id ibn Al'As, who was then governor in Medina, to cut off his hand. Sa'id refused to do so and said, "The maroon slave's hand should not be cut off if he steals"; Abdallah Ibn Umar asked him: "In which passage of the Book of Allah, did you find this decision"? Thus, Abdallah Ibn Omar, ordered to bring the slave and cut off his hand”. 
(1578) 29 - Malek reported that Zuraiq Ibn Hakim told him that he retained a maroon slave, while stealing. He pursues: "being embarrassed about him, I write to Omar Ibn Abdul Aziz, to get his opinion, was he that time governor, telling him that I have heard that one does not have to cut off the hand of a maroon slave, if he steals. Omar Ibn Abdul Aziz, replied to me in writing, where he quotes his completely opposite opinion, saying: "You made me learn in writing, that you heard it said, not to have to cut off the hand of a maroon slave s 'he steals. However Allah Blessed and Most High has said in His Book (meaning): “Cut off the hand of the thief and the thief: it will be a retribution for what they have done and a punishment from Allah. Allah is mighty and just" (Qur'an Surah V, verse 38). Thus, if what is stolen by the maroon slave is of a price of a quarter of a dinar and more, to cut off his hand”. (...) 30 - It was reported to Malek that al-Kassem Ibn Muhammad, Salem Ibn Abdallah and Ourwa Ibn Al-Zoubair said: "If a maroon slave steals what deserves to have his hand cut off, cut it off." - And Malek to add: "such is what is indisputable following with us (in Medina), namely, that if what a maroon slave steals is of a price requiring his hand to be cut off, it is cut off”. Chapter IX No intercession about a thief if the case is already with the Sultan 
(1579) 31 - Safwan Ibn Abdallah Ibn Safwan a reported that Safwan Ibn Oumayya was told: “He who has not made the hijrah is in trouble”. So Safwan Ibn Omayya came to Medina, and lay down in the mosque, resting his head on his robe. A thief came and, and took his garment, he was stopped by Safwan who brought him to the Messenger of Allah r (salallahou alayhi wa salam) Upon him the grace and peace of Allah who asked him: "Have you stolen this man's garment"? He replied with a yes, the Messenger of Allah r (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Be upon him the grace and peace of Allah) ordered to cut off his hand. So Safwan said to the Messenger of Allah r (sallallahu alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah): “I did not want the matter to be such; this garment is an alms to him”. The Messenger of Allah r (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) replied: "Why did you not decide to do it, before you came to my house"?. 
(1580) 32 - Al Zoubair Ibn Al-Awam reported that he met a man who was holding a thief, and wanted to go to the Sultan. Al Zoubair interceded about the thief, for the thief to be released, “No, not before I go to the Sultan,” the man replied. Al zoubair said to him: "Once you are with the Sultan, Allah will curse the intercessor and the one who accepts intercession”. Chapter X General section qu subject of the hand . 
(1581) 33 - Abdul Rahman Ibn Al Kassem reported according to his father that a man from Yemen arrived, having his hand and foot amputated, and went down to Abu Bakr Al Siddiq, and accused the governor of Yemen who judged him unjustly. This man spent the night praying when Abu Bakr said to himself: “By (the Lord) of your father, I find that a a man who spends the night like this is not a thief”. Later, if realizing that a necklace belonging to Asma Bint Oumaiss, wife of Abou Bakr Al Siddiq, was lost, the man with the family of Abou Bakr, began to seek him, saying: “Great Allah! It's up to you to punish the one who came rob this virtuous house (implying that of Abu Bakr)”. The necklace was found at a jeweler who admitted that the amputee had sold it to him. The amputated man confessed his theft, or even testimony was brought against him. So Abu Bakr ordered his left hand to be cut off, saying, “By Allah! his invocation against himself was to me more painful than his flight. - Malek said: “What is followed in Medina about of the one who does not stop stealing and against whom one asks for help, what one has only to cut off his hand, for all that he had stolen, if one had not yet applied the prescribed penalty. Now, if this sentence has been applied, and then he steals what requires that his hand be cut off, we must do it again for another member”. 
(1582) 34 - Malek reported that Abu Al Zinad told him told that a prefect of Omar Ibn Abdul Aziz had retained men, without them having killed anyone (but for stealing). He wanted or cut off their hands or kill them; so he learned this in writing from Omar Ibn Abdul Aziz who answered him: "You will have to choose the lightest sentence to punish them". - Malek said: “what is followed at home (at Medina) about the one who steals what people have displayed in the market, and whose owners have well kept and collected objects, one must cut off his hand if the stolen object is of a price which requires that the cut be made and whether it is done day or night, whether the owner is present with his objects or not". - About the one who steals what demands cutting of the hand, then that one finds on him the stolen object, and that one returns it to its owner, one always cuts off his hand" says Malek and continuing, he says: "If one disputes that in saying: “How to cut off his hand, and the stolen object has already been returned to its owner? “In fact, his case is like that of a drunkard who smells of wine without being drunk with it; thus one subjects it to the prescribed sorrow, answered Malek”. Thus, therefore, the drunkard is subject to the prescribed penalty who even if he drinks without becoming drunk, because he drank it only to be drunk. Likewise, the thief's hand is cut off for the object he has stolen even if he has not used it, and that it be returned to its owner; thus, the steering wheel, it intended to keep it. - Concerning the group of people who enter a house and steal it, then all go out, carrying together what they have found, namely, either a crate, or a stretcher, or a basket or the like, which they bring out of their place where they are kept, and that the price of the stolen object requires submission to the prescribed penalty, because it is three dirhams, their hands must be cut off”. If each of them comes out with an object on him whose price is three dirhams or more, his hand will be cut off. As for the one, who steals an object of less than three dirhams, he will not have his hand cut off”. - And Malek to continue: “What is followed at us (in Medina) in case a man has a house where he lives alone, and it is closed, it is because we do not cut off the hand of the thief if he steals anything from this house until after he has taken it out. Corn in case the house has several inhabitants, and each one closes his own door, the thief who steals something from this house, by taking it out, will have his hand cut off, because he has caused it to be moved from a guarded place to another who is also guarded; so we have to cut off his hand”. - Malek to continue: “What is followed at home (at Medina), when a slave steals his master's belongings, and he is neither one of his servants nor one of those entrusted to guard the dwelling, but who in secret has stolen what requires, cut off his hand, or don't cut it off. It is the same for a slave, who steals the effects of her master: "As for the slave, who is neither servants, nor of those to whom one has entrusted to keep the house, and who steals the effects of his master's wife, which requires cutting off his hand, cutting off his hand". Similarly if it is the slave of a wife, in case she is neither one of her servants, nor one of her husband, nor yet of those to whom the house has been entrusted, and she enters clandestinely, stealing the effects of the wife of his master, his hand is not cut off if the stolen object is of a value requiring that be done”. Such is also the case of the slave of a woman who is not one of her servants nor of those to whom the residence is entrusted, who enters clandestinely and steals her mistress's effects, the value of which requires cutting, one does not don't cut off his hand." - Malek to add: the same for the man who steals the belongings of his wife, or that the wife steals the belongings of her husband, which requires their hands to be cut off, in case each of them has stolen the belongings of the other, from a house which is other than the one where they live, their hand is cut off if the stolen object is of a value that requires it to be done". - Malek to say again: "In case we steal, at a small child and mute, their effects, or what is in their houses, they cut off the hand of the one who committed the theft. But if the child and the mute are outside their house, and they are stolen, one does not cut off the hand of the one who stole them. Besides, their case is similar to that of the fruits which are still on the tree or even of the herds lost in the mountains”. - Malek finally said, "What is followed at Medina, about the one who digs up the corpses, is to cut off his hand in case the stolen object is of a value requiring this penalty”. Because, explains Malek: "The tomb is a sacred place just like the house, and where the penalty is only applied once the digger has brought out stolen objects from the tomb". Chapter XI Which does not require the cutting of the hand. 
(1583) 35 - Muhammad Ibn Yahia Ibn Habban reported that a slave stole a small palm tree from a garden belonging to a man, and planted it in his master's garden. The owner of this palm went out looking for his palm; the finding, he accused the slave to Marwan Ibn Al-Hakam who put him in prison, also wanting to cut off his hand. Immediately the master of the slave went in search of Rafé Ibn Khadij; asked him about it, he said that he heard the Apostle of Allah r (sallallahu alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) say: "One does not cut off the hand of him who steals fruit from the tree, nor plans of palm tree". So the man said to Rafé: “Marwan Ibn Al Hakkam has retained one of my slaves and intends to cut off his hand; I want you to come with me to tell him what you heard from the Messenger of Allah r (sallallahu alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah). Rafé accompanies him to Marwan and asks him "Have you retained a slave who belongs to this man"? - "Yes, answered Marwan"; Rafé went on: "What do you want to do with him"? “Cut off his hand”; Rafe cried, "I heard the Messenger of Allah r (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) say: "One does not cut off the hand of the one who steals fruit from the tree, nor palm tree plans". Marwan thus ordered that the man be released. slave". 
(1584) 36 - Al-Saib Ibn Yazid reported that Abdallah Ibn Amr Al-Hadrami, brought to Omar Ibn Al-Khattab, his slave, and said, "Cut off my slave's hand, for he has stolen." Omar asks him: what did he steal”? The other replied: “A mirror of my wife, the price of which is sixty dirhams”. Omar then said, “Leave him; he do not apply the cut to it, because your slave has stolen an object from your effects”.
