(1585) 37 - Ibn Chehab reported that Marwan Ibn Al Hakkam received a man who had stolen effects. Wanting to cut off his hand, he sent someone to Zaid Ibn Thabet to question him about it. Zaid Ibn Thabet replied, "A stolen object does not require the hand to be severed." 
(1586) 38 - Yahia Ibn Sa'id narrated that Abu Bakr Ibn Muhammad Ibn amr Ibn Hazm related to him that he arrested a Nabataean who stole iron rings. He held him back, so that he would cut off the hand. Amra Bint Abdul Rahman sent him his slave called Umayya. Abu Bakr continued: “She came to my house, while I was among the men, and said to me: “Your maternal aunt Amra reports to you the following: “son of my sister! I was informed that you detained a Nabataean for stealing something of little value, and you intended to cut him off. the hand"? - "Yes, I answered". “Amra, continue the slave - says to you: "One does not cut off the thief's hand only to have stolen an object whose price is a quarter of a dinar or more”. Abu Bakr then said, "I have freed the Nabataean." - Malek said: “what is followed with us in Medina concerning the confession of slaves, in case one of them confesses his offence, it is that he is to submit to the prescribed penalty and to the corporal sanction. For his confession is tolerated to him, and one does not not accuse him of having personally compromised himself to this sentence". “But, continues Malek, if one of them confesses his offense in such a way that the indemnity goes to his master, we cannot tolerate that his confession harms his master”. - Malek further said, “If an employee or other put in the service of people steal, the penalty is not applied to them, because their case is not that of a thief, but rather of a traitor and the traitor is not subject to the cutting of the hand”. - Also Malek said, "he who borrows 'an aria' (namely an object that is used and then returned) and that he denies it, will not have his hand cut off. For his case is like one who owes a debt to another and he denies it; but the denial does not require the cut”. - Malek to add: "What is followed in Medina, in about a thief who is in a house, where he has assembled the effects, but where he has not yet left, it is because he is not subject to the penalty of the cut . For his case is like that of a man who had wine to drink in his hand; but not having drunk it, he is not subject to the prescribed penalty. Also, his case is similar to that of a man who finds himself seated with a woman, and who wishes to cohabit her in an illicit manner; however, not having done so, he is not subject to the prescribed penalty. - Finally Malek said: “what is followed at Medina is that stealing by stealth does not require the cutting of the hand, whether or not the stolen object is of a value that requires it”. MOUATTAA In the name of Allah the Merciful the Merciful Book 42 The book of drinks Chapter 1 The punishment prescribed for drinking wine. 
(1587) 1 - Ibn Chehab reported that Al-Saib Ibn Yazid told him that Omar Ibn Al-Khattab had come out, telling them: "As I found that such and such smelled of wine, and claimed that it was rather the smell of a broth; I ask you what he drank; but if it is a drink that gets drunk, I will whip it”. But being such, Omar whipped him." 
(1588) 2 - Thawr Ibn Zaid al-Daili reported that Omar Ibn Al-Khattab consulted men about who drinks wine (wanting to know what punishment to prescribe). Ali Ibn Abi Taleb said to him: “I find that he should be whipped eighty times, since if he drinks he will be drunk; when drunk he will wander; and then he will lie and defame”. Thus Omar applied the penalty of eighty lashes to the wine drinker. 
(1589) 3 - Malek reported that Ibn was asked Chehab on the prescribed penalty to which a slave is subjected, drinking wine. He replied, "I have been told that he is subject to the prescribed half sentence, in comparison to the free man who is completely subject to it". Also Omar Ibn Al-Khattab, Osman Ibn Affan and Abdallah Ibn Omar, had flogged their slaves who drank the wine, with forty lashes, namely, half a penalty”. 
(1590) 4 - Yahia Ibn Sa'id reported that he has heard Sa'id Ibn Al Mus-saiab say: "Allah likes to forgive all sins, except for what is subject to the prescribed penalty". Malek said, “He is from the Sunna followed in our (in Medina), concerning one who drinks an intoxicating drink, whether or not becoming drunk, to be subject to the prescribed punishment”. Chapter II The vessels that are prohibited for fermentation. 
(1591) 5 - Abdallah Ibn Omar reported that the Messenger of Allah r (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) had preached a speech to the men during his expeditions. Abdallah Ibn Omar, said I walked towards him, but he left before I could hear him. I asked the men what he had said, and they replied: "He forbade the fermentation of drinks in gourds and skins coated with pitch." 
(1592) 6 - Abu Huraira reported that the Messenger of Allah r (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) has forbidden the fermentation of drinks in gourds and skins coated with pitch”. Chapter III The ban on fermenting certain fruits all at once 
(1593) 7 - Ata Ibn Yassar reported that the Messenger of Allah r (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) forbade the preparation of a liquor from green dates and from fresh ones, from both fresh and dried grapes». 
(1594) 8 - Abu Katada Al-Ansari reported that the Messenger of Allah r (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) forbade drinking the mixture made from dates and grapes, and even green dates and other fresh ones”. - Malek said: “and such is what is always followed with us (in Medina), by men versed in religion, namely, the prohibition of such drink (previously quoted), that the Messenger of Allah r (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) refused”. Chapter IV Of the ban on wine 
(1595) 9 - Aisha, the wife of the Prophet (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) reported that the Messenger of Allah r (sallallahu alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) when asked about the "Bita'" replied: "Any intoxicating drink is prohibited”. (1) Bita': liqueur prepared from honey, by the Yemenis. 
(1596) 10 - Ata Ibn Yassar reported that the Messenger of Allah r (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) when asked about "Al-Ghoubaira", replied: "She's got nothing good," and he banned it. Malek said: “So I asked: Zaid-Ibn Aslam: “What is Al Ghoubaira”? He answered me: “It is “Al-Ouskarka” (drink prepared from barley). (1) Ghoubaira: drink made from barley or rice. 
(1597) 11 - Abdallah Ibn Umar reported that the Messenger of Allah r (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said: "Whoever in this world indulges in drinking wine, without repenting, he does not will not drink in the hereafter". Chapter V The prohibition of intoxicating liquors in general. 
(1598) 12 - Ibn Wa'la Al-Misri reported that he asked Ibn Abas about the juice of grapes, he replied: "a man offered to the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him be Allah's grace and peace) a skin of wine; the Messenger of Allah (sallallahu alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the favor and peace of Allah) said to him: "Do you not know that Allah has forbidden it”. "No," replied the man. Another man sitting next to him whispers to him in secret. The Messenger of Allah (sallallahu alayhi wa salam) (Upon him be Allah's Grace and Peace) asked him, "What did you whisper to him?" To sell it, said the man. So the Messenger of Allah r (sallallahu alayhi wa salam) (Upon him be Allah's Grace and Peace) said to him: "He who forbade that it be drunk, also prohibited it for sale". The man thus opened the two skins and poured out their contents”. 
(1599) 13 - Anas Ibn Malek reported: “I gave to drink, to Abou Oubaida Ibn Al-Jarrah, to Abou Talha Al-Ansari, and to Oubai Ibn Ka'b, a drink made of green and fresh dates”. Anas continued and said: “a man came and told them: wine is forbidden”; Then Abu Talha said, “O Anas! Go smash those jars." Thus, says Anas: “I got up, took a trough and broke the bottom of the jars”. 
(1600) 14 - Mahmoud Ibn Labib al-Ansari reported: “Once Omar Ibn Al-Khattab had arrived in Cham (Damascus), the inhabitants lamented the serious illness that had struck the city, and said: “Nothing can restore us to good health but this drink”; Omar said to them, "Drink honey"; they replied, “Honey does not suit us”; immediately one of them said to him: "Would you like this drink to be prepared for you, which does not intoxicate"? “Yes, answered Omar”. So they put it to boil, until two-thirds had evaporated, leaving only one-third, which they brought to Omar. He dipped a finger in it, then withdrew his hand, the liquid expanded. Omar said, "It's like the preparation with which camels are coated", and he ordered them to drink it. Then Oubada Ibn Al-Samett said to him: “By Allah! You have made it lawful”! And Omar to resume: “No, by Allah! God is great! I will not give them back never lawful what You have forbidden, nor will I forbid them what You have made lawful. (...) 15 - Abdallah Ibn Omar reported that men of Iraq said to him: "O Abu Abdul-Rahman, we bought ourselves dates and grapes, then we made wine from them and we sold it". Then Abdallah Ibn Omar said to them: "I take as witnesses against you, Allah, His angels and all those who listen to the geniuses and men, that I do not order you to sell it, or to buy it, or to squeeze it, or to drink it, or finally to give it to drink, because it is an abomination invented by Satan”. MOUATTAA In the name of Allah the Merciful the Merciful Book 43 The Book of Blood Money Chapter I blood money 
(1601) 1 - Muhammad Ibn Amr Ibn Hazm reported from his father that in the letter written by the Messenger of Allah r (sallallahu alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah), and sent to Amr, it is emphasized that which follows: “For a stunned man the price of blood is a hundred camels, and so is it for a completely amputated nose; for an injury to the head influencing the brain, the third of the dyia, and the same to an attacked belly; for the eye, the hand, and the foot, each is of fifty camels; for every amputated finger, ten camels; as for the pulled tooth and the wound reaching the bone, each is five camels”. Chapter II The practice of blood money 
(1602) 2 - It was reported to Malek that Omar Ibn Al-Khattab evaluated for the inhabitants of the villages, the price of blood at one thousand dinars in gold, or at twelve thousand dirhams in silver, and that, according to the current fund”. - Malek, explaining this says: “The current fund in Syria and Egypt is gold; and in Iraq, it's the money”. (...) 3 - Malek has heard that the blood money is to be paid over the course of three or four years. - And Malek to continue: “And it is preferable to me that he be paid over the course of three years”. - Eventually Malek said, “What is followed at we (in Medina) are not to admit inhabitants of the villages, as blood money, camels; nor Bedouins, gold or silver; nor of those who possess gold, silver and vice versa”. (1) Note that this expression will be, throughout of this chapter, taken to mean "murder"; as to the term "dyia", a word of Arabic origin, it will be taken in the sense of "legal compensation" paid as compensation for an offense committed. Chapter III The price of blood paid for a willful crime and of a crime committed by a madman. 
(1603) 4 - Malek reported that Ibn Chehab said: "if the price of blood paid for a premeditated crime is admitted, it is twenty-five camels of one year of age, twenty-five camels of two years of age, twenty-five camels of three years of age , and twenty-five camels of four years of age”. 
(1604) 5 - Yahia Ibn Sa'id reported that Marwan Ibn Al-Hakkam wrote to Mu'awia Ibn Abi Sufian, asking his opinion about a mad man who killed another. Mou'awia answered him in writing: "impose the price of blood on him without killing him, because one does not submit a madman with the prescribed penalty”. - Malek said: “About two men, one of whom one adult and the other youngest, and who together premeditatedly kill a man, it is up to the adult to be killed, and to the youngest to pay half the price of blood. - Eventually Malek said, "The same goes for the case where two men, one free and the other a slave, together kill a slave; it is the slave who will be killed, as for the free man, he will have to pay half the price of blood». Chapter IV Blood money paid for an unintentional crime. 
(1605) 6 - 'Iraq Ibn Malek and Soulaiman Ibn Yassar reported that a man from Bani Sa'd Ibn Laith, was racing a horse, which crushed the finger of a man from Jouhaina, who had a bleeding, and ended up dying. Omar Ibn Al-Khattab said to the defendants: "Do you swear for fifty times in the name of Allah, that the man did not die because of this injury"? They refused and prevented themselves from doing this, and on his part Omar addressing the others, asking them also, to swear, and they refused, he demanded that the first to know supporters of Sa'd, pay half the blood money to the victim”. - Malek said, "this was not followed at home (in Medina)". (...) 7 - Malek reported that Ibn Chehab, Suleiman Ibn Yassar and Rabi'a Ibn Abi Abdul Rahman, said: "The price of blood for an unintentional crime is twenty camels one year old, twenty camels two years old, twenty camels two years old, twenty camels three years of age, and twenty camels of four years of age”. - Malek also said: “what is followed at home (at Medina), is not to subject young adolescents to the prescribed punishment, even if they have voluntarily committed a crime, unless they are pubescent. Thus, a homicide committed by a boy is not considered intentional, since, if a boy and an adult man both unintentionally knocked out a free man, it falls to the "a'quila" of each of them. , to pay half the blood money”. (1) "la a'qila" constitutes the set of united males by the legitimate family tie, namely "agnate", inheriting the dead who can be either the father, or the uncle, or the brother, or the grandfather.... - Malek finally said, "Whoever knocks unwillingly, he will pay blood money without being subject to corporal punishment, for the price in question paid for the victim is just like what property he has from what he can pay of a debt or even to make a bequest. Thus, if he has property, the blood money to be paid will be a third of it, and thus he is exempt from the diya, although this is tolerated for him. And if he has no property, except what is blood money, also this is tolerated for him to take the third to make it a legacy and an exemption if the victim's parents forgive him. Chapter V Blood money suitable for injuries caused unintentionally; 
(1606) 8 - Malek said: “What is followed with us (in Medina), concerning wounds caused involuntarily, it is that blood money is not to be paid until the injured person has healed. Again, if it's a broken hand or foot or whatever member of the body of the man, involuntarily caused, then that it is cured, returning to its initial state, there is not a price to be paid, but if this wound has caused a deformation or an ugliness, the price of the blood which is to be poured must be proportional to what has been deformed and ugly”. - And Malek to continue: "If it is a question of a fracture of the bones, of which the Prophet r (On him the grace and the peace of Allah) had specified the price of blood which is suitable for him, it must be in conformity with the prescriptions of the Prophet; but if it is that the Prophet (on him the grace and the peace of Allah) did not specify the price of blood, and that there is on this subject neither a sunnah nor a fixed price , we are trying to give a suitable sentence”. - Malek also said: "the scars caused by error, to the body involuntarily, do not require blood money, if the scar becomes healthy, returning to its original state. But, if the citratrice leaves a deformation or an ugliness, one considers what is suitable for him as diya, except if it is about a “jaifa”, which requires that the dyia be the third of that of a murder. There is not either, continues Malek, a dyia for the case of a “mounakkila”^ which is just like “the moudiha”^. - Malek finally said, “What is tracked at us (in Medina), in case a doctor in circumcising has the glans of the penis cut off, it is because this imposes a dyia on him. And this is one of the errors that la'aqila must assume in his responsibilities. It is the same for any error committed by a doctor, or that he goes beyond his duties, without his wanting it; if so, the dyia is due". Chapter VI The price of woman's blood. 
(1607) 9 - Yahia ibn Sa'id reported that Sa'id Ibn Al Moussaiab said: "The price of a woman's blood is a third of that of a man, but the dyia is the same whether it is an amputated finger or a broken tooth, or even the same so-called injuries. moudiha and mounakkila”. (...) 10 - Malek reported that Ibn Chehab and Ourwa Ibn al Zoubair said similarly to Sa'id Ibn Al Moussaiab about the price of a woman's blood, namely that it is one third of that of a man. And if this price already reaches the third, the dyia will be of the half that of a man'. Interpreting this, Malek said, “So for the wounds called the “moudiha” and the “mounakkila”, the dyia is the same as that of man; but as for the "jaifa" and the "ma'mouma", and other similar injuries, subject to a third of the price of blood, the dyia of the woman will be half that of the man". (...) 11 - Malek reported that he heard Ibn Shehab say: "It is from the sunnah that a man causing an injury to his wife, that he pays her the dyia suitable for this injury, without him be subject to the prescribed penalty”. - Malek also said: "Now it is such in case this injury is involuntarily caused by the man, by hitting his wife with a whip and gouging out her eye, for example”. (1) “jaifa”: it is a wound reaching the inside of the body. (2) “mounakkila”: an injury with dislocation. (3) “moudiha”: an injury without a fracture. (4) "la m'amouma": it is a fracture in the head reaching the skull. - Malek finally said, “Regarding the woman who has a husband and children who are neither of her "acebs" nor of her people, her husband, especially if he is of another tribe, will not have to pay blood money in the event of an offense, nor with regard to this woman, nor with regard to his children who are not of his own tribe, nor even with regard to his uterine brothers who are neither of his "acebs" nor of his people, for such have a right to the inheritance of this woman. As for relatives, they had, and in the time of the Messenger of Allah r (sallallahu alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah), to pay the price of blood, until our days. It is the same for the freedmen of the woman whose inheritance goes to the children of the woman even if they are not of her tribe. And the price of the blood of a crime unwittingly committed by the freedmen, will have to be paid by the tribe of the woman”. (2) "aceb": is the male who inherits from a dead person, the remainder of the inheritance, after the reserveees have had their share; or who inherits everything if there are no reservers. Chapter VII Fetal blood money. 
(1608) 12 - Abu Huraira reported that two women of the Hazil tribe, quarreled, during which one caused the other, who was pregnant, to lose her child. Thus, the Messenger of Allah r (sallallahu alayhi wa salam) (Upon him be Allah's Grace and Peace) demanded, "The ghourra” (as compensation) who is either a slave”. 
(1609) 13 - Sa'id Ibn Al Musaiab said: "The Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the mercy and peace of Allah) demanded, concerning the child killed in the bosom of his mother, "the ghourra" as lawful compensation and who is a slave. The man who owed this compensation, a Protestant said, "How shall I pay the price of a being who has yet drunk, neither eaten, nor articulates, nor speaks; thus such a requirement is invalid”. However, the Messenger of Allah r (sallallahu alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) replied: "This man is a fellow magician". (...) 14 - Malek reported that Rabi'a Ibn Abdul Rahman said: “The ghourra is valued at fifty dinars or six hundred dirhams; and the dyia of a free Muslim woman is five hundred dinars or even six thousand dirhams”. - Malek said, "The lawful compensation of a child killed in the bosom of his mother, a free woman, is equivalent to the tenth of his dyia; and the tenth is fifty dinars or six hundred dirhams”. - And Malek to continue: "I didn't hear anyone to say that for a child killed in the bosom of its mother, one should only pay a ghourra until the moment when its mother has aborted it or until it falls dead”. - “And always, on this subject, Malek said: “I have heard that if the child comes out of the lap of its mother alive and then dies, there again we demand full compensation”. - “Also Malek adds: “A child is only considered alive when he comes out of his mother's lap. Thus, if he leaves there and dies afterwards, the compensation is due. I also believe that the compensation for a child of a slave is a tenth of the price of his mother". - Finally Malek said: "if a pregnant woman kills a man or a woman involuntarily, she will not be subjected to the prescribed penalty until she has given birth to her fetus. If a pregnant woman is intentionally or unintentionally killed, whoever killed her killed will have nothing to pay Tegaruee her fetus. But if she is voluntarily killed, one kills the one who killed her, without his having to pay compensation with regard to her fetus. price of the mother's blood, independently of her foetus. (...) 15 - Malek was asked about the child of a Jewish or Christian woman, if he is aborted, he replied: "I think we should pay him a tenth of the price of his mother's blood". Chapter VIII Which is subject to full dyia. 
(1610) 16 - Ibn Chehab reported that Sa'id Al Moussaiab said: “For the two cut lips, one owes a complete dyia; but if it is only the lower lip, the dyia is two-thirds”. (...) 17 - Malek reported that he asked Ibn Chehab about the one-eyed man gouging out the eye of a healthy man? Ibn Chehab answered: “If the healthy desires that the punishment be applied to the one-eyed, this is his right; or else it may have a dyia of thousand dinars or twelve thousand dirhams”. (...) 18 - It was reported to Malek that for each lost pair of a man's limbs requires a complete dyia; so is the tongue, both ears with deafness, whether even cut off or not; also a full dyia is needed for the man's penis and both testicles» (...) 19 - It was again reported to Malek, that the dyia must be complete for both breasts cut off from a woman”. - Malek, on the other hand, said, “I think there is not a dyia about the cut eyebrows, nor about the man's chest either”. - Eventually Malek said, “What is followed at us (in Medina) is to give the man a full dyia in case he has lost much more than a limb. Also, if it is his hands, his feet and his eyes which are affected, knowing that he is broken and punctured, he has right to three dyia'. “As for the healthy eye of a one-eyed man, who by mistake is punctured, he will be entitled to a complete dyia”. Chapter IX The dyia poured about the eye losing sight 
(1611) 20 - Soulaiman Ibn Yassar reported that Zaid Ibn Thabet said: “For a healthy eye that has lost sight, you need a dyia of one hundred dinars”. - Malek was asked about the loss of the lower lid of the eye, and fracture of its socket; he answered: "one does not fail to find a suitable sentence, except if this harms the sight of the eye, then one considers what is harmful". - Eventually Malek said, “What is followed at us (in Medina), about a blind eye, if it is torn out, and likewise about a paralyzed hand which is cut off. there be a definite dyia about it. Chapter X The dyia corresponding to the wounds 
(1612) 21 - Yahia Ibn Sa'id heard Soulaiman Ibn Yassar say: "the moudiha" to the face is treated similarly to that which is made to the head, except if it makes the face ugly; so so, one adds his dyia, taking into account the difference between this one, and half of the dyia corresponding to the head and it will be seventy-five dinars. - Malek said: “what is followed in Medina about of the "mounakkila" is to give fifteen camels as a dyia. "The mounakkila", continues Malek, is the wound which causes the fine bones of the head to be lost without reaching the brain; she may as well be the head than in the face". - Malek to also say: "what is followed in Medina, about the "maamouma" and the "Jaifa", it is that they do not impose the prescribed sentence on me". And Ibn Chehab said: "the maamouma does not require pain". - And Malek interpreting said: "the maamouma is a fracture penetrating the bones of the skull; and it is only considered as such”. - Eventually Malek said, "What is followed at Medina is that there is no need to pay a dyia for a wound that is less than the moudiha; in fact the dyia is for what is the mudiha and a greater wound, because the Messenger of Allah r (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) had underlined it in his letter sent to Amr Ibn Hazm, where he made it correspond to five camels. Moreover, the imams of the past and of today have not demanded anything like dyia about the moudiha”. (...) 22 - Yahia Ibn Sa'id reported that Sa'id Ibn Al Moussaiab said: “Any deep wound practiced in one of the limbs, requires a dyia equivalent to one third of that of that limb'. (...) 23 - Malek said: "Ibn Chehab was not of the notice (quoted above); as for me, I did not find that we agreed on the subject of the deep wound practiced in one of the members, but rather it is up to the imam to find a suitable sentence”. - Also Malek said, "What is applied in Medina, it is to consider a wound as a maamouma or mounakkila or even moudiha, only if it is in the face or in the head. But any other injury made in any part of the body, calls only for a sentence”. - Eventually Malek said, "I don't conceive, for as for the lower jaw and the nose, to consider them as part of the head, so long as they are separated from it, and the head is his, one bone”. (...) 24 - Rabi'a Ibn Abdul Rahman reported that Abdallah Ibn Al Zoubair had applied the law of retaliation to a man who caused the mounakkila”. Chapter XI The dyia corresponding to the fingers. 
(1613) 25 - Rabi'a Ibn Abdul Rahman reported: “I asked Sa'id Ibn Al Moussaiab about the dyia for a woman's finger being cut off? He answered me: “It is ten camels” “And for two fingers, I resumed”? “Twenty camels, he replied” “And for three”? - "Thirty Camels"; “and for four”? - “twenty camels”. So I asked him: “How is it that the more serious the injury, the more the dyia decreases”? Sa'id replied, “Are you Iraqi? - "Actually a scholar with a fine mind, or an ignoramus to learn, I replied". Sa'id to reply, "Rather, he is of the Sunnah, O son of my brother." (1) Iraqi: designates the one who applies the reasoning by Syllogism. - Malek also said, "what is followed in Medina, it is to demand the dyia in case the finger of one hand is cut off. If it is the five cut off, their dyia will be that of a complete hand, namely fifty camels, starting with ten camels for each finger”. - Finally Malek said: "for the phalanxes of the hand, the required dyia is thirty-three dinars, and a third for each of them, thus corresponding to three camels and a third of a camel”. Chapter XII The dyia relating to the teeth. 
(1614) 26 - Aslam, the freedman of Omar Ibn Al-Khattab reported that Umar demanded that the dyia of one tooth be a camel, as well as for the collarbone and the rib”. I (...) 27 - Yahia Ibn Sa'id reported that he heard Sa'id Ibn Al Moussaiab say: “Omar Ibn Khattab demanded that the dyia of it be, for every tooth pulled out, a camel; and Mou'awia (on his part, let the dyia be five camels for every tooth pulled out". - Sa'id, continued, and said: "So therefore the dyia is decreasing according to Omar, and increasing according to Mou'awia. As for me, if I had to make up my mind, I would have imposed two camels for each tooth pulled out, finding that such a dyia is so suitable, and every jurist will be rewarded for it”. (...) 28 - Yahia Ibn Sa'id reported that Sa'id Ibn Al Moussaiab said: “in case the tooth is affected and therefore blackens, the dyia is payable. And if, after getting dark. it is uprooted, the dyia will have to be paid, in full”. [ Chapter XIII The application of the dyia of the teeth. 
(1615) 29 - Abu Ghatafan Ibn Tarif Al-Mourri a reported that Marwan Ibn Al-Hakam sent him, to ask Abdallah Ibn Al-Abas, about the unintentional pulling out of a tooth”? Abdallah Ibn AI Abbas replied: “The dyia paid is five camels”. Marwan me instructed to be again at Abdallah Ibn Abbas asking him “Do you consider molars as incisors”?. And Abdallah Ibn Abbas to answer: “don't the fingers of a hand require the same dyia”? (...) 30 - Hisham Ibn Ourwa reported that his father did not distinguish between the teeth, when it is about the dyia». * Malek said: “What is followed at home (at Medina) is that the dyia is the same for all teeth at once, is it the inolar ones or the incisors, the fact that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said: "for a tooth-involuntarily pulled out - the dyia is five camels, and the molar is nothing but one tooth among others, where they cannot be distinguished from each other”. Chapter XIV The dyia paid for the injury caused to a slave. 
(1616) 31 - It was reported to Malek that Sa'id Ibn Al Moussaiab and Soulaiman Ibn Yassar said: "the moudiha of the slave demands a dyia worth half of the tenth of its price". (...) 32 - It was also reported to Malek that Marwan Ibn Al Hakkam decided about the slave who was injured, that it is the duty of the one who injured, to give the payment of a dyia equivalent to what is the reduction of the price of the slave”. * Malek said: “What is followed at home (at Medina), is that the dyia paid for the injury caused to a slave, depends on the nature of the latter, just like what follows: * for the moudiha, a dyia worth the tenth of half the price of the slave. * for the mounakkila, it is a tenth and half a tenth. * for the maamouma and the jaifa: each is a third of its price. As for the other wounds, viz. everything that can reduce the price of the slave, one estimates, after the recovery of the slave, how much is the difference, between the value of the price of the slave after his wound, and his value before he did not undergo it. Then one asks to the author of the wound the payment of a dyia equivalent to the difference of the two prices”. - Also, about the slave whose hand or the foot were fractured, after which the limb healed, Malek said: "In fact, the one who caused this fracture, will have nothing to pay, unless this fracture causes the reduction of the price of the slave, or his dislocation then thus, the dyia to pay will be equivalent to the reduction of the price ". - And Malek to continue: “what is followed in Medina, it is that the law of retaliation is applied to slaves as well as to free men, namely: a slave can be killed for a slave, their wounds are still the same. Also, if a slave voluntarily kills another slave, the master of the latter will have to choose: either that he applies the law of retaliation to the slave, or that he has to recover the dyia, equivalent to the price of his killed slave. On the other hand, if the master of the homicidal slave wants to pay the price of the killed slave, he will be able to do so, or he will deliver his slave to the master of the murderer slave and again the other master having already the murderous slave, will not have to kill him. Such is the rule followed between slaves even in the case of a hand or a foot. cut or other punishment such as murder which is also subject to the law of retaliation". - Malek finally said about the slave Muslim, wounding a Jew or a Christian, that the master of this slave can pay him the dyia for his doing, or even that he delivers him for to be sold. Being such, one gives to the Jew or to the Christian, a dyia coming from the price of the slave, or still all the price so that the dyia is paid; but neither a Jew nor a Christian will be handed over a Muslim slave”. Chapter XV The dyia of the People of the Book. 
(1617) 33 - It was reported to Malek that Omar Ibn Abdul Aziz has decided, in case a Jew or a Christian is killed, that Sa dyia of each, be equivalent to half that of a free Muslim man", - Malek said: “What is followed at home (at Medina), is not to kill a Muslim because of a disbeliever, unless the Muslim kills the other by treason; consequently he shall be subject to execution". (...) 34 - Yahia Ibn Sa'id reported that Soulaiman Ibn Yassar said: “The dyia of a “majous” (one of the magi) is eight hundred dirhams”. And Malek to underline: “This is also what is followed with us (in Medina)”. - Finally Malek said: “The wounds caused to the Jews, Christians, and Magi have a relatively small dyia compared to the wounds of Muslims, which is as follows: For the moudiha, it is half of a tenth of the dyia (of Muslims); for the maamouma and the jaifa: each is a third party, and so it is with all their wounds”. Chapter XVI That which is subject to the dyia of a man's property. 
(1618) 35 - Hisham Ibn Ourwa reported from his father, that he said: "The aqila is not subject to the payment of the price of the blood, when it is a crime voluntarily committed; but this price is to be paid, if the crime is involuntary”. (...) 36 - Malek reported that Ibn Chehab said: “It is Sunnah no longer to require the aquila to pay the blood money for a voluntary crime unless she wants to do so”. (...) 37 - Malek added, that Yahia Ibn Sa'id was of the same opinion (quoted above). -And Malek to continue that Ibn Chehab said: "It is of the sunnah, in the case where it is a voluntary murder, and where the parents of the victim have withdrawn, that the dyia be paid from the own property of the murderer, unless the aqila intends to support him to acquit of his own free will”. - Malek also said, "what is followed in Medina, it is that the dyia is not obliged to pay it, except in the case where the dyia is a third party and beyond; being such, it is required to the aqila; if it is less than one-third, the dyia is paid from the author's own money”. - Malek added: “What is unquestionably follow-up in Medina about who, one accepts the payment of a dyia, for having committed a voluntary murder or even for an injury caused voluntarily, and where the relatives of the victim had accepted the dyia, is that nothing is required of the aqila unless it does so willingly; for in fact the price of blood, is to be paid from the own money of the murderer or of the one who caused the wound, if he possesses the money; otherwise, this remains a debt, from which he will have to discharge; therefore, the aqila will not have to pay anything unless she wishes”. - Malek further said, "Nothing is required of the aqila, in case a man kills or injures himself voluntarily or involuntarily; moreover, such is the opinion of men versed in religion on this subject. And I have never heard anyone say that the aqila must guarantee the dyia of a voluntary crime. This is known to by the words of Allah Blessed and Most High in His Book (meaning): "One should use proper procedures towards the one to whom his brother has forgiven part of the debt, and he himself will compensate him in the best way (Koran II, 178). This is interpreted as follows, and Allah is most knowledgeable: "Whoever takes part of his brother's dyia, let him follow him with a suitable deed, and let the doer kindly compensate him." - “Regarding the boy or woman, committing a package whose dyia is not more than a third of the blood money, and both of them do not have the money they need, Malek said: "In fact, it must be guaranteed from their own property, d where we take the sum; but if neither of them has the money, the blood money will be a debt they will have to pay, without the aqila having anything to do with it. On the other hand, the father of the boy will not have to pay what is the duty of this boy”. - Eventually Malek said, "What is unquestionably followed with us (in Medina), about the slave killed is that his dyia is to be assessed on the day of his murder. As for the aqila of the murderer, it will owe nothing of this dyia of some value, namely less or more. Because it's up to the murderer what does it mean to compensate with one's own money as much as the dyia will be. On the other hand, if the price of the slave is equivalent to the dyia whether it is superior or inferior to it, it will be taken from the money of the murderer, as long as the slave is considered as a commodity among others”. Chapter XVII The legacy of the dyia and its execution. 
(1619) 38 - Ibn Chehab reported that Omar Ibn Al-Khattab, addressed, while he was in Mina, the people saying: “Whoever has knowledge about the dyia, let him teach it to me”. Al-Dahhak Ibn Sufian arose and said: "The Messenger of Allah r (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) prompted me in writing to do to inherit Achiam al-Dibabi's wife her share of her husband's dyia'. Omar said to him: "Enter your tent and await my arrival". As soon as Omar showed up, Al-Dahhak teaches him what is the subject of the dyia; from then on, Omar decided on the business of the dyia. - And Ibn Chehab added: "The murder of Achiam was accomplished involuntarily". 
(1620) 39 - Amr Ibn Chou'aib reported that a man of Bani Moudiej known as Katada, throwing his sword at his son, hit him in the leg, after which, the son died because of of a hemorrhage. Suraqa Ibn Jou'choum, went to Omar Ibn Al Khattab, told him the incident, Omar, also said to him: "go to “Qadid”, count one hundred and twenty camels and wait for me to arrive”. Omar Ibn Al-Khattab arrived at the destined place, took camels counted, thirty camels of three years old, thirty camels of four years old and thirty more full, then said: “where is the brother of the knocked down”? "Here I am," he replied. "Take them", continued Omar, because the Messenger of Allah r (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said: “a homicide has no right to dyia”. (...) 40 - Malek reported that Sa'id Al Moussaiab and Soulaiman Ibn Yassar were asked, if the dyia was at increase, if it falls during a holy month? "No," they replied, but she undergoes an addition out of consideration to this month." Then Sa'id was asked: "Should the dyia corresponding to wounds be increased, just like that which is increased for murder"? "Yes," he said. - Malek added: “I see that they have, on this subject, acted, just as Omar Ibn Al-Khattab had judged the case of the dyia of Moudlaji, throwing his sword and wounding his son”. 
(1621) 41 - Ourwa Ibn Al-Zoubair reported that a Ansai man known as Ouhaiha Ibn Al-Joulah had an uncle who was shorter than him, living with his maternal uncles; Ouhaiha took him and killed him; thus the maternal uncles exclaimed: "we brought him up from his tender age, and when he grew into a strong man, a paternal nephew took him away from us." Ourwa then said: “it is for such a reason that a murderer does not inherit from his victim”. - Malek said: “What is unquestionably followed with us (in Medina), it is that the murderer who kills with all his will inherits nothing from the dyia of the victim, nor from his goods. Also, this murderer cannot prevent any reservator from receiving his share of the estate. And he who involuntarily kills, inherits nothing more dyia. However, regarding his right to inheritance, this has been subject to discussion, as long as he is not accused of having killed, to inherit the victim, nor to seize his property. So what I find good is that he will have to inherit his property, regardless of his dyia”. Chapter XVIII The dyia in general. 
(1622) 42 - Abu Huraira reported that the Messenger of Allah r (sallallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said: "No more dyia to put back in case of an accident from animal, well and metal. As for what is “rikaz” (it is what is buried treasures in pre-Islamic times) we count the fifth”. - Malek, on this subject, is of the same opinion. - Malek said, "The leader of a caravan, the driver of a beast and its rider, all are responsible for wounds caused by a mount, except the case where the beast kicks without being pushed by someone who makes him do so. On the other hand, Omar Ibn Al-Khattab, was for the payment of the dyia concerning the one who makes his mount run (ie thereby causing him an injury). - Malek added: “Besides the leader of a caravan, the driver of an animal and the one who rides it owe the payment of a dyia much more than the one who drives his mount”. - Malek further said, "What is practiced in Medina, is the following: “Whoever digs a well in the middle of the street, or ties up a mount or even does such a thing on the path traveled by the Muslims, and all these actions are what is not not allowed, and what causes harm to Muslims, he will be held responsible for what may happen, injury either she or otherwise. If the damage caused does not count even a third of the dyia, it will be taken from that man's own money; but if the sum is one-third or more, it is aqila. However, if the man had done what is permitted as an action, and this had caused damage or harm to the Muslims, he will not be responsible for it, such as digging a well to retain rain water. or get off a mount and tie it up beside the road, to satisfy a need”. - Also, about one who descends into a well, and another follows it, so that the first attracts the second, both ending up in the well, Malek said: "It's up to the first to pay the dyia". - The same for the boy, whom the man asks to descend into a well, or to climb a palm tree, and who ends up to die (by falling or other cause related to this order), Malek said: "It is up to the man to take the responsibility, thus paying the dyia". - Malek said again: “What is incontestably practiced among us (in Medina), it is to demand from women and boys the payment of the dyia with raqua, because in fact the dyia is only payable by men who are already mature”. -About the dyia required of freedmen Malek a said: "We can charge the aquila with it if she accepts, but in case she refuses they will belong to Diwan (1), or be abandoned. Also from the time of the Messenger of Allah r (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) and Abu Bakr Al Siddiq, the aqila regime was followed even before the diwan existed; therefore this diwan was instituted in the time of Umar. Therefore, it is not permissible for someone to be paid the dyia if they are not people of his tribe or his relatives, because the wala cannot be transmitted, although the Messenger of Allah r (sallallahu alayhi wa salam) On him the grace and peace of Allah said: "the right of patronage (in other words the wala) belongs to the one who frees". (1) The Diwan is designed as being the registry. But during the time of Omar Ibn el Khattab the Diwan consisted of governmental and official institutions such the public treasury the personal status and other… - And Malek to emphasize the wala is a fixed membership” - - Also, what is followed with us (in Medina) concerning beasts that have suffered harm; Malek said, "Whoever has caused harm to them, must pay for them a sum equivalent to the rate of diminution." - Concerning the man condemned to death, by committing a crime that subjects him to a prescribed sentence, Malek said: "The prescribed sentence is no longer taken into account, as long as death encompasses everything, except if it is the case of defamation, so one asks the defamed : "Why don't you ask for the application of the penalty to the one who defamed you"? And Malek to underline: “I conceive there, the application of the prescribed penalty to the defamer before killing him. Then we will kill him, I do not understand that we have the right to impose the payment of the dyia on him if it is an injury for example, because the death penalty does not leaves room for no other pain”. - Malek said again: “What is followed at home (at Medina), about a man killed, abandoned among the dwellings or in a village or other place. It's that we have no right to accuse the one whose house is near the slain, nor the one who lives near from the place where you were left killed, because it is possible that a man will be killed and then thrown out of people's doors so that they will be charged. Thereby such an act is to be rejected”. - Finally, about a group of people who, fight each other, and end in one killed or one injured without knowing who is responsible, Malek said: "The best thing I've heard about it is to demand the dyia of those who fought against him; and if the wounded or the killed was neither from one camp nor from another, the dyia will be demanded of both camps at the same time”. Chapter XIX Murder committed by treachery or magic. 
(1623) 43 - Sa'id Ibn Al Musaiab reported that Omar Ibn Al-Khattab ordered to kill five or seven people who knocked out, by treachery a man, and he said: "if all the inhabitants of Sana'a (city in Yaman where the crime took place) had conspired for his murder, I would have ordered them all to be killed at once”. 
(1624) 44 - It was reported to Muhammad Ibn Abdul-Rahman Ibn Sa'd Ibn Zarara that Hafsa, the wife of the Prophet (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) had ordered to kill one of her slaves she had already freed posthumously, for having bewitched her". - Malek said: "the magician practicing sorcery, without being bewitched by another (killing another by his magic) is to be compared to the man about whom Allah said in his Book (meaning): "Men know that he who does the acquisition of these vanities, will have no part in future life” (Koran 11,102). Therefore, he must be killed if he committed the murder himself”. Chapter XX The willful crime 
(1625) 45 - Omar Ibn Houssein, the freedman of Aisha Bint Koudama, recounted that Abdul-Malek Ibn Marwan delivered a man who had killed another with a stick to the defender of the victim who, he killed the culprit with a stick. - Malek said: “The unquestionably followed standard with us (in Medina) is as follows: "In case a man strikes another with a stick or throws a stone at him or even strikes him voluntarily, and the man dies, such is the voluntary crime subject to the law of the retaliation”. - Malek added: “Thus, the crime considered voluntary with us (in Medina), is for one man to strike another until he dies; on the other hand, it is still a voluntary crime, the fact that a man strikes another because of animosity or even as a result of a quarrel, and then leaves him still alive. However, if this last one dies as a result of hemorrhage, we will resort to "Kaça-ma" (see next chapter). - Malek finally said, “What we follow at us (in Medina) is that in the course of willful murder, guilty freemen should be killed by one freeman, women by one woman, and slaves by one slave”. Chapter XXI The law of retaliation applied to a murder 
(1626) 46 - It was reported to Malek that Marwan Ibn Al-Hakam had written to Mu'awia Ibn Abi Sufian that a drunken man had been brought to him, who killed a man. On this subject, Moua'wia answered him "Make him killed". - Malek said: “The best I heard about the explanation of this verse (the meaning): “The free man for the free man, the slave for the slave“, (Koran II, 178), such are the males, and "the free woman for the free woman", it is that the application of the law of retaliation is the same, both to women and to men. Thus, one kills a free woman for a free woman, just as one kills a free man for a free man, yet one kills a male or female slave, for a male or female slave. female. So the law of retaliation is applied the same way too women as well as men, in accordance with the words of Allah Blessed and Most High in his book (meaning): "We have prescribed for them, in the Torah: life for life, eye for eye, nose for nose, ear for ear, tooth for tooth. Wounds fall under the law of retaliation” (Koran V,45). Thus, Allah Blessed and Most High had mentioned that life is for life, meaning that the free woman can be killed by a free man, and his wounds are like his, subject to the law of retaliation". - Concerning the man who cares for another, a man for the second to strike the third and kill him on the spot, Malek said, "If the first holds the third, so that the second can kill the latter, both must be killed. But if he holds him believing that the second wishes to strike the third, thereby wishing to reform him, without his seeking to kill him, the murderer must be killed; as for the one who held the victim, he will be severely judged and imprisoned for one year without being condemned to death”. - Concerning the man who voluntarily kills a another or put out his eye, after which the murderer will be killed, or they will put out his eye, before the law of retaliation is applied to him, Malek said: “He will neither pay a dyia, nor be subject to the law retaliation, because he who has been killed or whose eye has been gouged out, had the right to apply a similar sanction to one who has voluntarily killed. Because in fact he is in the same situation as that of a man who voluntarily kills, then dies. Thus, since the murderer is dead, the parents of the victim will not be entitled to a dyia, nor to any other legal compensation, and this by reference to what Allah Blessed and Most High has said in His Book: “the law of retaliation is prescribed for you in case of murder: the free man for the free man, the slave for the slave” (Coran 11,178). - Explaining this, Malek said, “So then the victim has the full right to apply the law of retaliation to the murderer; but if the murderer dies, the victim will have neither blood money nor an application of the law of retaliation”. - Finally Malek said: "the law of retaliation is not not to apply to a freeman injuring a slave; but if a slave voluntarily kills a free man, he will be killed; as for the free man killing a slave, he will not be killed even if the crime is voluntary. And that's the best I've heard." Chapter XXII Forgiveness for a voluntary crime 
(1627) 47 - Yahia reported that Malek had crossed men versed in religion and approved of him, say: "If a murdered man recommends (before dying), to forgive his murderer who killed him voluntarily, it is permissible for him, because he had more than right than others, to dispose of the person of the murderer (namely either to condemn him to death or to pardon him). - Concerning a murdered man, who forgives, before to die to his killer who killed him willfully, once sentenced to death, Malek said, "The victim no longer has the right to blood money, except that he asks her for it by granting her forgiveness”. - And Malek to continue: In case the willful killer is pardoned, he will be flogged for a hundred lashes, and will be imprisoned for a year. - When a man voluntarily kills another, and this is already in evidence, while the victim has sons and daughters, if the sons forgive the killer and the daughters refuse him, this forgiveness is valid as long as it is more considered than that of the girls; therefore the girls will have no right to claim nor forgiveness, nor blood money". Chapter XXIII The application of the law of retaliation, about injuries. (1628) - Malek said: "What is unquestionably followed with us (in Mcdine), in the subject of the one who voluntarily causes a fracture in the hand or in the foot of a man, it is to apply the law of retaliation to him without claiming the dyia”. -Also Malek said: "The law of retaliation will not be applied to the culprit only if the wounds are healed- If the wound caused to the culprit is similar to that of the attacked once healed, such will be the penalty; in case the wound is more grawc, or else the culprit is dead, the assailed owes the culprit nothing-If the assailed becomes paralyzed or his wounds have healed leaving a bodily defect or deformity or dislocation , while the aggressor is completely cured, he will not have the right let the culprit have his other hand broken, or let him be punished. However one pays, by compensation the dyia which must be equivalent to that dislocation; and wounds will be treated the same as broken bones”. -Malek said a if a man voluntarily dies a eye to his wife, or breaks her hand or cuts off her finger, or causes her a similar injury he will be subject to the law of retaliation. As for the man who hits his wife with a rope or a whip, thus causing her any harm whatsoever involuntarily, he will pay the dyia without being subject to the law of retaliation”. (....)“-Malek finally said I was told that Abu Bakr ibn Muhammad ibn Amer ibn Hazm had decided to apply the retaliation far for a fractured thigh”- Chapter XXIV What is suitable as dyia to "Al Sa'iba" and the crime he commits 
(1629) 49 - Soulaiman Ibn Yassar reported that a pilgrim had freed his esdave as a Sa'iba, this one killed a man from Bani 'Aez. The father of the victim comes to find Omar Ibn AI-Khattab, claiming the blood money of his son-Omar says to him: "He does not have the right to a dyia”; then the father answered: What will be your decision if my son had killed him”? Omar replied, "In that case, you you have to pay him the dyia» - The father then said: "So he is like a viper who left, she eats everything, killed, another viper will take revenge". (1) Al Sa'iba is a slave freed by his master without the latter retaining the right to patronize him. (2) It was said in pre-Islamic times when a viper was Killing another viper was his revenge. MOUATTAA In the name of Allah the Merciful the Merciful Book 44 The Book of the “Kaçama”(1) First chapter: On the primacy given to rights holders to do "the Kaçama" (1) The Kaçama: comes from the word "Kaçama" meaning: "to swear"; thus one asks the having-rights to swear, in the event of a crime, in order to claim the price of blood of their victim or the application of the talion. According to other scholars, it is a question of asking the heirs to take the oath fifty times, provided that they are males, and that according to their shares. of inheritance. There then, the term “Kaçama” means to distribute “the oath”. 
(1630) 1 - Sahl Ibn Abi Hathma reported that notables of his tribe told him the following: “Abdallah Ibn Sahl and Muhayssa, having suffered a total defeat, went to Khaibar. We came to tell Muhayssa that Abdallah Ibn Sahl had been knocked unconscious and abandoned near a well or a palm tree. Jews arriving at the place, Muhayssa said to them: “It is you, by Allah, who killed him”, and the Jews replied: “By Allah!, we did not kill him”. Mouhayssa, returned to his tribe, to inform them of the event, then came with his brother Houayssa, who was taller than him, and Abdul Rahman. Thus, Muhayssa, who was in Khaibar, wanting to speak, the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) remarked to him: "Let the greatest have the word"; Houayssa spoke, then his brother Mouhayssa had to his turn the word, after which, the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the mercy and peace of Allah) answered them: “Or that the Jews pay the price of blood, or that the war is declared”. Then the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) informed the Jews of his decision in writing, who answered him: “By Allah! we did not kill him”. So, the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said to Houayssa, Muhayssa and Abdul Rahman: "Would you swear, which will make you deserve the price of your brother's blood"? When they refused, he continued: “Would you like the Jews to swear to it”? - "No," they replied, "they don't are not Muslims. Thus, the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Be upon him the mercy and peace of Allah) paid them from his goods (namely from the public treasury) the price of blood, sending them a hundred camels, which were returned to their abode, where Sahl said: "the camels being received by us, one of them, red-haired, kicked me ". 
(1631) 2 - Yahia Ibn Sa'id reported that Bouchair Ibn Yassar told him the following: “Abdallah Ibn Sahl al Ansari and Muhayssa Ibn Massou'd having gone to Khaibar where they parted for business, Abdallah Ibn Sahl was knocked unconscious. Then Muhayssa came to the Prophet (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) accompanied by his older brother-Houyassa and Abdul rahman Ibn Sahl. Abdul Rahman, being the brother of the victim, wanting to speak, the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said to him: "May the greatest have the speech"; thus Houayssa took the floor then Mouhayssa, and learned from the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) does. The Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (Be upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said to them: "Would you, by fifty times, oath and you would deserve the blood money of your brother or the culprit”? They replied, “O Messenger of Allah! We were neither present nor witnesses to this fact”. So the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said to them: "Do you want the Jews swear to you their innocence, fifty times”? They replied, “No! Messenger of Allah! How could we accept the oath of unbelieving people? - Yahia Ibn Sa'id added: "Bouchair Ibn yassar claimed that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) paid with his goods, the price of blood”. - Malek said, “What is unquestionably followed with us (in Medina) and which I heard being practiced by those who accepted the Kaçama, and which, on the other hand, had been concerted by the ulemas in the past and nowadays, it is that we must proceed to make "the Kaçama", by asking the accused to take an oath. As a result, this Kaçama is only obligatory in two cases: either that the victim, before dying, says: "so-and-so killed me", or that the parents, again say, the beneficiaries present a evidence, however weak, and not conclusive against the culprit. In this case, the Kaçama is required for the accusers against the accused, and the Kaçama will never be admitted in any other case”. - Malek to add: "This is the sunna which is indisputable, and which moreover continues to be put into practice by people, namely, asking the rights holders to start doing "the kaçama", whether it is a voluntary crime or not". - Malek to continue: “and the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the mercy and peace of Allah) had first asked the men of the Haritha tribe - who are the subject of the two previous hadiths - to do the Kaçama with regard to their victim killed in Khaibar". - Malek said further: "If the accusers proceed at the "Kaçama", they will be entitled to the price of the blood of their victim, and even to kill the culprit. However, "the Kaçama", being done, only one culprit will be killed, and never two. Thus, for "the Kaçama" to be executed, fifty men among the beneficiaries will make fifty oaths; but if their number is less or even if some abstain, their oath is no longer to be considered, and the others must thus complete the fifty oaths. But if among those who have abstained, there is one of the heirs who has the right and the price of blood and the right to forgive, there will no longer be an application of the death penalty to the accused. - And Malek continued: “So if one of the fifty, not enjoying the right of forgiveness, abstains, the others will have to complete the fifty oaths; but if it is one of the heirs who is entitled to forgiveness, abstains, even if he were a single individual, the other heirs are not asked to complete the fifty oaths, for the good reason, that it comes back to the accused to take the oath for fifty times, so that each will do it for once; if the number is less than fifty, they will complete them; if there is only one accused, it is up to him alone to make the fifty oaths, if he is innocent”. - Malek to add: "Besides, we have to do the distinction between the "Kaçama" concerning blood money, and the oaths proper to rights (namely that the Kaçama requires fifty oaths, as for the other, it is only of one oath). And Malek explains it: if a man owes a debt to another and he manages to to prove it effectively, and that the man intends to kill another, he will not kill him in the midst of the people, but he seeks to do it far from them, and without there being witnesses. Because if the Kaçama were to be considered, only in the case where there is clear evidence, and if we proceeded to put it into practice in the same way that is appropriate for the affirmation of other rights, blood would be shed. everywhere (meaning, that the killing will be increasing); therefore, people, taking part in it, would not stop practicing murder. However, the "Kaçama" was not held as standard to the victim's heirs, beginning with taking an oath, only for the purpose of inducing people to repel the practice of killing; also, so that the murderer is only condemned according to what is decided by the victim before his death. - On the other hand, concerning the people, who are at number of fifty being accused of murder, while the number of heirs is less than that, Malek said: "Each of these heirs will make for fifty times an oath, emphasizing that their oaths will not be considered unless each has made oath for fifty times”. And, that's the best I've heard about it. -Finally Malek said: "The Kaçama comes back to the close relatives of the killed who are in fact his heirs; and who if they take an oath the accused will be killed. Chapter II The heirs from whom the Kaçama is accepted. (1632) -Malek said, "What is a standard unquestionably followed in (in Medina), it is that one does not accept "the Kacama" of women, when it is a voluntary crime. In case the victim has only women for heirs, one does not accept neither their Kaçama^ nor their forgiveness”. - Malek added: a.-In case a man is willfully killed, and that his relatives or his freedmen say: "We will take an oath and we will have the price of our victim's blood" this is tolerated. b- - If women want to forgive the guilty they are not allowed to do so because close male relatives and freedmen have more rights than they do in taking an oath to have blood money”. c. - In case the close relatives and the freedmen forgive the culprit, after having had the price of blood, and that the women refuse saying: "We do not want to leave the murderer of our victim, there they will have the right and the primacy to do so, because he who is for the application of the law of retaliation has more right than the relatives and the women who left him, once this judgment was legally possible". d. - For a crime made of any will, one do not accept less than two of the accusers who are asked to take an oath fifty times in order to have the right to convict the culprit. And such is the norm with us (in Medina)”. e. - If a group of people hit a name until that he dies under the blows on the spot, all are punishable by the death penalty. So if he dies after this attack, we proceed to the Kaçama. This Kaçama is only held for a single man who is the victim and it is only to be applied in the case of a single man”. Chapter III The Kaçama relating to an involuntary crime (1633) - Yahia reported that he heard Malek say: "If it is an involuntary crime, we ask the entitled to take an oath for fifty times, according to the inheritance distributed among them. If, the Kaçama done, fractions are present, the one who has the largest share is asked to swear much more than the others (so that the fifty oaths are completed”. - Malek said: “if the victim has only women to inherit it, they will swear and have the dyia, if the victim has only one male heir, he will take an oath for fifty times and will have the dyia. However, this is to be applied in the event that it is an involuntary crime and not the contrary”. Chapter IV The inheritance, in case the Kaçama is pronounced. (1634) - Malek said: “If the heirs beneficiaries, accept the dyia, it will be shared between them, according to what is prescribed in the Book of Allah, namely that the daughters of the victim, her sisters, as well as other females will inherit this blood money. If, the distributed dyia, leaves a remainder, this returns to the closest to the killed man”. - And Malek to add: "If someone from the heirs of the man voluntarily killed, intends to have his share of the dyia, which is his right, while the others are not present, he will be able to take nothing, and will not collect anything from the dyia less or more, before until he has completed the Kaçama, that is, until the fifty oaths have been taken. So if these oaths are made, he'll take his share of the dyia, because in fact the blood money is only due if the fifty oaths have already been fulfilled, and the dyia is only due after the condemnation of the culprit. Now if soon after one of the heirs arrives, and he swears as much as his share of the inheritance, he may to have his share of the dyia until all the heirs have had it, in turn. If a uterine brother presents himself, he will have the sixth of the dyia and will make 6/50 of the oaths; thus, every heir who has sworn an oath, will receive his share; on the other hand, the one who prevents himself from doing it, he will receive nothing. On the other hand, if some heirs are absent, or even that there are prepubescent boys, those who are already present, will each make an oath in proportion to his share of the dyia, also though to his share of the inheritance. - Malek finally said, "and that's, what I help heard best about it." Chapter V The Kaçama of slaves (1635) - Malek said: “What is followed with us (in Medina), about slaves in case one of them is voluntarily or involuntarily killed, then his boss comes up with a witness, swears once, he is entitled to the price of his slave. Thus, on the subject of the voluntary or involuntary murder of slaves, the norm of the Kaçama is not applied, and I have not heard that a man versed in religion has acted otherwise”. Thus, continues Malek, if the slave is voluntarily or involuntarily killed, the master of this slave has neither to take account of a Kaçama, nor to sow seeds; although this master is not entitled to the price of the slave, unless he presents clear evidence or a witness swearing with him”. - And Malek said, "That's the best I've heard about it." MOUATTAA At Name of Allah The Merciful The Merciful Book 45 The Book of Miscellaneous Subjects First chapter: Prayers made for Medina and its inhabitants 
(1636) 1 - Anas Ibn Malek reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him be Allah's grace and peace) said: “Great Allah! bless them (meaning the people of Medina) in their measure, bless them in their sa'as and mudds”. 
(1637) 2 - Abu Houraira said: "At the picking the first fruits, people brought them to the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah). On taking it, the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him be Allah's grace and peace) said: “Great Allah! Give us Your blessing in our fruits, bless us in our mudd. Great Allah! Abraham, your servant, your confidant friend, and your envoy, and I am your servant, your prophet. He called upon you for Mecca, and I, I invoke You for Medina, and I, I invoke You with the same intentions for Medina, just as he had done for Mecca, and once as much”. Then the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) called the smallest boy he had seen, and he gave him these first fruits”. Chapter II The subject of dwelling in Medina and leaving it. 
(1638) 3 - Katan Ibn Wahb Ibn Oumair Ibn Al-Ajda' a reported that Youhanness, the freedman of Al-Zoubair Ibn Al-Awwam taught him, that being seated at Abdallah Ibn Omar, while it was the incursion (against Yazid Ibn Mu'awia), a slave came to greet him saying: "I want, O Abu Abdul-Rahman, to leave Medina, because life there is so difficult". Abdallah Ibn Omar replied: “Stay there, ignorant; I heard the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) say: "Anyone supporting the hard life in Medina, and the hardship of its conditions, I will be his intercessor or witness on the day of the resurrection”. 
(1639) 4 - Jaber Ibn Abdallah reported that a Bedouin had sworn allegiance to Islam with the Messenger of Allah r Upon him the grace and peace of Allah. The Bedouin, fell sick in Medina and came to the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Be upon him the grace and peace of Allah) and said to him: O Messenger of Allah! release me from my oath”, which the Messenger of Allah refused to do. Then the Bedouin came back a second time, repeating the same request, which was always refused, then again for a third time, where the request was also refused. The outgoing Bedouin, the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said to him: "Medina is like the breath of a forge where the slag is expelled, and where the odor is purified”. (164t) 5 - Abu Hurairah reported that he heard the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r Upon him the grace and peace of Allah say: "I was ordered to be in a borough devouring all the other boroughs it was called Yathreb, but it is Medina It expels the (bad) people just as the bellows of a blacksmith purifies the iron of impurities”. (1641)6 - Hisham ibn Ourwa reported from his father that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r Upon him the grace and peace of Allah said: “No one leaves Medina for a dislike against it, except that Allah installs there better than the one who left it. 
(1642) 7 - Sufian ibn Abi Zouhair reported that he heard the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r Upon him the grace and peace of Allah say: "Yemen will be conquered, then people will come calling others to go there with their parents and others who will also respond to their call, although Medina their is the best place, if they knew it. Also Chàm (Syria) will be invaded, people will call others to go there with their parents-and still others will respond to their call, while Medina is the best place for them, if they knew it. Iraq will still be invaded, where people will call others to go there with their parents, and others also will respond to their call, yet Medina is the best place for them, if they knew it". (1643) - Abu Hurairah reported that the Messenger of Allah r Upon him the grace and peace of Allah said: "You will leave Medina although she will be in the best possible condition; which will cause dogs and wolves to enter there and urinate on the pillars of the Mosque or on the Minbar. the animals, that is to say the birds and the beasts who will seek them." 
(1644) 9 - It was reported to Malek that Omar Ibn Abdul Aziz, coming out of Medina, took a look at it, wept and said to his freedman: “O Muzahem, are you afraid that you are one of those expelled from Medina”?. Chapter III The sanctity of Medina. 
(1645) 10 - Anas Ibn Malek reported that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him be Allah's grace and peace) looking at Mount Ouhod, said: “Such is a mountain that loves us and that we love. Great Allah! Ibrahim asked You that Mecca be sacred and I ask You that Medina be a sacred territory between its two extremities (covered with black volcanic stones)”. 
(1646) 11 - Sa'id Ibn Al Moussaiab reported that Abou Houraira said: "If I had seen the gazelles grazing the grass at Medina, I wouldn't have frightened them. For the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Be upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said: "The space between the two extremities (covered with volcanic stones), in Medina, are sacred”. 
(1647) 12 - Ata Ibn Yassar reported that Abu Ayoub al-Ansari found in Medina, young boys cornering a fox; so he drove them away (thus freeing the animal). - Malek said: “I was taught, that he had said to them: "do you do this, in the sacred precincts of the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah)”? (...) 13 - Malek reported that a man told him said, “Zaid Ibn Thabet came to my house, while I was in Al-Aswaf (place in Medina). Finding in my hand a shrike, which I had captured, he took it away from me and released it». Chapter IV From the epidemic to Medina 
(1648) 14 - Aisha, the mother of believers reported: “Once the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah) went to Medina, Abu Bakr and Bilal fell ill. Going to their house, I said to my father: “Father, how are you feeling? And to Bilal: “How do you feel”? Aisha continued and said, "Abu Bakr was feverish, and said, 'Every man wants to be in good condition in the morning with his family, but death is closer to him than the laces of his sandals.' As for Bilal, each time he pulled himself together, he said: “How much I want to know, if I would spend a night in a valley surrounded by aromatic rushes (izkhir) and couch grass (Makka). Or that I will drink of the waters of the source Majinna (Place near Mecca) "Or that I will see Chama and Tafil". (Two mountains at a distance of 30 miles from Mecca.) Aisha continued: "I went to the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him be Allah's grace and peace) and told him about them (about namely of Abu Bakr and Bilal). So he said to me, “Great Allah! do that we loved Medina just as we love Mecca, even more. Make this city healthy for us, and bless for us its sa'as, its mudds, and make the fever be transmitted from this city to Juhfa”. (...) 15 - Aicha said: "and Amer Ibn Fouhaira said: "I knew death before I tasted it. "The coward's death comes to him from above." 
(1649) 16 - Abu Huraira narrated that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him be Allah's grace and peace) said: "The angels guard the entrances to Medina; neither the plague nor the Antichrist will penetrate it”. Chapter V Of the Exclusion of the Jews from Medina 
(1650) 17 - Ismail Ibn Hakim reported that Omar Ibn Abdul Aziz said: "The last words spoken by the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him be Allah's Grace and Peace) (during his illness) are: “May Allah curse the Jews and Christians who have taken the tombs of their prophets places to pray. Two religions that will never exist in the land of the Arabs”. 
(1651) 18 - Ibn Chehab narrated that the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Be upon him the grace and peace of Allah) said: "two religions can never exist together in the Arabian peninsula". - Ibn Chehab added: "Omar Ibn Al-Khattab, investigates in order to reassure himself of the words of the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r Upon him the grace and peace of Allah who had said: "Two religions can never exist together in the Arabian peninsula"; after that, Omar excludes the Jews from Khaibar”. 
(1652) 19 - Malek said: “And Omar Ibn Al-Khattab had excluded the Jews of Najran and Fadak. However, the Jews of Khaibar left this city without being entitled to its fruits or its territory. On the other hand, the Jews of Fadak had the right and half of the fruits and half of the territory, because the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the mercy and peace of Allah) had made a pact with them from their give half the fruit and half the territory. So Omar appropriated to them half of the fruits and half of the territory, giving them in exchange gold, silver, camels, ropes, and packsaddles, and then he expelled them”. Chapter VI From the subject of Medina 
(1653) 20 - Hisham Ibn Ourwa reported from his father that the Messenger of Allah (sallallahu alayhi wa salam) r (Upon him the grace and peace of Allah), at the sight of Mount Ouhod, said: "It's a mountain that loves us, and that we love". 
(1654) 21 - Abdul Rahman Ibn Al-Kassem reported that Aslam, the freedman of Omar Ibn Al-Khattab, taught him, that while visiting Abdallah Ibn Ayach Al-Makhzoumi, he found macerated grapes at his home, while being on the way leading to Mecca. Aslam told him, "Omar Ibn Al-Khattab likes such a drink." Abdullah Ibn Ayach filled a large cup, brought it to Omar and set it before him. Omar put it in his mouth then raised his head saying, “This drink is so delicious”. He drank and then passed the cup to a seated man who was on his right. As soon as Abdallah wanted to leave, Omar Ibn Al-Khattab called him and said: "Did you say that Mecca is better than Medina”? Abdallah replied: "Rather, I had said that this city is the sacred enclosure of Allah where his Sacred House is". Omar resumed: “there is nothing to say about the enclosure Sacred to Allah and His House". Omar repeating the same question a second then a third time, after which Abdallah left”. Chapter VII About the plague 
(1655) 22 - Abdallah Ibn Abbas reported: "Omar Ibn Al-Khattab left for Châm (Syria), arriving at Sargh (a town in the valley of Tabouk) of the commanding generals of the armies, Abou Oubaida and his companions met him and told him that the plague was widespread in Cham. Ibn Abbas to continue: “So Umar Ibn Al-Khattab said: “Bring me the oldest of the Mouhajirins (known as emigrants). These arrived, Omar asked them for advice about the plague spread in Cham., then there, they showed themselves of several opinions where some said: "Since you are here for a business to complete, we advise you to continue your way", while others suggested that he turn back, especially since he is in the company of last survivors of the companions of the Messenger of Allah (salallahou alayhi wa salam) (On him the grace and peace of Allah). Umar then said to them: “Leave me alone” and demanded that the Ansars be brought to him. They were summoned and Omar asked their opinion, having acted similarly to the Ansars, and again having disputed the opinions, Omar said to them: "leave me" and asked bring to him the old men of Quraish who emigrated during the conquest of Mecca. The old men were all of the same opinion and said to Omar: “we envisage that you turn back with your companions without running the risk of entering a country where the plague has spread”. Then Omar announced to the men: “I will be on my mount, on my way back, tomorrow morning; so prepare yourselves”. Abou Oubaida Ibn al Jarrah said to him: "Are you fleeing the destiny of Allah"? Omar answered him: “If it was someone other than you who had told me? O Abu Oubaida! Yes. We flee the fate of Allah for another. How would you behave if you had a herd of camels that you brought into a valley that has two slopes: one is fertile and covered with grass, while the other is barren and arid. By grazing the camels in the fertile slope, will you not do so according to the destiny of Allah? And by grazing it on the other slope, will it not be again in the name of Allah's destiny"?
